HEADLINE: In Need of Public Support, Doctors Try Image Transplant

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
For Dr. Michael Elia, a Westchester orthopedic surgeon, the national debate over health care has come to this: he has taken the M.D. license plates off his sports car.
"People see you driving around in a little convertible with M.D. plates and they get hostile," said Dr. Elia, who practices at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. "It's just a $14,000 Miata, but people see the plates and assume its a $60,000 Porsche. There's such resentment against doctors; why make it worse?" 
 Across the country, doctors like Dr. Elia are coming to terms with the fact that they are losing in the battle for public opinion. While most doctors describe themselves as healers and advocates for the sick, a growing number of patients see them as the overpaid cause of the health-care crisis.
 
Shift in Status
 Doctors are reacting to their shifting status in ways large and small. Many say they do not use their title as often, are more conscious of appearing ostentatious, and do not expect the comfortable perquisites of the past, like choice parking spaces and priority at restaurants.
Some doctors are even trying to fight back. One surgeon's wife has formed a group to promote doctors as hard-working and devoted. And an association of Manhattan doctors is in the process of hiring a public relations firm to polish its image.
That might not be a simple task. Polls show that while most Americans like their own doctor, they believe doctors in general earn far too much. The Clinton Administration apparently feels the same way. Hillary Rodham Clinton said as recently as last week that curbs on payments to doctors, insurers, hospitals and other health-care providers will be a major part of her proposals for change.
"Too many people have made too much money" providing health care and health insurance, Mrs. Clinton said in a speech to hospital and nursing home workers. "The status quo exists because there are people who benefit from it. Talk to your friends and neighbors about what you see every day in terms of price gouging, cost shifting and unconscionable profiteering."
 
Once, a Nice Living
 Those are particularly harsh words to doctors who entered medicine when it brought automatic respect along with a nice living.
The average primary care doctor was paid $111,000 in 1991, according to the American Medical Association. The mean for all doctors, including higher-priced specialists like Dr. Elia, who would not disclose his actual income, was $171,600. But, doctors say that their incomes are not the cause of the nation's skyrocketing health-care bill.
"It's shocking to realize how people see us," said Dr. Caryl G. Mussenden, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Washington. "We should have seen this coming. We were just going along, doing our jobs, and we didn't realize that the world was changing."
The hardening image of the doctor-as-bad-guy is all the more frustrating to doctors because, while the public has come to view them as the perpetrators, they have come to see themselves as victims.
First there was the consumer movement of the 1970's, when patients began questioning doctors' judgment -- asking for second opinions and demanding to be involved in every facet of care. Most doctors praised the theory but believe it has gone too far with patients often demanding care that they do not need. The increased scrutiny came hand-in-hand with an explosion in malpractice suits and, consequently, insurance premiums. The 1980's brought the growth of managed care, where insurance companies can veto many treatment decisions.
 
'Do It or I'll Sue'
 "Here's what it means to be a doctor nowadays," said a Manhattan internist who asked not to be identified because he did not feel it was professional to criticize his patients publicly. "A patient comes in and tells me to do a certain test because he read about it in the newspaper or because his neighbor had it done. The insurer tells me I can't do that test. The patient says, 'Do it or I'll sue.' On top of all that, Hillary Clinton is saying I'm greedy. Is this why I went to medical school?"
A poll released last month by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation found that while 89 percent of Americans are happy with the care they receive from their own doctors, 56 percent believe the health-care system needs a "complete overhaul."
When pollsters asked the causes of the health-care crisis, 35 percent listed doctors. They also blame malpractice attorneys (48 percent) and insurance companies (36 percent). Only 4 percent blame what health-care experts often cite as the main problem: an aging population, overdependence on high-tech equipment and the costs of such social ills as violence, poverty and drugs.
"It's clean and simple to blame doctors but it's just not true," said Timothy B. Norbeck, executive director of the Connecticut State Medical Society. Nationwide, doctors' fees make up 19 cents of each health-care dollar, he said. Up to half of that goes for office overhead, Mr. Norbeck said, meaning that doctors receive less than 10 percent of the money spent on health.
In contrast, he said, 50 percent of spending on health pays for the care of patients with preventable diseases brought on by life-style choices like smoking, drinking and poor exercise.
Regardless of their protests, doctors are aware that they are not gaining much sympathy. "People don't look at the specifics," said Dr. Marvin F. Kraushar, an ophthalmologist with offices in Westfield and West Orange, N.J. "Whatever we make, they think we make too much."
Dr. Elia, the Westchester orthopedist, thinks the public has blind spots when it comes to criticizing how much doctors earn. He says, he calculated his hourly pay during 10 years of training and arrived at an average of $1.50 an hour. "No one envied me when I was paying $20,000 a year in tuition," he said, "or when I was working 100 hours a week as a resident. No one was bashing me then."
Some doctors compare their public image to that of plumbers -- another line of work where the client often resents paying the bill. The comparison, they said, saddens them.
"We're being made into tradespeople and technicians," Dr. Kraushar said.
Of particular irritation to many doctors is the term "health-care providers," used by policy makers, politicians and insurance companies. The use of a single category that lumps physicians with nurses, therapists and home-care companions is seen as a slap in the face to doctors, who traditionally chafe at even sharing their title with Ph.D.'s and dentists.
"They call me a 'provider,' as if this is just another service," said Dr. Peter S. Liebert, a pediatric surgeon in Westchester County. "If I'm a provider, I could just as well sell fish."
Many doctors concede that the profession brought some of this backlash on itself.
"For all those years, physicians had this kind of aura about them, and they took advantage of that," said Dr. Mussenden, the obstetrician-gynecologist. "They were condescending to patients. They didn't explain things. This is a reaction to that."
Dr. Ted Tyberg, a Manhattan cardiologist, agreed: "Doctors have been fiercely independent for many, many years. It's hard to tell them, after they've suffered and worked hard, to hide the fact that they're doing well in a recession."
 
Trying to Make Repairs
 A few doctors are trying to repair their public persona. The Alliance for Physicians and Surgeons, which represents doctors at The Mount Sinai Medical Center, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, is interviewing public relations firms about creating an image and information campaign.
Mary Ann Liebert, Dr. Liebert's wife, has formed a group called Spousal Advocates for Doctors, to publicize the realities of doctors' lives.
"The complaint is that doctors make so much more than the average worker," said Mrs. Liebert, who runs her own medical publishing company. "Does the average worker work a 60-hour week? Does the average worker get up in the middle of a rainy night and race to the hospital? Does the average worker never know if he'll be home for dinner, or a child's school play? Is the average worker responsible for human lives?"
More than 200 spouses have joined her group, she said, which was formed in the belief that someone has to defend doctors because they have not done a very good job of defending themselves.
"If my husband could argue his own case," Mrs. Liebert said, "he would have been a lawyer."

The Economy
An increasing number of people with AIDS are accusing their health insurance plans of discrimination forbidden under the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990. The patients are facing the loss of medical benefits that keep them alive. Several dozen cases involving health insurance plans that have eliminated or limited coverage for AIDS patients have been filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. [Page A1.]
President Clinton is seriously considering a hospital tax to help finance medical care for people who currently have no health insurance, Administration officials said. [A1.] In the midst of the national health-care debate, doctors are reacting to shifting public perceptions of them in ways large and small. [B1.] 
 Federal Reserve governors say they intend to do what it takes to bring inflation below the 4 percent rate of the last few months. That commitment could put them on a collision course with the White House, which seeks faster growth. [D1.]
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen vigorously thrust himself onto center stage of the budget battle last week, lining up a majority of House Democrats from Texas for the Clinton economic plan, buttonholing and cajoling senators, tearing into opponents at a news conference and giving loads of advice to the White House. [A11.]
 Ross Perot's grass-roots political organization is in turmoil, riven by disputes that are beginning to cost it some of its most committed volunteers. [A1.]
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned the operators of 34 reactors around the country that the instruments they use to measure the level of water in the reactors could give a false reading during shutdowns and fail to detect important leaks. [A10.]
There is a hard-earned sense of reality as New Haven waits to see if the Clinton Administration will begin a new assault on the nation's urban problems. [A1.]
 
International
A former Chrysler executive is setting a new style for Western executives in Eastern Europe. Gerald Greenwald is trying to turn around Tatra, the Czech Republic's oldest truck company. [D1.]
 
Companies
Astoria Federal and Green Point Savings plan to convert from mutual, or depositor-owned, organizations to shareholder ownership. The change will give depositors first crack at buying the new shares without using a broker. Depositors have been well rewarded in some similar conversions. [D1.]
American Airlines will begin laying off 350 pilots by Aug. 31, the first wave of pilot layoffs resulting from the airline's decision to park 31 of its biggest jets. [D1.]
 
 
Markets
The ruble fell to a new low of 1,024 to the U.S. dollar, breaking a largely psychological 1,000-ruble barrier. Specialists cited Russia's inflation, which has hovered around 20 percent a month. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Mutual Banks Moving To Shareholder Owners

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Depositors at Astoria Federal Savings and Loan in Queens and the Green Point Savings Bank in Brooklyn may soon have the opportunity to do more than just earn 3 percent interest on their money.
After more than a century of quietly collecting deposits and making loans without the bother of shareholders clamoring for dividends and higher profits, the two savings institutions separately announced plans last month to convert from mutual, or depositor-owned, organizations to shareholder ownership. 
 The change will not affect interest rates or deposit insurance coverage, but it will give depositors first crack at buying the new shares without using a securities broker. In similar conversions in the last year, shares were almost always offered to depositors at a price low enough to have them quickly increase when trading started, and depositors could sell.
Green Point, the country's largest mutual savings bank, with $6.3 billion in assets at the end of last year, and Astoria, with $3.4 billion, are just two of dozens of mutual savings banks or savings and loans to abandon the idea of mutual ownership recently.
 
Popular in 19th Century
 Mutual banks, a kind of cooperative arrangement popular in the 19th century when low- and middle-income individuals were shunned by commercial banks, now compete with ordinary banks, and regulators have encouraged them to increase their capital, which serves as a cushion to absorb unexpected losses.
With low interest rates, profits at mutual banks have been strong recently, and last year 57 mutuals issued stock totaling more than $900 million. Conversion activity was intense in the Chicago area, and is now spreading to other regions, including New York.
"We are in the middle of a feeding frenzy," said George L. Engelke Jr., chief executive at Astoria Federal.
In the last two months conversions have been completed in the New York area by Fidelity New York Federal Savings of Floral Park, L.I.; the Sunrise Federal Savings Bank of Farmingdale, L.I., and Hamilton Federal Savings and Loan of Brooklyn. In addition, the Roosevelt Savings Bank of Garden City, L.I., is in the midst of a stock offering to its more than 80,000 depositors.
 
$700 Million Expected
 Green Point's offering is expected to raise more than $700 million, the most ever for a mutual bank.
Although mutual ownership offers the freedom to operate without a narrow focus on the following quarter's profits, Mr. Engelke said that the chance to raise additional capital was too good for many institutions to pass up. The profits available to management and depositors who may buy the stock before it is available to the public have also fanned the enthusiasm for conversions.
In the 15 months that ended on March 31, the average gain in the first month after shares were issued was 33 percent, with 12 stocks rising 50 percent or more, according to SNL Securities of Charlottesville, Va.
Gains have been more modest among recent offerings. Shares of Fidelity New York, which converted last month at $11.50, closed Friday at $13.625 for an 18.5 percent gain. Sunrise Federal, which converted April 5 at $10 a share, closed at $12.625, up 26.3 percent, while Hamilton Federal, which converted April 1 at $10.80 a share, closed last week at $13.50, a 25 percent gain.
 
Interest High Despite Failures
 The interest continues despite failures of some mutual savings institutions that converted to stock in the mid-1980's, including Crossland Savings in Brooklyn and Empire of America in Buffalo; such failures wiped out investors. Now, low interest rates have made the surviving institutions more profitable and demand for their stock has been so strong that all available shares have been bought initially by managers, employees and depositors.
"The mutuals are institutions with value, and as they convert to stock companies, that value is up for grabs," said James Marks, an owner of SNL Securities. SNL has published lists of healthy mutual savings that could be candidates for conversion.
The potential profits have attracted a new class of depositors who have made a business of opening dozens and even hundreds of accounts around the country so they will be eligible to buy shares in mutuals that decide to convert. Because banks have given $500 depositors the right to buy as much stock as $10,000 depositors, opening new deposit accounts has been a relatively inexpensive way to get stock at low prices.
Among those depositors is Baupost Group, a Boston-based investment adviser that has been a depositor and investor in many savings institutions. But Paul O'Leary, a securities analyst at Baupost, says that it will probably begin to turn down opportunities "pretty soon," when lower-quality savings institions shift from mutual to stock ownership.
 
Not All Are Professionals
 Another investor who has opened deposits at many mutuals is Michael Price, an investment manager for the Mutual Series funds, according to bankers and lawyers. Mr. Price declined to return phone calls.
Not all the depositors who are looking for conversions are professional investors. James Rothschild, a Wilton, Conn., consultant who helps states evaluate utility charges, has opened accounts in a few dozen institutions, a handful of which have converted. His investments have done well, and while it is true that the stock is usually offered to depositors at below its eventual trading price, "it's not a free lunch," he said.
Depositors' demand has been so strong that many banks have not had enough stock to satisfy it.
For example, at the Home Savings Bank of Hollywood, Fla., depositors and management submitted orders for $105 million in stock last October, but the company was issuing only about $23 million.
"An awful lot of people from New York City somehow found out and made deposits so they could buy the stock," said Thomas H. Wohl, the chief executive. Because of the demand, he said, many depositors who submitted orders to buy $500,000 of stock were allocated only $560 worth.
 
Management May Buy 25 Percent
 Local depositors and a special category of "preferred investors," described by Harry K. McDougal, the executive vice president at Home Savings, as "relatives, good friends or someone known to the bank," were allowed to invest a maximum of $10,000.
Federal and state regulators give management the right to buy 25 percent to 35 percent of a new stock offering, depending on the bank's size, with remaining shares going to employees and depositors.
Managers and directors of Home Savings took about 30 percent of the shares offered. "Yes, management got a lot of the stock, but that just shows we were willing to put our money where our mouth was," Mr. McDougal said.
In Home Savings' case, outside investors bought the stock heavily in the days after shares went public, pushing the share price from $10 in October to $17.25 a week later. It closed at $20 on Friday, down $1.
As bankers have become wise to the practice of opening accounts at dozens of mutuals, many have limited the number of new depositors they will accept and have even closed some accounts. Mr. Engelke of Astoria Federal said that "junk money" from depositors whose aim was to become qualified to buy stock was such a problem that Astoria stopped accepting deposits from people outside the New York area in March.
 
Many Investors 'Flip' Shares
 In many cases, more than half the shares issued are traded in the first two days, indicating that many depositors are "flipping" the shares -- selling them for a quick profit rather than holding for the long haul. Regulators require that management hold its shares for at least a year.
Because of the scarcity of shares, some depositors with a right to buy stock but little money have been tempted by offers to buy shares for others who were not depositors.
Such dealings were uncovered last year at Firstrock Bancorp, the holding company for First Federal Savings and Loan in Rockford Ill., where speculators offered $1,500 to depositors who would order $210,000 worth of stock on their behalf. Regulators at the Office of Thrift Supervision are looking at other situations where depositors bought far more shares than would seem reasonable given their income and deposit size.
Although profits for depositors who buy shares have been almost automatic in the last year, analysts warn that the market could turn sour if interest rates begin rising, or a high price is set on a weak bank.
 
Warning to Investors
 "People who are playing this game and think that it is a sure way to make a profit are going to get slapped on the wrist," said Mark B. Cohen, a partner at Adams, Cohen Securities, a Great Neck, L.I., firm that helps arrange conversions. He also noted that before approving stock offerings regulators were pushing for higher prices on new shares so the bank received as much money as possible.
But even if profits are not as great as in the past, some analysts expect that conversions of the nation's remaining 1,200 mutual banks or savings and loans will continue.
Eric Luse, a partner at Luse Lehman Pomerenk & Schick, a Washington law firm that has handled many conversions, said the supply of new stock issues was likely to remain strong, partly because the managers making the decisions stood to benefit.
"Imagine you are a 60-year-old manager of a thrift who has been there for a few decades and done a good enough job that it survived the 1980's," Mr. Luse said. "When you see the profits earned by managers of those which have converted recently you have to wonder whether you should delay the process and let the gains go to the next generation of managers."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
A ZONING PLAN FOR LINCOLN CENTER
The Planning Department will propose zoning changes that would put new restrictions on commercial development and building heights in the area around Lincoln Center. The new use and design requirements for the Lincoln Square special zoning district are intended to limit vehicular and pedestrian traffic in an area that has seen the addition of 18 new buildings since 1969. B3.
 
CYCLIST IS HIT TWICE AND DRAGGED BY CAR
A man was knocked off his bicycle by a drunken driver in Washington Heights, and as he limped to his feet he was struck again by the same car and dragged for eight blocks, the police and witnesses said. The episode was the latest in a series of accidents involving drivers whose licenses had been suspended or revoked. B2.
 

TEARS FOR A WEDDING NEVER TO BE
Dressed as bride and groom, Hema Sakhrani and Shaleen Wadhwani were mourned as they lay a few feet from each other in a funeral parlor in Elmhurst, Queens. Early yesterday morning, there was a kind of wedding ceremony. Later, several hundred relatives and friends crowded into the same room for the funeral. B3.
 
A RENOWNED SCHOOL STRUGGLES
St. Augustine School of the Arts, a nationally renowned Roman Catholic elementary school in the South Bronx, is experiencing the best and worst of times. An award-winning documentary about the school opened in New York on Friday, and the school's principal was recently honored as one of the nation's outstanding educators. But a fire last December that destroyed two-thirds of the main school building has left St. Augustine struggling to maintain its financial footing. B3.
 
MAYORAL RACE FOCUSES ON A WORD
A dispute over the use of the word "pogrom" by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, has once again focused the race on the disturbances in Crown Heights two years ago. It was not the first time he has harshly criticized the Dinkins administration's handling of the Crown Heights unrest. This time Mayor Dinkins reacted more forcefully. B3.
 
REGION
 
SEEKING LINKS TO THE SUBURBS
Three decades ago, New Haven was an exciting laboratory for change, a model of urban renewal. Today it is a city of disappointments and diminished hopes. The laboratory is long closed and cluttered with its failures: misshapen renewal projects that haunt downtown, and the unchecked spread of poverty through neighborhoods. Yet as New Haven waits to see if the Clinton Administration will begin a new assault on the nation's urban problems, there is a hard-earned sense of reality. The fate of older cities like New Haven, many local leaders have concluded, was never theirs to determine. It rested with the suburbs growing up around them. A1.
 
A HEATED RACE FOR DISTRICT ATTORNEY
As the Westchester County District Attorney's race heats up, one thing is certain: for the first time in a quarter-century, the winner will not be Carl A. Vergari, who has held the post since 1968. His retirement has touched off a feverishly contested race, with the main contenders proposing fundamental changes in the way the law is enforced in this suburban county. B5.
 
Chronicle B4
 
Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves B5

HEADLINE: The Federal Reserve Prepares for a Rate War

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Governors of the Federal Reserve say they intend to do what it takes to bring inflation below the 4 percent rate of the last few months -- a commitment that could put them on a collision course with the White House, which is eager for faster growth.
The worried mood at the Fed is far different from that earlier this year, when Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, began his honeymoon with President Clinton. At that time, with inflation dipping toward 2 percent, it seemed that Mr. Greenspan could relax and go fishing for all of 1993. 
 But Mr. Greenspan's happy days were rudely interrupted by an unexpected burst of inflation in April. Suddenly the central bank had to shift to a war footing, ready to attack the next outburst of rising prices.
This means the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates in a month or two if inflation continued to grow. But the White House, which believes the current low rates are a boon to the economy, would view such action as a declaration of war. And it would probably direct its heavy artillery at Mr. Greenspan.
 These strains are perhaps inevitable, because the chief executive and the central banker have different missions. The Federal Reserve's raison d'etre is combating inflation, and it is deeply worried that prices have climbed at an annualized clip of more than 4 percent in recent months.
"The central bank's purpose is to get ahead of the curve," said Wayne D. Angell, one of the seven governors of the Federal Reserve. "If we're ahead of the curve, our credibility and the value of our money is maintained. Some of my economist friends tell me, 'We don't feel much inflation out there, but we feel better knowing that you're worried about it.' "
But President Clinton has different goals: to create jobs and fix the nation's anemic growth rate. Probably the last thing he wants is higher interest rates, especially after the economy grew by a dismal nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter.
Administration officials seem to be betting on continued low interest rates to lift the economy. They see that as the main, perhaps the only, stimulus once its deficit-cutting plan and its tax increases kick in and start slowing growth.
The Federal Reserve's governors -- none appointed by Mr. Clinton -- serve 14-year terms, to make them immune to the winds of politics. Thus, the governors said, if they have to make an unpopular rate increase to bring inflation under control, so be it.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor who is pushing his colleagues to raise rates immediately, said in an interview, "I hope we can send a signal to people that the Federal Reserve is serious about inflation and that we're not going to let inflation come back."
People familiar with the thinking of Federal Reserve officials indicated in interviews that the central bankers voted at a May 18 meeting to tilt their policy toward raising rates, although the consensus was to wait and see if further bad news about inflation emerged in the next month or two before ratcheting up rates.
That decision, at a meeting of the central bank's main policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, gave Mr. Greenspan leeway to raise short-term interest rates, now 3 percent, by up to one-half of 1 percent before the next meeting in early July. The committee also includes five presidents of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks.
 
 
Wait-and-See on Prices
 But recognizing that economic growth remained fragile, the central bank might forgo any rate increase if consumer prices rise modestly in May and June, perhaps a tenth of 1 percent, compared with April's jump of fourth-tenths of 1 percent. Perhaps even more frightening for the Federal Reserve governors is that prices at the producer level rose six-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Those numbers were a stark contrast to the situation a few months ago, when Mr. Greenspan hinted that an era of price stability was at hand. He appeared to define such stability as inflation at 2 percent or below.
Many economists said they thought April's surge in inflation would prove to be an aberration. Soon, these forecasters predicted, the Fed would again see that torpid growth, not inflation, was the nation's No. 1 economic problem, and that lower rates, not a rate increase, were needed.
"I would assume that inflation will subside in May and June," said Henry Kaufman, who owns a New York-based economic consulting firm. "There is still a very distinct possibility of another easing of monetary policy early this summer."
 
 
Inflationary Expectations
 But at the Federal Reserve's marble headquarters, that seemed like wishful thinking. The way some officials there saw it -- and again, all were appointed by Republican Presidents -- stubborn inflationary pressures have built up because businesses were worried that their costs would rise as a result of Clinton Administration actions. Their concern was that inflationary expectations were being fueled by increased regulation, the prospect of new taxes to finance health care and fears that unions would take a tougher bargaining stance because of the Administration's pro-labor beliefs and actions.
People familiar with the May 18 discussions said a compromise was reached between hawks who wanted to raise interest rates at once to short-circuit inflationary expectations and doves who argued that the economy was so weak that rates should stay put. Mr. Greenspan built a majority for a tilt toward higher rates but without immediate action. Such a tilt would mean the Fed would likely raise rates if inflation did not lose steam soon.
Among the governors, Mr. Lindsey and Mr. Angell are often described as hawks, and Susan Phillips as a dove. Mr. Greenspan is said to have taken a middle position, while the Federal Reserve's Arkansas native and vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr. -- who pushed the central bank to cut rates more aggressively during the 1990-91 recession -- is said to have lined up near the hawks.
 
 
Question Is When
 "After Chairman Greenspan heaped praise on the President's deficit plan and after he sat next to Hillary at the State of the Union, Mullins felt a lot of pressure not to be seen as caving to the Administration," said David M. Jones, chief economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "In my view, the question is not whether the Fed will raise rates, but when."
The dollar's recent nose dive to a post-World War II low against the yen has increased the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise short-term rates because higher rates strengthen the dollar by attracting investors from abroad. The Fed is also worried that a weak dollar would fuel inflation by making imports more expensive.
For some Administration officials, a rate increase now would be tantamount to a breach of contract. They believed there was a tacit agreement with the central bank that if the President pushed his deficit-reduction plan through, the Fed would keep rates low.
"So long as the Administration and Congress stay on the track of deficit reduction, the bottom line of what Alan Greenspan does should be low rates, not higher ones," said Allen Sinai, an economist and managing director with Lehman Brothers.
 
 
Comparison to Carter
 Amid all of President Clinton's recent stumbling and fumbling, some at the Federal Reserve have compared him to President Jimmy Carter; and when central bank officials make that analogy, it has frightening connotations. To the Federal Reserve, Mr. Carter symbolized double-digit inflation, and the bank helped insure his defeat in 1980 by increasing interest rates toward 20 percent.
To be sure, no Fed official expects the return of double-digit inflation, in part because the central bank seems intent on doing what it takes to bring inflation below 3 percent.
Although it may sound perverse, one view inside the Federal Reserve is that a rate increase now will not only be therapeutic for the Administration but might help Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign in 1996.
Which would be better for the President, this line of thinking asks: an rate increase of one-half of 1 percent now, which would in theory help insure a longer-lasting recovery with low inflation, or raising rates by a full 3 percent in early 1996 or so, should inflation rise too high? The latter scenario could abort Mr. Clinton's hopes of a robust recovery in 1996.
Still, Fed officials have recognized that any interest-rate increase would fuel tensions with the Administration. "The classic remedies against inflation may further stagnate the growth rate," John P. LaWare, another Federal Reserve governor, said.

HEADLINE: New Haven's Task: Tying City to Region To Promote Growth

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 28

 BODY:
Three decades ago, when Lyndon B. Johnson came into office with an ambitious urban agenda, this small New England city was an exciting laboratory for change, a model of urban renewal and a testing ground for the war on poverty.
Today New Haven is a city of disappointments and diminished hopes. The laboratory is long closed and cluttered with its failures: misshapen renewal projects that haunt downtown, and the unchecked spread of poverty through neighborhoods. 
 Yet as New Haven waits to see if the Clinton Administration will begin a new assault on the nation's urban problems, there is a hard-earned sense of reality. The fate of older cities like New Haven, many local leaders have concluded, was never theirs to determine. It rested with the suburbs growing up around them.
There is increasing agreement among New Haven's political and business leaders that the great flaw of urban policy in the 1950's and 60's was that it dealt with cities as cities, not as the centers of metropolitan areas, and that the future now lies in repairing that rupture. New links need to be established with surrounding towns, they say, based on the economy they all share.
The great puzzle for New Haven and other old industrial cities across the North is how to reconnect themselves with the independent suburbs that encircle them, to become the equivalent of Houston, Phoenix and other younger Sun Belt cities that have grown by annexing their suburban areas.
New Haven and neighboring towns have begun discussions on how to cooperate economically, working together to attract new business to the region. But more formal measures like a regional tax that would recognize the city's role in providing health and social services for the area are only talked of, and the idea of reforming government so that city and surburban residents vote for the same officials is even more distant.
Basic matters like public education are a source of deep division and distrust; the efforts of state officials to promote regional integration plans have stirred intense anxiety in the New Haven area, as well as around Hartford and Bridgeport.
"The biggest thing that's different between 1960 and 1990 is that there's been such a shift in activity from the center city to the suburban areas," said Matthew Nemerson, president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce. "The whole flawed conception was, 'What can we do for the city?' It was the wrong question. The real question was, 'What kind of metropolitan area do we want?' "
Almost anything seemed possible in the 1950's as Mayor Richard C. Lee and his aides mastered the art of winning Federal grants and rebuilt much of New Haven. A slum hemming in downtown was cleared for a highway connector to the new Connecticut Turnpike. While malls everywhere else were rising on wide-open suburban tracts, Mayor Lee built a mall anchored by Macy's downtown.
 
Models for Federal Efforts
 Run-down housing razed in the poor Dixwell neighborhood was replaced by a shopping center, a community house and a school that stayed open 16 hours a day. As the problems of poverty became more apparent, the city used Ford Foundation grants for social-service programs that became models for Federal anti-poverty efforts.
"I wanted to be mayor because I wanted to change what the city looked like," Mr. Lee, who left office in 1969, said in a recent interview in his home near the Yale Bowl. "No matter what happens in the next 100 years in New Haven's history, my mark will be there."
Today, the soaring confidence and high ambitions of that era have been replaced by a sense that City Hall has limited power to shape the future. Even at the height of urban renewal, critics say, its importance was vastly outweighed by the highway and mortgage subsidies that were sending the middle class and jobs to suburbia.
Does urban renewal still have a role to play? This month ground was broken for the Ninth Square project, a long-awaited plan for a new neighborhood of apartments and stores on four downtown blocks. But around it are the failures of the first round of urban renewal: a flawed coliseum that is a burden to the city; the struggling mall, which has lost both its department stores; a failing hotel; the highway connector, which razed a neighborhood but leads nowhere.
While Mayor Lee renovated and rebuilt, all the metropolitan region's growth occurred in surrounding towns. From 1960 to 1990 the towns gained 110,000 residents and 97,000 jobs; New Haven lost population, and though its number of jobs did not drop, as economic activity moved to the suburbs, it lost thousands of the unskilled factory jobs that had supported its working class.
The new suburbanites were white and middle class, while the people arriving in the city were poor and black or Hispanic. By 1990 New Haven, with 130,000 residents, was 51 percent black and Hispanic, a rise of 10 percentage points in a single decade. It was the state's third-poorest community. More than half of its children lived below the poverty line.
 
Appearance of Thriving
 The lively streets around Yale University and the graceful Green, bounded by Yale, government buildings and Mayor Lee's mall, offered the appearance of a thriving small city. But behind that core lay rundown housing projects and neighborhoods succumbing to poverty and the violence of the drug trade.
The growing racial and economic isolation threatened to replace the city's traditional role as a commercial crossroads with a new one: warden of the poor.
"It's totally, totally unfair to compare New Haven in 1993 with what happened in 1953 or 1963," said Mayor John C. Daniels, whose four years in office have been defined by budget problems and who announced recently that he would not seek re-election. "It's two different worlds. In the 1950's, cities all over the country were powerful."
New Haven's leaders find themselves considering a new vision for their city, a modest one that relies more on the city rediscovering its place within the regional economy than on government action.
The Federal Government could be most helpful, they say, by increasing support for badly needed services while creating incentives for cities and suburbs to establish financial and political links. The biggest mistake it could make, they say, would be to once again ignore those links.
"If we just throw money at the city and say the city is going to do this and everyone else can do whatever they want, because they're not connected, I don't think it will work," said Mr. Nemerson, the Chamber of Commerce president.
 
Affecting Political Power
 Mayor Daniels said: "There's no such thing as a New Haven problem. When people say, 'It's a New Haven problem,' they're saying it's a regional problem that their town doesn't want anything to do with."
Reconnecting the city with its suburbs is a delicate task. Decades of suspicion have built up, racial divisions are deep, and many people who no longer live, work or shop in New Haven now fear the inner city.
New regional arrangements would also dilute the political power of minority groups in New Haven, where Mr. Daniels was elected the first black mayor in 1989. Blacks make up 35 percent of the city, but 11.6 percent of the region.
"You'll never hear anyone in Dixwell talk about regionalization," said Pete Gray, who heads the Dixwell Neighborhood Corporation, a nonprofit agency that sponsors housing, job-training and community health programs. "Because we're a 98 percent black community and we're the stakeholders, we're the people who need to make the decisions. In a regional government, they'll have more votes and they'll just outbid us."
But business and civic leaders recognize that the city and suburbs are linked economically and that their sharp racial and economic divisions increasingly detract from the strengths that make the metropolitan region, as a whole, one of the nation's 30 wealthiest.
"I see New Haven as the plug in the basin," said Warren Kimbro, a former Black Panther who now heads Project MORE, an agency serving ex-convicts. "With the plug gone, all of the water drains out. Some of us may be the last drops down, but we're all going."
Recently Mr. Nemerson, business executives and city and town officials formed a Regional Economic Development Steering Committee to encourage cooperation across the region to attract new business.
 
Renewal Effort Called Bold
 Among critics, the widespread redevelopment of Mayor Lee's era now seems piecemeal and ill-conceived, mainly having benefited Yale University and Yale-New Haven Hospital by clearing slums and building middle-class housing that buffered them from poor neighborhoods.
But Mr. Nemerson said the renewal effort was "a bold experiment" that preserved New Haven's role as a regional shopping center until very recently. As a result, New Haven is not ringed by suburban malls, and now a national developer, the Taubman Company, has proposed a huge new mall for downtown.
A new, bigger mall, supporters say, would bring people into the city again, re-establishing a basic economic link with its suburbs. Others, looking at the lessons of urban renewal, and the more than $100 million in state and city aid that Taubman wants, say cities should give up their obsession with bigness.
Let a regional mall be built wherever land is cheapest, they say (and share its tax revenue across the region), and build on the city's recognized assets: the research at Yale and Yale-New Haven, the cultural activities anchored by Yale and the blocks of restaurants and shops that prosper near the university, away from the renewal area.
"The critique of urban renewal says there was an illusion that changes in brick and mortar would constitute a lasting change in the city," said Douglas W. Rae, a Yale political scientist who served as Mayor Daniels's chief administrative officer for two years. "That is an illusion. Cities solve their problems through their strengths."
Many people think that realism at the regional level will lead toward more cooperation between the city and surrounding towns, just as Yale, with its enormous stake in New Haven's image, has increased its payments to the city in lieu of taxes and its investments in projects like the Ninth Square.
Even Mr. Lee, who still relishes what he and other mayors were able to accomplish for cities in an earlier time, sees an inevitability to New Haven and neighboring towns joining together.
"It's just a matter of survival," he said. "The towns are going to have to become part of the city, geographically and in programs, especially in education. People might say that's not a dream, it's a nightmare. But it's going to have to happen if we're going to preserve our way of life."

HEADLINE: Ruble Reaches Record Low, Dropping to 1,024 to Dollar

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 31

 BODY:
The ruble fell to a new low of 1,024 to the United States dollar today, breaking a largely psychological 1,000-ruble barrier. Specialists cited Russia's inflation, which has hovered at about 20 percent a month.
The 30-ruble drop on the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange today continued a pattern that began with the decline of Soviet authority and the collapse of the Soviet Union itself late in 1991. At that time, the ruble still traded at about 100 to the dollar. 
 The currency, now Russia's, was battered in 1992 and began 1993 trading about 400 to the dollar. It slumped to 692 by April 1. On Thursday, the official rate was 994 to the dollar. The ruble has fallen even further on the black market, where $1 now buys 1,150 rubles, according to the Itar-Tass news agency.
Despite Western talk of making the ruble convertible, the ruble still cannot be traded on major world markets.
"The actual numbers do not mean too much," said Vitaly Kulakov, a member of Parliament who serves on the Committee for Economic Reform. "The problem, of course, is that the ruble keeps falling."
The average Russian wage is about 23,000 rubles a month. The currency's falling value goes hand in hand with inflation in the prices of consumer goods. As inflation continues to rise, this devours profits made by Russians or foreign-owned businesses.
The ruble's decline apparently did not reflect a recent agreement between the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin and the Russian central bank aimed at controlling inflation and securing a $3 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund.
Under terms of the agreement, the bank restricted credits and said it would stop intervening in currency trading to prop up the ruble.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Uncertainty Is Around the Corner

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prospects for approval of President Clinton's economic program improved greatly over the weekend with the disclosure of a prospective compromise in the Senate. But while that development should help calm some of the growing fears about the President's ability to cut the deficit, the bond market must still face, with its usual trepidation, the uncertainty surrounding both the May employment data scheduled for release on Friday and two important reports on inflation in the following two weeks.
Since the bond market rally reached its peak in early March, prices and yields have moved in a narrow range. For the 30-year bond, the yield has been stuck between 6.72 percent and 7.05 percent. 
 With each month's new economic data, investors, traders and speculators have hoped for a clearer indication of the course for both economic growth and inflation. But each month's data has only led to confusion and debate about the pace of price increases and the weakness of the economy.
 
Fed's Course Seems Clear
 The only "certainty" for the market right now seems to be this: the Federal Reserve is poised to raise short-term interest rates if inflation in the May consumer and producer price data continues at the heated pace of the first four months of the year, when the Consumer Price Index jumped at a 4.3 percent annual rate. This conclusion sent short-term rates sharply higher last week.
Like the employment reports for February, March and April, there is a wide range of forecasts for the closely watched nonfarm payroll data for May, which are to be released on Friday. The forecasts range from an increase of 55,000 to 250,000 jobs.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, made some forecasters wonder about their predictions when he said last week that the United States was on the verge of a significant expansion in employment.
"After someone like Greenspan makes a comment like that, you wonder if he knows something that we don't know," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy in Princeton, N.J.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities, predicted that nonfarm payrolls would be up 175,000. He said there were signs of renewed economic strength in the car- sales reports for the second 10 days of May, which were reported last week. Sales rose to an annual rate of 7.4 million, up from a 6.8 million rate for all of April.
"It was the first economic statistic that I could say was strong," Mr. Fine said. Compared with production numbers of 6.2 million cars in March and 6.1 million in April, he said, "this tells me that this production pace will be increased."
 
Inflation at Bay
 The bond market can be knocked about by any surprising data, as it was by the unexpectedly high inflation reports for April, which were released in mid-May, and as it could be by this week's employment data. But the market's trading range since early March seems to reflect several underlying themes that traders and investors fall back on in the periods between the release of crucial data.
Despite the climb of the Consumer Price Index at a 4.3 percent annual rate through the first four months of the year, one theme appears to be that inflation is not taking off. While many forecasters expect consumer prices to rise more than last year's 2.9 percent, the increase is not expected to be large -- maybe to 3.5 percent.
"The fact that the bond is living comfortably around 7 percent tells me that people are not buying the inflation story and are not worried about the economy overheating," said Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation. On Friday, a short trading day, the yield on the 30-year bond ended at 6.98 percent.
But Mr. Fine said that as the year moves on, concern about inflation will shift from this year to 1994. And if inflation is expected to increase in 1994 after rising in 1993, then traders and investors will begin to push prices lower and yields higher.
 
Economics and Politics
 Another underlying theme is that the economy is still sluggish and is not yet likely to grow fast enough to push prices much higher. The new report on the gross domestic product for the first quarter, which was released on Friday, emphasized that fact. Growth was revised down to nine-tenths of a percent from the initial estimate of 1.8 percent at an annual rate.
A third theme is that while confidence in Mr. Clinton has waned, by the end of last week the market had not decided that a disaster was at hand. A narrow victory in the House for the President's program was a boost for him, and developments over the weekend that point to a possible compromise in the Senate may make market participants feel even better.
A breakthrough for the President came when Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma and a crucial swing vote on the Senate Finance Committee, indicated that a compromise acceptable to him could be reached if the President's proposed energy tax was scaled back and spending cuts were increased.
Allen Sinai, a managing director at Lehman Brothers, had argued at the end of last week that Mr. Clinton would get much of his deficit-reduction plan implemented. And if this is the case, there are two positives for the bond market.
One is that the record Federal budget deficit might begin to decline. But in the nearer term, the negative impact of the tax increases are expected to keep the economy growing only moderately at best, which means there is less inflationary pressure. That is good for a fixed-income market, in which rising overall prices eat away at investors' income.

HEADLINE: Week's Treasury Auctions Will Be Confined to Bills

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this holiday-shortened week includes today's regular weekly auction of new 3-month and 6-month maturities and tomorrow's auction of 13-day cash management bills.
Traders said that by the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.05 percent and the rate on a six-month bill 3.20 percent.

HEADLINE: The '93 Cliburn Competition: Pianissimo

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, Tex., May 31

 BODY:
Any news a page turner makes can only be bad, but it is also likely to be small. As the Ninth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition enters its final week here, a page turner has been the biggest news in this year's calm and amicable proceedings. By the standards of past competitions, Cliburn or otherwise, this has been a placid affair, seemingly free of contentiousness among the jurors and of charges of scandal from the contestants.
The lone tempest, such as it was, began on Friday morning, when Fabio Bidini, a 24-year-old Italian, opened the semifinal round of competition with a performance of Morton Gould's "Ghost Waltzes," an 11-minute work commissioned for the event. Each of the 12 contestants who remain, from 35 who competed in the prelimary round, must perform the Gould work as part of a 75-minute recital that makes up half of the semifinal requirement. Since the competitors received the score less than six weeks before coming to Fort Worth, they were not expected to know it from memory. Of the first six semifinalists to perform, only two played without the score. 
 But the page turner assigned to Mr. Bidini's performance, which was in fact the work's world premiere, failed to arrive, because of a communication mix-up, competition officials said. A volunteer -- a "backstage mother," as she is called in this studiedly homey environment -- was pressed into service. Never having seen the score, and working without her reading glasses, she jumped the gun on some turns, causing Mr. Bidini to fight off her efforts while continuing to perform.
 
Second Time Around
 By all accounts, he fared admirably under the circumstances; two of the jurors said they were intently following the score and were unaware of the desperate combat onstage. The jury arranged for Mr. Bidini to play "Ghost Waltzes" again this afternoon, in connection with his chamber performance, the second half of the semifinal requirement. He did so beautifully, and without incident.
So Mr. Bidini has had a fair crack at the gold watch to be awarded for the best performance of the commissioned work. But whether the upset of Friday hampered his subsequent performances, and thus his chances of advancing to the competition's finals, remains an open question.
"I was really prepared for the stage," Mr. Bidini said on Sunday, gamely dismissing the mishap as a mere test of professionalism. "I cleared my mind for a few minutes and went back out like new."
It is ironic that volunteers should be a part of the controversy, for this quadrennial competition, in its 31 years of existence, has become famous for its amenities, which are rightly held up as a model of Texas hospitality. Each contestant is taken in by a Fort Worth family for the duration of the competition, as are other guests, and no fewer than 650 volunteers keep the event running smoothly, adding a warm, personal touch.
"This is the most important and the most stressful competition in the world," Mr. Bidini said, "but it doesn't feel like that, because the people are very friendly."
Fate notwithstanding, Mr. Bidini, who has already placed highly in two international competitions, appears to have a good chance of becoming one of the six finalists, representing a strong Italian contingent this year. Another of the four Italians who began the competition, Enrico Pace, 25, was a popular favorite in the preliminary round. Mr. Pace and Alexander Korsantiya, a 28-year-old from the Georgian Republic, said to be among the more idiosyncratic interpreters, were both eliminated early. But even their strong supporters, including John Ardoin, the critic of The Dallas Morning News, greeted their elimination with dismay and disbelief rather than outrage.
"These are performers of finish and obvious accomplishment, who intrigue and stimulate," Mr. Ardoin wrote, "and this makes it doubly difficult to imagine why they were left not just standing at the altar but locked out of the church."
In any case, some colorful figures remain from what is generally regarded as the strongest field in more than a decade. And since the old repertory requirements mandating works by a particular composer or from a particular period have now been lifted, these individualists are able to show their colors more fully.
 
A Touch of Audacity
 Frederic Chiu, a 28-year-old American, advanced from the preliminary round on the strength of an audacious program made up mostly of transcriptions, including his own flashy arrangement of Prokofiev's "Lieutenant Kije" Suite. Christopher Taylor, a 23-year-old student of Russell Sherman's in Boston, devoted most of the 50 minutes of his preliminary program to Bach's "Goldberg" Variations and included Pierre Boulez's Sonata No. 2 in his semifinal recital. Armen Babakhanyan, a 25-year-old Armenian, played Bach-Busoni, Franck, Berg and a "Poem" of his own composition.
Mr. Babakhanyan, a soulful performer who looks world-weary beyond his years, has become a strong sentimental favorite for having surmounted desperately impoverished conditions in his war-torn homeland. His participation was made possible by another innovation this year. For the first time, the competition is paying travel as well living expenses for all the contestants. Richard Rodzinski, the executive director of the competition, said that the change had been made in direct response to political and economic shifts in eastern Europe. "National agencies used to pay for travel to competitions," he said, "but they no longer do."
Generally, the changes in the Cliburn Competition this year seem to reflect a heightened sensitivity to the personal and artistic welfare of the performers. Competitions have been criticized heavily in recent years, both in principle, for treating art as sport, and on practical terms, for turning up the "wrong" winner. The Cliburn Competition in particular was subjected to intense scrutiny in Joseph Horowitz's book "The Ivory Trade" three years ago, and Mr. Horowitz went on to direct a sort of counter-Cliburn festival at the 92d Street Y in New York, presenting in recital three pianists who had been eliminated from previous competitions.
 
The Last May Be the First
 Mr. Horowitz was making the point that the "losers" of these events often have more to say than the winners. Indeed, the winner of the 1989 Cliburn Competition, Aleksei Sultanov, has received virtually no notice since.
"Time will tell," Mr. Rodzinski said of Mr. Sultanov's career. He acknowledged that Mr. Horowitz's criticisms of the competition not only produced a more introspective attitude on the part of the administrators this year, but also played a part in bringing about specific changes, like the lifting of the repertory requirements.
Whether the innovations will produce a better result remains to be seen. But almost everyone concerned feels that they have made for a livelier competition, and one that is likelier to present the contestants in their best light.
And who knows? There is still plenty of time and opportunity for some good old-fashioned mayhem and controversy.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Way Universities Profit by War Research

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The Cold War and American Science
The Military-Industrial-Academic
Complex at M.I.T. and Stanford
By Stuart W. Leslie
Illustrated. 332 pages. Columbia University Press. $42.
In "The Cold War and American Science," Stuart W. Leslie, a professor in the department of the history of science at Johns Hopkins University, takes off from the theme of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's only memorable phrase: his warning against the unwarranted influence of "the military-industrial complex." Mr. Eisenhower used the words in his farewell address on Jan. 17, 1961, just before leaving the White House, but its significance echoes to the present time of big-power peace. 
 Professor Leslie extends the Eisenhower phrase to include the major universities that depend on Pentagon contracts for their research laboratories: the "military-industrial-academic complex." (He credits Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, an early opponent of the Vietnam War, for adding the word "academic.") The author argues that with the end of the cold war, there's even less reason for the universities to put their brainpower to work for the Pentagon and the arms merchants.
"For better and for worse, the cold war redefined American science," Professor Leslie writes. "In the decade following the second World War, the Department of Defense became the biggest single patron of American science, predominantly in the physical sciences and engineering but important in many of the natural and social sciences as well. Driven by the politics of national security and by the Pentagon's belief in the competitive advantages of high technology, spending for defense research and development surpassed its wartime peak (already 50 times higher than prewar levels) by the end of the Korean War, then climbed to dizzying heights after Sputnik, reaching $5.5 billion a year by 1960."
In the next two decades, the Defense Department's share of Federal Government research and development spending decreased, but this didn't mean that America's scientific professoriate was going out of the military business. The Pentagon's declining share reflected the fact that other agencies -- the National Science Foundation, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Institutes of Health -- contributed to ever-greater increases of the military presence in American science. The defense buildup of the 1980's, the author says, actually pushed military research and development spending past the record levels of the Vietnam War.
To prove his theme, Professor Leslie concentrates his own research on the two universities that profited most from the Federal Government's largesse: the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University. But he also notes that among other universities, the California Institute of Technology, Harvard, Johns Hopkins (his own university) and Columbia (whose university press is his book's publisher) also received Government research-and-development contracts.
Professor Leslie writes that the Massachusetts Institute of Technology "profited enormously" from its military connections and the financing sources they provided. With this money, the university put together highly regarded engineering programs that were "financially and intellectually" successful. But even among those who benefited, there was a growing awareness that "the price of that success might be higher than anyone had imagined: a pattern for engineering education set, organizationally and conceptually, by the requirements of the national security state."
Stanford quickly caught up with M.I.T. in the contest of winning defense contracts for its research and teaching programs. "Electronics at Stanford, as at M.I.T.," the author says, "predominantly meant military electronics, from the actual hardware prototypes produced in classified laboratories to the most 'basic' theoretical research, which made them possible, and from the academic laboratories and classrooms that trained future electronics engineers to the local defense contractors that hired most of them."
Professor Leslie's book would have been stronger had he included spokesmen for the military-industrial-academic complex: Pentagon officials, defense contractors and professors who, rightly or wrongly, believed they were making a contribution to the national defense and economy in the cold war years. Even if one agrees with his theme that what was good for the Pentagon and arms manufacturers wasn't necessarily good for the universities or the country, the other side might well have been heard from.
Inevitably, the cold figures of cold war costs are lacking in authorial sexiness; they're about as exciting as Ross Perot's charts. That's one reason the subject of Pentagon and other Federal agency support for military research in the universities has not been adequately reported in the press, on television or in books. Professor Leslie deserves credit for opening up the subject. "The Cold War and American Science" helps tell why the transition from a quasi-wartime economy to the hobbled peacetime economy the Clinton Administration inherited is so daunting and necessary.

HEADLINE: Guatemalan Leader Is Pressed to Yield Power

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, May 31

 BODY:
The opposition to President Jorge Serrano Elias's seizure of almost dictatorial powers grew more defiant today as the Government's isolation increased.
One day after military leaders backed away from their support for the President, prominent citizens called for his resignation, small groups of protesters again challenged a ban on public assembly, and newspapers began to openly mock the standing censorship of the press. 
 The country's business organization, citing fears of the economy's "imminent asphyxiation" by sanctions from abroad, demanded that he restore the constitutional order immediately.
Last night, as politicians predicted that the President was about to be forced from power, Mr. Serrano, flanked by the Vice President and Minister of Defense, spoke to the nation on radio and television, denying rumors that he would resign.
"This political problem has to be solved politically," he said.
After meeting with Mr. Serrano for a second time here this afternoon, the Secretary General of the Organization of American States, Joao Baena Soares, gave no indication that he expected the President to back down soon from the measures he took last Tuesday. These included the dissolution of the Congress and the Supreme Court and the suspension of basic constitutional rights.
But diplomats involved in his talks with the Government and its opponents said Mr. Soares made it clear that Guatemala could expect stinging censure from its neighbors on Thursday when foreign ministers of the organization's member states hold an emergency meeting in Washington to discuss the problems in Guatemala.
"Since the coup," a diplomat involved in the talks said, "they have realized that the international reaction against them has been much stronger and much quicker than they expected."
Even more than the cutoff of most of an American aid package worth nearly $50 million and the suspension of $100 million in aid from European countries, businessmen have panicked at a threat by the United States to withdraw Guatemala's trade benefits under the Generalized System of Preferences.
According to the Guatemalan central bank, 36 percent of the country's exports to the United States, or about $160 million worth, would be affected by such a step, but United States officials put the figure considerably higher. Tourism industry officials said they had already received a significant number of cancellations by foreign tour groups and others, but said they were still calculating the effects.
"If measures are not taken very quickly to resolve this crisis, the cost to Guatemala would simply be too high," said Mario Granai y Fernandez, president of the umbrella business organization, the Coordinating Committee of Agricultural, Commercial, Industrial and Financial Associations.
On the streets of the capital, the reflection of the Government's troubles grew more apparent. Two days after a group of prominent journalists had huddled in the basement of the United States Embassy relating their fears of arrest, scores of reporters marched on the National Palace demanding Mr. Serrano's resignation. The police did not intervene.
After refusing to publish since Wednesday because of censorship, a leading Guatemalan newspaper, Siglo Veintiuno, or Twenty-First Century, printed a blacked-out front page under the banner Siglo Catorce, or Fourteenth Century.
After editors at another newspaper, La Hora, made a show of refusing to accept any censorship, the police officers around its office simply dispersed. Members of the staff then ran through the streets, gleefully distributing the day's first edition.
A group of demonstrators who marched past the palace to the presidential residence were headed by the Government's human rights ombudsman, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, who was in hiding only a few days ago.
"This cannot go on much longer," Mr. de Leon Carpio said of the Government's suspension of constitutional rights.

HEADLINE: Pressure on Bentsen Mounts as Senate Faces Budget

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen vigorously thrust himself onto center stage of the budget battle last week, lining up a majority of House Democrats from Texas for President Clinton's economic plan, buttonholing and cajoling pivotal senators, tearing into opponents at a news conference and giving loads of advice to the White House.
Probably the best proof that he was in the thick of things was the photograph taken in the Oval Office last Thursday night: a beaming Mr. Bentsen stood between President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore as they telephoned Speaker Thomas S. Foley after the House approved the plan by a margin of six votes. 
 But now that the focus turns to the Senate, the pressure on Mr. Bentsen is sure to mount. Mr. Clinton tapped the 72-year-old Texan for the Cabinet with much hoopla about how his 22 years in the Senate, and especially his six years as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, would insure smooth sailing for the economic package.
 
Rattled by Questions
 Even though the Senate will not formally take up the legislation for another week, Mr. Bentsen and his lieutenants have already felt rattled by questions about why his legislative savvy has not been enough to steer the plan clear of Congressional dangers.
"Certainly, Bentsen hasn't been the front man as we expected him to be," said Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "That's the historical role of the Treasury Secretary, and we were led to believe he was appointed to play that role."
Secretary Bentsen declined to be interviewed for this article, aides said, partly because of concerns that he would appear defensive. But his supporters in the Administration and in Congress said in interviews that the President's economic package ran into trouble not because of Mr. Bentsen, but because of unpopular parts of the plan and because of the White House's failure to do a better job of selling it.
Indeed, one Treasury official attributed some of Mr. Clinton's problems to his failure to heed all of Mr. Bentsen's advice. When several conservative Democrats proposed a scaled-down version of the President's $19 billion economic stimulus package, the Treasury Secretary urged a compromise. His advice was rejected, and the legislation went down in defeat.
 
Trust the Leadership
 Since then Congressional Republicans have tasted blood and conservative Democrats have hesitated to rally round the President's economic plan, creating the need for last week's hand-to-hand combat to round up enough votes in the House.
On Thursday, the day of the House vote, the White House seemed to pay Mr. Bentsen more heed. When several White House officials suggested Thursday afternoon that the House leadership pull the bill because of insufficient support, the Secretary said they should trust the House leadership to decide whether the bill should go forward.
The White House listened to him, the House leadership concluded the votes were there, and on Thursday evening, Mr. Clinton and others in the Oval Office gave Mr. Bentsen a round of applause after the vote.
Questions about Mr. Bentsen's performance reached their height after two of his former colleagues who were among his closest friends in the Senate -- David L. Boren of Oklahoma and J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana -- declared war on the President's package, especially the energy tax. "It's particularly bad for my state," Senator Johnston said. "All the charm, persuasion and judgment in the world can't change that."
 
Signs of Compromise
 On Sunday, Mr. Boren indicated on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that he might be willing to compromise, but Administration officials feared that many hurdles would remain before winning Mr. Boren's vote.
The Administration believed that if a Treasury Secretary with close ties to the oil industry embraced the tax, it would be hard for the industry and oil-state senators to oppose it. Clearly, someone miscalculated, and as a result Mr. Bentsen spent most of the last two months -- and will undoubtedly spend much of June -- cutting and trimming the energy tax to keep some Democratic senators from defecting.
Not only did the Boren revolt appear to be a personal betrayal, but it also meant that Mr. Bentsen was not even able to lock up a majority in the 20-member Senate Finance Committee because Mr. Boren is a member of it.
But some Washington veterans say the Administration had impossibly high expectations of Mr. Bentsen.
"Any foolish expectation that he can leave the chairmanship of the Finance Committee, move from the legislative to the executive branch and still yield the same type of influence over the committee is just plain naive," said Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic national chairman.
 
A Matter of Arithmetic
 Some Bentsen supporters say a rebellion was inevitable by at least one Democrat on the Finance Committee, where the Democrats have a two-vote majority. This arithmetic gives conservative Democrats a huge incentive to hold out against the President's plan since the last senator aboard can extract the most concessions.
"This is not a Bentsen problem," an Administration official said. "This is an 11-to-9 problem in a highly partisan context."
Some officials say that after years of independence as the senior Senator from Texas, Mr. Bentsen feels a bit awkward being a gear in someone else's machine. He sometimes seems to fear that if he grabs the spotlight he will be upstaging his boss.
But occasionally the Secretary is out of the limelight because he gets cut out of the action. That happened when Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, dealt directly with the President to negotiate major changes in the economic plan, among them lopping out the proposed investment tax credit and scaling back the increase in the corporate income tax.
 
Importance of Quiet Diplomacy
 Probably the best reason for Mr. Bentsen's lack of visibility is that he prefers it: he learned the importance of quiet diplomacy as chairman of the Finance Committee.
Aides say Mr. Bentsen devotes most of his days to meetings and phone calls with lawmakers, concentrating on Democrats but also seeking to pick off some moderate Republicans. He talks several times a day with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who succeeded him as the Finance Committee chairman, and keeps in close touch with every Democrat on the committee.
In a recent three-day period, for example, Mr. Bentsen talked more than a half dozen times with Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, including two meetings in the Senator's office. Mr. Breaux, another member of the member of the Finance Committee, almost defected from Mr. Clinton's economic plan until Mr. Bentsen talked him out of it.
"If we didn't have him as Treasury Secretary, the package would not be in as good a shape as it is," Mr. Breaux said.
Mr. Bentsen, an expert as horse-trading, helped keep Mr. Breaux from joining Mr. Boren's rump faction by brokering a deal in which part of the energy tax would be refunded to petrochemical companies, a powerful force in Louisiana.
He also helped keep Senator Kent Conrad, a North Dakota Democrat and another member of the Finance Committee, on board by pledging not to apply the tax to ethanol, a fuel made from corn, and by promising a smaller increase than proposed in inland barge fees, both measures that would hurt farmers.
Senator Moynihan has praised Mr. Bentsen's performance. "He's often on the Hill, which is new for Treasury Secretaries, who often stay in their Greek Temple and think deep thought," Mr. Moynihan said recently. "He hasn't been very visible. That's what has been helpful about it."
