HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Raytheon Will Acquire Jet Business

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
In a bid to broaden its product offerings in the business jet market, the Raytheonn Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire British Aerospace's Corporate Jets division for $390 million.
Like many large corporations that have been seeking to spin off noncore operations and focus more intensely on what they think they do best, British Aerospace has been trying to sell the division for some time as part of a six-year-old restructuring effort. 
 Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., makes Beechcraft turboprops and small jets, and believes British Aerospace's longer-range business jets will complement its current line-up of shorter-range corporate jets.
 
 
'Into the Core'
 "It puts the company powerfully into the core of the corporate aircraft market," Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst at UBS Securities, said.
The companies started discussing a sale more than a year ago, but talks broke off for a number of reasons. Sources familiar with the latest talks said sticky issues that were finally resolved included not only price and protection against currency fluctuations, but also employment assurances for some British Aerospace workers.
According to the agreement, for example, British Aerospace will supply the major subassemblies for its 125-800 and 125-1000 models for at least three years.
If the deal is approved by industry regulators in each country, the acquisition will increase Raytheon's annual sales in the corporate jet market by roughly 35 percent, to more than $1.7 billion. In 1992, the sales of the division rose 14 percent, and it reported an operating profit of $140 million. The British Aerospace division recorded a small profit for last year of about $9 million on sales of about $450 million.
Analysts described the agreed-to price as fair, but no bargain for Raytheon. The acquisition gives Raytheon a running start in a new product line, while eliminating a potential competitor. Raytheon's challenge, however, will be to make the division sufficiently profitable that it can reinvest in the product upgrades that are required to remain competitive in the corporate aircraft business.
 
 
'Open Question'
 The outlook for that market is "an open question," according to Jack Modzelewski of Paine Webber. While some industry analysts have been surprised by the market's ability to weather the recession in recent years, it remains unclear whether large companies will feel the itch for new corporate aircraft once their fortunes improve.
Raytheon has not been decided whether the new aircraft will maintain a separate identity or be folded into the Beechcraft line.
As part of the deal, Raytheon will acquire Arkansas Aerospace Inc., a British Aerospace subsidiary in Little Rock, Ark., that customizes business jets and maintains airplanes.
Raytheon, a diversified company perhaps best known for its Patriot missiles, operates its Beech Aircraft division in Wichita, Kan. Raytheon's stock closed at $55.625 yesterday, up 75 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
High Court Defines One Error by Judges It Will Not Tolerate

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Overturning a murder conviction, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that regardless of the evidence, a criminal conviction is invalid if the judge did not instruct the jury properly on finding guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
In an opinion by Justice Antonin Scalia, the Court held that mistaken jury instructions on reasonable doubt could never be disregarded as "harmless error," even if it appeared that the guilty verdict was not the product of the mistake. 
 In recent years the Court has expanded the category of errors -- committed either before or during trial -- that can be disregarded as harmless if the evidence of guilt is otherwise clear.
Two years ago, for example, the Court characterized coerced or involuntary confessions as harmless errors after such confessions had previously been treated as automatically invalidating a conviction. The Court was bitterly divided in that 5-to-4 decision, Arizona v. Fulminante, and it was unclear how much further the Court would be willing to go.
The decision today indicated at least an outer boundary to the harmless-error doctrine. Justice Scalia said a jury's understanding of the burden of proof -- guilt beyond a reasonable doubt -- was so central to the trial itself that a faulty understanding deprived defendants of the right to trial by jury, "without which a criminal trial cannot reliably serve its function."
The decision, Sullivan v. Louisiana, No. 92-5129, overturned a decision last year by the Louisiana Supreme Court. There was no dispute in the case that instructions on reasonable doubt given to the jury in a 1980 murder trial were erroneous. The only issue was whether the faulty instructions could be viewed as harmless error.
The instructions, once widely used in Louisiana, were declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court in another Louisiana case three years ago. The Court found that by using such phrases as "grave uncertainty" or "substantial doubt," the instructions failed to make clear that the state has the heavy burden of proving guilt "beyond a reasonable doubt."
In the case before the Court today, the Louisiana Supreme Court had upheld the conviction of John L. Sullivan for killing another man during an armed robbery in a New Orleans bar. The state court ruled that while the instructions were invalid, the error was harmless. Mr. Sullivan had initially been sentenced to death, but the state court set aside the sentence on other grounds.
In his opinion today, Justice Scalia said that once a jury had been instructed improperly on reasonable doubt, that error could not be harmless. The error is structural, he said, with effects on the verdict that cannot be measured or cured.
He said it was as if there had been no jury verdict at all. "There being no jury verdict of guilty-beyond-a-reasonable-doubt, the question whether the same verdict of guilty-beyond-a-reasonable-doubt would have been rendered absent the constitutional error is utterly meaningless," he said. "A reviewing court can only engage in pure speculation -- its view of what a reasonable jury would have done."
But because the right to trial by jury is constitutionally guaranteed, judges cannot arrive at their own verdict of guilt, Justice Scalia said.
Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the author of the opinion two years ago that placed coerced confessions in the harmless-error category, joined Justice Scalia's opinion with a concurring opinion that struck a distinctly reluctant tone. "Harmless-error review has become an integral component of our criminal justice system," the Chief Justice said. He added that he had "lingering doubts" about whether to treat deficient jury instructions on reasonable doubt as "a breed apart."
The Court also took action on these other cases:
 
Cable Regulation
 The Court upheld a provision of a Federal law on the authority of local governments to regulate cable television.
Under the 1984 law, private cable systems that draw signals to an apartment building or group of buildings by satellite dish are regulated differently, depending on whether the buildings share common ownership. Systems serving a single building or commonly owned buildings are exempt from the requirement of obtaining a local franchise, while systems using the same technology but serving a number of buildings with different owners are subject to the same franchise requirements as any other cable system.
Last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit declared the distinction unconstitutional, on the ground that it violated the equal protection rights of the systems serving the buildings with different owners. The appeals court's decision was a provocative one that drew attention from beyond the narrow world of cable regulation, because it departed from the Federal courts' general view that the Constitution should not be invoked to overturn economic regulations.
The Supreme Court reversed the appeals court's decision today in an opinion by Justice Clarence Thomas. The vote was 9 to 0, with seven Justices joining Justice Thomas and Justice John Paul Stevens writing a separate concurring opinion.
"Equal protection is not a license for courts to judge the wisdom, fairness, or logic of legislative choices," Justice Thomas said. He added that the distinction between the cable systems should be upheld as rational as long as there was any theoretical basis for it. The opinion cited several possible reasons for the distinction. "A legislative choice is not subject to courtroom fact-finding and may be based on rational speculation unsupported by evidence or empirical data," Justice Thomas said.
The case was Federal Communications Commission v. Beach Communications, No. 92-603.
 
Vanna White May Sue
 Without comment, the Court let stand a ruling that permits the game show hostess Vanna White to sue an electronics company and its advertising agency for infringing her "right of publicity" through a television commercial that the company said was a harmless parody, protected by the First Amendment.
The commercial for videocassette recorders made by Samsung Electronics showed a robot, dressed as Ms. White and wearing a blond wig, on a set resembling her "Wheel of Fortune" game show. Her lawsuit, filed in Federal court in California, asserted that the company had appropriated her public image without her permission. The suit said the advertisement had no constitutional protection.
The district court dismissed her suit, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, reinstated it last year. "The difference between a 'parody' and a 'knock-off' is the difference between fun and profit," the appeals court said. The case is Samsung Electronics v. White, No. 92-1629.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Georgetown of Clinton, Meet Georgetown Today

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On June 5, members of Georgetown University's class of 1968 will celebrate their 25th reunion at the White House at the invitation of their classmate Bill Clinton.
For the rest of the homecoming weekend, the class members will have plenty of time to get reacquainted with one other and the university they left 25 years ago. They will have changed, but probably not nearly so much as their alma mater. 
 They will find, for example, that that more than half of the undergraduates in this once exclusively male institution are now women; that some new students are not aware that Georgetown is a Roman Catholic university until after they arrive; that there is now a pregnancy hot line; that residence hall staff members, whose job used to be to make sure that lights were out at 11 P.M., are now trained to watch for eating disorders and suicidal tendencies.
The '68 alumni will also find that students today are more mature and self-assured and better educated than many were 25 years ago despite being subject to economic and competitive pressures that the alumni never knew. They will find students who have to hold jobs to pay for tuition but who still find time to tutor inner-city children and to campaign for feminist and gay causes.
"Georgetown is a different place; Washington is a different place," said the Rev. Robert Brooks Lawton, the dean of Georgetown College. "Both are more sophisticated, more international, more mature."
Much of the change, students and faculty members agree, was wrought by the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, the late Jesuit priest who was president from 1976 to 1989. His red-brick accomplishments are there for all to see: dormitories, classroom buildings, a student center, new academic buildings and additions to the medical school and the law school. When Bill Clinton arrived in 1964, the campus had 34 buildings; today it has 86.
More important, Georgetown people say, Father Healy invested the university with academic excellence. "He revived intellectualism here," said Rob Pegoraro, a graduating senior from Tewksbury Township, N.J. "He was the first to push the university as one of the best in the country."
In the mid-1960's, Bill Clinton, a Protestant from the Deep South, was in a distinct minority at Georgetown, which was still a relatively exclusive Catholic university for men. Women were admitted to the Schools of Foreign Service, Nursing, and Languages and Linguistics, but the university did not become fully coeducational until 1969, when Georgetown College admitted women.
Once attended mostly by people from the mid-Atlantic region, Georgetown's 12,000 students today come from all 50 states and 100 countries. Twenty percent are members of minorities, and almost 10 percent are from outside the United States.
In a way, this is a return to the goals set by Georgetown's founder, Archbishop John Carroll, in 1789. "He wanted citizens from every class," said the university's current president, the Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan. "Those early classes had the sons of plantation owners and sons of women who took in washing to pay the fees. And at Carroll's insistence, they came from every religion."
Jodi Padnick, the editor of The Hoya, the twice-a-week undergraduate newspaper, is one of about 400 Jewish students. "Some of the Jewish kids act as if they're not Jewish," she said, "but a lot of us think that attending a Catholic school makes us feel more Jewish. We feel we need to learn more about Israel, about what we believe. I think it makes us stronger."
Like most students, Ms. Padnick, a junior from Paradise Valley, Ariz, said there was never any effort on the university's part to impose Catholic values. Every student must take a course called "The Problem of God," but it is taught by laymen and chaplains of all the major faiths.
The traditional Jesuit presence on campus is now spread thin, with the number of priests down to 40. "The Catholic influence is more implicit than overt," Father Lawton said. "The Jesuit influence is seen in the general atmosphere. Whatever the subject being taught, we try to talk about the question of values, of ethics, of ultimate meanings."
But there is concern, even among students, that the university is too materialistic. "It's not as tense as some Eastern schools," Ms. Padnick said, "but there is a lot of competition. All anyone thinks about is going to law school."
University figures show that about 30 percent of each graduating class goes directly to graduate school, with 70 percent to 90 percent indicating plans to go eventually.
Students also express considerable concern about money, and about 40 percent receive some kind of student aid. Others work one or two jobs to help pay tuition and fees of about $24,000 a year. In 1964, when Bill Clinton here, those fees were $2,450 for men, $50 more for women.
Speaking of today's students, Renee DeVigne, the interim dean of students, said: "There is a lot of anxiety. They work hard because they are worried about the economy and the problem of meeting even their parent's level of success. The old idea of always doing better has changed. They see themselves struggling to stay in the middle class."
Father Lawton added: "They do work hard, but they are involved in so many things. They are juggling studies, community service, jobs, internships and social life."
At any given time, several hundred Georgetown students are serving internships in Congress or in Federal agencies and departments. Such internships are eagerly sought by students heading for law school and planning careers in the public sector, and they highlight the symbiotic relationship between Georgetown and the Federal Government.
That link gives the university a special position among American institutions of higher learning. "It's a difference that counts," one student said. "Otherwise you might as well go to Duke or Brown."
Another student was even more specific, saying: "In the Middle West, you have to demonstrate to make a point. Here you can go work in the Government and actually get something done."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Georgetown University's 12,000 students come from 100 countries and all 50 states. Twenty percent are members of minorities, and almost 10 percent are from outside the United States. (Tracey Attlee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Enthusiasm Builds Strongly For Allstate Public Offering

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Money managers and analysts were talking with rising enthusiasm yesterday about the imminent initial public offering of the Allstate Company. The sale, expected to raise more than $2 billion, would be the largest initial public offering ever in the United States.
The company, the nation's second- largest insurer of homes and automobiles, is being spun off to the public by Sears, Roebuck & Company, which is shedding financial services assets to focus on its retail operations. 
 People familiar with the offering said the stock was expected to be priced this evening after the market closed. They expected the offering price to be near $27 a share, in the upper range of what Sears announced in its prospectus.
Yesterday, at a closed presentation to investors at the New York Palace Hotel, the ballroom was so filled , one participant said, that representatives of the large underwriting houses in the deal had to stand.
The underwriters of a stock offering, of course, are anxious to generate reports of overwhelming demand. That demand may or may not materialize when Allstate's stock is available on the New York Stock Exchange. But people familiar with the deal said there has been keen interest on the part of money managers.
Some buyers at yesterday's presentation expressed reservations about Allstate's exposure in Florida and in other states to losses from hurricanes and other natural disasters. They also worried about roadblocks Allstate faces as it tries to reduce its risk in such areas by dropping policies. But by and large, buyers were said to be mostly impressed by Allstate's plans to reduce its exposure over time and increase capital, its so-called surplus, in part with proceeds from the offering.
"It is a company that has a well-articulated strategy for increasing earnings," said Diane L. Lockard, a vice president with Society Asset Management in Cleveland, which manages more than $16 billion. "I look for comfort to their capital base and the fact that a good portion of the funds they raise will be used to boost surplus."
In interviews yesterday, money managers and analysts described Allstate as a company with a household brand name and a straightforward explanation of why its future looks bright. It has relatively low costs, a top-flight distribution network of agents that can't be duplicated and a strong balance sheet, they said. In addition, many analysts consider Allstate's proposed selling price to be modest compared with the price of comparable companies.
 
Low Price-Earnings Ratio
 Depending on the offering price, Allstate's shares are expected to sell at about 10 or 11 times earnings, said Orin Kramer of Boston Provident Partners, a Englewood, N.J., money manager. Companies such as Safeco and Ohio Casualty sell for more than 12 times projected 1993 earnings. Some companies such as Geico, sell for as much as 19 times projected earnings.
With 12.5 percent of the nation's homeowners and automobile insurance policies, Allstate is second in size only to State Farm, which is a mutual company that has about one- fourth of the market.
"It is one of the largest and best- capitalized insurance companies in the nation," said Alan B. Snyder of Snyder Capital, an independent money manager in San Francisco, referring to Allstate.
Sears Roebuck initially announced that it would offer 20 percent of Allstate in at least 78.5 million shares at between $24 and $27 a share. At $26 a share, the company would raise roughly $2.04 billion.
One reason Sears may choose to keep the price of the offering at the low end of the range, analysts say, is that with Sears planning to retain 80 percent of the stock, it hopes to take advantage of higher prices in the future. It will also establish stock options for 2,000 top Allstate employees on the basis of the initial offering price. A lower price would benefit those employees.
But not every money manager was enthusiastic. Carl M. Lindberg, a managing director of Brandywine Asset Management, said that he was wary of the risk that state regulators would block rate increases, and of the prospect of higher automobile insurance losses if the economy recovers, which would mean an increase in automobile driving and a rise in the number of accidents.
"I don't think this is a table-pounder for us," Mr. Lindberg said.

HEADLINE: Stony Brook President Plans to Step Down

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 1

 BODY:
Dr. John H. Marburger, president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, announced today that he would step down and return to teaching, ending a 13-year tenure marked by strains to maintain academic standards as state aid steadily declined.
In announcing his resignation, Dr. Marburger said he would leave his $146,000 position as soon as a successor is found, which he estimated would take up to a year. He pointed out that when he was appointed to the post in 1980 he said he planned to stay for only 10 years. 
 "But 1990 was the first year of deep budget cuts, and our current administrative team was then brand new," he wrote in an open letter. "While the forthcoming year will not be an easy one for Stony Brook, the additional cuts are not large and there are many signs of recovery."
 
Praise From Associates
 Dr. Marburger, who will return to teaching posts in the school's physics and electrical engineering departments, was praised by his associates today, though some worried that the school would suffer from his resignation.
"I am disappointed and surprised," said John G. Truxal, the former dean of the College of Engineering and Applied Science, now a professor of electrical engineering. "We are still a fairly young university, and he's a man who has had a picture of what Stony Brook could be and he has consistently stuck to that picture."
Mr. Truxal said Dr. Marburger had been extremely supportive of academic programs but had often been besieged by budget problems as state funds dwindled. "I really was amazed they didn't wear him down years ago."
 
Largest Employer on L.I.
 In an interview today Dr. Marburger said he had tried to counter some of the cuts in state money -- which dropped to $150 million this academic year from $173 million in 1989-1990 -- by seeking private contributions. Donations to the university have gone to $15 million from $5 million a year before he became president, Dr. Marburger said.
"We've become entrepreneurial," Dr. Marburger said. "We've had to find new ways of doing our business as state support has diminished." The university recently opened the Long Island High Technology Incubator, which rents research, laboratory and office space to fledgling hi-tech businesses on Long Island.
With 10,000 employees, the university is the largest employer on Long Island, and is closely connected to the island's economy. Dr. Marburger, 52, sits on the board of the Long Island Association, the major business group, while the Long Island Association's president, James L. Larocca, sits on the Stony Brook Council, which will choose Dr. Marburger's successor.
The 16,000-student research university, which draws 80 percent of its student body from Long Island and New York City, was once envisioned as the premier school in the state university system. Dr. Marburger was largely credited with trying to fulfill that promise despite the budget hardships.
"Putting it bluntly, we're a creature of the budgetary process, and Jack Marburger and his staff have been fighting valiantly with the legislature for the university," said Aaron Donner, chairman of the Stony Brook Council. "Sometimes the great work is a proposed cut ain't going to take place rather than getting something new. These are difficult times for SUNY."

HEADLINE: Bonds Rise On Loss By Gold

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A sharp drop in gold prices and an improved outlook for President Clinton's deficit reduction plan helped send prices of Treasury securities sharply higher yesterday. More sluggish economic data also helped the market.
The rally in the bond market and a $9 drop in the price of gold to $371.30 an ounce helped send stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.91 points, to 3,552.34. [Pages D8 and D17.] 
 But in the bond market, prices and yields -- which move in opposite directions -- still appear locked in a tight range, with traders and investors awaiting the next important economic data, which will come in the May employment report to be released Friday.
 
 
Crucial Data
 It is those data, and the following reports on inflation, that will help decide if the bond market remains in its present range or whether prices move toward new high or low territory. For prices to reach new highs -- and yields to fall to new lows -- the data will have to do two things: show that the economy is still growing slowly and that the sharp rise in inflation during the first four months of the year is subsiding.
Peter McTeague, a fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, is bullish about the outlook, because he thinks that the inflation worries that sparked the selloff near the end of May were overdone. "In the worst case we are in a trading range and will test the highs," he said, referring to prices. "In the best case, we will break out to new highs."
Mr. McTeague said that a 1.67-point drop in the Commodity Research Bureau Index of commodities, including a sharp drop in the price of soybeans, also contributed to the relaxation of inflationary tension, at least for the day.
 
 
Short-Sellers Cited
 He added that yesterday's price rises were accentuated by buying from investors and traders who had been negative on the market and were either sitting out or had sold short in hopes that prices would fall, allowing them to profit by buying back their securities at lower prices.
"Too many people expected the bond to go to 7.125 percent before it went back to 6.75 percent," he said.
In late trading in the secondary market, the price of the 30-year bond due in February 2023 was up 19/32 percentage points as the yield fell to 6.88 percent, its lowest level since May 12. The yield was down from 6.98 percent Friday. The bond market was closed Monday for Memorial Day. An afternoon surge in the bond's price coincided with a sharp drop in the price of gold. On the Commodity Exchange in New York the price of the August contract was down nearly $13 an ounce before ending up at $371.30.
The prices of Treasury notes were also higher, with the 10-year note up 24/32 point as the yield fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.15 percent.
The market's impetus came partly from comments made over the weekend by Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, a key member of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Boren had said he opposed the President's proposed energy tax, a crucial element in the deficit reduction plan. His opposition would make it hard to win approval in the committee.
But the Senator said in interviews that he could now consider a compromise that would scale back the energy tax and replace the lost revenue with more spending cuts. That program shift would be positive for the bond market, where many analysts believe that spending reductions are the only way to achieve long-term deficit reduction.
 
 
Two Reports
 Two economic reports yesterday, one on personal income and the other the purchasing managers' report, showed that the economy, while growing, was moving at a sluggish pace.
This sluggish growth is positive for investors because it means that it is not likely that the economy will put much more upward pressure on prices, which means that the surprisingly high rate of increase in the Consumer Price Index for the first four months of the year -- 4.3 percent at an annual rate -- might subside.
Wayne Angell, a governor of the Federal Reserve and one of the members reportedly pushing for higher short-term interest rates to curb rising prices, said yesterday that he thought inflation would rise by 3 percent to 3.5 percent this year. This is a modest forecast that could be reassuring to some investors. But it is also higher than the Fed's main forecast of 2.5 percent to 2.75 percent made in February. Last year the Consumer Price Index rose 2.9 percent.
The drop in the price of gold may also have helped relieve some anxiety because there are investors who see in its rise the expectation of higher inflation. But while some gold traders said that the price plunge yesterday reflected a relaxing of inflationary fears, others contended that it was just the kind of correction that should be expected after the price had risen more than 16 percent since March.
 
 
Weekly Bill Auction
 In the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rates jumped to their highest level since the first auction of the year. The average rate for the three-month bill was 3.08 percent, up from 3.06 percent last week and the highest since 3.15 percent at the Jan. 4 auction. The rate for the six-month bill was 3.22 percent, up from 3.19 percent last week and the highest since 3.28 percent on Jan. 4.
This rise is in part a response to reports of the last week that the Federal Reserve has decided on a new monetary policy that has a bias toward higher short-term interest rates because of the unexpectedly high inflation data through April.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday:

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Is Down $9 and Silver Also Falls as Fever Breaks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
old prices plunged by as much as $9 an ounce in heavy trading yesterday as speculative fever broke after having pushed prices up nearly 18 percent this spring.
Other precious metal prices also tumbled. Analysts said the market's sentiment had changed. "My guess is that we may already have seen the high for the year," said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. 
 Gold for June delivery dropped $8.80, to $369.50 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The more actively traded contract for August delivery sank $9, to $371.30.
July silver plummeted 21.7 cents, to $4.405 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, July platinum fell $7.70, to $392.10.
 
No Clear Reason Cited
 Analysts could cite no clear reason for the drop in the metals, which followed a week of volatile activity and steep declines in gold and silver on Friday.
Mr. Milling-Stanley said the investment funds that helped drive spot gold prices up from the March 10 low of $326 had became increasingly wary as prices approached $390. June gold peaked at $384.50, a 28-month high, on Friday; the August contract peaked at $386.50.
He said floor traders managed to depress prices enough yesterday to panic the big funds into selling.
Peter Cardillo, research director with Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York, linked the selloff to a rally in stock and bond prices amid rising expectations that President Clinton would win Senate approval for a Federal deficit-reduction plan.
Mr. Cardillo also said inflation fears, one of the factors behind gold's springtime surge, were fading.
"I'm not quite sure it's the end of the rally but the perception is beginning to change," he said. "People are more willing to sell into the market and take their profits than they were two weeks ago."
Mr. Milling-Stanley said supply-and-demand factors should keep the August gold contract from falling below $365. He predicted the metal would settle into a trading range of $365 to $385.
He was less optimistic about silver, which had risen more than 34 percent from a February low of $3.51 to last week's high of $4.72. "I see no signs of a major economic recovery in the United States," he said. "I'm seeing no resurgence of major demand from major North American industrial customers."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reverses Early Drop To End Day Little Changed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed against major currencies yesterday after it recovered from another record low against the Japanese yen. There was speculation that the Federal Reserve was again buying dollars to stem the currency's slide.
The dollar fell to a new low of 106.55 yen in London trading. It recovered in New York to finish at 107.15 yen, up from 106.95 yen late Friday. 
 The British pound, meanwhile, tumbled on concerns that Prime Minister John Major's shake-up of his Cabinet will result in a greater willingness to lower interest rates to bolster economic growth. In late New York trading, the pound sank to $1.5515, from $1.5617 late Friday.
Currency trading was slow yesterday. On Monday, markets in New York, London and other European cities were closed for holidays.
The Fed aggressively bought dollars last week after the dollar started its most recent decline, traders said. If the Fed was in the market yesterday, traders said, its purchases were probably smaller and more discreet. The Fed does not discuss its currency trading activities.
"The Fed's recent intervention is making people think twice about selling the dollar," said Steve Flanagan, vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. The dollar also gained as traders sold the yen to take advantage of its rapid rise, he said.
The dollar went into a tailspin last week after the Treasury Department issued a report saying a strong yen could help curb Japan's trade surplus. The dollar has fallen more than 3 yen since then. Since the beginning of the year, the yen has risen more than 14 percent against the dollar.
Traders said the dollar's recovery from record lows yesterday did not mean that its slide against the yen was over. They noted that the American economy remained sluggish and that the country's trade deficit with Japan was still growing.
"This is a bit of a respite," said Brian Dolan, a trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York. "We'll resume the downward trend in a week or two."
Without robust economic growth, the Federal Reserve is less likely to raise interest rates, which would buoy the dollar by making dollar deposits more attractive to investors.

HEADLINE: Bankers Balk At New Rules

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., June 1

 BODY:
Resisting fierce pressure from the banking industry, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued two new accounting rules today that bankers say will give investors a false impression of their finances.
Statement 114 covers how banks and other financial institutions account for bad loans. It would require them to estimate the percentage of the loan they will get back from their creditors and list only the discounted amount on their financial statements. 
 Currently, banks do not have to adjust the value of their troubled loans on their financial statements.
Statement 115 requires banks and other financial institutions to report the market value of all debt securities as well as any equity securities for which a fair value can be determined. Many financial institutions report the value of such assets on their books at the price they paid for them. With the new rule, only bonds that banks promise to hold until they mature will be eligible for such historical cost accounting.
Bankers contend that the rule will cause the value of their regulatory capital -- the money the Government requires them to keep on hand to pay back depositors -- to fluctuate with interest rates. Banks typically invest their capital in bonds.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Ambition vs. Practicality in Cable-Phone Link

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
In theory, the recently announced Time Warner-U S West deal is the perfect marriage. Time Warner's cable television system already has the potential to deliver hundreds of channels of programming. U S West is an expert in building telephone networks that can instantly route millions of phone calls at the same time.
Want to order up a video how-to guide on repairing your car or building a deck? Click the remote control. Want to choose from a long list of movies, and specify when they will be shown? Just click again, and put the bill on a credit card. Want to make a plain old phone call? The new networks planned by Time Warner and U S West would do that, too. 
 But now comes the hard part. While experts say the core principles for such a network are firmly established, the technology is still so new that a multitude of glitches are inevitable and many crucial components are not yet commercially available.
Time Warner and U S West hope to have an experimental new-age cable system operating in Orlando, Fla., by early next year. And the two allies hope to begin providing advanced services in other cities as early as 1995. But that timetable could prove difficult.
"To make a cable network perform like a telephone company doesn't require any new science," said Charles M. Lillis, executive vice president and chief planning officer at U S West."The issue is: how will this era of video-on-demand and multimedia evolve? How do you get movies from a video storage and stream it through a network to a person's home to produce video-on-demand? There are no switches that can do that now, as we speak."
High-speed "switches" that can simultaneously route voice, video and computer data are only beginning to be used in corporate private networks and have never been built for this kind of job. Likewise, nobody has yet begun to sell the giant electronic jukeboxes -- computers known as servers -- to store thousands of movies in digital code and distribute them to thousands of customers on a moment's notice.
Some experts have also raised questions about the technology that Time Warner plans to use for two-way communications -- from making phone calls to ordering videos. Finally, the most devilish problems may be the human ones: designing consumer-friendly software that allows even technophobic viewers to navigate a maze of offerings without becoming intimidated or hostile.
Potentially, the networks will bring much more than just a smorgasbord of video services. Indeed, the most immediate beneficiaries may well be long-distance telephone companies, whose stocks jumped after the two companies announced their plans. Why? Because the cable networks will link long-distance companies to their large business customers, cutting back on the steep access charges imposed by local phone companies.
Ultimately, Time Warner and U S West hope to set the standard for a global network that can deliver any kind of information and entertainment. "What we're really doing is putting a tremendous amount of band width in people's homes with an almost infinite amount of switching in the network," said James Chiddix, senior vice president of engineering and technology at the Time Warner Cable unit. "Someday we hope to see this as part of a global network."
Time Warner's current systems transmit over coaxial cables. These cables have huge theoretical capacity, but the signals need to be amplified at frequent intervals and the practical capacity is limited over distances greater than a mile. To deal with that, Time Warner intends to install hair-thin optical fibers along the main arteries of its network and let the older cable carry signals from a neighborhood hub to homes.
Most cable companies are pursuing similar plans to give their networks huge untapped capacity. Time Warner and companies like Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's biggest cable company, are also planning to adopt digital compression technologies to pack as many as 10 channels into space now occupied by one.
 
Advanced Switches
 What sets the Time Warner design apart is the incorporation of an advanced telephone switching technology called asynchronous transfer mode, or A.T.M. In such switches, all information is transmitted in small electronic packets that contain the ones and zeroes of computer code. These packets are like little trains of data that chug through the network. The "engine" at the front end has five bytes of address information to tell the computer where the data should go. The "cars" that trail behind carry an additional 48 bytes of actual content -- the equivalent of half a dozen typewritten words.
While packet networks are not new, they have never been capable of blending streams of video and voice information with bursts of computer data. The reason is that the older packet networks simplify the job of routing packets by making them long. That is fine for computer files, but it is unworkable for voice and video signals that would sound garbled if key packets were delayed by being trapped behind a bulky computer file.
An A.T.M. network eliminates this problem because it keeps all packets to a uniformly short length that makes it possible to blend the streams without unacceptable delays. This requires extremely high-speed processing by the switch, which acts like a railroad switchman that identifies and routes millions of trains every second.
So far, A.T.M. switches have been installed only for specialized purposes -- like routing huge volumes of voice and computer data on private corporate networks. Using them to distribute voice and video over a public cable or telephone network requires that they be modified. That can be done, but the machines Time Warner starts with will be among the first off the assembly line. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has won a contract to supply the switch for the Orlando system.
The network's other major component is the "server," the computer that stores and dispenses the programs in digital form. Servers essentially perform as jukeboxes do, and are now routinely used as data bases for networks of personal computers. But no one has built machines to work on a scale to serve so much data to so many people at one time.
"Right now, servers are limited as to the total amount of data they can pass in and out at any given moment," said Neal Hill, a senior analyst at the Yankee Group, a market research firm in Boston. "They are fine for the ones and zeroes of computer files, but handling pictures and sound is much more difficult."
Companies like International Business Machines, A.T.& T., Silicon Graphics and Sun Microsystems are racing to meet that challenge. Indeed, A.T.& T. announced yesterday that it hopes to begin selling such a server by this fall, and it is expected to announce today that the cable company Viacom will use the machine in a market test. Time Warner has not selected a server vendor yet for its prototype system.
Mr. Chiddix of Time Warner said the technology already existed and just needed to be adapted. "We don't think we have to invent the wheel," he said. "There are arrays of hardware available that already store many trillions of bytes of information."
Time Warner has in the meantime outlined a plan for "reverse" traffic -- the signals from individual customers back to the main switch -- that is new for the cable industry.
Traditional cable television systems set aside a small band of relatively low frequencies so that the boxes on top of the set can signal the network for ordering pay-per-view programs and other limited forms of interactive television.
Time Warner and U S West will allocate a big chunk of fairly high frequencies for telephone calls, data communications and other uses. This provides room for fairly high-powered services, but it also poses challenges. Because the frequencies are quite high, the signal amplifiers are more delicate, and cable strung above ground on utility poles is vulnerable to disruption.
 
Some Key Questions
 "It's really on the bleeding edge of work," remarked Edward Surkowski, who heads interactive television research at the Bell Laboratories of A.T.& T. "I think it's manageable. The question is whether its deployable and economic."
The network, which may also be used for wireless phones, will ultimately need a huge amount of advanced software -- to retrieve data rapidly, to manage billing issues, to preserve security and privacy, and to make the system so easy to use that ordinary Americans will be willing to participate. The business is potentially huge, but the market is still ill defined.
Despite the uncertainties, Mr. Chiddix hopes to begin service in Orlando by early next year. Will most of the bugs be worked out? Stay tuned.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "To make a cable network perform like a telephone company doesn't require any new science," said Charles M. Lillis, executive vice president and chief planning officer at U S West. "The issue is: how will this era of video-on-demand and multimedia evolve?" (Steve Zavodny/Denver)
 
Diagram: "A Network of the Future"
 
The joint venture between Time Warner and US West to build advanced communications networks will use technology so new that many parts are not yet available. Her is how it maywork.
 
Video Service
 
The VIDEO SERVER is a large computer capable of storing thousands of movies. It is linked by a FIBER OPTIC CABLE to the SWITCH, the brains of the network. Fiber optic lines continue and stop at NEIGHBORHOOD NODES. The nodes transfer the fiber optic signals to the COAXIAL CABLE TV lines to each home.
 
Business Service
 
FIBER OPTIC CABLES from the SWITCH are connected directly to LARGE-BUSINESS customers. Heavy long-distance users, like banks or brokerage firms, save large sums of money by reaching their carrier without paying access charges to a local phone company.
 
Wireless Phone Service
 
The COAXIAL CABLE Lines threading through neighborhoods have RADIO RECEIVERS at regular intervals, which can be used to transmit signals from wireless telephones and portable computers.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
WINE and travel are inextricably entwined. Not a year goes by without the appearance of a dozen new books, nominally about wine but mostly about the countryside where the wine is made.
Take for example, two new books on New York State wines and wineries, published just in time for the summer traveling season: "The Wines and Wineries of the Hudson River Valley," by Alan R. Martell and Alton Long (Countryman Press, $14.95), and "The Wines of Long Island," by Philip Palmedo and Edward Beltrami (Waterline Books, $16.95). Both are wine books, but they are travel books as well. 
 Wine travel is a relatively new phenomenon. When Alexis Lichine published the first edition of "The Wines of France," in the 1950's, he provided relatively little information on visiting the vineyards about which he wrote. His last edition, the third, published in 1986, devotes almost as much space to restaurants and hotels as it does to wine.
Most Bordeaux wine makers were offended when Mr. Lichine erected roadside billboards in the 1960's inviting the public to his own chateau. Slowly and reluctantly, many of the Bordeaux wineries have changed, opening modest visiting centers. To their astonishment, many have discovered that tourists are a lucrative additional source of business.
Likewise, on Long Island and to a lesser extent in the Hudson Valley, winery-hopping has become an important new tourist attraction. For example, Pindar Vineyards, in Peconic, on Long Island's North Fork, not only produces 50,000 cases of wine a year, but also attracts some 500 people a day in summer to tour the winery and sample wines. Pindar is by far the largest winery on Long Island in terms of production; most are in the 7,000-to-10,000-case range.
The Long Island wineries have excelled at promoting themselves, individually and through the Long Island Wine Council. Popular parties at the Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue and at the Windows on the World restaurant in Manhattan have carried the Long Island message to the affluent New Yorkers who spend summers and weekends on Long Island's east end, where all but one of the wineries are situated.
In 1988, the Long Island wineries garnered national attention by inviting some of Bordeaux's most prominent chateau owners and wine makers to a symposium. Two years later, a second gathering, concentrating on the merlot grape, lured more wine-making stars, from both France and California. Both sessions resulted in national exposure that inevitably positioned Long Island wines among the world's best.
"The Wines of Long Island" lists the locations and visiting hours for 15 wineries. It notes special events, like wine seminars and dinners with wine makers; it names the owners and managers, the kinds of grapes they grow and the wines they make. There are trip suggestions and a map.
In fact, no wineries could be easier to find. Where the Long Island Expressway ends, it becomes Route 25. Nine of the wineries are along Route 25 between Riverhead and Peconic. Three others, Palmer, Hargrave and Bidwell, are on Sound Avenue, north of Route 25. Mattituck Hills is just off Sound Avenue, on Bergen Avenue in Mattituck. The Southampton Winery and the Bridgehampton Winery are on the South Fork. One winery, Banfi Vineyards in Nassau County, is not open to the public.
Wine was made on Long Island as early as the 17th century, but only recently on a commercial scale. The Hudson Valley is another story. Barbara Ensrud writes in the foreword to "The Wines and Wineries of the Hudson River Valley" that "New York boasts the country's oldest surviving wine industry and . . . the Hudson Valley served as cradle for its first commercial vineyards."
French Huguenots set vines near New Paltz in 1677. Successful hybrid vines, crosses between local and European varieties, were developed in the 19th century to counteract harsh Hudson Valley winters. A modern commercial winery was established at Washingtonville in 1839; as the Brotherhood Winery, it still exists. Benmarl, the region's best-known winery, was established on the site of vineyards planted in the 1870's.
Like the Long Island book, "The Wines and Wineries of the Hudson River Valley" provides pertinent information on visiting hours and special attractions, and a map of the region. Twenty wineries in the valley are open to visitors, Mr. Martell and Mr. Long write. Most of them -- 14 -- are west of the Hudson.
The closest one to New York City is the North Salem Vineyard in northern Westchester County. The most distant is the Meadery in Greenwich, N.Y., east of Saratoga Springs, too far north to make anything from grapes. As the name implies, the wine here is made from honey. There are also apple wines.
Among the special attractions: Benmarl, in Marlboro, runs a Societe des Vignerons, which is like a club for customers who help with the harvest and buy most of the wine. At Royal Kedem, in Milton, everything is kosher. Millbrook Vineyards, in Millbrook, experiments with some 20 grape varieties, while Clinton Vineyards in Clinton Corners uses only one: seyval blanc. Cascade Mountain Winery, in Amenia, operates an attractive restaurant.
The Hudson Valley is not Long Island -- culturally, geographically or economically. The wineries are widely separated and not always easy to find; except for rich communities like Millbrook and Amenia, the region has little of the perceived cachet of eastern Long Island.
But there are signs of change. More and more second-home owners are fleeing Long Island's nightmarish traffic jams, crowds and high prices for the breath-taking scenery and rural attractions of the Hudson Valley. It's only a matter of time before they discover the charms of the region's wines, and the wineries that make them.
 
TASTINGS
Hamilton-Russell Pinot Noir, South Africa, 1989; about $14.
 
Sanctions against South Africa were lifted a year ago in a burst of optimism over that country's political future. While the quest for equality may be a long one, South African wines, in the meantime, are being permitted into the United States, and this Burgundian-style pinot noir is one of the best. At Hermanus, overlooking Walker Bay (a great whale-watching spot), Tim Hamilton-Russell operates Africa's southernmost vineyard and winery. Chardonnay and pinot noir are the specialities. This one was made by Peter Findlayson, the original wine maker at Hamilton-Russell, who is now a competitor, with vineyards of his own right next door. This was a relatively closed wine, say people who knew it when it was young. It has come into its own as a delicious alternative to expensive Burgundy, with pronounced earthy flavors and Burgundy bouquet. Perhaps the long trip helped it along. No pinot noir enthusiast should miss a chance to try it.

HEADLINE: Too Many Musicians? An Overhaul at Juilliard -- A special report.;
A New Juilliard for a More Challenging Era

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
The sun was beating strongly on the plaza in front of the Juilliard School on a recent weekday, but the real heat was coming from another source. Before an audience of students sprawled on the white stone or crowded around a buffet table set up for the school's year-end picnic, Eugene Park was going through an ear-splitting, high-voltage rendition of a Hungarian czardas by Vittorio Monti.
This was a crowd that knew its Monti and liked what it was hearing. Mr. Park, a first-year student whose face was obscured by long hair, rocked back and forth on his heels in the slower sections, building anticipation, then let it rip in the fast passages, bow hairs snapping as he punished the strings of his electric violin. It was Paganini with a few dashes of Pete Townshend thrown in for extra attitude. The students clapped and whistled, grateful perhaps for diversion from the week's main focus: solo performances before a faculty jury to determine their final grades.
 
The Advent of Change
 It was a scene at odds with the traditional picture of Juilliard, the most prestigious conservatory in the United States, and perhaps in the world, one whose graduates account for about 20 percent of the musicians in the Big Five American orchestras (and half of those in the New York Philharmonic). 
 Juilliard is an institution where in past decades students arrived, took their lessons and left. Four years of this, and they settled in with a top orchestra or jetted around the world pursuing a solo career. The school could be tough and grim, elitist and insular, but most of its students toiled away in full confidence that the jobs were out there.
Not any more.
"I hope that I can make a living doing what I love," said Angella Ahn, a Korean-born violinist finishing her fourth year, and part of the wave of foreign students who now make up more than a third of the student body. "But there are so many of us. I don't know if there is room."
 
Recasting an Image>
 For most of its history the Juilliard School has not had to think about such matters. But a crisis in government and corporate support for the arts, the near-collapse of musical education in the primary and secondary schools and a shrinking marketplace for classical musicians have changed all that. Under Joseph W. Polisi, the school's president for the last nine years, Juilliard is becoming a very different place.
As a practical measure, Mr. Polisi has introduced a policy of admitting fewer students, particularly in the piano and violin departments, and raising admission standards. He said in a recent interview: "We have to be sure that every student admitted has the potential for some kind of life in the arts."
He has hired new faculty and reconfigured the course work so that students will be exposed to more teachers and performance situations and leave with a broader range of skills than those acquired by the narrow specialists of a generation ago.
More subtly, Mr. Polisi has tried to expand the school's mission and the students' sense of their social role as artists.
 
A Need for Broader Skills
 "The field we are sending young people into today is different than at any time this century," said Mr. Polisi. "You cannot go out there with the idea that 'I've mastered the solo repertory, so I'm ready.' You have to be able to perform chamber as well as solo, you have to be articulate about your art verbally, you have to become involved in the relation between the urban center and the arts."
The retooling of Juilliard has gone forward over much initial skepticism by faculty members used to operating as autonomous units and some puzzlement among music educators who see nothing wrong with the old Juilliard.
"It's going to be a long time before we don't need what Juilliard has always done: Take the best applicants, put them in the practice rooms and make them good at Brahms," said Larry J. Livingston, dean of the music school at the University of Southern California.
The pressure to find creative ways of making a living has two principal causes, both of which that trouble Mr. Polisi and are driving a number of his initiatives: the declining audience for classical music and a shrinking of the American talent pool. These are the results, in large part, of the drastic deterioration of the public-school music programs in the United States.
"We now have a whole generation that hasn't had music classes in school," said Joel Sachs, who teaches music history at Juilliard and organizes the annual Focus festival of contemporary music.
Mr. Polisi said: "America really is the center for advanced musical study in the world, so it's ironic that primary and secondary schooling here is as weak as it is. Thirty years ago the music system in New York City was a vibrant and highly disciplined program. That system is now essentially gone, and it hasn't been replaced by anything else. Where are the future audiences going to come from? Are they going to have an epiphany at age 47 that they need a subscription to the Philharmonic?"
 
Reaching Out to the Community
 In response, the once-aloof Juilliard is trying to make its case to the wider world. The most ambitious move toward community outreach is the Music Advancement Program, in which teachers from Juilliard canvass the neighborhoods of the city, auditioning young musicians. The most promising are admitted to a two-year program of Saturday instruction that includes studio lessons and ensemble training.
This year the school auditioned 350 students and accepted 35, and the hope is that some will enter Juilliard's pre-college division.
In a second outreach effort, the Performing Arts Programs for Schools, Juilliard sends students and recent alumni into the area's elementary and secondary schools to perform and discuss classical music and jazz.
 
The Symptoms
Foreign Students Rise in Number
Another index of the decline in American musical education is the rising foreign enrollment at Juilliard. The school has always served an international student body. As long ago as 1964, the president of the school remarked proudly in an address to the trustees that the school had the highest percentage of foreign students of any institution of higher learning in the United States. The figure then was 19 percent. Today it is 35 percent, and 75 percent in the piano department.
Foreign enrollment can be read as a barometer of political and economic events abroad. In the early 1950's, Juilliard received a wave of musicians from the newly created state of Israel. In the mid-60's, Japan overtook Israel, only to be overtaken in recent years by Korea. The collapse of the Soviet Union and ensuing turmoil in its conservatories have resulted in a surge from Russia and other former Soviet republics in the last three years.
The rise of Korea has been particularly rapid, symbolized at Juilliard by Ms. Ahn and her two sisters, who have played together as a piano trio since early childhood. All three applied to the school and were accepted. Faculty members invariably comment on the discipline of their Asian students, the high regard for Western classical music instilled in them as they grow up, and their parents' close involvement in their musical education.
"I like to say that the Koreans think they're Jewish," said Herbert Stessin, the chairman of the piano department. "You see the same ethos, the same focus and concentration, and the mothers are the same pests."
 
The Effect
Dwindling Jobs For Graduates
The influx of foreign students, many of whom pursue careers in the United States, coincides with bankruptcies among American orchestras, curtailed orchestral seasons and a cutback in faculty hiring. In short, sharply increased competition for fewer traditional music jobs.
"When I got out of school, in 1973, you could count on a full-time career in an orchestra," said Raymond Mase, chairman of the brass department. "Orchestras were more successful then; they didn't have to be creative. Now, even in the New York Philharmonic, you need to be trained in brass quintet."
Many orchestras now run a pops season along with their traditional classical-music season, presenting players with a new repertory to learn. "The trumpet is very prominent in film scores, which pop seasons use," said Mr. Mase. "On the chamber side, brass players have to go into the schools and on the road."
 
New Areas of Study
 In his effort to present what he calls "alternative life styles" to his students, Mr. Mase has brought in early-brass specialists for demonstrations and lectures and, in one case, a performer who specializes in an instrument of his own devising, the "mutan-trumpet."
"We want students to see that there are lots of different ways for a musician to make a living and be musically happy," said Mr. Mase.
Now, skills and courses that used to exist on the periphery have moved toward the center. The American Brass Quintet, in which Mr. Mase plays trumpet, was brought into the school as a resident company. The Juilliard String Quartet now spends less time on the road and more time at the school, working with students.
In a direct response to the changing marketplace, Juilliard recently established the country's first doctoral program in accompanying, and it offers a seminar on the business of music.
At the same time, Juilliard has worked to push students outside the school and expose them to musicians who have carved out other than solo or orchestral careers.
"I'd love to play in a symphony orchestra," said Mark Inouye, a third-year trumpet student. "But I'd also love to be a jazz player, and even studio work would be good."
 
The Response
Remaking Juilliard And Its Program
The mere existence of a brass department is symbolic of recent changes at the school. For most of its history, Juilliard had only one department: piano. Last year, the rest of the faculty was organized into departments as the most recent move in a sweeping restructuring of the administration, the curriculum and the physical and social environment at the school.
When Mr. Polisi arrived at Juilliard in 1984, both faculty and administration agreed that Juilliard was too large. The piano department, the school's largest, was cut from 200 to 155 students. The current plan is to reduce the school's total number of students to about 715 from the current 815 in the next three years, with most of the reductions coming in the piano and violin departments.
At the same time, faculty salaries, which had always been low, were raised by 20 to 25 percent and have been adjusted subsequently to keep them in line with university salaries elsewhere in New York.
Mr. Polisi, a bassoonist who came to Juilliard after serving in administrative posts at the University of Cincinnati's School of Music, the Manhattan School of Music and the Yale School of Music, and whose father taught bassoon at Juilliard for many years, judged the school wanting as a congenial place for students.
 
Fostering a Sense of Community
 The physical and emotional environment could be daunting. Designed for 650 students, the school was accommodating more than 900 in 1984, creating a scarcity of practice rooms and a surplus of career anxiety for the hordes of pianists and violinists gearing up to compete for disappearing jobs.
The place didn't feel like a school. It was a building where students came, took lessons and left. Because there was no student housing, there was little sense of a Juilliard community. Even the building plan was hostile. The uninviting main entrance, on 66th Street near loading docks and the back door to Alice Tully Hall, deprived students of the time-honored pleasure of simply hanging out and socializing.
Mr. Polisi moved quickly on the quality-of-life issues, establishing a student affairs office in 1985 to offer the kinds of services taken for granted at most colleges: housing-referral information, psychological counseling, student advisers for incoming freshmen.
 
Dormitory Opens Doors
 For the first time, Juilliard got a student newspaper and a student council. And in 1990 it opened its first dormitory, part of a $100 million building project at Lincoln Center, relieving many students, some of them new to the United States, of the enormous burden of finding their own apartments in New York.
The project had the side benefit of moving the school's entrance from 66th Street to a pleasant pedestrian walkway on the opposite side of the building, now a gathering point for students, especially the 40 percent of them who live in the residence center.
An unanticipated improvement is that dormitory living has, at a stroke, broken down the rigid barriers that formerly separated students in different disciplines.
Gary Graffman, the director of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, said of his counterpart at Juilliard: "I find Joe extremely understanding and caring of the students, which is not always the case with the heads of music schools and departments."
 
Team Teaching Introduced
 Mr. Polisi also moved to modify the school's traditional tutorial system, under which students spent nearly all their time studying with a single teacher. The result was a closed world in which students were seldom if ever exposed to other teachers at the school and in which teachers operated as autonomous units, rarely coming into contact with their colleagues and paying scant attention to classroom instruction.
Greater emphasis was placed on team teaching, guest lectures and coordination of subject matter in complementary classes. Master classes, a rarity at the school, became routine, allowing small groups of students to work intensively with a visiting artist.
"There are some great musicians coming through here," said Alexis Gerlach, a cellist in the graduate school. "Rostropovich came to conduct the orchestra, and I got a lesson with him."
 
The Outlook
More Liberal Arts, More Diversity
The undergraduate academic program, previously a scattering of courses, was redesigned into a formal liberal arts department, based on instruction in the great books and the Socratic method.
For students who wanted more liberal arts study than Juilliard could offer, the school worked out an arrangement in 1989 that allows Juilliard students to take elective academic courses or to earn a Bachelor of Arts in any major from Columbia University or Barnard College while they earn a Master of Music degree from Juilliard.
Juilliard's graduate school, which accounts for 42 percent of enrollment, changed its admissions policy, requiring all entering students to audition rather than giving a virtual free pass to Juilliard undergraduates.
The result has been an influx of students from other conservatories and liberal arts colleges. "This has opened things up, encouraged more of a mix," said Joel Sachs, "It's much more lively than it was."
 
New Approach Meets Resistance
 Selling the new program was not easy. Mr. Polisi admits that the initial reaction of the faculty was one of suspicion. James S. Allen, Juilliard's provost and dean, said: "There was some resistance on the part of the faculty, who said you'd be diminishing the most important thing, developing talent. Our contention was, trust us, you'll see, the opposite will happen. The students will be no less dedicated and have more resources. Those complaints have gone away."
In some respects, the furious pace of change seems curious. Standards at Juilliard are as high, or higher, than they have ever been. Its prestige remains untarnished, reflected in the fact that more than 90 percent of the students who are accepted at the school choose to go there. (Tuition, room and board cost about $20,000 a year.)
Financially, the institution rests on a solid foundation. Its endowment has nearly tripled in the last eight years, from $96 million in 1984 to $250 million.
"It's not that it's broken," said Mr. Allen. "We could go on as we did in the past, but the conservatory is a 19th-century invention, and the lives of people are not the same anymore. The pristine ivory tower where students came to refine their gifts and go off to become a star -- that's over."

HEADLINE: Congress's Twists and Turns Reshape Bill on Energy Tax

SERIES: The Fine Print -- A periodic look behind the law.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Five months ago, seeking to raise billions for President Clinton's economic programs and at the same time promote conservation, the White House proposed a broad tax on most forms of energy.
Then armies of lobbyists beseeched the White House to make the tax fairer, squadrons of Congressmen amended it to make it less onerous, and Mr. Clinton horse-traded some clauses to gain support for his budget. 
 What resulted, some experts say, is one of the most exemption-loaded, head-scratchingly complicated, brow-furrowing revenue raisers in history. Never very simple, the proposed energy tax is now so convoluted that one fuel, diesel, would be taxed at at least five separate rates and dyed in enough distinguishing colors to make Crayola green with envy.
 
The Electron's Distinction
 In the House version of the bill, oil is taxed more than gas. Gas is taxed more than solar energy, which is not taxed at all. Electricity is taxed, but at a floating rate derived from the taxes on all the coal, oil, gas and other energy sources used to generate the previous month's power.
The tax would promote conservation, but the House version gives a sizable tax break to one of the most power-hungry industries, aluminum smelting, though not by name. It is the first tax proposal to grant exemptions not just to certain molecules, but to one subatomic particle, the electron.
Mr. Clinton's energy tax still faces a tough bout in the Senate, and the President seems resigned to more amending and scaling back. Today, in Milwaukee, he insisted that he will fight for the tax in the Finance Committee, but he conspicuously omitted it from a list of five non-negotiable items in his budget.
Already, some accountants and economists are calling the House version of the tax an administrative nightmare.
"A simple value-added tax without a hell of a lot of exemptions will require 2 to 4 percent of its revenues for administrative costs," said Philip Verlager, an economist who was a special assistant on domestic energy matters in Jimmy Carter's Treasury Department. "I think this one's going to require something on the order of 10 to 20 percent because it's gotten so complex. In some sense, it's a full-employment program for bureaucrats."
Mr. Clinton's specialists agree that the energy tax isn't as simple as it was before the political system massaged it, but they contend that most fears are based on misinformation.
 
'Certain Amount of Confusion'
 "This tax has evolved since it was first proposed," said Leslie Samuels, the Treasury Department's assistant secretary for tax policy. "So there is a certain amount of confusion. As people understand it more, they'll be more accepting of it."
How complex is it?
Consider this regimen prescribed under the proposal for taxing diesel fuel:
First, determine which taxes apply to diesel. Diesel is already subject to a Federal excise tax; the new energy tax overlaps that tax sometimes, and sometimes does not. For example, diesel fuel for autos is subject to both the excise and energy taxes; diesel for farm tractors and home heating is subject to neither. But the tax for diesel-burning boats varies with the boat: pleasure craft pay both levies; commercial boats and business yachts pay only the energy tax. Buses and trains, with different excise taxes, pay entirely different rates.
Next, correlate the tax rate with the new fuel color. Diesel would be sold in hues intended to signify both its tax status and pollutant content. For example, diesel carrying neither excise nor energy taxes would be the same color as high-sulphur diesel (which must be indelibly dyed as part of the 1992 Clean Air Act), even if the tax-exempt fuel doesn't contain a lot of sulphur. High-sulphur fuel exempted from the excise tax -- but not the energy tax -- will be the same color, with an added chemical marker to identify its tax status. Low-sulphur diesel subject only to the energy tax will be dyed another color. Fuel subject to both taxes will apparently be left undyed, regardless of how much sulphur it contains.
Actually, the energy tax on diesel is comparatively simple. Although it would require inspectors to police the use of dyes, and new storage tanks and trucks to segregate green fuel from red from purple, paperwork would be minimal because the same wholesalers who already pay the excise tax would pay the energy tax.
 
Now, the Really Hard Part
 Where the tax turns to kudzu, experts say, is in its calculation of rates. There, they say, the details of a seemingly fair and environmentally progressive tax are now devilish.
The legislation would raise $72 billion from energy taxes through 1998, or almost a third of the $250 billion or so in new taxes Mr. Clinton is seeking. The yardstick for taxation is the British Thermal Unit, or B.T.U., the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of a pound of water by one degree Fahrenheit. A gallon of gasoline contains about 125,000 B.T.U.'s; a McDonald's quarter pounder with cheese, at 510 calories, would equal about two B.T.U.'s.
The bill would tax most fuels at the rate of 26.8 cents per million B.T.U.'s, with a 34.2-cent surtax added to most oil, gasoline and diesel. Most "green" energy, like electricity-making windmills and solar power, would be exempt. Hydroelectric and nuclear power would be taxed at 26.8 cents.
But totting up one's daily purchase or sale of B.T.U.'s would prove no easy matter, especially in the heavily adjusted House version of the bill.
A prime example, tax experts say, is the electricity tax, which would be collected by electric utilities from their customers. But rather than levy a flat rate per kilowatt hour, utilities would have to calculate the heat content of every fuel they used to generate electric current.
Moreover, some electricity users would be exempted, meaning they would be entitled to rebates. Chief among them is the aluminum industry, which devours power in its mills and worries that the tax would drive the price of the metal beyond reason.
To assuage those fears, the House amended the tax to help those exceedingly select industries in which "electrolytic processes utilize electricity to provide a flow of electrons which bond with other ions in production.
"The exemption is limited to electricity which acts as an electron donor," the House says.
 
Imports and Exports
 The clauses that are potentially the most complex would exempt exports from the tax, and instead tax "energy intensive" imports, including goods whose "energy inputs" constitute more than 2 percent of their value.
The idea is to prevent the energy tax from hobbling the competitiveness of homemade products, but some experts are skeptical. They predict that importers would take advantage of a clause allowing them to contest the Government's determinations of what is energy-intensive, and litigate with abandon.
Not to worry, says the Treasury's Mr. Samuels. "Obviously, any tax has new issues with it, and with respect to the administration of this particular tax, people feel comfortable that the administrative concerns have been met and should not be burdensome," he said.
Ada Rousso, now a senior manager at the Price-Waterhouse accounting firm, used to write tax regulations and tax legislation at the Internal Revenue Service. She says Mr. Samuels has a point, and gives the Administration and Congress high marks for trying to simplify current tax law at some points in the bill.
But asked to cite a tax that is more labyrinthine, she replied: "You know, offhand, I can't. I'm sure there are many others, but I can't come up with one."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 7, 1993, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Wednesday with an article about proposed energy taxes described two elements of the plan incorrectly. As passed by the House, the plan would tax liquefied petroleum gas at 26.8 cents per million British Thermal Units, not 61.0 cents, and would impose a natural gas tax on consumers, not utilities.
The related article referred to an economist incorrectly. He is Philip Verleger.
