HEADLINE: AIDES SAY CLINTON WILL DROP NOMINEE FOR POST ON RIGHTS

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to withdraw the nomination of Lani Guinier to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, White House officials said today, an acknowledgement that her chances of winning confirmation have evaporated under an assault by critics of her proposals to bolster the political power of minorities.
The decision came at the end of a day in which Mr. Clinton publicly said he disagreed with some of her writings and offered only lukewarm support. 
 White House officials said President Clinton decided this evening that he could no longer win a fight to confirm Ms. Guinier in the face of growing Senate opposition to her nomination. The officials said that only the timing and manner of Ms. Guinier's withdrawal remained to be worked out.
 
Nominee Won't Withdraw
 But at the end of the day on "Nightline," the ABC television program, Ms. Guinier gave no indication that she was about to withdraw. While acknowledging that "the nomination has proved to be a lot more complicated than anticipated," she said she expected to testify about her philosophy before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
"I am the nominee and am looking forward to an opportunty to present my views to the Senate," she said.
Ms. Guinier steadfastly refused to say whether anyone from the White House had told her the nomination was dead.
The abandonment of the nomination was one of several maneuvers today by the Clinton Administration to try to clear away obstacles interfering with the President's efforts to reclaim the political center and to steer his economic proposals through Congress.
Administration officials said they would probably delay unveiling their health-care reforms until July or August or possibly even September, effectively putting off until next year a project that Mr. Clinton had said must be completed this year. [Page A20.]
 
Move Toward Center
 Officials also said the Administration had delayed plans to push for a higher minimum wage because of worries about undermining job growth and antagonizing conservatives and the business community while the President's budget hung in the balance.
Asked this afternoon about the prospects for her confirmation, Mr. Clinton praised Ms. Guinier (pronounced gwa-NEAR) as a fine lawyer. But he said he would have to take into account the growing opposition in the Senate to her.
At a White House briefing today, George Stephanopoulos, the President's spokesman, repeatedly declined to go beyond vague statements of support for Ms. Guinier. He seemed uncomfortable, even pained, as he struggled to deal with the awkward situation of publicly propping up a nomination that was on the verge of collapse.
Ms. Guinier, who has generally declined to speak to reporters about the nomination, has embarked on a campaign to defend herself before senators and newspaper editorial boards. She paid courtesy calls on about 10 senators last week and was scheduled to make more such visits next week. She met with the editorial board of The New York Times today, and a Justice Department official said she had also met with the editorial board of The Washington Post.
On "Nightline," her first public appearance since her nomination, Ms. Guinier seemed to plead for the opportunity to explain her theories before the Senate, which could complicate matters for Mr. Clinton.
 
Opportunity to Respond
 "I would like to have a hearing before the Senate so that the distortions which have been picked up by the media and have been echoed in a game of telephone in which I haven't even had access to the initial speaker -- that I would have an opportunity to respond to those distortions and correct the record," she said. "My own mother does not recognize me in terms of the press and media I have been receiving."
An Administration official said after the broadcast that the television appearance would not change Ms. Guinier's situation. The official said the White House initially did not want Ms. Guinier to appear on the program but acceded to her wishes so that she would have the opportunity to defend herself to a national audience, not in any hopes of reviving her candidacy.
"She wanted to go on," the official said. "The general rule at the White House is that you don't go on television until you are confirmed."
On Tuesday, Administration officials said several top White House aides believed the Guinier nomination would have to be withdrawn, and a senior Democratic Senator said as many as two dozen Democrats in the Senate had told the White House the nomination should be withdrawn. The Senator, who declined to be identified, also said Ms. Guinier would not be able to win approval in the Judiciary Committee.
Asked today about Ms. Guinier, Mr. Clinton said: "I think that I have to talk to some of the senators about it because of the reservations that have been raised both publicly and privately.
"I want to reaffirm two positive things about her. One is everyone can see she is a first-rate civil rights lawyer, and no real civil rights lawyer has ever held that position before -- someone who's made a career of it.
"Secondly, I think any reasonable reading of her writings would lead someone to conclude that a lot of the attacks cannot be supported by a fair reading of the writings. And that's not to say that I agree with everything in the writings. I don't. But I think that a lot of what has been said is not accurate. On the other hand, I have to take into account where the Senate is and I will be doing that and talking to them. I think until I do that, I should have nothing else to say."
One other incident in Mr. Clinton's recent past suggests that when he offers seemingly half-hearted words of support for an embattled nominee, that person ought to not quit her current job too soon.
When public opinion began to turn sharply against the President's first choice to be Attorney General, Zoe Baird, amid a furor over her hiring of two illegal immigrants as household workers, Mr. Clinton and his spokesmen said they had no plans to withdraw their support, an expression similar to one offered by official White House spokesmen today. Soon afterward, the Baird nomination was withdrawn.
 
Majority Rule Faulted
 Ms. Guinier, a 43-year-old law professor at the University of Pennsylvania who is a friend of both the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton, has been criticized for writings in which she argues that majority rule is often insufficient to guarantee blacks their fair share in the political process.
In articles in the University of Michigan and University of Virginia law reviews, Ms. Guinier has written that even if blacks are elected, they will always be in the minority and may be outvoted and ignored as important decisions are made. For such cases, she has proposed several alternative voting schemes to enlarge the influence of black lawmakers.
Her supporters say that her views have been distorted and that her proposed solutions would apply only in isolated cases of extremely resistant racism.
Civil rights groups rallied to Ms. Guinier's defense and asked Mr. Clinton to do the same. "We're urging him to stand tall on an excellent nomination," Jesse Jackson said at a news conference.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1563 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Untested Role for Moynihan in Budget Fight

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has played many roles in many areas of public life, ranging happily from foreign to domestic policy, from ethnic conflict on the international scene to the problems of children and poverty at home.
But the New York Democrat is still a novice as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, a job he began six months ago, and he faces the challenge of a chairman's lifetime. President Clinton's economic plan has lurched through the House -- just barely -- and landed with a somewhat ominous thud in Mr. Moynihan's lap. 
 The nine Republicans on the Finance Committee are considered certain to vote no, so Mr. Moynihan must hold all 10 of his fellow Democrats if he is to prevail. And one of them, Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, has given new definition to the word "renegade," although he seemed to be inching back to the fold this week.
 
Zen-Like Simplicity
 After 16 years in the Senate, Mr. Moynihan is known as a scholar, a challenger of conventional wisdom and a wit. But he is not known as an arm-twister or a Presidential enforcer. The question of toughness inevitably arises. "We'll see, won't we?" he replied coolly last weekend.
The discursive Mr. Moynihan, whose conversation often rambles into obscure pockets of history and general lore, describes his present task with Zen-like simplicity. "We have to find 11 votes on the Finance Committee, at a minimum 51 votes on the floor," he said in an interview on Saturday. "We have to pass the bill, and we will."
Yes, there will be changes, he said: more spending cuts and revisions in the proposed energy tax that has caused such anxiety in oil-producing states. Yes, he said, he is meeting with the President, and working toward a compromise with his colleagues, notably Mr. Boren.
"In the end he said he would be with us," Mr. Moynihan said of Mr. Boren. "And he will. This is the first Democratic President we've had in 12 years. We asked to be given a chance to show we can govern. There are some arguments that come down to, 'You have to.' "
Mr. Moynihan's allies note that this is not the first time he has faced the task of moving a huge bill, laden with provisions that rouse the protective instincts of every senator who breathes. He was a prime mover behind the huge transportation law of 1991 and, says Senator Tom Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, "I think he surprised a lot of people with his ability to bring about a consensus."
Still, consensus is not a word that comes to mind in the Finance Committee these days. The Republicans, who often work with the Democrats on this panel, backed out early, in keeping with the solid wall of Republican opposition in the House.
"I asked Bob Packwood about five weeks ago, 'Are you guys going to be part of this budget process?' " Mr. Moynihan said, referring to the ranking Republican on the committee. "And he said, 'No, can't be with you on this one.' "
 
Just Basic Politics
 "We had the same thing when we had to increase the debt ceiling," he continued. "We did it on an 11-to-9 vote, and the Republicans made speeches suggesting the tyranny of the majority, but there was no heat in it."
It was basic politics, Mr. Moynihan suggested, "all very friendly, perfectly straightforward." He added, "What upsets me is when people say one thing and do another."
What was not basic politics, however, was the conduct of Mr. Boren, a damaging voice of Democratic opposition in recent weeks, taking his case against the energy tax to the talk shows, holding forth on his demand for greater spending cuts. Senators often break ranks with their party, but rarely so visibly, and rarely when the stakes are so achingly high.
Mr. Moynihan, in keeping with his role as broker, maintained that Mr. Boren was only temporarily a prodigal son. Mr. Moynihan offered Mr. Boren a way back into the family on Saturday, when Mr. Moynihan signaled that he and the Administration were ready to scale back the size of the energy tax. The next day, on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Boren was a model of conciliation. The process, as they say on Capitol Hill, was moving forward -- at least for the moment.
"I think what Senator Boren needed to see was that the chairman and the President were ready to move in his direction on some of these things," said Lawrence O'Donnell, chief of staff of the Finance Committee. "It was very important and perfectly timed to continue the momentum coming out of the House."
Mr. O'Donnell added: "The remaining hurdles are the details, on both the tax side and the spending cuts side. But the spirit seems to be coming back."
As the Boren episode suggests, the job of finance chairman requires more than just muscle. The chairman is part family therapist, part tax attorney, piecing together bills that satisfy enough egos, enough parochial interests, enough philosophical beliefs to pass. Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, a former chairman, once described the job's basic quandary succinctly: "Don't tax you. Don't tax me. Tax that fellow behind the tree."
 
Breadwinner for Constituents
 Not to put too fine a point on it, but the finance chairmanship entails another equally important role: breadwinner for the voters back home. Influencing how the Government raises trillions of dollars -- and from whom -- is one of Congress's most precious powers.
Past chairmen, like Mr. Long and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, have not been shy about using it to advance pet state interests from oil to real estate. In time, New York's sprawling constituencies are likely to look to Mr. Moynihan for no less.
"One of the things that it means to be chairman is that the White House always has to stop and think before proposing anything: Is this bad for New York?" Mr. O'Donnell said. "There is nothing on the top priority list of this President that does not go through the Finance Committee."
But while Mr. Moynihan has brought home his share of the bacon, he is curiously constrained, for now, from being publicly political about his new role. As the steward of Mr. Clinton's budget package, his first job is to win the votes of fellow Finance Committee members, a nonpartisan duty that entails handing out tax breaks more than acquiring them. "With a Democratic President," Mr. O'Donnell said, "the burden of the chairmanship is that you have to do so much of the President's bidding."
 
He's No Lloyd Bentsen
 Democrats on the Finance Committee said Mr. Moynihan brings a much different style to the job than did Mr. Bentsen, who was chairman of the committee for six years before becoming Treasury Secretary in Mr. Clinton's Cabinet.
"Bentsen was more of a chairman of the board," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. "Pat is a freewheeling-type spirit who has a tremendous mind."
Mr. Daschle noted that the two chairmen's interests also differed substantially: Mr. Bentsen's focus had been on taxes; Mr. Moynihan's was on social policy.
Mr. Moynihan also confronts a strikingly different political scene: a Democratic Presidency that could well rise or fall on the success of its economic proposals, most of which must make their way through his committee. "The expectations for him are tremendous -- deliver, just deliver," said a Democratic Senator who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
An Administration official said, "There's a general feeling that this will be a real tough test for him, as tough as any freshman chairman ever faced."
Mr. Moynihan's relations with the Administration showed signs of strain earlier this year, when a quotation attributed to an anonymous Administration official in Time magazine suggested that the White House intended to "roll right over" Mr. Moynihan if necessary. The President scolded members of his staff afterward, telling them that Mr. Moynihan had been a good friend in the 1992 campaign, particularly during the New York primary, when Mr. Clinton took on former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and his proposal for a "flat tax."
"Clinton said that when we were fighting for our lives in New York, this guy really came through for us," a White House official said.
 
He's Still Unpredictable
 But Mr. Moynihan retains his unpredictable streak; he has not suddenly become a disciplined partisan messagemeister like the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. For example, the Senator delivered a stinging denunciation of the Administration's policy in Bosnia on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" earlier this month.
And in an interview over the weekend, he chatted happily for a while about the history and the language of taxation, even amid hard revenue estimates and the nuances of the energy tax. He bemoaned, for example, the "impenetrable language of the budget clerisy." (According to Webster's, the well-educated or learned class.)
He noted that there was a strong possibility of surprises in the House bill, adding, "Once we enacted the phone number of one of the staffers: 'Beverly, call Evelyn.' "
And he noted that the Federal Government's experience with raising taxes is comparatively short. "We used to have tariffs," he said. "About half the revenue of the Federal Government came from tariffs collected in the Port of New York."
Musing about the struggle ahead, he said: "Nobody's very good at this. But we'll pull through."

The Economy
Plans to push for a higher minimum wage have been delayed by the Clinton Administration because of worries about undermining job growth and antagonizing conservatives and business executives while the President's budget hangs in the balance. [Page A1.]
The index of leading indicators edged up a puny tenth of a percent in April, and new-home sales surged. But analysts said the reports pointed to a continuation of a sluggish recovery. [D1.] 
 President Clinton has again delayed his health-care proposal, allowing Hillary Rodham Clinton's task force to expire. [A20.]
Broadway is still perilous for investors despite a successful season for ticket sales and signs of a busy fall ahead. [A1.]
Competitive bids will be required for all underwriting contracts by New York City under legislation to be proposed. [B3.]

A Nintendo publicity stunt that went awry got things off to a ragged start at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Cold-war Trade Weapon Isn't Used on China and May Never Be.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TRAPPED between his own campaign rhetoric and the advice of both the business and foreign policy establishments, President Clinton punted. China, he announced last week, would have one more year of open trade with America. Thereafter, renewal of China's "most favored nation" trade status would depend on the Old Guard's willingness to slip gently into the democratic night.
Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who has led the Congressional push to punish China for Tiananmen and Tibet, pronounced herself satisfied with "President Clinton's commitment to human rights and democratic freedoms." But it is still difficult to imagine how the President will be able to wield the trade weapon with much effect when the deadline passes. For as the tough old Communists who still rule the roost in China apparently understand, closing down trade would undermine a variety of American interests. 
 "Clinton has bought time," concludes Pei Minxin, a professor of politics at Princeton University. "But he has not dug his way out of his China problem." Indeed, the M.F.N. option may prove a liability in dealing with the world's newest candidate for economic superpower status.
Virtually all countries automatically benefit from the lowest tariff rates negotiated by America. But under 1974 legislation, "nonmarket" economies are eligible for so-called most favored nation status only if the President annually certifies that open trade will advance the cause of human rights. Congress has 90 days to disapprove of the President's decision. The White House, in turn, has the authority to veto the disapproval, subject to a two-thirds override by both House and Senate.
One limitation on the weapon is that it was designed for the cold war rather than for an era in which even the bad guys pay lip service to free markets: Nobody is about to use the Jackson-Vanik proviso to revoke the M.F.N. status of the tyrants who rule the Syrians, Zairians or Burmese. A less obvious limitation is that trade is, in practice, a problematic instrument for advancing human rights.
On first look, revocation of M.F.N. seems a punch that China would dare not absorb. China runs a $20 billion-plus trade surplus with America, exporting roughly three times as much as it imports. That surplus is what makes it possible for the world's fastest-growing economy to finance its development without foreign borrowing.
Were M.F.N. revoked, tariffs on China's leading exports to the United States -- everything from shoes to clothing to consumer electronics -- would rise from the 4 to 12 percent currently to as high as 70 percent. Sales to America would collapse since Wal-Mart and Sears could obtain similar sweaters, jogging gear and boom boxes more cheaply from Malaysia, Thailand or Mexico.
But that is far from the whole story. While China is a net exporter to America, it still imports billions of dollars of American goods that would be vulnerable to retaliation. It is already a major customer of American aircraft, computer and construction equipment makers. And because it is growing so rapidly, China could soon rival the big European economies both as a market for manufactured exports and as a location for foreign factories to serve domestic demand.
Boeing, Caterpillar, Motorola and company know Japanese, European and South Korean rivals are waiting for openings -- a fact that helps explain why 298 large American corporations and 37 trade associations signed a letter last month urging President Clinton to stay the course.
As important, argues Richard Fisher, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, the economic fate of Taiwan and Hong Kong is rapidly becoming hostage to China's trade fortunes.
Taiwan's and Hong Kong's export surpluses with America have been falling at roughly the same pace that China's surplus has been growing -- and by no coincidence. High wages in these two hugely successful economies are driving entrepreneurs to shift labor-intensive production to the mainland, creating an integrated Chinese economy that Paul Armington and Uri Dadush of the World Bank have dubbed the world's "fourth economic pole." Cutting off American trade with the mainland would smash Taiwan's and Hong Kong's multibillion-dollar earnings from a variety of auxiliary services such as banking and shipping, not to mention their returns from mainland investments.
A more perplexing issue facing Bill Clinton is how to use the threat of trade barriers to do greater harm to democracy's enemies on the mainland than to its allies. The success of export-oriented free enterprise in southern coastal China has weakened Beijing's political grip there and, by example, has discredited Communism in the bitterly poor interior. "Free trade makes sense even on human rights grounds," Mr. Fisher concludes.
A year is a long time on the roller coaster of international power politics. If Mr. Clinton is lucky, political liberalization will proceed from domestic pressures and thereby free him from a face-off with China's masters. If he is not, the President may be stuck with a weapon that looks more like a doomsday machine than a smart bomb.

HEADLINE: President Again Postpones Unveiling of a Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Preoccupied with efforts to win approval for his economic program, President Clinton has again postponed his proposal to remake the nation's medical system and has allowed his wife's task force on health care to expire.
As a result of the new delays by the Administration, Congress is highly unlikely to pass comprehensive health-care legislation this year. In a speech on Feb. 17, Mr. Clinton said Congress must pass such legislation "this year -- not next year, not five years from now, but this year." 
 The Task Force on National Health Care Reform, headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, went out of existence on Sunday. The 12-member panel, created with fanfare four months ago, analyzed hundreds of options, but never finished the work for which it was created by Mr. Clinton: to prepare comprehensive health-care legislation for submission to Congress.
White House officials said today that the task force had expired without deciding how to carry out Mr. Clinton's campaign pledges to control health costs and to guarantee health insurance coverage for all Americans.
Describing the likelihood of further delays, White House officials said today that Mr. Clinton would probably not unveil his health-care proposal till July or August or possibly even September. In early July, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to go to Japan for an economic conference with leaders of other industrial countries.
 
'Focusing on Passing Budget'
 "There's been no decision for a sustained delay here," Mr. Clinton said today. "But I'm focusing right now on passing the budget when the Senate comes back next week."
Work on the President's health-care plan seems to have lost some momentum as Mr. Clinton and top White House officials try to persuade senators to raise taxes and cut the growth of popular Government spending programs.
Mr. Clinton has postponed meetings where he was to have discussed the health-care plan with his advisers on economic and health policy. White House officials said Mr. Clinton was still weighing these questions, among others: What new taxes should the Government impose on employers to pay for health care? Should the Government regulate doctors' fees, hospital charges and drug prices? Which companies will have to buy coverage for their employees through health insurance purchasing pools?
The charter establishing the task force said it "will terminate on May 30" unless the President renews its charter. Mr. Clinton took no action to extend its life.
But doctors are still demanding access to work papers and records of the task force, and the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is expected to rule soon on their lawsuit.
Haley Barbour, the new chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that the delays in Mr. Clinton's health plan reflected Democratic concern about public disenchantment with certain features of the plan: higher payroll and tobacco taxes and "the potential for a hugely increased Government role in medicine."
But Mr. Barbour said "you will see overwhelming Republican support for some insurance reform," to guarantee that small businesses and people with high medical risks can buy coverage at affordable prices.
The Administration's deadline for submitting health-care legislation to Congress has repeatedly slipped since March. In early April, Administration officials said that President Clinton probably could not meet the deadline of May 3 that he had set for unveiling his health-care plan. Some officials were quoted then as saying they hoped to complete work by late May or early June, while others said July or August was a more realistic goal.
Commenting on that report, Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the task force, said then: "We are very much on schedule. This process is on track, on time, and it is working. We will produce a health-care reform package in May of this year."
The Administration's goal for finishing the health plan slipped to May 17 and then to mid-June, and now officials refuse to specify a date for submitting legislation to Congress.
 
Staff Changes Cited as Cause
 Aides to Mr. Clinton said today that changes on the White House staff and the search for a Supreme Court nominee had slowed efforts to design the health plan. The hiring of David R. Gergen as counselor to the President may contribute to further delays.
In U.S. News & World Report, where he was editor at large, Mr. Gergen wrote last month: "Clinton needs to refocus attention on his economic plan, especially on the creation of jobs, and postpone his health-care proposals until fall. Otherwise, he risks loss of both."
Mr. Clinton created the task force on Jan. 25. Its staff eventually numbered more than 500.
Explaining the latest delays, Mr. Clinton said today: "We're trying to, first of all, get as many of the kinks worked out as we can before we go forward. It's an enormously complicated issue. And then we want to make sure that we have, you know, discussed it with as many people as possible, as many groups and everything, after we've reached some final conclusions, and that when we present it to the Congress, it's presented at a time and in a way that both the Congress and the American people can focus on it."

HEADLINE: Advocating Vigorous Action on Clean Water

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Water has seldom been an issue in New York City in this century, but as the city squares off with Washington over whether a multibillion-dollar filtration plant is needed, environmentalists are working to make clean water as politically urgent as crime or taxes.
The Federal Environmental Protection Agency wants New York City to filter its water, as all other major American cities do, but the plant would cost up to $8 billion to build and $300 million a year to operate, forcing sharp increases in water rates. The city has won a reprieve with a promise to protect its 2,000-square-mile watershed upstate, by committing $47 million this year for buying property, among other actions.
 
Forestalling Filtration
 But the environmentalists want the city to take more vigorous action to forestall filtration. They plan an eight-mile Walk for Water on Saturday, part fund-raiser and part protest, at Croton Gorge Park in Ossining. Lewis Rudin, the real-estate developer, has helped charter a Metro-North commuter train that can carry 1,000 people from Grand Central Terminal to the Croton-Harmon station, near the reservoir. Organizers say that the Port Imperial Ferry Service will send two boats, each with a capacity of 200 people, up the Hudson from a pier at West 38th Street in Manhattan. 
 The organizers hope to raise $200,000 for lobbying and lawsuits, but the march is also an effort to spur the city on. The Dinkins administration is not certain whether the organizers are allies or adversaries. The organizers are not sure either.
"We're not going to do any better than Dinkins," said Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a lawyer for the Hudson Riverkeeper, which is sponsoring the event along with the Open Space Institute, a land trust based in Ossining. "At the same time," Mr. Kennedy said, "I see that Mayor Dinkins is balancing a lot of different problems right now and it's our job to make this a priority, without seeing him thrown out of office."
 
Protecting the Watershed
 City officials assert that they are doing all they can to protect the watershed, as an alternative to building a filtration plant.
"I would hope we will make common cause," said Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, who said that she and Albert F. Appleton, Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, will probably participate. "I do believe we're all headed in the same direction," she said.
Many experts say a filtration plant would be a blow. At the Regional Plan Association, John E. Feingold, a director, said, "The city having to carry another infrastructure investment in the neighborhood of $5 to $7 billion, plus $200 to $300 million to operate the thing, could have a real effect on the city's economy, raising water rates and making the cost of business yet higher."
One tactic, he said, is land-use control. "You've got 78 villages and towns comprising 2,000 square miles in the watershed," he said. "Each one makes its own land-use decisions." Only about half have zoning or other land-use controls, he said.
The Dinkins administration has no apologies. "If you look at what we've done over the last three years, I think we have a sensational record," Mr. Appleton said. New York City has brought 25 suits under Federal clean water laws, he said. It has forced the United States Postal Service to drop plans to build a distribution center near Westchester County Airport, forced Putnam Hospital Center in Carmel, N.Y., to improve its sewage system, put administrative machinery in place to begin buying land in the watershed, and begun working with upstate towns on land-use planning.
 
Options to Buy Land
 But the city, under its agreement with Washington, is supposed to announce by the end of this month that it has signed options to buy $15 million worth of land in the watershed, and Mr. Kennedy predicted that the city would miss the deadline. Mr. Appleton said it was too soon to tell.
Environmentalists are considering a highly public effort to get the city to move faster. The Riverkeeper and the Creative Coalition, a group of New York City actors and others in the entertainment field, have raised nearly $300,000 in cash and services for an ad campaign on radio and billboards. The billboards, designed by Kirschenbaum & Bond, are designed for shock value. One shows a urine sample glass with a drinking straw in it.

HEADLINE: Big Nations Optimistic On Tariffs

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 2

 BODY:
The major industrial nations said today that they were optimistic about soon reaching a breakthrough in their long, start-and-stop efforts to lower barriers to world trade.
Finance and trade ministers from the United States and the other largest economic powers, meeting here, said that they expected by next month to reach broad agreement in amajor category of their negotiations -- eliminating or reducing tariffs on hundreds of products. 
 This would give new impetus to the completion of a formal worldwide trade pact by the end of the year.
Negotiations toward a worldwide agreement, which have been going on for more than six years under the aegis of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, must still overcome two other difficult problems -- differences between the United States and the European Community on dealings in food and other agricultural products, and the complexities of turning general agreements into specific rules.
 
Both Cohesion and Friction
 The optimism here today was further tempered by strains between the United States and Japan over Japan's huge, and growing, trade surplus.
But officials said that the apparent willingness of the Europeans to agree with the United States, Japan and Canada on tariff cuts would allow the large nations to present a united front and to exert pressure on smaller countries to sign on to a tariff plan.
Successfully completing tariff negotiations would remove one of the biggest hurdles to completion of a deal among the 110 nations who are members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, was among those here expressing optimism. "We are at least within striking distance of the outline of the largest market-access package in history," he said at a news conference.
The officials said they hoped to complete their work on tariffs before President Clinton and the other leaders of the seven largest industrial nations, the Group of Seven, or in shorthand, the G-7, meet in Tokyo beginning on July 7. Trade ministers from these nations -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan -- will meet there a few days earlier, toward the end of this month, to try to wrap up a deal.
"It's realistic to aim for an outline agreement on market access by the time of the G-7 summit," said Sir Leon Brittan, a former British Cabinet member who is the top negotiator for the 12-nation European Community. Until today, the community had sent mixed signals on its willingness to reach a tariff agreement before the economic summit meeting. "Today's meeting was an important step in the GATT process," Sir Leon said.
It was unclear what concessions might now have to be made by Clinton Administration officials or by those of other countries to secure a tariff agreement. Those taking part in the talks here, which are being held under the auspices of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, released no details of the proposals on the table.
 
Bentsen Lectures Japanese
 Amid all the optimism, there was renewed sniping between the United States and Japan over trade and economic policy. The American Secretary of the Treasury, Lloyd Bentsen, told the meeting that the Japanese Government, despite its announcement in April of a new package of public spending, could do still more to stimulate its faltering economy and to increase the demand for imports.
"Japan's trade and current-account surpluses continue to expand, as domestic demand grows even more slowly than income," Mr. Bentsen said. "These surpluses are a global problem. They are hurting world growth. That must change."
Japanese officials struck back by questioning the commitment of the Clinton Administration to free trade, saying that its philosophy of managed trade and its proposal to set numerical goals for exports to Japan were misguided and would be ineffective.
Officials said the United States and Japan were wrangling over the language of a final communique, in which Japan was seeking a condemnation of managed trade.
Despite the tension, Japanese officials said they had brought specific proposals to Paris, worked out in meetings with the United States in the last several months, to remove impediments to trade in financial services. This is an area that has proved troublesome over the course of negotiations. Whatever concessions might be available from the Japanese were not disclosed.
 
What the Sides Might Want
 Indeed, officials declined to discuss in any detail their progress on the broader tariff-reduction issue, saying that they would leave it to the their top national leaders to spell out any agreement next month in Tokyo.
Some objectives are known, though. The United States has been eager to eliminate tariffs in lumber and paper products, construction equipment and electronics. The Europeans seek lower duties on items like textiles, glass and shoes.
As the major nations seemed to be making progress on tariffs, attention here began shifting toward the dispute over agriculture between the United States and Europe.
Although these two sides reached agreement last fall, the deal was subsequently blocked by France, whose politically powerful farmers argued that the arrangement would cause them great economic harm. The conservative French Cabinet that took office a few weeks ago has at times said it would work toward resolving the dispute with Washington.
 
Shriveling of Growth Estimates
 The discussions here came against a background of growing worry about the weakness of the world economy. On Tuesday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reduced its estimates of economic growth this year for many of the largest nations, including Japan, which it said would grow only 1 percent in 1993.
At the end of 1992, the O.E.C.D.'s growth estimate for Japan this year was 2.3 percent. Similarly, the organization predicted that Germany's growth would shrink by 1.9 percent this year, compared with an estimate of 1.2 percent growth that it made in December.
The O.E.C.D., a government-financed research and policy-study group, slightly raised its growth estimate for the United States, to 2.6 percent this year from an earlier forecast of 2.4 percent.
Mr. Bentsen, in a briefing for reporters, said he believed that the Administration's own growth estimate of 3.1 percent would be reduced.

HEADLINE: St. Petersburg Is Fearful That Its Golden Hopes Will Trample on Its Glories

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
The people at the St. Petersburg Inspectorate for the Preservation of Monuments have mixed feelings about what is going on these days at the Yusupov Palace, a mansion on the Moika Canal where Grigory Rasputin, the Siberian monk who wielded a sinister influence over the family of the last czar, met a grisly end in December 1916.
Once the exclusive preserve of the Trade Union of Education Workers, the mansion in the last two years has opened its doors wide to the public -- maybe too wide, some say. Tour groups tramp through the basement, where the famous murder took place, while upstairs elegant rooms, recently restored, are made available for concerts and private parties, including a New Year's Eve gala organized by NeimanMarcus, the Texas-based department store. 
 "There are different ways of looking at it," said Aleksandr V. Pozdnukhov, who heads the city's historic preservation department. "Of course, the union needs the money to maintain the building but we also worry about the damage -- from too many people, from high heels, from people being careless, drinking and smoking."
 
Old Facades; New Uses
 This is a typical quandary these days for the guardians of St. Petersburg's historical legacy as they nervously watch this fragile and beautiful city edge its way toward a market economy. The changes have been slow in coming, but new stores, hotels and restaurants are springing up along Nevsky Prospekt, the city's central avenue, behind 18th- and 19th-century facades retrieved from beneath a heavy coat of Soviet veneer.
The worry here is that the new economic order could overpower St. Petersburg's delicate majesty and sully its artful, asymmetrical vectors of streets and waterways with commercial clutter.
"We worry that by the time of the city's 300th anniversary, we will not be able to keep its development within civilized bounds," said Mr. Pozdnukhov. "The issue here is maintaining a high level of culture."
It has been less than two years since this city, built by Peter the Great on the swampy banks of the Neva River, retrieved its original name from the wreckage of its tumultuous history. As Sankt-Peterburg as it is called in Russian, or "Peter" for short -- a nickname always preferred by its residents even when the maps called it Leningrad -- celebrates its 290th birthday, the city still seems to be juggling its past glory with its current realities.
 
Second-City Status
 Once the elegant capital of a powerful empire, it is now Russia's second-largest city, suffering from the same economic malaise and confusion as the rest of the country, and lagging behind its age-old rival, Moscow, which for seven long decades held it in thrall.
In fact, St. Petersburg, with its 15,000 historic buildings, was spared precisely because the Bolsheviks, after the 1917 revolution, abandoned it for Moscow.
While Moscow's historic center bore the brunt of its new masters' mania for destruction, St. Petersburg's long rows of ornate mansions, which glide above its river and canals like pastel mirages, have remained intact. They are in a bad state of repair, with peeling paint and broken windows, but at least they are standing. The main tourist attractions, like the Winter Palace and St. Isaac's Cathedral, are in relatively good shape.
"The city was simply transported in its entirety into our era, albeit worse for the wear," said Aleksandr V. Kobak, deputy director of the St. Petersburg Cultural Fund, a private group. "It was left alone not because of its beauty but because there wasn't enough money to tear it down."
 
A Mayor's Hopes
 When political change began in the Soviet Union, people here -- most prominently the city's newly elected Mayor and most indefatigable salesman, Anatoly A. Sobchak -- had hopes that the romance of the city and its prime location on the Gulf of Finland would turn it into a showcase not only of architectural splendor, but also of economic renaissance. Soon after his election in 1990, Mr. Sobchak spoke of making the city a "free economic zone," where foreign investors would be lured with tax breaks and liberal land-use policies.
But the idea of St. Petersburg as a unique free-market island in a socialist sea has died a quiet death, killed by political changes in Moscow where a failed coup and the collapse of the Soviet Union led to the creation of a new government, determined to bring economic reform to all of Russia.
Since then, St. Petersburg's fortunes have tended to lag behind Moscow's. While the number of foreign companies investing here is growing, their number is smaller and the impact of new businesses is not as keenly felt as in the capital. For all its attractions and its potential, St. Petersburg is a poor city of five million people with the bad luck to be a major center of the old Soviet defense industry, now faltering after deep cuts in Government orders.
According to Western analysts, though, privatization of small and medium-sized enterprises has moved faster here than in other parts of Russia, and foreign investors speak highly of the educated work force and the cooperation received from the Mayor's office.
 
Big Plans
 The first two foreign banks licensed to open full-scale operations in Russia will be in St. Petersburg, helping sustain Mr. Sobchak's latest dream to make it the financial center of the country. Big projects are on the drawing boards, including a new seaport at Ust-Luga, about 70 miles west of the city, to be financed with private capital in the hope that it will be the largest port on the Baltic Sea by the end of the century.
But continuing squabbles between Mr. Sobchak and the City Council over control of the city's properties -- from industrial sites to prerevolutionary mansions -- have slowed many other projects, including a proposal for several small free economic zones, a scaled-down version of Mr. Sobchak's first scheme.
New Holland, one of the city's many small islands, is one example of a grand idea that went sour. A joint Russian-French project called for the restoration of the island, used for centuries as a storage site for the city, and its conversion to commercial use. But the project ran into heavy political opposition, from -- among others -- nationalists and historic preservationists who objected to the "sale" of the city's treasures to foreigners.
Since then, another plan for the restoration of New Holland has been drawn up, but Mr. Pozdnukhov at the preservation department says its financing and its completion date are now uncertain. Similar disputes have held up other restoration projects, with the result that after all the talk, and all the hopes, much of the old city looks as shabby and neglected as it did in the Soviet era.
"There was a myth that St. Petersburg would turn around quickly, that so many tourists would come, and bring so much money that the city would recover," said Mr. Kobak, the deputy director of the Cultural Fund. "Now three years later, it is clear that was a complete utopia."
To restore St. Petersburg to its full glory would take a huge investment, which neither the city nor the Russian Government can afford, Mr. Kobak said.
"It would not be within the means of any country, let alone a poor one," he said, noting the similarities with Venice, another city built on canals, which even with the help of international organizations is losing its battle to save its heritage.
Like the people at the preservation department, Mr. Kobak is ambivalent about the role played by private capital in historic preservation. He noted cases where entrepreneurs had moved into old buildings and ripped out and sold priceless fireplaces, murals and woodwork that had miraculously survived the Soviet era.
As in Moscow, the privatization of public property here has been rife with corruption, as city officials take advantage of their positions to distribute state-owned real estate. The Cultural Fund itself had to fight attempts to sell its own premises, on Nevsky Prospekt in the building of the old city Duma, right out from under it. "When I got the notice that the building was to be sold on a commercial basis," said Mr. Kobak, "my first thought was, 'Who gave what to whom?' "
Members of St. Petersburg's arts world tend to point to the city's distaste for "commercialization" as something that distinguishes it from Moscow, where as they see it, everything -- except perhaps the Kremlin -- has its price. At the Tam-Tam club, a raucous gathering place for St. Petersburg's "post-punk" generation, the manager points proudly to the fact that the admission price -- now 200 rubles, or roughly 20 cents -- costs less than a ticket to the movies.
"Moscow doesn't have any such places," he said, "or if they do, they charge more and if possible, in dollars."
"In Moscow, it is all 'pop' -- as in, all that is popular," said Leonid Tikhomirov, a musician who is organizing a "World Jeans Festival" outside St. Petersburg this summer. "There, they are closer to power and however much they may try to fight against it, they are still court jokers." The Jeans Festival is an example of St. Petersburg's zany counterculture scene, organized around Mr. Tikhomirov's premise that anyone who wears jeans can take part in it.
But Gely Sysoyev, a St. Petersburg actor who recently starred in an American play about Anastasia, the daughter of the last czar, staged in what had once been her family's private theatre in the Winter Palace, worries that this kind of high-mindedness could prove fatal.
"Right now, Petersburg theater is at a dead end," he said mournfully. "Moscow is way ahead of us. They are more brazen, and they understand commercialism. It is not just a question of money, but of ideas, about how to understand 1993."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Manages Increase, While Gold Drops Slightly

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar rose against several major currencies yesterday, buoyed by a surge in new-home sales in April and a pause in the Japanese yen's recent surge.
Gold prices declined slightly, following up Tuesday's steep selloff that sent bullion down as much as $9 an ounce. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery slipped an additional 50 cents, to $370.80 an ounce. 
 The British pound fell for a second day amid persistent speculation that the Government of Prime Minister John Major had become more willing to cut interest rates. In New York, the pound finished at $1.541, down from $1.555 late Tuesday.
The dollar also jumped 1.5 pfennigs to finish at 1.598 marks, up from 1.583 marks Tuesday, The dollar was unchanged at 107.15 yen, holding onto gains made Tuesday when talk of Federal Reserve buying helped pull the dollar from a record low of 106.55 yen.
 
Home Sales Are Strong
 The dollar's firming against the yen prompted investors to bid it higher against the mark as well, traders said. The dollar added to those gains after the Commerce Department reported that single-family home sales jumped 22.7 percent in April, the biggest increase in more than six years.
Even so, strong housing sales are not expected to change traders' skeptical outlook on the dollar because other economic data have been weak, said James McGroarty, senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets in Greenwich, Conn. "You don't turn the ship that quickly," he said. "The dollar will probably drift lower."
The housing report came on the heels of a smaller-than-expected rise in the index of leading indicators, which showed that the American economic recovery is sluggish at best. Without signs of robust growth, the Federal Reserve is not likely to raise interest rates aggressively. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive, increasing demand for the currency.
"The economic numbers aren't great for the dollar," said Earl Johnson, a foreign exchange adviser at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "The risk for the dollar is still on the downside."
The dollar could slip against the mark today if, as many traders expect, the German central bank leaves interest rates unchanged after its policy meeting. The Bundesbank left key money market rates unchanged yesterday, indicating that interest rates were not likely to drop this week.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Lift for Tax-Exempt Municipals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The improved outlook for President Clinton's deficit reduction plan appears to be giving a lift to the tax-exempt municipal bond market. Analysts said yesterday that the increase in income tax rates under the plan would make tax-exempt bonds more attractive.
"Frankly, were having a busy day," said said Terry Tracy, the national sales and marketing manager for municipal bonds at Lehman Brothers. "It certainly helps," he added, referring to the talk of compromise on both the President's proposed spending cuts and his energy tax, which could lead to approval in the Senate, where the economic plan had been expected to face difficult sledding. 
 Actively traded municipal bonds were up 1/8 to 1/4 point yesterday, and the Bond Buyer index of 40 municipal bonds fell to a yield of 5.86 percent, its lowest level since mid-May.
 
 
Comparing the Numbers
 Simple math shows why Mr. Clinton's tax increases make tax-exempt bonds more attractive. At the current top Federal income tax rate of 31 percent, a 5.5 percent tax-exempt bond has a taxable equivalent yield of 7.97 percent. With the 36 percent top rate that the President is proposing, that taxable equivalent yield jumps to 8.59 percent. And with the proposed surcharge on higher incomes, which lifts the effective top tax rate to 39.6 percent, that taxable equivalent yield rises to 8.96 percent.
What may soon dawn on more bond salesmen and investors -- and help encourage more buying -- is that under the Clinton budget proposals approved in the House last week by 219 to 213, the higher tax rates are effective retroactively to the beginning of the year, which means there is a higher taxable equivalent yield already to be made.
"I didn't know that," said an amazed head of a firm that advises states and cities on municipal issues and who asked not to be named.
And as of now, it does not appear that the retroactivity will be changed -- even if it appears it may have a chilling effect on consumer spending while the economy is still weak. One House Ways and Means staff member dismissed the possibility of a change yesterday, saying, "We need the money."
 
 
Ratio Cited
 One of the signs that traders and analysts look for in measuring whether the prices of tax-exempt bonds have begun to reflect the expectation of a tax increase is the ratio of the yield on municipal bonds to the yield on comparable taxable Treasury securities. With tax rates climbing, the ratio should be falling.
But as of yesterday, the ratios had not moved much in the last several weeks and were still well above their lows for the last year. For example, the ratio of a 10-year municipal bond yield to the yield on a 10-year Treasury note was 82 percent, well above its recent low of 75 percent.
The increase in demand for tax-exempt municipals is helping to offset the downward pressure on the market from the continuing flood of new issues as states, cities, towns and other entities take advantage of lower interest rates.
Despite the record $232.4 billion of new issues last year -- which included $120.5 billion in refinancings -- analysts said there were still plenty of higher interest rate bonds to be replaced with lower interest rate bonds.
And the data for this year bear out this fact. Through May, there was a total of $112.7 billion of new tax-exempt issues, with $75.95 billion of them refinancings of old issues.
Traders and analysts have said they expected several billion dollars more of new issues alone this week, including an $800 million negotiated sale by the New York Dormitory Authority to be priced today, with Goldman Sachs & Company the lead underwriter. Yesterday, there was about $2 billion in new issues.
In yesterday's biggest deal, the Puerto Rico Public Building Authority sold $704.5 million in bonds to refund older, higher interest rate bonds. For the new bonds, the taxable equivalent yield for New Yorkers is even more attractive because the bonds are exempt from Federal, New York State and New York City taxes.
The Puerto Rico issue, with the First Boston Corporation as the lead underwriter, was priced to yield 4 percent for bonds due in July 1996; 5.4 percent for bonds due in July 2003, and 5.85 percent for bonds due in July 2015. The taxable equivalent yields at current top tax rates, with triple tax exemption, are 7.69 percent, 10.38 percent and 11.25 percent, respectively.
 
 
Treasury Market
 After a volatile day of trading, Treasury prices finished little changed yesterday. The price of the 30-year bond due in February 2023 was up 3/32 as the yield slipped to 6.87 percent from 6.88 percent Tuesday.
The wildest swing in the market came in the morning when the Government reported an unexpected 22.7 percent surge in the sales of new homes in April. The surprise, coming after the report of a weak one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the index of leading economic indicators for April, sparked an immediate selloff. But prices rebounded as traders refocused on the overall signal of April economic data, which is that the economy, while growing, is still weak.

HEADLINE: Clinton Delays Push to Increase Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has delayed its push for a higher minimum wage because of worries about undermining job growth and antagonizing conservatives and business executives while the President's budget hangs in the balance, Administration officials said today.
They said the Administration would probably wait until next year, and then propose an increase in the minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour, that would be far smaller than the $1-an-hour rise contemplated when President Clinton took office. 
 The move came on a day in which the White House seemed to be stepping back from, or at least delaying, a number of actions that have created distractions from Mr. Clinton's top priority, his economic plan.
 
Economic Climate Cited
 Several Clinton advisers acknowledged today that proposing an increase now in the minimum wage would simply antagonize business executives and conservatives in Congress, making it harder to win passage of the President's economic package. And at a time of weak economic growth, with the unemployment rate seemingly stuck around 7 percent, the Administration appears wary of throwing its weight behind a minimum wage increase, which would open it up to charges that it is sabotaging job growth.
"Unless we have six months of terrific employment growth, this thing is going to slide for a while," said one Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
But Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said Mr. Clinton still planned to fulfill his campaign promise of increasing the minimum wage.
"There is no question that the President is committed to raising the minimum wage," Mr. Reich said in an interview. "But the legislative calendar is so crowded at the moment that it is not time to put forward an increase in the minimum wage."
Other officials gave additional reasons for the delay. For one, they said, the Administration does not want to distract its focus and energies from getting its deficit-reduction plan and health-care changes enacted. The White House also seems to be heeding the power of Washington's business lobbyists.
Speaking about the minimum wage, a senior Administration official who insisted on anonymity said: "It is on the back burner. There's an awful lot on the economic plate that has come to Congress, or that's about to come to Congress, that's upsetting business."
Business, which abhors the idea of an increase, is already seething about the proposed energy tax, a higher corporate income tax and new burdens that companies are expected to face to finance the Administration's health-care package. Indeed, business hardly seems appeased by the delay and the decision to push for a smaller increase in the minimum wage.
"We believe a minimum wage increase will have a devastating effect just when jobs are starting to come back," said Nelson Litterst, a lobbyist with the National Federation of Independent Business, an association of 600,000 small businesses. "Coupled with the tax package and employer mandates on health care, this would be a final straw for small business."
 
More Modest Increase Seen
 In January, at the start of the new Administration, officials talked about raising the minimum wage by about $1 an hour, to roughly $5.25. They said that wage, after being adjusted for inflation, would be about $1.25 lower than it was in 1979. But Labor Department officials now talk of a far more modest increase, one that would index the wage to inflation and raise it to somewhere between $4.50 and $4.75 an hour.
Labor Department officials initially said that to help lift workers out of poverty they would tie a rise in the minimum wage to an increase in the earned income tax credit. The President proposed a higher earned income tax credit in February as part of his economic package, but there was no proposal on the minimum wage.
In delaying any push on the minimum wage, the Administration could run the risk of having members of Congress introduce minimum wage legislation over the next month or two and then demand that Mr. Clinton make good on his commitment to an increase.
That happened with proposals to ban striker replacements. The Administration wanted to put the issue on the back burner, but the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and its Congressional allies got legislation moving and pressed the Administration to get behind it far sooner than the White House would have liked.
But while officials in the labor federation want the minimum wage raised to at least $5.40 an hour, they say it is not as high a priority for them as the striker replacement bill or the health-care package. One business lobbyist told of going to a meeting with Administration officials who said the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was not going to make a big push on the minimum wage this year.
 
Impatient for an Increase
 Still, unions with many low-wage workers are eager for the Administration to act soon. Ray Abernathy, a spokesman for the Service Employees International Union, said: "The low-wage workers of America have been waiting 12 years for the minimum wage to be put back to where it should be, and another six months' wait is not going to kill us. But it's not something we're going to let slide off the plate."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Labor Committee, seems impatient for an increase and wants to work with the Administration to make sure it remains a priority.
"For 70 percent of American workers, the Reagan-Bush years saw a steady erosion in their real wages, and the trend has been particularly destructive for low-wage workers," he said. "No one who works full time in America should have to live in poverty."
In 1989, President George Bush vetoed legislation that would have raised the minimum wage to $4.55 from $3.35. But in a compromise, he later accepted a bill that raised the wage in two steps to $4.25, as of April 1991.

HEADLINE: Young Organizers Lead Labor's Push

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Ingrid Nava is a little rabble-rouser in tennis shoes. She is 5-foot-2, 25 years old and a former student leader at Stanford University. She lugs a woven shoulder bag stuffed with notebooks, handbills and her pager. At 8 A.M. six days a week, she sets off from her Long Beach apartment, driving her second-hand Honda Civic to Bellflower, a few miles to the north.
Ms. Nava is a labor union organizer, working at the Kaiser Permanente hospital in Bellflower. A few days ago, she distributed stickers the size of playing cards for hospital employees to wear on their smocks. They depicted a tombstone inscribed, "Short staffing is hazardous to your health." 
 After a supervisor charged two workers with disobeying orders for refusing to remove their stickers, Ms. Nava returned with stickers five times the size of the originals.
 
Trying to End Decline
 Now that union membership has shriveled to just 16 percent of the American labor force, many unions are renewing their efforts to attract organizers like Ms. Nava, people who recruit members and rally them for campaigns like the one in Bellflower for a better contract for Kaiser workers. For more than a decade, unions have been railing against courts and the labor laws that they see stacked against them, and they are now hopeful that the Clinton Administration will right the balance.
But some unions, like Ms. Nava's Service Employees International Union, also admit that they contributed to the problem by letting their organizing campaigns languish in the 1980's.
To help recruit and train organizers, the service employees union and 13 others established the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Organizing Institute in Washington, which has now dispatched some 200 people into the field to take up the slogging, low-paid, often futile toil of trying to revive the American labor movement. Ms. Nava is one of the first graduates of the institute.
Of 600 applicants since the institute was formed three years ago, 200 have survived the initial screening and four months of training and apprenticeship leading to full-time assignment to a union. Most of the new organizers, who earn about $20,000 a year, work on campaigns to bring union representation to non-union workplaces.
 
Praise for Organizers
 With no signs yet of a resurgence in union membership, it is too soon to gauge the new organizers' impact. But Richard Bensinger, the director of the institute, said the trainees he has seen had the blue-collar idealism and the sense of social injustice that inspired the unions' growth from the 1930's to the mid-1950's.
"It has nothing to do with the fact that some went to a good college," he said. "It's in spite of that. People are good because they have natural intelligence, not book intelligence. Most of these college kids, even the ones from Brown, Yale and Stanford come from working-class families."
Ms. Nava is the daughter of a postal worker mother and a father she has never met. She was born in Washington and reared in San Antonio. At Stanford she majored in political science and was co-president of the student body for two years.
She spends 12-hour days in Bellflower, helping unionized workers at the Kaiser hospital press for higher wages and a stop to the big health-maintenance organization's reductions in hours and staff.
The workers' contract expired April 1, and rather than strike, Ms. Nava and the 12,000-member Local 399 of the service employees union are trying to pressure management from the inside.
Workers at the hospital, one of 10 in Kaiser's Southern California division, seem to welcome Ms. Nava's attentions. They say she is a departure from the Local's infrequent attention of the past. "She's our organizer," said Eva Hernandez, a maintenance woman. "She gets us doing things to push the hospital."
 
Contract Offer
 The central issue at the Kaiser hospitals is management's offer of a three-year contract with a 3 percent raise in the first year and $600 bonuses in each of the next two years. Kaiser would also eliminate a paid holiday for either Christmas Eve or New Year's Eve.
Newly hired workers would lose a bonus that other workers receive for not using their sick leave, but they would be allowed for the first time to carry over unused sick leave from one year to the next. The union wants to retain the bonus and the holiday and seeks 5 percent raises each year.
Each side has strong reasons for holding its ground. Kaiser, like other health-care institutions, is trying to curb the rising cost of care, especially now. Health-maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, will be vying for contracts to provide care to uninsured Americans under the Clinton Administration's overhaul of the health-care system, and Kaiser, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt organization and the nation's biggest H.M.O., wants to be able to charge competitive fees.
For their part, the workers and their union have incentives to insist on a rich contract. The contract in 1987 left some workers with no wage increases at all, just lump-sum payments that left their wage base unchanged. After the 1990 contract, which followed an eight-day strike, some workers lost their modest wage increases to an increase in union dues, which are currently $22.50 a week. More contracts like the last two, and the workers might look for another union.
 
Working From Inside
 Local 399 holds out the threat of a strike, but it is reluctant to resort to one because of the region's depressed economy. "It would take 30 days, and the membership is not able to stay out long," Ms. Nava said. "They can't afford it. A lot of them have laid-off spouses. So we're using an inside strategy."
Ms. Nava is important to the strategy. She goes from office to office in the hospital, greeting workers, passing out handbills urging them to attend spirit-raising meetings, probing for complaints of management abuse and jotting them down in a notebook, pressing workers to sign petitions to present grievances to management.
In one department four workers complain that their supervisor is denying them the weeks they have requested for their vacations. For that and other reasons, they tell Ms. Nava, morale has collapsed.
In cases like these, Ms. Nava encourages workers to sign petitions, the first step in a collective effort to force the employer to correct abuses. "My goal is to get everyone in a department to sign," she said, adding that she would proceed with a complaint if she got 65 percent.
"The biggest issue is workload," Ms. Nava said. To control costs, Kaiser has eliminated 173 jobs through attrition and layoffs at the Bellflower hospital, and reduced some some workers' hours. Workers now complain that excessive demands are made upon them as a result of the staff reductions, and employees in at least two major departments have filed petitions complaining of short staffing.
 
Little Political Dogma
 Unlike their forebears, the new union organizers seem not to have been captured by any particular ideological dogma.
"I believe in some measure of economic equity and justice," Ms. Nava said. "But I don't think there's any one system to march to, because the world is constantly changing. Capitalism is not the same as it was when Marx was alive."
If she has a hero, she said, it is probably the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
No one can tell whether Ms. Nava, for all her hustle, will help produce a better contract for the Kaiser hospitals. But David Borden, who transports patients throughout the Bellflower hospital, said she has already had an impact: she brought new energy to the workers and inspired him to become a union steward.
"Most people have a sense they can't make any changes in their working conditions," Mr. Borden said. "So it's exciting when you do realize you have some power."

She handed out leaflets at a hospital in Bellflower, Calif. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hevesi Urges Rivals to Limit Underwriters' Contributions

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Alan G. Hevesi, the Assemblyman from Queens who is running for City Comptroller, yesterday challenged his two rivals to voluntarily limit campaign contributions from firms that underwrite city bonds.
Seeking to take advantage of the widespread perception that firms use campaign contributions to influence the selection of bond underwriters, Mr. Hevesi, a senior member of the Assembly, also said he would introduce legislation that would force the city to put out to competitive bidding the bulk of its underwriting business. 
 Under the current practice, the mayor and the city comptroller jointly choose a syndicate of bond underwriters on subjective grounds and then negotiate each sale with them. Consequently they benefit indirectly by receiving thousands of dollars from bond brokers and Wall Street firms that believe, rightly or wrongly, that it is necessary to give to get.
"The current system is rotten and presents an appearance of a conflict of interest," Mr. Hevesi said.
 
Limit for Candidates
 Mr. Hevesi said the three comptroller candidates should agree to limit to $10,000 the total amount they collect from executives of each of the 30 firms in the underwriting syndicate or their families. The city Campaign Finance Law, which is not mandatory, limits contributions to $6,500 per individual but does not prohibit many individuals from the same firm from giving up to the limit.
The incumbent Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, who is under investigation because she received a large campaign loan from a banking company that later was recommended by her office to become an underwriter, immediately rejected Mr. Hevesi's proposal. She said the current limits were sufficient.
"In an ideal world we would have 100 percent public financing for elections and I heartily endorse that," Ms. Holtzman said through her campaign spokesman, George Arzt. "But there are campaign finance limitations already on the books and we strenuously abide by them."
Herman Badillo, a Democratic candidate for comptroller who is also running on the Republican line, said he thought the voluntary limits were a good idea, but he stopped short of saying he would abide by them. He said his decision would depend on how much money the other candidates have raised.
"It's really unfair to collect a million dollars and then ask the other guy to start limiting himself," Mr. Badillo said. "I don't want to put myself at a disadvantage."
Mr. Hevesi said he had not decided yet whether he would stick to a $10,000 cap from each firm if the other candidates did not. "It's very likely I will abide by the cap regardless of what the others do," he said.
City officials said Mr. Hevesi's legislation would cripple the city's ability to save money by refinancing bonds and using innovative financing techniques like zero-coupon and variable-rate bonds. If forced to use a competitive bidding system, the city could not control when it goes to market and would have to sell only fixed-rate notes that, on average, cost the city more in interest.
"What he's proposing is a bad idea," said Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "If it came to pass, it would cost the city a ton of money."
He said about a third of the $5 billion in bonds the city sells each year could be handled through competitive bids but the city would likely end up paying higher interest rates. Such deals are riskier for underwriters because the bids are opened and the bonds sold 10 days after the city advertises the sale, no matter what the market conditions are.
Competitive bidding, he added, is not a guarantee against corruption. After all, bids can be rigged to favor a single firm, and firms can form cartels to control prices, he pointed out.
 
To Dispel Cynicism
 But Mr. Hevesi said the extra cost of a competitive system would be worth it to dispel public cynicism about the selection process.
"The trade-off is we get a system where there is no appearance of a conflict of interest," he said.
Mr. Hevesi's vow to pass legislation is not an idle threat. As the second ranking member of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, he has legislative clout, and other influential lawmakers, including the committee chairman, Sheldon Silver, have indicated support for the idea.
In addition, the city must seek permission each year from the State Legislature to forgo competitive bidding and negotiate its bond sales, so the Legislature has leverage over the administration.
