HEADLINE: In Albany, Dinkins's Fiscal Gantlet;
Mayor Faces Stumbling Blocks From Allies and the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 2

 BODY:
In the delicate dance that every New York City mayor performs when seeking state aid, Mayor David N. Dinkins has rarely been mistaken for Fred Astaire.
He has been criticized for not comprehending the Kremlinesque intrigue of Statehouse politics, for not lobbying state legislators enough, for crying wolf.
But this is a year Mr. Dinkins seems destined to stumble despite his best efforts, as he seeks $280 million in state aid to help close a $500 million budget gap. His allies seem weaker, his opponents more determined and the independents more complacent than usual.
 
Trouble Across the Divide
 For Democrats, the problem is largely the state's tight budget. Behind public talk about supporting Mr. Dinkins, there is much private hand wringing about a sluggish economy that has left them few resources for a bailout and many excuses for whittling down the city's plan. 
 Even Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Dinkins's strongest ally, has said he wanted an aid package to be "zero-sum," meaning it should have no net impact on the state budget. Republicans have questioned whether that is possible.
Across the political divide, the Republican-controlled Senate has traditionally impeded aid to New York City, arguing that it drains resources from upstate and the suburbs.
In the past, such partisan opposition has occasionally been softened by the six Senate Republicans from the city, who have helped Democatic mayors navigate legislation through the Senate when it benefited their districts.
But this year, that loose alliance could be weakened by the strong campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor. Amid conflicting allegiances, the six Republicans might let a bailout package die without a fight in hopes of helping Mr. Giuliani, aides to Mr. Dinkins said.
Democrats point to another reason Republicans from the city might duck the uphill battle: they are not up for re-election this year and lack the urgency generated by the heat of a campaign.
The Republicans deny that. "We aren't going to sabotage the city's well-being to play politics," said Senator Guy J. Velella, a Bronx Republican. "Whoever is going to be mayor in January is going to have a heck of job handling the city's finances, and we'll have to account for that."
But Democrats are girding for the ritual hostage-taking that usually marks the end of the legislative session. In this case, aid for New York City in exchange for aid to local governments on Long Island.
"The Republicans will be driving a hard bargain this year," said Senator David A. Paterson, a Manhattan Democrat. "Everyone says partisan loyalty is not a factor, but it's always a factor. And even more this year."
To be sure, portions of the city's package are very likely to be approved. Mr. Cuomo has identified about $65 million in actions he can take without legislative approval, including reimbursing the city an additional $11 million for foster-care placements and assuming the administrative costs for collecting certain taxes. But that would still leave the city, by its own account, with a shortfall of more than $200 million.
 
Selling Airports Suggested
 Mr. Cuomo has refused to drop several lawsuits with the city, a move the Dinkins administration said would have saved them $90 million. In turn, he has proposed that the city sell La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for $300 million.
But the city has expressed only lukewarm interest in the idea, saying the airport land is worth closer to $2 billion. With no deal in sight, some state and city officials have questioned whether Mr. Cuomo's proposal was meant to give the appearance of aiding the city while shifting the responsibility to another authority.
Both city and Port Authority officials have questioned the wisdom of selling the airports, because the city would be relinquishing a steady source of revenue for a one-time infusion of cash. "It's not clear to me that the city should do this kind of one shot," said a Port Authority official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Several of the city's other big-ticket requests also seem remote at best, including having the state assume $50 million in Medicaid costs. Medicaid proposals have been mired in the Legislature for more than a year, and are not expected to pass this year.
At least one bailout bill that the Dinkins administration had believed was safe remains at risk. The proposal to sell the value of delinquent property taxes to an outside collection agency would be worth $215 million to the city. Though it has not drawn clear opposition, there are enough questions about it to delay passage until next year.
Amid the parlor politeness surrounding the bailout negotiations, there have been few overt suggestions that Mr. Dinkins's plan is in trouble. But between the lines of the news releases are questions about the depth of the city's fiscal crisis and Mr. Dinkins's ability to resolve it.
 
Welfare Costs an Issue
 Republicans have criticized Mr. Dinkins for not bringing spending more in line with revenues, saying he reneged on a promise made in 1991 to appoint a commission to study reorganizing city government.
"I don't think the city is doing everything it can to control its welfare costs," said Senator Frank Padavan, a Queens Republican.
There are skeptics among the Democrats as well. Some think Mr. Dinkins knows he must cut services to control his ballooning budget, and has positioned himself to hold the state responsible when that time comes. Some members of Mr. Cuomo's staff also believe the city has more money than it claims and can balance its budget with less drastic cuts than Mr. Dinkins has threatened.
"They are going to balance their budget, regardless of what the state does," said one of Mr. Cuomo's aides, speaking on condition of anonymity. In the wake of such uncertainty, some legislators said they sensed that Mr. Dinkins expected to lose on most of his package, and has begun looking for ways to turn political rejection into a public relations gain.
During a visit to Albany last week, Mr. Dinkins brought representatives from 10 community organizations who spoke to state legislators about the devastating effect service cuts would have on poor and minority neighborhoods.
But several legislators wondered afterward whether Mr. Dinkins's goal was to impress the neighborhood groups with his lobbying efforts. "They were the most important people on this trip," said one Republican senator.
Even if that was not his intent, Mr. Dinkins may have achieved that goal. "From my position, I thought the Mayor was extremely skillful in keeping the Senate Republicans on the agenda, which was the agenda we brought," said Geoffrey Canada, president of the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: G.E. Gives Midtown Tower To Columbia University

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A century after moving its campus from mid-Manhattan, Columbia University returned yesterday to accept the 50-story General Electric Building at 570 Lexington Avenue as a gift from the General Electric Company.
The slender landmark Art Deco skyscraper at 51st Street -- ornamented by lightning bolts and electric rays -- is valued at $40 million. 
 "It may not be the largest gift in the history of Columbia, but we believe it's the tallest one," said Dennis D. Dammerman, senior vice president of finance at General Electric.
In fact, said Michael I. Sovern, the president of Columbia, it is the second largest single gift, exceeded only by John W. Kluge's donation of $60 million in April.
 
A Gift Also for the Giver
 What General Electric gets out of the deal is a $40 million tax deduction and the successful disposal of a 62-year-old commercial building that is two-thirds vacant.
What Columbia gets is relief from the squeeze on space at its Morningside Heights campus, Mr. Sovern said, and a place to put programs that "can work as effectively, even more effectively, in midtown" -- like those in business, journalism, international affairs and the arts.
The tower is two blocks from Madison Avenue and 49th Street, the site occupied by Columbia in the 19th century. "Our predecessors moved uptown in order to expand," Mr. Sovern said. "We are returning -- in part -- for the same reason."
Most New Yorkers probably think of 30 Rockefeller Center as the G.E. Building, since the company's name and logo are emblazoned on that tower, where NBC has its studios. And many New Yorkers associate Columbia with Rockefeller Center, since the university owned 11.7 acres under the center until 1985, when it sold the land to the Rockefeller Group for $400 million.
But 570 Lexington Avenue served as General Electric's headquarters until 1974, when the company moved to Fairfield, Conn. One-third of the 428,000-square-foot building is still occupied by G.E. divisions.
General Electric will remain as a tenant of Columbia, but Mr. Sovern would not disclose the rent -- "since we might want to charge someone else more."
 
Possibilities Abound
 Columbia will occupy much of the rest of the building. There might be classes for executives given by the School of Business, Mr. Sovern said, a center for computer-assisted reporting sponsored by the School of Journalism or collaborative ventures involving the United Nations and the School of International and Public Affairs.
Mr. Sovern said 570 Lexington Avenue could be used for a "whole range of cultural activities," including art exhibitions, and would almost certainly be developed as a conference center, taking advantage of its 130-seat auditorium.
Those parts of the building used by the university for educational purposes will be exempt from city real-estate taxes. But Mr. Sovern said that the city's loss of tax revenue ought to be offset in part by the economic activity generated by the new academic center. The tax bill last year was about $3 million, Mr. Dammerman said.
Mr. Dammerman first approached Mr. Sovern about a possible deal two months ago, said Fred Knubel, Columbia's director of public information. Because the arrangement is still so fresh, Mr. Sovern said, it is too early to say how much money will go into remodeling interiors or running the building.
The transfer of the property from General Electric to Columbia University is set for the end of the month. Mr. Sovern said that the 50 G.E. workers who maintain and operate the building will remain and become Columbia employees.
 
Deeded to G.E. in 1931
 Originally intended as the home of the Radio Corporation of America, which was owned by a consortium including General Electric, 570 Lexington Avenue was deeded to G.E. when RCA moved to Rockefeller Center in 1931. Two years later, a Federal court forced G.E. to liquidate its RCA holdings. The companies were reunited in 1985, when General Electric acquired RCA.
Electricity provides an appropriately flashy motif for the lavish ornamentation. Throughout the facade, stylized clenched fists grasp sharply angular bolts. Halos of electric rays can be seen in the pinnacle of the tower and in the recesses of the barrel-vaulted ceiling in the lobby.
 
Landmark Status
 The Landmarks Preservation Commission gave the building landmark status in 1985 and has described it as "one of the most expressive skyscrapers of its era." Mr. Sovern noted with pride that the architect, John Walter Cross, of Cross & Cross, had studied at Columbia.
G.E. spent $20 million to repair and restore the facade in the mid-1980's, replacing thousands of bricks and hundreds of windows, as well as relighting the building's lacy crown.
"Columbia will use and cherish this work of art with purpose and respect," Mr. Sovern said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Columbia University received its tallest, and second richest, gift when General Electric donated its 50-story Art Deco building at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street. The building is valued at $40 million. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Mini-Van Revival at Renault

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 28

 BODY:
A decade ago, the large French industrial companyMatra came up with a plan for a mini-van and offered it to the auto maker Peugeot. For Peugeot, however, the concept was too bizarre in a European market still convinced that people rode in cars not in vans. But Renault promptly stepped in and started production of the first European mini-van, the Espace.
For Renault, it was not a time for big risks. It was piling up enormous losses -- 12.1 billion francs in 1984 alone -- and many analysts believed the state-owned auto maker would be the first casualty of a chronically overcrowded European car market.
 
A Remarkable Success
 "The place looked more like an employment agency than a business enterprise," said Karl Ludwigsen, a former executive at Ford who is now an auto industry analyst. 
 But the Espace was a remarkable success, steadily increasing sales and carving out a new niche. Today, it accounts for about 50 percent of the European mini-van segment and it is clear that Renault, like Chrysler in America, has based its revival partly on understanding the mini-van's appeal ahead of everybody else. Indeed, Ford of Europe and Volkswagen, which are together building a new mini-van factory in Portugal, are still catching up.
 
Nimble and Innovative
 The Espace says much about the way Renault has defied conventional wisdom lately. The only state-owned company among Europe's big six auto makers, Renault was supposed to be the most cumbersome, bureaucratic and vulnerable. Yet it has proved more nimble and innovative than most, reporting net profits of 5.68 billion francs ($1 billion) in 1992, a year in which Ford lost $1.28 billion on its European operations.
Lumbered with a reputation of building medium-quality small cars that could only succeed in southern Europe's highly protected markets, Renault has successfully retooled its image with quality autos of all sizes. The turnaround is best illustrated in the competitive and sizable German market, where Renault's market share has nearly doubled to almost 6 percent from just over 3 percent in 1985. Over all in Europe, the company has increased its market share to 10.6 percent last year from 9.9 percent in 1990.
Because Renault faced its crisis before the rest of the industry confronted the worst auto sales slump in decades, the company has moved faster to cut costs, reduce staff and raise productivity. Over the last six years, its staff has been reduced by 50,127 people, to 146,604, or about 25 percent. It now takes an average of 27 hours to assemble a car at Renault, not as efficient as Japanese plants that can do it in 20 hours, but far better than the nearly 40 hours in German auto plants.
"I think we have demonstrated that it is an American prejudice to believe that state-owned companies cannot be as well run as private ones," the chairman of Renault, Louis Schweitzer, said in an interview. "Indeed, we act just like a private corporation."
Not quite. As recently as 1990, Renault received the equivalent of about 10 billion francs ($1.83 billion) from the French Government, in the form of a loan write-off and an injection of new capital. Such aid, not available to private auto makers, has helped improve the company balance sheet, cutting net debt to 12.55 billion francs, or 7 percent of sales, from 27.1 billion francs, or 16.6 percent of sales, in 1990.
Now, however, Renault finally wants to put all state coddling behind it and become a private corporation. This month, the conservative French Government said the auto maker would be among 21 state companies to be put up for sale to the private sector. The company's management is enthusiastic.
 
'Privatization Seems Logical'
 "In the profession we are in, there is no reason for us to remain a state company," said Mr. Schweitzer, 50, a technocrat who once worked as the chief of staff to a Socialist Prime Minister. "A privatization seems logical to me, on condition that Renault remain a French-owned company. This corporation is a national symbol, and our labor unions and the public in general would not understand if we ceased to be French."
Analysts liked the idea of Renault going private, arguing that it would strengthen its capital base and make it more competitive as the long-predicted shake-out in the European auto industry finally seems imminent. "Renault will issue more equity, eliminating its remaining debt problems, and should emerge a still stronger company," said John Lawson, an analyst at the DRI auto research firm.
But big obstacles remain. Chief among them is the state of the European car market, now in the midst of its worst recession for 20 years. Renault expects car sales to fall 12 percent from last year's near-record 13.4 million. But predictions grow worse by the month; Ford of Europe recently suggested that sales might drop more than 20 percent.
 
Any Profit Would Be Small
 "If sales drop by more than 20 percent, no European car makers will make money," Mr. Schweitzer said. Renault's profits have plunged to 240 million francs ($44 million) in the first quarter of this year, a 90 percent drop over the comparable period a year ago. The chairman acknowledged that if Renault made any profit this year, it would be small.
More worrying is that there is no sign of a recovery -- Mr. Lawson of DRI said he expected 1994 to be as bad as the current year -- and the reasons for the extent of the market's collapse are unclear.
The best theory is that nervousness and caution are inhibiting consumers as unemployment and recession spread in Europe.
In France, where Renault has a 29.5 percent market share, it remains protected from Japan. Japan's French market share, as a result of restrictions, is 4 percent, compared with 12.4 percent throughout Europe. With an agreement now to lift all barriers to Japanese imports into the European Community by the year 2000, Renault appears vulnerable to a Japanese onslaught.
These factors are certain to weigh on any privatization, and may mean that a sale is put off at least until the European market shows convincing signs of revival.
 
Models Show Originality
 But Renault's attractions -- most analysts said they believed it was the strongest auto maker in Europe alongside General Motors -- remained conspicuous. Its models, including the recently introduced economy car, the goggle-eyed Twingo, have continued to show a striking originality, reflecting the work of Patrick Le Quement, a designer hired in 1987 from Volkswagen and widely regarded as among the most creative in Europe.
Among Renault's strengths is what amounts to the most successful transnational alliance in Europe's auto industry. At the beginning of 1991, Volvo took a 20 percent stake in Renault, while Renault took a 25 percent stake in the Volvo Car Corporation of Sweden. At the same time, the two companies took stakes in each other's truck operations. The results have been positive.
With many components now jointly acquired and the two companies providing each other with engines and transmissions, savings have been enormous. For example, Mr. Schweitzer said, when the alliance began, both companies had plans for a two-liter engine. They decided Volvo would build the gasoline version and Renault the diesel. The result: a saving of nearly $200 million for Renault.
"We have not taken a decision yet, but it would be logical to seek a merger with Volvo," Mr. Schweitzer said. "What we must be careful about is not losing any of the capacities of the two companies in putting them together."
 
Raising Political Questions
 A problem, up to now, had been the fact that Volvo is private and Renault state-owned, but that would be resolved if Renault was privatized. Moreover, cooperation has not been so successful in the truck divisions, where the two companies are direct competitors and Renault has continued to lose money. Delicate political questions would also arise because both companies are symbols of their respective nations.
What is clear, however, is that Renault is a potentially attractive partner to Volvo, a situation in sharp contrast to a decade ago. Indeed, having lost $610 million last year, the worst result in its history, Volvo has said it was keen to examine closer cooperation with Renault.
Over all, Renault's survival no longer seems in any doubt, which is more than can be said for some other auto makers in a European market still with a basic problem: although it is about the size of the American market -- with 13.4 million cars sold last year against 13 million in the United States -- there are six major auto makers based here rather than three. And in Europe, the Japanese have only just begun their assault.
"This is crunch time for European car makers, with a gory five years ahead, and we believe there will be five big auto makers here rather than six by the end of the decade," Mr. Ludwigsen, the analyst, said. "Renault's survival seems assured, while that of Ford of Europe and Fiat seems much more questionable. Indeed our prediction is that Fiat will become the majority holder of Ford of Europe's operations by the end of the century."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Rise Sharply After Home-Sales Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices leaped yesterday after the Government reported a sharp rise in home sales in April to the highest level in more than six years.
Spruce two-by-fours for July delivery shot up the permitted daily limit of $10, to $279.80 per 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. 
 The Government's report that sales of new single-family homes in April rose 22.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 751,000, was "absolutely stunning," William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
Many economists had expected no more than a 2 percent increase. "This may just be the key that will spur some renewed demand in the lumber market," Mr. O'Neill said.
Analysts said lumber futures were ready to rally after plunging 45 percent from the March 15 record high of $493.50. Lumber futures typically rise in the spring as demand for building materials picks up. This year, the seasonal effect was muted by cold, wet weather that discouraged outdoor work and by large supplies of lumber laid in by dealers during the winter in anticipation of a and construction boom that never came.
Bud Merrill of Shearson Lehman Brothers said dealers remained reluctant to buy more lumber until they saw further evidence of a stronger housing market. He predicted they would, citing the highest inventory of unsold homes and the lowest mortgage rates in 20 years. "Things could really get a little bit on the hot side in the second half of the year," he said.
 
Platinum Drops Sharply
 On other commodity markets, platinum futures tumbled amid talk that Russia, the second-largest platinum producer after South Africa, sold large amounts of the metal in the last two weeks to gain hard currency. July platinum deliveries skidded $8.40, to $383.70 a troy ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Profit taking hit energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude oil for July delivery fell 21 cents, to $20.03 a barrel; July heating oil fell 0.34 cent, to 54.80 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline fell 0.64 cent, to 58.33 cents a gallon; July natural gas sagged 7.1 cents, to $2.108 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Rise In Yield in the Latest Period

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds rose in the latest week, according to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
Tax-exempt money fund yields were up for the period ended Tuesday, reflecting higher rates of money market instruments like Treasury securities, negotiable certificates of deposit and commercial paper over the last few weeks. But with an expected heavy supply of new tax-exempt municipal issues this week, yields could increase again next week, analysts said. 
 Yields on tax-exempt money market funds gained an average of 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in the week, as assets of tax-exempt funds fell $801 million, bringing total assets to $99.4 billion.
But money managers once again held fast and resisted shortening the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in their portfolios, keeping the number of days to 48 over the last four weeks.
IBC/Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt money market fund rose 5 basis points, to 2.23 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield up to 2.20 percent. Over the last 30 days, the compounded yield was averaging 2.08 percent and the simple yield about 2.06 percent.
For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable bond equivalent yield, less state and local taxes, for the average seven-day yield is 3.09 percent, and about 3.19 percent for investors in a 31 percent bracket.
The Money Fund Report's survey noted that among the tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund remained the best performer for the last five of six weeks. The fund was yielding 2.88 percent, up from its leading 2.86 percent in the previous week.
 
Taxable Funds
 Assets of taxable money market funds fell by $12 billion in the week ended yesterday, to a total of $474.6 billion.
Institutions accounted for a major portion of the cash withdrawn from the funds in the week. Institutional assets declined by $10.8 billion, to $160.6 billion, as a rising stock market and higher yields in the fixed-income market attracted institutional cash.
The average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios remained at 64 for the third consecutive week.
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund moved higher by 3 basis points, to 2.66 percent, with the seven-day simple yield up by the same amount, to 2.62 percent. Over 30 days, the compounded average yield is 2.64 percent and simple is 2.60 percent.
Walter S. Frank, the chief economist for the Money Fund Report, said he believed that yields would remain flat and might even edge higher as inflationary fears and uncertainty surrounding the deficit bill, which have dogged the markets over the last several weeks, take hold.
"Besides, the Federal Reserve continues to show reluctance to make any move," Mr. Frank said. "What could change the game plan, is a series of really miserable inflation numbers."
Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund, which has dominated the general purpose fund category for the last month, continued its leading performance by reporting the best yield last week, 3.43 percent.
For the purpose of comparison, banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investor cash, are offering an average yield of 2.51 percent to depositors, down from 2.52 the previous week.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Dr. JOSEPH DUFFEY, former president of American University in Washington, who was also chancellor and president of the University of Massachusetts, is being sworn in this morning as the 13th director of the United States Information Agency. Then he will plunge immediately into the business at hand: explaining United States foreign policy by presiding over a panel discussion for U.S.I.A. employees, "A New Time: How Will America Present Itself to the World?"
The answer to that, Dr. Duffey said, will have to evolve with the times and the circumstances. 
 The agency, which will be 40 years old in August, was established at the height of the Cold War, "when propaganda characterized its intent," he said yesterday. "Now we are far less certain what our message must be, because we are having a great national dialogue ourselves and we are demonstrating that democracy is not a finished product."
Dr. Duffey, who was also chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities in the Carter and Reagan administrations, said the agency was now being called upon to project the American image on a far different global screen. "Leadership will be in the form of coalitions and partnerships, not single voices," he said. "We are no longer separated into two worlds, nor is there one flash point related to one great East-West struggle, but there are many there are many flash points and many issues."
Asked if he wasn't facing a formidable challenge, Dr. Duffey, 60, quoted the playwright Neil Simon. "You know what he says, 'If it weren't for trouble, the day would be over at 11 o'clock.' "

HEADLINE: Tougher Odds On Broadway: A special report.;
Make Money on Broadway? Break a Leg

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
On May 1 "The Will Rogers Follies" celebrated its second anniversary on Broadway. Only 4 of the 19 productions now running have been on Broadway longer. The show, winner of the 1991 Tony Award for best musical, still regularly fills three-fourths of the 1,420 available seats in the Palace Theater and on one recent week brought in more than $425,000.
A smash hit, yes? The investors are rolling in profits, right?
Well, no. "Will Rogers" is likely to close, this year or early next, without recouping the $7.5 million it cost to put on. In fact, it hasn't even come close: one major investor estimated recently that after two years he had gotten back not quite 60 percent of his money.
 
Joy With a 'But' Clause
 This weekend, as Broadway indulges in its annual self-salute and presents the Tony Awards on national television, there is much to celebrate. More than 7.5 million people spent over $300 million on Broadway tickets in the season just ended, both figures topping those of the Great White Way's much-ballyhooed revival of a year ago. And half a dozen shows are already announced for October and November, indicating a reversal of the recent fallow-fall syndrome. Seemingly, by some standards anyway, Broadway has turned off the downward economic path it traced through the 1980's. 
 Yet "Will Rogers," which may be an egregious case, is far from an isolated one. By virtually all accounts, the odds against a show making money on Broadway are greater than ever.
 
Success Isn't Money
 To wit: "Guys and Dolls," hailed as the savior of Broadway when it opened in April 1992, reached the break-even point only in mid-February. "The Secret Garden," which closed in January after a run of 20 months, never made a profit; neither did "Jerome Robbins's Broadway," which ran for nearly two years, but closed in 1991 having failed to return more than 55 percent of its initial $8 million investment. "Jelly's Last Jam," winner of three Tonys a year ago, has still not recouped its investors' money either.
Gone are the days of "My FairLady," commonly said to have cost $350,000 to put on in 1956 and to have recouped in 12 weeks; it ran for more than six years. Gone are the days of "Fiddler on the Roof," which by June 9, 1965, less than 24 weeks after it opened, had paid back its $375,000 investment, and as of last month had provided a return of 3,390 percent. Gone, even, are the days of "Annie," which cost $1 million in 1977 and has earned about $300 million since then.
 
What Raises the Costs
 The fact is that rising labor costs, the high price of big-name talent (stars such as Martin Short and Bernadette Peters of "The Goodbye Girl" and Mickey Rooney, who joins the cast of "Will Rogers" as Will's dad on July 6, may earn $20,000 a week or more), and the spectacular sets and pyrotechnical effects that are expected now by audiences but which routinely cost $1 million or more, have made Broadway shows, particularly musicals, enormously expensive. So expensive that, with occasional exceptions ("Falsettos" is one), they have to run at least a year and sometimes much more to earn back their capital investments. The result has been not only fewer shows but, many people argue, blander ones as well.
Of course, investing in theater has always been a high-risk venture; more shows topple than soar. Always have, always will.
"But with movies, if you flop, you can still sell them in Mozambique," said Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns five Broadway houses and both invests in and produces many shows. "Even horse racing has more downside protection than the theater."
 
And Low Reward
 Now, however, in addition to the high risk, the business of Broadway has also become low reward.
"The rule of thumb used to be that a musical should be able to pay back within six months," said Roger Berlind, who has produced and invested in some 20 Broadway shows since 1976. "Now the rule of thumb is a year." Mr. Berlind, whose successes include "City of Angels," which has returned about 150 percent on its original investment (a production is currently on in London), and whose failures include "Jerome Robbins's Broadway," said he's about even in the lottery; about half his shows have been moneymakers.
"People tell me that's pretty good," he said, though he added that the potential payoff is nowhere near what it used to be. "I don't think you can look for getting back 10 times your money any more," he said.
Is it any wonder that investors are scarcer than ever? "How do you tell people to invest in something that doesn't make money?" asked one entertainment lawyer who advises corporate and individual clients on theater investments. He spoke on condition of anonymity because he doesn't want his clients to know he thinks they're nuts.
Indeed, the economics have become so dicey that the business of investing has dwindled to very few hands. The proverbial Broadway angels -- people who put up some money and got out of the way -- have more or less vanished. And modest speculation by individuals interested in expanding their portfolios or thrilled by the prospect of proximate glamour has virtually disappeared; producers no longer seek out the hordes of small investors whose $1,000 or $5,000 or $10,000 checks once made up the bulk of Broadway money. After all, if a show costs $5 million, it would take a thousand $5,000-investors to put up the money.
"Used to be I had 80, 90, 100 investors in a show," said Robert Whitehead, the producer whose first Broadway show, "Medea," with Judith Anderson and John Gielgud in 1947, cost $75,000. "Now if somebody calls me and says, 'I've got $20,000 I want to put into your new show,' I say, 'Call me after I get the first million."
 
Who Pays the Piper?
The Real Business In Show Business
With the ever-vaster sums needed to put on a musical, it is not surprising that producers are turning more and more frequently to corporate backers. Corporations have helped finance the theater for decades, but now they are not necessarily seeking to profit from the Broadway run of a show. Rather they're eyeing the ancillary benefits of owning an original entertainment property.
A case in point is Polygram Diversified Entertainment, a two-year-old division of Polygram N.V., the European record company. The new division, which produces television specials and concerts as well as theater, has invested in three shows: "Jelly's Last Jam," which it is also helping produce; "The Goodbye Girl," the Neil Simon musical in which Polygram is only a financial partner, and an Off Broadway show, "CBS Live," which the company produced last fall. That one flopped.
John Scher, president of the new division, said that should "Jelly's" stay open into the fall, the investors could get back 125 percent of their money. Purely as a financial investment, he said, given the amount of time and effort that has already gone into earning that return, it stinks. Polygram's stake in "Jelly's" is $1 million, just under 20 percent.
"It certainly wouldn't be a good investment for John Scher as an individual," he said. "But for Polygram it is good. There are negotiations for a film, which Polygram has the right to produce. The cast album will far outlive the Broadway show. And then we've had the opportunity to work with some great talents -- George Wolfe, Tonya Pinkins, Savion Glover -- young talents with long careers ahead of them who now have a relationship with Polygram."
 
The Deep Pockets
 In addition to corporate backers, there remains a small band of deep-pocketed individuals who continue to invest in the theater for a living, and every veteran producer knows who they are. Among the names: Martin Richards, Terri Allen Kramer, Kenneth D. Greenblatt, Roger Horchow, Max Weitzenhoffer and Mr. Berlind. They are often the best-informed people on Broadway about projects in the works because they're asked to invest in almost every one of them.
"I call them 'the big 8,' because there's only about eight of them," said James B. Freydberg, the producer of "Fool Moon," who is about to try to raise $6 million for a musical adaptation of the film "Big."
"There are only a few of us, it's true," said Mr. Weitzenhoffer, whose investments include $500,000 in "Will Rogers" and $100,000 in loans to the show. "And the general perception is that those of us who do invest have nothing better to occupy ourselves. But the theater is a business, exactly like any other. You have to analyze every project carefully."
Mr. Weitzenhoffer, who holds a theater degree from the University of Oklahoma, said he got into the business end of the theater because he looked in the mirror one day and faced the fact that he was a lousy actor. His first venture was "Sleuth," the 1971 Tony winner, which was mounted for $150,000. Mr. Weitzenhoffer's stake was $6,000, and it was returned to him tenfold.
 
Pride Goeth
 "Then I thought I knew everything," he said, "and I promptly turned down 'Same Time, Next Year.' "
Eventually, said Mr. Weitzenhoffer, who has backed such successful ventures as "Equus," "The Elephant Man," "Mass Appeal" and "Les Miserables" (and who once lost $250,000 on a Broadway production of "Harold and Maude"), he expects to make money from "Will Rogers" because the road production of the show is proving popular and it hasn't even gone abroad yet. But he turned down the opportunity to invest in both "Guys and Dolls" ("I knew it would be a hit, but I didn't think it would be a moneymaking hit") and "Jelly's Last Jam" ("It was a terrific project, but I was concerned what would happen once Gregory Hines left. In 'Song and Dance,' when Bernadette Peters left the cast, the party was over.")
Another member of this small club is Mr. Berlind, a former Wall Street executive who became a full-time producer in 1976 simply because he had always loved the theater. He always invests in his own shows, he said, because looking after someone else's money is easier to do if you're also looking after your own. Asked about how he decides what projects to undertake, he said: "You start at the end. You try to make sure you can get everybody's money back within a certain time frame." His next project, a $4 million musical, "Paper Moon," is due on Broadway in the fall.
"It's like the stock market," Mr. Berlind said, about investing in Broadway. "The difference is you get your results immediately. And you can't get emotionally involved in securities. I mean, it is fun. Buy 100 shares of G.M. and there's no opening night party."
 
Theaters Also Invest
 A third group of investors is made up of Broadway's theater owners, which essentially means the Shubert Organization, the Nederlander Organization and Jujamcyn Theaters. The owners have been active investors for only about the last two decades. Before that, general practice was that shows were mounted on a sharing basis. Producers provided the show, putting up money for the creators, the performers, rehearsals and promotion. Theater owners invested not cash but other tangible assets: the house, the tickets and the crew. The revenues were divided, on the order of 70 percent for the producers, 30 percent for the owners.
In the early 70's, however, the Shubert Organization, then as now the largest theater owning group, adopted the system in practice in England, in which the theater owner, eschewing a portion of revenues, charges the producers rent as well as all the costs of running the theater while the show is on. Obviously, that's an increase in expenses for producers, and to help defray those costs and keep their own theaters lighted (in taxes and maintenance, a dark theater can cost an owner $15,000 to $20,000 a week), owners began to invest in shows, which they continue to do in varying degrees. (Of the three theater owners, Jujamcyn is the most aggressive investor; it also produces shows itself than the two other owning groups do.) Producers have welcomed the owners' money, of course, but it doesn't come without strings, for it ends up giving the owners added leverage in the business partnership.
 
Producers' Grumbles
 This arrangement, now commonplace, is generally disliked by producers. They say that it gives the owners an incentive to charge high fees for the use of their theaters and in effect gives the owners a guaranteed flow of cash from a show while the return to the other members of the investors' pool depends on the show's revenues.
For instance, the Nederlander Organization and the producer and investor Stewart Lane, who jointly own the Palace Theater, together have $1 million invested in "The Will Rogers Follies," and they are still some $400,000 short of recouping that investment; but for more than two years Mr. Lane and the Nederlanders have been collecting $20,000 to $30,000 a week from the producers for the use of the theater. The exact weekly figures vary because of complex formulas dependent on attendance, but the total is well over $2 million. And that doesn't count the nearly $100,000 a week it costs the producer to pay the salaries of the Nederlander employees who work in the theater. In other words, every week the producers of "Will Rogers" pay the theater owners $120,000 to $130,000 from the show's gross receipts. And after expenses, if the show makes money that week, the theater owner (as investor) gets a share of that as well.
Mr. Lane, who has had money in several shows at the Palace and is also a major investor in "The Goodbye Girl," was asked about the nature of investing in the theater these days.
"It helps if you own the theater," he said.
 
The Consequences
Blockbusters, Yes; Innovation, No
Interestingly enough, the way the Broadway economy has evolved, the percentage of shows that return their investors' money has not declined. Indeed, according to George Wachtel, director of research for the League of American Theaters and Producers, about one in three shows that have opened on Broadway in the last five years has at least broken even, a slightly higher percentage than has historically been the case. But in the two decades since inflation, labor costs and an increasing demand for spectacle on stage began to drive up production costs (and ticket prices), the number of shows has steadily diminished; 32 shows opened this season, down from 36 last year and 46 a decade ago.
Many theater professionals (and theatergoers) say the adventurousness of the whole Broadway enterprise has diminished as well. What gets onstage now, they say, is the hype-able theatrical event that can appeal to a mass audience. With the Broadway audience perceived as diminishing, the innovative show often does not find backers. Jim Freydberg, who has been producing on Broadway and Off Broadway for 20 years, said it is increasingly rare that potential investors want to read the script of a new show; instead, he said, if it has been produced elsewhere, they want to see the reviews.
"The problem with Broadway, it seems to me, is there aren't enough failures," said Robert Whitehead, who has been bringing shows to Broadway for five decades. "A lot of what we get now is 'event' theater, which has nothing to do with us, really."
The Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals, with their melodramatic stories, spectacular sets and sentimental melodies sung with operatic intensity are, of course, paradigmatic. They and others like them, shows like "Les Miserables" and "Miss Saigon," are financial juggernauts, of course, as close as Broadway has to sure things. And their producers have the luxury of keeping investors within a small favored family; shares are not offered to the public.
The difficulty of finding money for shows that would expand the Broadway horizon and return it to the days of the theatrical supermarket is especially evident with nonmusical plays. They are far less expensive than musicals, but with the exception of those written by Neil Simon and perhaps Wendy Wasserstein, they are not so attractive to Broadway theatergoers and, by extension, to investors.
"The Song of Jacob Zulu" got its financing of $1.4 million only after the creative team agreed to terms more favorable to the investors than to themselves; the show won six Tony nominations, including best play, but still closed at a huge loss after only 53 performances. "Angels in America," at $2.2 million perhaps the most expensive nonmusical ever, is still seen as a dubious venture by those who put up the money, even after the gargantuan media attention surrounding its arrival, even after the playwright, Tony Kushner, won the Pulitzer Prize, even after the sterling reviews. The producers estimate it will have to run at least a year to break even.
 
The Scramble
One Show's Fight To Find Investors
Even with musicals, though, struggling to raise money and to pay it back is the rule, not the exception. And "Will Rogers" is a case in point.
It was in 1982 that Pierre Cossette, a television producer best known for the annual Grammy Awards show, made a deal with the Rogers family, obtaining the rights to Betty Rogers's memoir to turn it into a stage show. Between then and his first backers' audition in November 1989 with the book writer, Peter Stone, joining Cy Coleman, Betty Comden and Adolph Green in performing their songs at the "21" Club, Mr. Cossette had raised $200,000 of his budget, which was then $6.25 million.
The first audition brought in another $200,000 -- from former Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon. Another audition, in January 1990, brought in $100,000. A third, on April 4, brought in, in Mr. Cossette's recollection, "not a damn thing," and another one a month later ended up the same. By that time, however, James Nederlander, the president of the Nederlander Organization, had come in for $1 million, though he wanted the show in the Gershwin Theater, which, because of its cavernous size, is more difficult to book than the Palace. Unfortunately, Tommy Tune, the director and choreographer, insisted on the Palace, and Mr. Nederlander's partner in the Palace, Stewart Lane, didn't want the show.
Finally, on Aug. 9, 1990, Mr. Cossette flew in the show's star, Keith Carradine, for a last-ditch effort at Tavern on the Green, and that, at last, did the trick. Mr. Lane changed his mind, and Japan Satellite Broadcasting, a communications conglomerate that wanted to be able to film the show for its pay-per-view network, expressed interest, though it didn't come across with a check just yet.
 
Time Runs Out
 By this time, however, things had been delayed so long that Tommy Tune was facing conflicts with other obligations, and the only way he could do the show was if it opened by the following May. Auditions for a far from fully financed show began on Nov. 1. On Nov. 15, the day before the scheduled first workshop of "Will Rogers Follies," the Japanese pitched in with $2 million; buoyed by this, Mr. Weitzenhoffer added $500,000, and a few other waffling investors finally bit the bullet. Still short, Mr. Cossette gulped and put in $1,150,000 of his own.
"We now had our $6.25 million," he said.
The rush at the end had its costs, as did the switch from the Gershwin to the Palace. Mr. Cossette said the move, the premature opening and a stepped-up advertising budget necessitated several investors' lending $1.25 million more to the production. And in addition, some 300 seats in the Palace's second balcony proved unusable because the scenery and lighting obscured the view.
"Those 300 seats are the difference between recoupment in a year and where we are now," Mr. Weitzenhoffer said.
So. The show opened. But running it, with its large cast and extravagant sets, cost the producers just under $400,000 a week, the largest "nut" of any Broadway show then running. According to figures provided by someone close to the show who insisted they be attributed to Will Rogers himself, equipment rentals and special effects alone cost more than $25,000 a week, advertising more than $50,000, salaries for the cast and crew about $130,000. Some recent frugality has brought the nut figure down a bit, to about $360,000, but that's still not low enough to guarantee a weekly profit. Over a recent four-week period, the show lost money twice; overall the profit was less than $100,000. That doesn't pay back a $7.5 million investment very quickly.
 
The Profits
The Money Comes After Broadway
Ultimately, Mr. Cossette said, largely owing to the road company of "Will Rogers," his investment will prove worthwhile. And that, too, is an indication of how the economics of Broadway have changed.
Road shows, blowing into small cities for, at most, a few weeks at a time, tend to be booked into huge auditoriums, sometimes three or four times the size of Broadway houses. One recent week at the Lyric Theater, a 2,522-seat house in Baltimore, the "Will Rogers" road show earned $446,000, or $100,000 more than the New York production did.
And because they have to travel, road productions tend to be less extravagant and less expensive than their Broadway counterparts; the road company of "Will Rogers" was financed for $4 million.
"You know how we light up all those steps in the show?" Mr. Cossette said, speaking of one particularly opulent set in the Broadway version. "Well, that costs a small fortune. We don't light them up on the road and nobody misses a thing."
 
The Up Side
 Max Weitzenhoffer said that though he regrets some of the things that happened to the Broadway production, he has no regrets about investing in "Will Rogers"; indeed, his investment on Broadway, which earns him a road royalty, also earned him an opportunity to invest directly in the road company, which he took advantage of, to the tune of $320,000.
"We'll make money," he said. "A significant change in the economics is that over the last 20 years for musicals there's now a world market." "Will Rogers," he said, is preparing to go to Japan and Canada.
"Broadway isn't where you make the money any more," Jim Freydberg said. "It's where you establish the project so you can make the money. When you mount a show now, you really have to think about where it's going to play later."
Perhaps the best summary of the situation was offered by Michael David, a partner in Dodger Productions, producers of "Guys and Dolls" and "Tommy," among others. In order to attract investors, he said, Dodger makes it a practice to consider things like merchandising, road companies and future production rights. "You have to create as many streams of income as possible; that's your job. That's the basis on which we produce a show. Broadway is just the taproot."

HEADLINE: Ballet Theater Revives, With Help From Friends

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
American Ballet Theater, which last September was close to financial collapse, announced yesterday that it had paid a $2 million bank debt and raised an additional $1 million toward a new production of "The Nutcracker" to be performed in California in early December. The company also announced the formation of "The Partnership for A.B.T.," a special fund-raising task force headed by Peter Joseph, the new president of Ballet Theater's board, and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Peter Duchin and Wilbur Ross, a senior partner at Rothschild Inc., who played a major role in saving the New-York Historical Society.
"It's not a question of survival any more," Mr. Joseph, chairman and chief executive officer of Rosecliff, a merchant banking company, said yesterday. 
 Ballet Theater started its New York season in early May with a $5.7 million deficit accumulated during the directorships of Mikhail Baryshnikov and Jane Hermann. Kevin McKenzie, a 39-year-old former principal dancer with the company, became the director in October.
 
Large Personal Loan
 In addition to the bank debt, the deficit included $1.1 million owed to venders, $2 million the company owed to its cash reserve and a $600,000 loan from Howard Gilman, chairman of the Gilman Investment Company and a major supporter of the company.
Under the terms of the loan from Mr. Gilman, Ballet Theater may not borrow more money until it has repaid him. "While some might see that as restrictive, in fact I think it will help instill increased discipline in the organization and I hope will allow us to accelerate our regular fund raising," Gary Dunning, executive director of Ballet Theater, said.
"Kevin and I wanted to move quickly," Mr. Dunning continued. "The worst message would have been that it's business as usual at Ballet Theater. The best is, 'My God, we've got a plan and we're doing it.' The banks had to be dealt with first." The bank debt, he said, was hobbling the company's fund-raising efforts and its credibility.
One tactic used by Mr. Dunning, Mr. McKenzie and Mr. Joseph, as head of the partnership, was to convert skeptical potential donors and use them to encourage giving. When Lloyd Rigler, a philanthropist in Los Angeles, made a substantial gift toward the elimination of the bank debt, 15 board members followed suit.
The payment of the bank debt was also part of a stabilization plan, Mr. Dunning said, that started with the negotiation of concessions from unions representing company employees. In one such concession, the dancers agreed to a reduction of their contractually guaranteed 36 work weeks to 26 during the current season. They also agreed to extend their contract an additional year at the same wage levels and to negotiate the number of guaranteed work weeks in 1994 should reductions be necessary.
Mr. Dunning said that there were 26 weeks of work at this point and that several tours now under discussion would add an additional six weeks. "I think we'll be able to demonstrate to the dancers a real step forward after this first season," Mr. Dunning said. "This has been a hard season for them."
He said that the dancers, whom he described as some of the company's most effective advocates, had received training in public speaking and were being enlisted in the partnership's fund-raising campaign. Four performers are members of the group. A benefit party produced by the dancers and other company personnel in March raised $100,000. (Ballet Theater's annual spring benefit last month raised over $500,000.)
Mr. Joseph said that, with the bank debt retired, the partnership would concentrate on building up the company's cash reserve, "inducing new people who care about A.B.T. to get involved," and raising money for new ballets, including "The Nutcracker," which will cost a projected $1.5 million.
 
More Time in California
 Talks are under way for an additional two-week season at the Music Center in Los Angeles after the two-week premiere engagement of "The Nutcracker" at the Orange County Performing Arts Center in Costa Mesa. The production will be staged by Mr. McKenzie with a scenario by Wendy Wasserstein. "I can speak to businessmen and art lovers about 'The Nutcracker,' " Mr. Dunning said. "It's a nice focal point."
Another talking point, he said, is that Ballet Theater seems likely to be $100,000 under its $14.6 million budget (reduced from $18 million in 1992) for the fiscal year ending on Aug. 31. Asked about ticket sales for the company's current season at the Metropolitan Opera House, where it performs through June 12, Mr. Dunning would say only that sales were "just about what we expected."
The critically acclaimed engagement features the revivals of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's "Manon," Agnes de Mille's "Three Virgins and a Devil"; works by Harald Lander, George Balanchine and Glen Tetley, and company premieres of dances by Lar Lubovitch and Christian Holder.

HEADLINE: A Deal on the Economic Plan

 BODY:
Three Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee -- David Boren of Oklahoma, Kent Conrad of North Dakota and John Breaux of Louisiana -- are threatening to hold President Clinton's economic plan hostage. Each insists that the Administration revise the plan's $70 billion energy tax that accounts for nearly a third of the total revenue increase but which threatens oil producers, farmers and manufacturers. Unless each Democrat votes yes, the plan won't clear the committee.
The White House believes it knows how to win over Senators Conrad and Breaux: Shrink and restructure the B.T.U. tax, and offset that lost revenue with additional spending cuts. But Mr. Boren's threat -- that he'll vote no unless the B.T.U. tax is dropped entirely -- is more ominous. Still, the White House holds powerful cards. With Senators Conrad and Breaux on board, Mr. Boren is unlikely to scuttle the plan and thereby single-handedly smash an already wobbly President. 
 On the merits, the White House shouldn't have to give up any of the energy tax and thus force it to squeeze investment programs. But a compromise appears necessary and tolerable. Mr. Clinton seems prepared to knock, say, $20 billion off the tax and restructure it to protect U.S. manufacturers. One way is to waive the tax on energy-intensive exports like petrochemicals and levy an offsetting tax on energy-intensive imports.
With these changes, the energy tax won't threaten U.S. businesses facing foreign competition. There are some technical problems with this solution, because export exemptions and import taxes are illegal under current trade law. If imposed unilaterally, they could interfere with completing the current round of international trade talks. But Congress has ways to impose energy taxes that do not bump up against trade agreements.
The knottier problem is deciding how to cut spending to make up for the $20 billion in lost revenues. The Finance Committee's easiest choice -- to cut Medicare, which is under its jurisdiction -- is the wrong choice. Premature pruning of Medicare would almost certainly interfere with the structure and financing of the President's health-care package, whose release is expected to be delayed until next month so that it won't get in the way of passing the budget.
The better place for the Senate to look for cuts is the President's list of discretionary programs -- even though his plan doesn't accommodate many of the useful investment initiatives promised during the campaign and, contrary to widespread belief, holds non-defense discretionary spending nearly constant.
Yet there are specific proposals -- like urban tree planting -- that could be sacrificed. And after Tuesday's senatorial election in Texas, Senate Democrats could take a fresh look at the $14 billion the Administration proposes spending on the superconducting supercollider and the space station.
Traveling to Wisconsin this week, the President heard from a generally supportive crowd the unsurprising message that voters want a smaller tax hike and the surprising one that they're willing to tolerate steeper spending cuts. The dual message provides the elbow room to meet Mr. Boren and friends halfway. Mr. Clinton can take the sting out of the energy tax without undermining his health-care initiative or backtracking on deficit reduction.

HEADLINE: Guatemala's Counter-Coup: A Military About-Face

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, June 2

 BODY:
When President Jorge Serrano Elias startled Guatemalans last week with the announcement that he was dissolving the Congress and suspending the Constitution, his seizure of power seemed to have been accomplished at a stroke. The military, which had led many coups in the past, backed his actions and not a protester appeared in public.
But on Monday, the military switched sides and ousted Mr. Serrano. Today he flew to El Salvador, and the State Department in Washington said he was expected to travel to Texas to visit his ailing mother. 
 Why Mr. Serrano launched his palace coup in the first place and to what degree he initiated it or was pushed into it by the army was never entirely clear. But the reasons for his downfall were clearer.
Most important, it seems, was the concern of business leaders that Guatemala's rising exports to the United States and Europe could be devastated if threatened sanctions were imposed. Within hours of an American threat to cut Guatemala's trade benefits, business leaders who in the past had supported authoritarian rule began pressing government and military officials to reverse Mr. Serrano's actions.
Acknowledging tacitly that political power in Guatemala has spread, the businessmen also consulted Indian leaders and unionists, university rectors and newspaper editors. All were demanding a restoration of democracy with a public vehemence to which Guatemala is unaccustomed.
 
Moves Declared Illegal
 Unlike most of the military dictators who preceded him, Mr. Serrano felt the need for a modicum of legal approval. But instead of giving the compliant responses that authoritarian actions had received in the past, the Constitutional Court declared the President's moves illegal and the electoral board rejected his plan to hold new elections for an assembly to change the Constitution.
Mostly, though, Mr. Serrano needed the military and the military wavered.
As public opposition to Mr. Serrano's move grew, commanders who initially supported the President's action kept their soldiers off the streets, leaving it to the police to control the demonstrators who challenged a ban on public assembly and the newspapers that tried to evade censorship.
According to Guatemalans close to the military, the commanders heard stronger and stronger arguments from within the officer corps that by backing Mr. Serrano the army would squander what public support it had won since accepting the return of civilian rule in 1986.
The military command never explained its initial support for Mr. Serrano. Diplomats have speculated that the generals supported the ouster of corrupt politicians and some judges, or perhaps feared for the country's stability after the President's political coalition weakened and the militancy of street protests increased.
But when the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Domingo Garcia Samayoa, began to back away publicly from Mr. Serrano on Sunday, he cited both international pressure and the need to keep the situation "from converting itself into a social explosion the consequences of which we can have no idea."
Efforts to restore democracy were thrown into confusion this afternoon when Mr. Serrano's Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero, announced that despite an earlier plan for him to resign so that a new leader could be chosen by Congress, he intended to remain as President.
General Garcia Samayoa seemed to try to distance the military further from the situation, calling Mr. Espina's move a fait accompli. But it was still not clear tonight whether the Congress would support Mr. Espina as well.
 
A March on Congress
 Even earlier, the democratic character of the political transition seemed questionable.
Though it appeared that the military made no concerted effort to take power itself, its claim to have removed the President in compliance with the orders of the Constitutional Court was somewhat absurd. The court had ruled Mr. Serrano's seizure of power unconstitutional a week before, and the military had stuck by him.
More liberal political, union and Indian leaders, including Rigoberta Menchu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, sharply criticized the way in which Mr. Serrano was removed. "It is completely clear that this is a coup d'etat against the people," Ms. Menchu said as she led a small march today on the Congress, where legislators were making no apparent progress in negotiating a promised purge of corrupt politicians before moving on to choose an interim President.
That only a few hundred people turned out for the march may have proven Miss Menchu's point rather than refuted it. From conversations with ordinary Guatemalans, that turnout seemed to have less to do with the depth of their feelings than with the fear of political activity engendered by a conflict in which more than 100,000 people are believed to have been killed.
Mr. Serrano gave a jumble of reasons for his seizure of power, including his inability to push through needed economic policies and the destabilizing effects of student and worker protests against his austerity policies.
Mr. Serrano apparently hoped that his actions would be supported above all as a step to fight the corruption that many Guatemalans say is widespread in the Congress and the courts.
Initially, at least, the Guatemalans seemed willing to face international censure. Shortly after Mr. Serrano announced his measures, an American official noted that Guatemalan military officers had defied a series of court rulings against them for human rights abuses, including cases that prompted sharp criticism from the United States. "The army has certainly been thumbing its nose at us," the official said.
 
Businessmen Are Upset
 But Mr. Serrano's measures turned out to threaten much more than international criticism and the loss of tens of millions dollars in American and European aid.
After years in which the tourism industry has boomed under civilian rule, industry officials say, planes began to arrive nearly empty last week.
More important still was the reaction from nontraditional export industries like handicrafts, vegetables and clothing, which saw sales to the United States jump from $192 million in 1990 to $335 million in 1991. Businessmen in those areas were described as especially ardent in demanding that Mr. Serrano turn back.
The breadth of the movement against Mr. Serrano was clear from the name tags that military aides had placed on the high-back chairs where Guatemalan notables were to sit for the news conference announcing the President's departure. On either side of the generals and the head of the Constitutional Court were places for the Roman Catholic archbishop, three university rectors, the Government's outspoken human rights ombudsman and Miss Menchu.
And while Miss Menchu swept angrily out of the National Palace before the news conference took place, denouncing the military's role in the coup and the survival of corrupt politicians, the ombudsman, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, said he thought it enough to have had the counter-coup observe democratic forms.
"The concern was to come up with a legal solution," Mr. de Leon Carpio said today. "I think this is the only time in Latin America that a Constitutional Court has asked the Defense Minister for help."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 5, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Thursday about the Guatemalan political crisis misstated the day of the military ouster of President Jorge Serrano Elias. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan End Talks, Sparring

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 3

 BODY:
With the United States pressing a reluctant Japan to reduce its trade surplus, officials of the two nations sought support today for their opposing positions from the governments of other leading industrial countries, with both sides claiming some success.
Japanese representatives plan to meet in Washington next Friday with Clinton Administration officials to begin negotiating a framework for trade relations. President Clinton has insisted that such a framework include a Japanese pledge to buy specific levels of American goods as a measure of progress in whittling down the $50 billion trade imbalance in Japan's favor. 
 But the Japanese used the two-day meeting here of top trade and economic officials of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to argue that the specific targets sought by Mr. Clinton are contrary to free-trade principles.
Apparently seeking to capitalize on the feeling among many nations that the Clinton Administration is more willing than the Bush Administration was to be confrontational , Japan proposed unsuccessfully that the meeting's final statement include a passage denouncing managed trade.
 
The Japanese Argument
 On Wednesday, Hajime Funada, the Japanese Economic Planning Minister, said, "Some argue that setting numerical targets is a useful way of redressing current-account imbalances, but it is almost impossible to resolve the problem in such ways."
Such an approach, he added, "is not only impossible, but leads to a way of thinking that denies the very system of the market economy itself."
American officials -- including Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; the President's trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown -- argued that Japan was, in Mr. Kantor's words, a "special case," and needed to be dealt with aggressively.
"Our friends are trying to divert attention from a serious problem," Mr. Kantor said of the emphasis on managed trade. "Clearly, the Japanese market is not as open as other markets in the industrialized world.".
In the end, the meeting produced a compromise statement that muted references both to managed trade and to Japanese trading practices.
The 24 nations pledged "to abide by and further strengthen multilateral disciplines" in world tariff talks.
They also promised to take "no recourse to initiatives and arrangements which are inconsistent with the principles of free trade and undermine the multilateral system."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
European Retaliation
 BRUSSELS, June 3 (AP) -- The European Community has threatened the United States with $15 million worth of sanctions in retaliation for a ban imposed last week on bidding for public contracts with a total value of $20 million.
A community diplomat said envoys on Wednesday approved "measures against the United States" that are similar to the American sanctions. The European measures must be approved by community foreign ministers, who will meet on June 8.
In addition, Bloomberg Business News reported, European representatives have asked Japan to reopen car-import talks, with the aim of setting still lower limits in view of of a sharp drop in European makers' sales.

PRISONER'S DEATH RULED A HOMICIDE
An epileptic prisoner who died in police custody at a Manhattan hospital was beaten to death while he was lying face down with his wrists manacled behind him and unable to breathe adequately, the New York City Medical Examiner said. He ruled the death a homicide. A1.

Unemployment among New York City's teen-agers rose to 40 percent in the first three months this year, the city says. That is nearly double the rate of two years ago and the worst in the 25 years that records have been kept. A1.

A suspended Episcopal priest says that he intends to go on a hunger strike at the diocese office until Bishop Richard F. Grein meets with him to discuss the suspension. His supporters also vowed to continue their protests until he is reinstated to his Mott Haven church. B2.

A man has been sentenced to barely a month's time in jail, to be served on weekends, for his role in the death of an artist in a Greenwich Village street fight in 1991. The sentence drew angry responses from the victim's friends, who have assailed the handling of the case. B2.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ex-Chief of Sunbeam Files $3.2 Billion Suit

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The former chairman of the Sunbeam-Oster Company, Paul B. Kazarian, filed a $3.2 billion lawsuit yesterday against his investment partners in the consumer products company, Michael Price and Michael Steinhardt.
In the suit, filed in Rhode Island Superior Court, Mr. Kazarian contended that he had been the victim of a conspiracy that led to his ouster from the company, based in Providence, R.I., in January. He also contended that he had been denied the earnings he was owed and that the partners had attempted to smear his reputation. 
 Mr. Price's office was closed last night, and Mr. Steinhardt did not return a telephone call yesterday.
The suit is the latest, and certainly the biggest, volley in a legal and public-relations battle waged between Mr. Kazarian and the company he once ran as chairman, chief executive and president. His dismissal in January was unexpected, particularly because Mr. Kazarian was widely credited with turning around the company, the former Allegheny International, after it was brought out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 1990 as Sunbeam-Oster.
Since January, Mr. Kazarian and Sunbeam-Oster executives have been contending they were victims of the other's actions. Mr. Kazarian contends there was a conspiracy to remove him from the company, and thereby eliminate his veto power over key decisions and deny him the millions of dollars he says he is owed. The company counters that it was forced to remove an erratic and irrational boss who threatened to damage the company's value for shareholders.
Several legal actions between the various parties are pending. Shares of Sunbeam-Oster rose 25 cents yesterday, to $16.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In the suit, Mr. Kazarian charged that Mr. Price and Mr. Steinhardt and investment funds they controlled "regularly sought economic gains for themselves contrary to their fiduciary duties to Sunbeam."
For example, the suit contended that in the winter of 1991, Mr. Price, who at the time was a director and major shareholder of R. H. Macy & Company, put pressure on Mr. Kazarian to have Sunbeam-Oster "extend favorable terms" in its sales to Macy despite the fact that Macy was on the verge of filing for bankruptcy protection.
The suit also cited Mr. Kazarian's theory for why his partners wanted to remove him from the company: that their partnership agreement locked up Mr. Price's and Mr. Steinhardt's investment, and that their respective investment portfolios are under financial pressures that would be relieved by selling part of their stakes in Sunbeam.
He also repeated earlier contentions that certain Sunbeam executives conspired to drive him from the company because their employment contracts were not going to be renewed, and they would therefore lose valuable stock options.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise by 5,000

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The number of newly laid-off workers who filed claims for jobless benefits rose by 5,000 last week, an indication of what analysts said was a lackadaisical labor market.
"It seems to be basically more of the same," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "We're locked in a claims level which is consistent with job growth, but unsatisfactory job growth." 
 New applications for unemployment insurance totaled 344,000 last week, up from a revised total of 339,000 during the week ended May 22, the Labor Department said today. The department had originally said first-time claims were 340,000 for the earlier week.
Mr. Dederick said the unemployment rate would probably remain at 7 percent in May for the fourth straight month, though it could rise to 7.1 percent as students entered the job market. The department was scheduled to release the May employment report on Friday.
