HEADLINE: Hard-Hit Military Contractors Plead for Loans

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 3

 BODY:
With economists predicting continued decline for Long Island's military industry, a group representing more than 100 Defense Department subcontractors yesterday implored Federal and state officials to help them find the money to convert their companies to peacetime operations.
Without an infusion of cash, in the form of low-cost loans from banks and Government agencies, small and medium-sized companies that have long depended on military contracts will be unable to compete for commercial contracts and will close their doors, leaders of the newly formed group say. They say that during the last 18 months Long Island subcontractors seeking commercial business would have won $500 million in contracts if they had had the money to finance startup work. 
 Leaders of the organization -- with the unwieldy name of the Aerospace and Defense Diversification Alliance in Peacetime Transition -- said that it was formed to provide a forum for the vast network of subcontractors on Long Island and throughout New York that has flourished in the margins of military production.
The companies make everything from landing gear for jets to medical supplies for ground troops, and the subcontractors say their businesses have been hard hit by the military cuts of the last several years.
 
More Losses Forecast
 Long Island, home to the Grumman Corporation, a major manufacturer of military aircraft, has seen its military industry decline markedly in the last several years as a result of Pentagon cutbacks in weapons procurement and other programs. In 1985, for example, Defense Department contracts to Long Island companies totaled $5.28 billion; last year, the amount had dropped to $2.86 billion, said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
From 1985 to 1991, Dr. Kamer said, the state of New York lost 29,000 military-related jobs, with about half the losses occurring on Long Island. In the next four years, she said, the state could lose an additional 45,000 to 60,000 military-related jobs as a result of anticipated budget cuts.
"I think we see a continued downsizing through most of this decade," Dr. Kamer said.
Large and small companies that do business with the military are trying to offset the losses by moving more aggressively into commercial fields, like civil aviation. But some subcontractors -- companies that have relied on major military contractors like Grumman to pass on work to them -- say that while they have the technology and the personnel to compete, they lack the money. The Government, they say, kept them afloat by paying as the work went on, while commercial contracts typically pay upon delivery.
Greg Frisby, chief executive officer of Frisby Airborne Hydraulics Inc. of Freeport and head of the new group, said small and medium-sized companies must have a financial cushion to survive the transition. Today, at a news conference with the Nassau and Suffolk County Executives and four of the five members of the Long Island Congressional delegation, Mr. Frisby said local companies need about $200 million in loans to secure about $1 billion in commercial contracts.
 
Doing Commercial Work
 "Without access to low-cost working capital, a portion of New York's aerospace and defense-manufacturing base will find themselves facing two undesirable options: going out of state or going out of business," Mr. Frisby said at the news conference, at an aviation museum at Mitchel Field, the airfield where Charles A. Lindbergh took off in 1927 on his trans-Atlantic flight.
Mr. Frisby said his company, which employs 70 people and produces hydraulic systems for Boeing, Lockheed and other aircraft manufacturers, had depended on military contracts for 90 percent of its business until the mid-1980's, when another major Long Island aircraft maker, Fairchild-Republic, went out of business. His company survived, and today 75 percent of its work is nonmilitary.
Marc Finkelstein, another organizer of the subcontractor group, heads a company in Garden City that makes heat exchangers, a kind of radiator for jet and other engines. His company, too, has converted in the last few years from mostly military to mostly commercial work. But Mr. Finkelstein said that while he has $75 million in commercial contracts pending over the next decade, he has no cash on hand and has a hard time persuading banks to lend him money.
"We've made the conversion," he said. "The bad news is, we're broke." Like other subcontractors, he wants the Government to encourage banks to offer low-cost, long-term loans to the industry to allow it to expand. "We're not looking for a handout," he said. "We're looking for assistance."
State and Federal officials who attended the news conference said there were some financial initiatives and loan programs that could help the businessmen, but most were modest. Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, a Democrat from Coram, said that a $500 million Federal program to provide grants for new technologies had received requests for financing totaling $6 billion.

HEADLINE: Daily News to Shift Printing to Jersey City

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
New Jersey state officials and the owner of The Daily News said yesterday that the newspaper would replace plants in Brooklyn and Kearny, N.J., with one in Jersey City.
The planned move, to a Clorox plant, ends a heated battle between New York and New Jersey for the plant's 1,600 jobs. The decision is a victory for New Jersey and its Governor, Jim Florio, in an election year in which jobs are an important issue. 
 "I think New York made a serious effort," said Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News. "But we were able to find an existing building at an extremely competitive price, and that meant that we could not only avoid construction costs but also complete it a year earlier."
Governor Florio of New Jersey said in a statement that he was pleased by the announcement. But Mayor David N. Dinkins reacted bitterly, issuing a statement accusing New Jersey of using its share of rents from the World Trade Center "to finance a bidding war for these jobs." Through the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the two states share income from the center.
"In effect, lock, stock and barrel, the State of New Jersey bought The Daily News printing operation by providing a $35 million cash grant and full financing," he said. And he said that he was "very disappointed to learn that New York's hometown newspaper has decided to move its printing plant to the suburbs."
The Daily News announcement and Mayor Dinkins's sharp reaction made it clear that a so-called regional nonaggression pact dating to October 1991 was dead. New York State, New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut agreed at that time not to try to lure companies from the others.
 
No Specifics
 New Jersey state officials and Mr. Zuckerman refused to discuss the specifics of yesterday's deal, and Mr. Florio's statement said the Economic Development Authority was still developing "a financing structure."
A New Jersey official involved in the talks said that the financing package was likely to include a bond issue. Despite Mayor Dinkins's assessment, this official said that out-of-pocket cost to New Jersey would probably be less than $10 million.
Steve Villano, a spokesman for Vincent Tese, New York State's Commissioner of Economic Development, said New York was not prepared to match New Jersey's offer, which he characterized as "very generous."
He declined to discuss specifics but said: "If we feel that what's being asked is more than what we can afford, and if what's being asked per job is more than will benefit the state or the city, we say, 'This far we go, but prudence dictates that we can't go beyond that.' That was the case here."
The Daily News negotiations were the most recent in a series of talks over economic benefit packages intended to keep major companies in New York, including a deal with The New York Times last year to grant tax incentives, low-cost energy and other benefits worth a total of $29 million over the course of a 35-year lease to build a new printing plant in Queens.
The Daily News plans to consolidate its printing, which is now done at plants at Brooklyn and Kearny, N.J., that cannot handle four-color production. Another Daily News plant at Garden City, L.I., has not been in use for several years. The eventual fate of the Brooklyn plant was not disclosed.
The agreement to purchase the 251,000-square-foot Clorox building on 20 acres is contingent on engineering and environmental issues, the company's news release said, adding that closing on the sale is expected within in 90 days.
Mr. Zuckerman said he expected the plant to be working early in 1995. Clorox has previously announced that it expects to shut down its operations there by October of this year.
 
Split From Coliseum Issue
 The decision apparently signals that the question of the Daily News plant site has been disconnected from the issue of the New York Coliseum, which Mr. Zuckerman has an option to use as a development site. There have been reports over the past several months that the issue of a package of incentives to keep the printing plant in New York was closely intertwined with Mr. Zuckerman's eight-year-old plan to build a new development on the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle, a proposal that has been beset by court challenges and the decline in the New York City real-estate market.
While Mr. Zuckerman still has an option to build an office building on the Coliseum site, it is clear that building now would be folly because of the weak market. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the buildings on the site, has collected proposals for an interim rental use of the site.
The M.T.A. has been interviewing those who submitted eight or nine of the 14 proposals with an eye to drawing up a short list of top contenders, M.T.A. officials said yesterday. Mr. Zuckerman's letter of credit, which serves as a down payment on the site, expires at the end of the month, and must be collected or renegotiated before then.
Asked yesterday about that issue, Mr. Zuckerman said, "I have nothing to say about the Coliseum but I hope to by the end of this month."

HEADLINE: YOUTH JOBLESSNESS IS AT RECORD HIGH

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Unemployment among New York City's teen-agers rose to 40 percent in the first three months this year, the city said yesterday. It was nearly double the rate of two years ago and the worst in the 25 years that records have been kept.
The sharp increase indicated that the long recession has had an especially severe impact on young job seekers. "Our young people used to be on the bottom of the list -- now they are not even on the list," said John Bess, executive director of the Manhattan Valley Youth Program, a nonprofit group that helps teen-agers find work. 
 In a city where teen-agers have always had greater difficulty finding work than their peers elsewhere, the recession has deepened the disparity. The rate of joblessness for New York City teen-agers is now more than double the national average of 19.6 percent.
The report, issued by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, covered teen-agers aged 16 to 19. It gave no separate figures for minority youths. Their jobless rate has consistently run far higher than that of white youths, however, and Ms. Holtzman's staff said they had no reason to conclude that the wide difference among races had narrowed.
 
Few Entry-Level Opportunities
 Experts attributed the young job seekers' plight in part to rigid new hiring constraints, imposed by many employers here and elsewhere, which have all but eliminated entry-level job opportunities. Instead of hiring newcomers, the employers are demanding more work and longer hours of employees already on their rolls.
The recession has worsened other barriers faced by teen-agers, but they are not expected to disappear when the economy improves, the experts said. Among them are the huge wave of immigration to the city, which has put thousands of adults in competition for work with young people, and the increasing technical sophistication required of all workers, from the mail room to the board room.
The 40 percent rate compared with a 9.6 percent overall rate in March, which increased to 9.8 percent in April. For all workers, the unemployment rate failed to provide a full picture of the problem of joblessness, because many frustrated job seekers simply stop looking and therefore are no longer counted as part of the labor force.
At City Hall, officials said the report prompted fears about the social stability of the city, as well as its economy.
"Kids are waiting for these jobs, and their expectations are high," said Josephine Nieves, the Commissioner of the Department of Employment. "At some point you have to tell them the jobs are not there, and it could lead to a volatile situation."
In its report, the city said the unemployment rate for teen-agers had risen almost steadily since 1987, when it stood at 17.9 percent, at that point only a shade above the national average. It said the rate had risen most rapidly since a year ago, when it stood at 30 percent.
The study derived its data from surveys by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics released earlier in the year, which it adjusted for seasonal variations.
Although precise comparisons were not available, the report said that New York's youth unemployment would put it in close contention with Detroit for the unhappy distinction of having the nation's bleakest joblessness among young people.
The dire turn in unemployment comes amid setbacks for large summer jobs programs, which have been sponsored for years by both the city and private companies but seem certain to provide fewer jobs this summer than they have in past years.
 
Program Cut Back
 The city's program, which last year provided 52,000 summer jobs in government agencies, all at the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour, has been scaled back because Federal financing has been reduced. Ms. Nieves said the program will provide no more than 39,000 summer jobs this year, far too few to accommodate the 100,000 teen-age applicants expected.
A separate summer jobs program, administered by the New York City Partnership, a business group, created 42,500 jobs at private companies last year. But because of cutbacks at many of the same companies that have participated, "there are going to be significantly fewer" jobs available this summer, said Nelson Smith, vice president of the business group.
Analysts in Ms. Holtzman's office said that 25 percent of the city's 373,000 teen-agers 16 to 19 years old were counted as part of the labor force in the first three months of the year, meaning that they were either employed or looking for work.
This figure means that the young people were a tiny minority in the city's labor pool of 3.58 million workers and job seekers.
 
An Expanding Pool
 One encouraging finding was that more teen-agers have been looking for work -- only 22 percent of the 16 to 19 years had sought employment in 1992. But despite their efforts, fewer succeeded in the first three months of this year.
The soaring unemployment rate "clearly wiped out" the benefits of an expanding pool of job seekers, said John Tepper Marlin, the chief economist on Ms. Holtzman's staff.
"Big companies are lopping off their support staffs, and they are not willing to make commitments" to teen-agers or other new entry-level job seekers, he added.
For decades young New Yorkers people have faced a tough market for part-time and entry-level work, particularly when compared with teen-agers in the suburbs, smaller cities and rural America.
One reason is the city's vast scale and the centralized pattern of its employment. Where teen-agers elsewhere walk, ride bicycles or drive to after-school and summer jobs, many of New York's young people, living far from Manhattan, downtown Brooklyn and other job centers, have to endure long subway commutes to work.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mostly Lower, With Dow Off 8.58

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market was mostly lower yesterday in seemingly heavy trading. But much of the volume came from two big active issues -- Hanson P.L.C. and the initial public offering of the Allstate Corporation.
The two stocks accounted for one-fourth of yesterday's Big Board volume of 285.6 million shares. In contrast, 295.6 million shares were traded on Wednesday. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 8.58 points, to 3,544.87. But the Dow Jones transportation average fell sharply, losing 26.89 points, to 1,577.44. The transport average was dragged down mainly by seven stocks falling 1 3/8 points or more.
 
Market's Biggest Decliners
 The two big decliners were Federal Express and Burlington Northern. Federal Express, the air transport company, closed down 3 3/4, to 46 1/8, after the sudden defection of two top executives and the consequent downgrading of investment recommendations by analysts. Federal Express investors are nervous about management instability in a company whose prospects are tied to an uncertain economy.
Burlington Northern, the rail company, closed down 2 3/4, to 51, after reports that coal and grain traffic in May were leveling off.
Broader market indicators also declined, and there were signs that some traders were reluctant to buy stocks in advance of today's Government report on employment in May. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 1.36 points, to 452.49. The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.68 point, to 249.59. Declining stocks outnumbered gainers by 1,000 to 881.
But the Nasdaq composite index, with more than 3,500 smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, gained 0.36 point, to 706.22. And the American Stock Exchange market value index closed up 0.94 point, to 440.91 for the second consecutive record-breaking day.
 
Strong Demand for Allstate
 The biggest story of the day was the unsurprisingly strong demand for the initial public offering of Allstate by Sears, Roebuck & Company. Allstate was the second-most-active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, at 28.3 million shares, closing at 29 3/8 in its first day of trading.
The most active stock was Hanson P.L.C., a diversified holding company in Britain, with 44.7 million shares. Hanson's volume neared the volume for Royal Dutch/Shell with 45 million shares traded in a single day.
Like Shell, Hanson is in the middle of a gigantic dividend play among large investors, in which mostly institutional buyers seek to minimize their tax bills by either buying or selling the stock shortly after the ex-dividend date. The American depository receipts of Hanson closed down 1/8, to 18.
Retail stocks, especially Dayton Hudson, saw their shares fall over concern with the sluggish economy in general and sluggish retail sales in May in particular. Dayton Hudson, a big department-store chain, reported same-store sales that disappointed analysts. It closed down 3 1/4, to 66 1/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Just a Bit Higher

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices were only marginally higher yesterday as the bond market awaited today's employment report for May.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 6/32 point, to 10312/32 , as the yield fell to 6.86 percent, from 6.87 percent Wednesday and the lowest it has been since May 12. 
 The biggest change in the bond market since then is that short-term interest rates have risen sharply. The higher rates followed reports that the Federal Reserve had shifted its policy to a bias toward higher interest rates because of rising inflation in the first four months of the year.
 
 
Yield Curve
 This means that the yield curve -- the difference between the yield on short-term and long-term maturities -- has narrowed sharply. On May 12, the yield on the 2-year Treasury note was 3.79 percent and the yield on the 30-year bond was 6.85 percent, for a spread of 306 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
By yesterday, the yield on the two-year note had jumped to 4.13 percent, cutting the spread to 273 basis points. That is just five basis points from the low for the year of 268 on May 27, when the yield on the 30-year bond was at 6.92 and the yield on the two-year note was 4.24 percent.
The sharp narrowing of the yield curve has given many traders a chance to make big profits. They do this by selling shorter-term securities, like the two-year note, and buying longer term securities. But this has been a hard bet to make because the spread has bounced around so much.
 
 
Looking for Clues
 In today's employment report, the market will be looking for clues as to how fast the economy was growing in the second month of the second quarter. Figures for the first quarter, which was extremely week, and for April show that the economy is growing but only sluggishly.
If today's data confirm that trend, there may be more room for long-term yields to fall further. And if the inflation data due out over the next two weeks are also subdued, then yields might have a chance of moving to new lows. But that development will probably also depend on the outlook for President Clinton's deficit reduction plan in the Senate. Although the prospects for the plan have improved recently, there is still a chance that it could quickly run into new trouble.
Forecasters are not exactly sure what to expect in today's employment data, with predictions for the increase in nonfarm jobs ranging from 55,000 to 225,000.
What might add some confusion to the interpretation of the jobs data today is that the Labor Department will be revising its old data as well. It is expected that these revisions will add about 25,000 jobs to the monthly data back to April 1992.
 
 
Municipal Bonds
 The New York State Dormitory Authority yesterday sold about $780 million of bonds as prices in the tax-exempt municipal market were little changed. The pricing of the issue is tentative, with both the final size and structure subject to some changes, according to the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The dormitory issue, which is for the refinancing of old higher interest rate debt for the City University of New York, was increased in size by about $100 million.
Robert Culnane, a vice president in the municipal bond department at Goldman, Sachs, said the size of the issue was enlarged because tax-exempt interest rates were a little lower than anticipated. This created more room to pay off more old bonds because the gap widened between the old interest rate levels and the rates on the refinancing bonds. When this gap widens, more old bonds become eligible for refinancing.
Under the tentative pricing, the yields on the issue were from 5.15 percent for bonds due in July 1999, 5.6 percent for bonds due in 2003 and 6.05 percent for bonds due in 2020. The taxable equivalent yield for these bonds at the current top tax rate of 31 percent is 7.46 percent, 8.12 percent and 8.77 percent, respectively.
 
 
Corporate Bonds
 TheChrysler Financial Corporation capped a busy day in the corporate market with a $1.2 billion asset-backed deal. The First Boston Corporation was the lead manager.
The certificates, backed by car and light-truck loans, are being sold to the public in four classes, with $252 million of the class A-1 priced to yield 3.375 percent. This class has an average life of 0.44 year and is rated P1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A-1+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A $403 million issue of class A-2 certificates with an average life of 1.34 years was priced to pay a floating rate of 15 basis points above the one-month London interbank offered rate, or Libor, and is rated triple-A by the rating agencies.
For $497 million of triple-A rated class A-3 certificates, with an average life of 3.09 years, the yield at pricing was 4.973 percent, while $48 million of class B certificates with an average life of 2.37 years and rated A-3 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P., was priced to yield 5.22 percent.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Plans More Cuts To Fill $280 Million Gap

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
All but giving up hope that New York City would receive much of the state and Federal aid they had been seeking, senior aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday presented their most dire view yet of the city's fiscal condition.
They said they would now be forced to cut city spending by $280 million in the next fiscal year, including scaling back by half the 8,000 workers they had planned to hire. The spending plan that Mr. Dinkins presented last month called for a net increase of 1,500 workers during the next year; officials now expect to shrink the work force. 
 Since January, many City Council members and independent fiscal experts have been saying that the Mayor's hopes for additional aid were unrealistic and that he would inevitably be forced to cut services drastically. But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel argued yesterday that the administration had been right to try to seek all possible aid before turning to painful budget cuts.
 
Dashed Expectations
 The $31.4 billion budget proposed by Mr. Dinkins last month included the expectation of an extra $280 million in aid from the state and an additional $250 million in Federal aid. The Mayor and the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, have visited Albany several times in recent weeks to seek aid. Advisers to the Mayor and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have also met many times, often with legislative staff members.
The announcement by Mr. Steisel and Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, that the Dinkins administration would have to cut spending more severely than previously planned, and in the middle of a mayoral election year, served to kick off the final round of budget negotiations between the Mayor and the Council.
By law, the Council is required to approve the spending plan for the fiscal year that begins July 1 by tomorrow. The Council usually has extended the deadline in previous years, and yesterday all signs pointed toward another extension. But Council leaders and senior mayoral aides said they hoped to reach agreement on final details of the budget by late this weekend or early next week.
 
Less Than Hoped For
 While the city was seeking an additional $280 million in state aid, In the end, the negotiations have produced only $80 million to $100 million in new state aid, Mr. Jones said yesterday during a hastily called news conference in his tiny City Hall office. The Mayor and his aides have decided that they will have to cut spending to make up for the $180 million in state aid that they now think will not be received, he said.
City officials now say that they are likely to come up $100 million short of the $250 million in additional Federal aid that they have been seeking, he said. That, too, will be made up by spending cuts.
Where to make the reductions will now be the subject of private negotiations between the Mayor and Council leaders. Mr. Steisel said that talks between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone would probably begin today.
Mr. Jones said the Mayor would try to save $50 million by cutting in half the number of people he had planned to hire during the next fiscal year.
Previously announced efforts to hire new police officers and new teachers will not be affected by the partial freeze, but hiring in virtually all other city agencies will be, Mr. Steisel said. The Mayor hopes to avoid layoffs but cannot rule them out, Mr. Jones said.
Details of the hiring freeze and details of other spending reductions have not been worked out. Mr. Dinkins proposed a contingency list of $176 million in service cuts in his spending plan last month, including reductions in day care, summer school and drop-in centers for the homeless.
Preliminary talks between mayoral aides and Council staff members have produced tentative agreement on $55 million in spending cuts, Mr. Jones said. He declined to disclose details.
A few hours before the Mayor's aides announced the broad decisions reached in private meetings with Mr. Dinkins yesterday at Gracie Mansion, a senior member of the Council told reporters that local lawmakers had abandoned hope of getting much more help from Albany.
Councilman Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Finance Committee, said the Council's staff had presented the administration with a list of $350 million in spending cuts. Mr. Berman said he and other Council leaders believed that the potential budget gap caused by the city's inability to win more aid in Albany and Washington was larger than the administration's projections.
The Mayor has been criticized by some fiscal experts and his political opponents in recent weeks for failing to act decisively to deal with the uncertainties in his spending plan for the next fiscal year. Since January Mr. Berman and many other fiscal experts have contended that Mr. Dinkins's hopes for additional aid from Albany and Washington were unrealistic, and that when the aid did not materialize, he would be forced to cut services to balance the budget.
But Mr. Steisel said that it had made sense to seek the additional help, and he argued that, until Senate Republicans balked at President Clinton's economic stimulus plan, it had been realistic to hope that New York would receive $250 million in additional Federal aid.
"It made a lot of sense to go after it," Mr. Steisel said. "I think reality has now set in on a number of fronts."
"I think this shows that we have a very difficult circumstance and that we're willing to make tough decisions," he said.
Several fiscal experts warned that there were enough other uncertainties built into the Mayor's spending plan that additional cuts might be required later.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Higher as Trading Slows Ahead of Jobs Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar meandered higher against most major foreign currencies in quiet trading yesterday ahead of the Government's release of employment statistics for May.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 107.25 yen, up from late Wednesday's 107.15 yen. The dollar also rose to 1.6003 German marks, up from 1.5975 marks. But the British pound edged up to $1.5438, from $1.5405 on Wednesday. 
 Economists expect today's employment report to show that nonfarm payroll jobs rose 55,000, to 225,000, in May. Typically, an increase substantially more than expectations would signify economic strength and help push up the dollar.
 
Attention Is on Inflation
 But some analysts said the currency markets were focusing less than usual on the monthly employment numbers after the Federal Reserve's decision last month to raise interest rates in the future, if need be, to help check inflation. That is diverting more attention to May inflation figures, scheduled to be issued beginning next week.
Higher interest rates would help lure more investors to dollar-denominated investments, thus increasing the dollar's value.
"Unless we get a significant aberration from market expectations, I don't see anything significant happening tomorrow," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "All eyes are toward next week's numbers to see what inflation looks like, in terms of the Fed's next move."
In early trading yesterday, the currency markets focused on rumors of interest rate changes. David Gilmore, a currency analyst with MCM Inc., said there were unconfirmed rumors around midmorning in New York that the British Government planned to cut a key short-term interest rate by one percentage point. That briefly helped the dollar gain against the British pound.
But there was little reaction to an announcement by Germany's central bank that it did not cut its discount rate, also a key short-term rate. The announcement was expected.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Jumps $5.40 an Ounce, But a Big Rally Is Doubted

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices jumped more than $5 an ounce yesterday, but analysts said the rebound from this week's steep losses lacked the broad-based buying that recently pitched gold to a 28-month high.
"The oomph of this rally was not as strong as some of the earlier rallies we've seen in the metal," said Martin Reichenberg, manager of trading services for Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. 
 Other precious and industrial metals, including cooper, also rose sharply.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded contract for gold for August delivery rose $5.40 an ounce, to $376.20.
The Commodity Exchange estimated total trading volume in gold at about 43,600 contracts. That would be less than Tuesday's volume of 67,400, when gold sank as much as $9 an ounce, and far below the 91,000 contracts traded on the last big rally, on May 27, when June gold climbed $6.10.
The market had been in a slide since reaching $384.50, a 28-month high, last Friday.
"We've had a very sharp downward move and I think today's action was just a correction within that," Mr. Reichenberg said.
 
 
'Buying on the Dips'
 Stephen W. Platt of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said gold was still attractive to speculators. "I still get the impression that people are buying on the dips, and this was the kind of dip they were looking for," he said.
Mr. Reichenberg said the market would probably bounce between the recent high and low for several weeks, barring a recurrence of the inflation fears that underpinned the spring rally.
Traders will be looking for new signs of inflation in Government reports on May producer prices on June 11 and on May consumer prices on June 15.
Among other metals, copper jumped to a five-week high, with July copper gaining 2.8 cents, to 84.2 cents a pound, on the Commodity Exchange. Mr. Platt said the rally in copper was touched off by talk of Chinese buying in London and by auto makers' reports of strong sales in late May.
Meanwhile, July silver surged 9 cents, to $4.458 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange; July platinum leaped $8.90, to $392.60 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Elsewhere, gasoline led oil futures lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a petroleum industry report showed abundant gasoline stocks. Light sweet crude oil for July delivery fell 29 cents, to $19.74 a barrel; July heating oil fell 0.61 cent, to 54.19 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline fell 1.26 cents, to 57.07 cents a gallon, and July natural gas rose 0.06 cent, to $2.114 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: 3 Candidates Striving to Leave No Republican Unturned

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 3

 BODY:
Jim Wallwork came here to greet noontime shoppers and noshers around the Morristown Green today at a campaign stop that showed the difficulties of winning votes in the Republican primary for governor.
He shook the hands of Democrats. He shook the hands of independents. He even shook the hands of a few of New Jersey's 799,000 Republicans, who make up only about 20 percent of the state's 3.9 million registered voters. 
 Since only 350,000 of those Republicans and a handful of the state's undeclared voters are expected to pick the candidate who will face Gov. Jim Florio in the fall, Mr. Wallwork's campaign effort was more a media event than a serious search for voters, but it is a tradition, and the West Point graduate and businessman approached it with relish.
 
Mixed Results
 His first two contacts met with mixed results. Lorie Spohn of Morristown, a member of the Morris County Human Relations Commission, said that she was a Democrat but that if she were a Republican she would vote for Mr. Wallwork.
After the encounter Ms. Spohn said she was going to vote for Mr. Florio because of his fight to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the state and because "he's done a lot of good."
Guy De Torrice of North Brunswick, who was making a delivery to a store opposite the park, told Mr. Wallwork he would vote for him after the candidate identified himself as a "conservative businessman," the phrase that has been at the heart of Mr. Wallwork's campaign.
"Only conservatives are true Americans," Mr. De Torrice said. He said he would vote for Mr. Wallwork on Tuesday, and in November if he has the chance, "no matter what."
Mr. De Torrice said later that he had no use for any liberal, with one exception: "Ed Koch. I like him."
 
Going to the Air
 After spending about an hour in the park or in front of the stores that frame it, Mr. Wallwork left to do what his two opponents for the nomination, Christine Todd Whitman and Cary Edwards, were doing: preparing to tape a television program that will be broadcast on Sunday.
While the campaigns sharpened plans to get out their supporters on Tuesday, their final mailings and television and radio ads were aimed at swaying the undecided voters that Mr. Edwards and Mr. Wallwork hope will enable them to defeat Mrs. Whitman, who started the campaign as a strong front-runner.
The Edwards campaign started running a radio spot today that features the voice of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, praising Mr. Edwards when he left the administration in 1988 after serving as Attorney General. The Whitman campaign said it was a thinly veiled attempt to make it appear that the popular former Governor was endorsing Mr. Edwards's candidacy.
Mr. Kean, the president of Drew University in Madison, said in a telephone interview that the Edwards campaign called him about using a recording of his remarks.
 
It's History
 "I told them anything I said on the record remains on the record, but I wanted it made clear that the remarks were made some time ago," he said. "I haven't endorsed anyone in this primary.
"I've also said some nice things about Christie Whitman and I have no objections to her using them as long as it is, again, made clear when they were said," he said.
The former Governor also criticized the television ads he seen from both the Edwards and Whitman campaigns, calling many of them negative and "inaccurate and unfair."
"At best some of the ads are exaggerations, at worst some are outright lies and I think the public knows it and doesn't want to hear it," he said. "The public wants to know what the candidates plan to do to lower the state's unemployment rate, which is the highest in the Northeast and probably the highest of any industrial state in the country."
He expressed concern that the ads would set the stage for Governor Florio's campaign strategist, James Carville, who, according to Mr. Kean, "has never been known to run a positive ad."
 
Has the Race Tightened?
 While Mr. Kean expressed his dismay at the tenor of the campaign, Mr. Edwards found something positive in Mrs. Whitman's recent ad comparing his record with Mr. Florio's when it comes to raising taxes and increasing state budgets. The ad concludes there is "not a dime's worth of difference" between the two. Mr. Edwards said that the Whitman campaign had begun running attack ads aimed at him proves that the race has tightened.
Mr. Edwards talked of a telephone survey of 5,000 likely Republican voters that his campaign conducted in Morris County on March 31. He said the survey showed that Mrs. Whitman had the support of 24.7 percent of the sample, he had 20.26 percent and Mr. Wallwork had 8.89 percent. The rest of the voters surveyed were undecided.
Mr. Wallwork this week talked of "soundings" of voters that convince him he will capture the nomination by a narrow margin over Mrs. Whitman by winning more than 40 percent of the vote with Mr. Edwards trailing badly. The only constant in the two self-serving reports is that Mrs. Whitman is the candidate to beat.
David Murray, Mrs. Whitman's campaign director, declined to discuss the campaign's tracking of his candidate's support but he said reports that her lead is slipping were untrue.
"She started as the front-runner when she announced and was endorsed by all six counties that held conventions to decide who to support, and nothing has changed," he said.
He said the television ad that got Mr. Edwards's attention used themes that will be emphasized in both the primary and general election, since taxes and spending are issues in both races. "We wanted to kill two birds with one stone," he said.
He also said Mrs. Whitman wanted to send a message to her opponents that she will not allow them to distort her record without a response.
"We want this to be an object lesson to Mr. Florio's attack-oriented campaign consultant that, beyond a shadow of a doubt, when faced with a slash and burn campaign, we will respond in kind," Mr. Murray said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Thermo Electron bucks the slow growth in environment services.

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
THE recent recession proved that the environmental services industry is not recession proof. In a downturn, companies with environmental liabilities can find ways to procrastinate before hiring someone to clean up their mess, even though the cleanup may be dictated by government regulation.
According to the Environmental Business Journal, a newsletter that reports on the industry, revenue growth last year was 3.9 percent, an improvement over the 2.1 percent rate of 1991, but well below the double-digit growth of the mid- to late-1980's. 
 Grant Ferrier, the editor of the newsletter, said the slow growth of the last two years did not mean there was pent-up demand building for environmental goods and services. Although much will depend on how rigorously the Clinton Administration enforces laws and regulations, he said, the industry outlook is for growth this year below the overall economy, with slightly greater-than-average growth in 1994 and 1995.
One company that has bucked the industry's slow-growth trend is the Thermo Electron Corporation of Waltham, Mass. Last year, Thermo Electron posted its eighth successive year of company records for revenues and net income. First-quarter earnings this year rose 22 percent, to $15.4 million, on revenues that increased 43 percent, to $293 million.
The company has an unusual structure and strategy. It is a grouping of a parent and seven partly publicly traded spinoffs. They include one of the largest environmental instrument companies, Thermo Instruments Inc.; a producer of paper recycling equipment, Thermo Fibertek, and a converter of truck and bus engines to run on natural gas, Thermo Energy Systems.
The shares of the parent company trade on the New York Stock Exchange while the spinoffs are on the American Stock Exchange. Thermo Electron shares closed yesterday at 60, up 3/8 and equaling its 52-week high. "The stock has had quite a ride since it was at 38 last August," said Kemp Fuller Jr. of RAS Securities.
The spinoffs are an essential part of the company's strategy, according to Nicholas P. Heymann, who follows some of them for County NatWest USA. He said the formula was to identify promising technology, develop it with as much government financing as possible and then spin it off as a separate company with the parent retaining a majority interest.
The idea, in the company's own words is to "combine the entrepreneurial features of new ventures with the advantages of a well-established, mature business."
"Basically what they do is take the technology, give the individuals involved plenty of upside -- stock and lots of options -- and raise money before they really need it," Mr. Heymann said. "They raise $20 million or $40 million and put it in the bank to provide a core income while they commercialize the products."
Thermo Electron was able to buck the United States recession because about half of the sales of its largest subsidiary, Thermo Instruments, were overseas. The unit produces equipment that monitors air pollution and analyzes food, drugs, water and soil for impurities.
Indeed, the strong performance is vindication of sorts for those who argue that nations with the strongest environmental laws are likely to be home to companies that develop the best monitoring and control equipment. Since these companies set the worldwide standard for pollution control equipment, they are attractive vendors for other countries that want to buy the most advanced gear.

HEADLINE: $346.4 Million Refunding Issued

 BODY:
The District of Columbia issued a $346.4 million general obligation bond refunding yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering will be used to redeem debt sold when interest rates were higher.
Initially, the bonds were priced to yield from 3.60 percent for an issue due in 1994 to 5 percent in 1998 and 5.35 percent in 2003. For investors in a 31 percent tax bracket, the taxable bond equivalent yields range from 5.22 percent in 1994 to 7.25 percent in 1998 and 7.75 percent in 2003. 
 The bonds in the issue that are not insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company are rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Tho insured bonds are rated triple-A by both.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wary Consumers Keep Retail Sales Stagnant

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Sales continued to stagnate for many of the nation's largest retailers in May, leaving the store owners and analysts who track their business wary about the outlook for consumer spending.
Retailers who reported their monthly results yesterday generally had disappointing news for the fourth consecutive month. 
 Store owners had hoped sales of spring apparel and other seasonal merchandise would pick up once the harsh weather of the late winter and early spring passed. But the weakening economy and continued uncertainty about taxes and health-care reform are nagging at shoppers and casting a shadow on retail profits.
 
 
Consumers Remain Cautious
 "The consumer remains extremely cautious," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, who warned that his company's second-quarter earnings would fall significantly from last year's results.
A few retailers, including Federated Department Stores Inc. and the May Department Stores Company, fared better than the others. But even they showed signs of weakness: Federated's chairman, Allen Questrom, said business in the Northeast lagged behind the rest of the country.
The big retailers' sales are considered an important indicator of economic health. Because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economy, Americans' willingness to shop determines how other segments, particularly manufacturing, will fare.
Analysts were pessimistic about the future. "The current economic news provides more disheartening data than positive evidence of a consumer recovery," Tom Filandro, an analyst with Gruntal & Company, said.
 
 
Retail Index
 The Salomon Brothers retail index, a barometer of sales performance, was up 3.7 percent after rising 2.6 percent in April. In May 1992, the index was up 5.6 percent as sales recovered from the recession.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, said sales at its stores open at least a year rose 6 percent from May 1992, while business at all its stores rose 23 percent.
Same-store sales are considered the most accurate assessment of how well a retailer is doing. The addition of new stores or the closing of older outlets can skew results.
Wal-Mart's sales remain below the double-digit increases it was known for in past years, a slip that analysts attribute in part to increased competition among discount retailers.
The Kmart Corporation said same-store sales rose 1.1 percent, while overall sales rose 10.8 percent. Uneven results from its specialty stores, including Pace warehouse clubs, have hurt Kmart's results.
Sears, Roebuck & Company said same-store sales were up 5.9 percent, and overall sales rose 4.9 percent. Sales for Sears were compared with extremely weak numbers last year.
Specialty apparel retailers got only a modest lift in sales. Limited Inc. reported its same-store sales rose 2 percent, while overall business was up 13 percent. Gap Inc. said same-store sales rose 3 percent, with overall sales up 14 percent.
 
Retailers' Sales Details
 Following are the details of domestic May sales.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
Month of May: Same-store sales rose 6 percent; overall sales totaled $5.47 billion, up 23 percent from $4.44 billion.
Kmart Corp.
Four weeks ended May 26: Same-store sales rose 1.1 percent; overall sales totaled $3.24 billion, up 10.8 percent from $2.93 billion.
Sears, Roebuck & Co.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales gained 5.9 percent; overall sales totaled $2.23 billion, up 4.9 percent from $2.12 billion.
Dayton-Hudson Corp.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales rose 1.1 percent; overall sales totaled $1.3 billion, up 7.7 percent from $1.21 billion.
J. C. Penney Co.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales rose 1.9 percent at Penney stores only; overall sales (including J. C. Penney, drugstores and catalogue sales) totaled $1.24 billion, up 4 percent from $1.2 billion.
May Department Stores Co.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales advanced 4.6 percent; overall sales totaled $831 million, up 7.4 percent from $773.4 million.
Federated Department Stores Inc.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales increased 4.4 percent; overall sales totaled $504.5 million, up 3.3 percent from $488.2 million.
Limited Inc.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales rose 2 percent; overall sales totaled $551 million, up 13 percent from $489.2 million.
Woolworth Corp.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store domestic sales rose 1.8 percent; overall domestic sales totaled $393 million, up 6.2 percent from $370 million. Total sales, including foreign, totaled $713 million, up 3.8 percent from $687 million.
Gap Inc.
Four weeks ended May 29: Same-store sales gained 3 percent; overall sales totaled $218 million, up 14 percent from $191 million.

HEADLINE: Gay Film Festival: The Personal and the Political

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
In "I'll Love You Forever . . . Tonight," Edgar Michael Bravo's gritty portrait of gay life in Los Angeles, a sullen young photographer is coaxed by his sometime lover into spending the weekend with some friends at a Palm Springs hideaway. What is supposed to be a restful little vacation turns into a joyless round of hard drinking and cold-blooded sexual games played by five good-looking men who seem totally at loose ends. Their emotional cruelty reminds the photographer of his childhood abuse by his father, whom he eventually telephones for an excruciating confrontation.
The tone of Mr. Bravo's film, which is being shown today and tomorrow at the Cinema Village as part of the New Festival, also called the 1993 New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival, suggests Mart Crowley's play "The Boys in the Band," as it might be adapted and updated for 1993 in the spirit of Bret Easton Ellis's novel "Less Than Zero." If the film offers a bleak picture of one segment of gay life, it carries a nasty ring of truth. 
 "It's a society I know well," said Mr. Bravo, a 31-year-old film maker who studied at the University of California at Los Angeles and completed the picture for less than $100,000. "The movie is not so much a political statement as an emotional one." He cited the John Schlesinger films "Midnight Cowboy" and "The Day of the Locust" as influential for their realism, and Mr. Ellis's novel and Jean-Luc Godard's film "Masculine Feminine" as evoking the mood he wanted.
In emphasizing the personal over the political, "I'll Love You Forever . . . Tonight" typifies many of the 30 feature films being shown in the festival, which opened yesterday and runs through June 17 at Cinema Village. While issues like homosexuals in the military and the AIDS epidemic have a prominent place in the festival, they are more than balanced by films that have no direct link to current news stories and hot talk-show subjects.
 
Gender Balance
 Now in its fifth year, the festival is showing 78 films and 92 videos by artists from 13 countries, with a special emphasis on Canada, which contributed more than 20 titles. While the ratio of male to female film and video makers is about even, the fact that it is easier for men than for women to get financing for their projects is reflected in the fact that the majority of the feature-length films are by men. Lesbians made the majority of documentaries.
The festival comes just as the number of films with gay and lesbian themes that are entering the mainstream of international cinema has expanded from a trickle into a flow. Over the last three years, Gus Van Sant's "My Own Private Idaho," Jennie Livingston's "Paris Is Burning" and Craig Lucas and Norman Rene's "Longtime Companion" have won large audiences and critical acclaim. "Paris Is Burning" had its premiere at the festival, as did Tom Kalin's "Swoon" and Monika Treut's "My Father Is Coming," two other films that went on to have commercial runs.
This fall, Jonathan Demme's big-budget film "Philadelphia," which stars Tom Hanks as a gay lawyer with AIDS, opens nationally. If it has any kind of success, Hollywood, which has long deemed gay subject matter to be uncommercial, could begin incorporating more gay characters and themes into its films.
"The increasing number of features with gay and lesbian themes has upped the stakes for everybody," said Jeffrey Lunger, who programmed the festival with Sande Zeig. "This year the general standards of film making are higher. There are a lot more features and a lot fewer videos."
"We're strengthening our position with the media and in getting mainstream reviews," Ms. Zeig said. "We've got the perfect public for test screening and word-of-mouth screening for a niche audience that a distributor might be looking for."
 
Tour of the South
 One of the festival's most anticipated documentaries is Ellen Spiro's "Greetings From Out Here." The video film, which Ms. Spiro made for just $45,000, is a personal tour of the South in which the director visits a lesbian music festival, a gay rodeo, a gay Mardi Gras ball and a gathering of Radical Faeries in the hills of Tennessee. She also encounters a lot of colorful and sympathetic local characters who are not gay.
"I'm a Southern expatriate who escaped to New York," said Ms. Spiro, who is 27 and grew up near Richmond, Va. "When I came to New York and became a raging activist, I started thinking about the gay people who didn't leave and stayed where they were. Going back, I found a very rich and diverse gay culture. I was also interested in showing the human South that breaks from the New York stereotype of Southerners as cross-burning racists."
One of the festival's more intense and visually arresting films is Mark D'Auria's "Smoke." The film was written, directed and edited by Mr. D'Auria, who also plays the lead character. "Smoke" explores the obsessions of a restroom attendant who has a preference for overweight, older men. After he is shot by a crazy woman while praying in a church, the lines between fantasy and reality begin to blur. As they do, the connections between his family, his Roman Catholic faith and his sexual imagination are revealed in baroque, feverish imagery.
"The film is a reverie that is about 60 percent autobiographical," explained Mr. D'Auria, who is 38 and a graduate of the Art Institute of Chicago. "It took me three years to make and cost $35,000. I built the sets by myself. For two years, I lived under an editing machine."
"I happen to like heavyset older men, but it can be difficult to be gay and to be attracted to these sorts of men," he added. "Sometimes you really do feel like an outsider among outsiders. But after the film premiered at the Rotterdam Film Festival, a lot of older women came up to me and said it was refreshing to see an older person eroticized in a nonironic way."
 
Varied Moods
 Beyond same-sex orientation, there is little if anything to connect this year's films to one another in style, mood and theme. Aerlyn Weissman and Lynne Fernie's film "Forbidden Love: The Unashamed Stories of Lesbian Lives" is an imaginative mixture of fact and fiction that intercuts documentary interviews about being lesbian in the 1950's and 60's with a cinematic dramatization of a typical 50's-style pulp lesbian novel.
Amos Gutman's "Amazing Grace" is an Israeli film that explores the volatile relationships among a network of gay and straight friends and their families in the age of AIDS.
The central character in Ryosuka Hashaguchi's "Slight Fever of a 20-Year-Old" is an ostensibly heterosexual economics student who hustles his body to men and becomes involved with a male co-worker in a club where they both work.
Rico Martinez's "Glamazon: A Different Kind of Girl" offers a close-up portrait of Barbara LeMay, a 61-year-old drag performer who worked for years as a stripper in carnivals and tent shows. The film follows her on a visit to her coal-mining West Virginia hometown where she reminisces with friends and neighbors.
In their harrowing documentary film, "Silverlake Life: The View From Here," Tom Joslin and his companion, Mark Massi, who both had AIDS, videotaped themselves living with AIDS and eventually dying. Earlier this year, the film, which was completed by their friend Peter Friedman, shared the award for best documentary at the Sundance Independent Film Festival.
At once lyrical and psychologically acute, "The Blue Hour," a German film by Marcel Gisler, details the affair of a gay callboy and the woman who lives next door.
Temistocles Lopez's "Chain of Desire," a very loose remake of "La Ronde," follows the sexual connections of an assortment of downtown Manhattanites of different sexual orientations.
Joan Jubela's "Homo Teens" offers incisive portraits of gay and lesbian teen-agers in New York City. The short video will be shown in the "Grrrls and Boyys" program at noon on June 12.
One of the most innovative artists in the festival is Cheryl Dunye, a young black video maker whose pieces explore issues of gender, race, class and sexuality in an intimate, deliberately crude cinema verite style.
 
Rebel Spirit
 If the work being shown in this year's festival is an extraordinary mixture of creativity, candor and sophistication among lesbian and gay film makers, some, like Ms. Zeig, worry that the rebel spirit in gay and lesbian culture could eventually be lost.
"As gay and lesbian lives come into mainstream press and media and we are acknowledged and accepted," she said, "I maintain that we're not just like everyone else, that our politics and life styles are subversive. We're not all interested in fitting in, getting married or joining the military. Some of us want to change society, and some of us do that by programming gay and lesbian film festivals."
 
78 Films and 92 Videos From 13 Countries
 The New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival runs through June 17 at the Cinema Village 12th Street, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets are $7 for each screening. There will be panel discussions and lectures by the film makers throughout the festival. Information and schedule: (212) 807-1820.

PUB-DATE: June 4, 1993

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2704 words

HEADLINE: Finding the Rhythm of the Road, at 10 Miles an Hour

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
I SING the body exhausted.
Dehydrated and jelly-legged, sunburned and sweat-grimy, I'd been bicycling the road from Boston since dawn and had spent a big part of the warm afternoon on unexpectedly vertical terrain in northeastern Connecticut. New York City, my final destination, seemed as distant as China. And for an hour, ever since Union, Conn., (the gateway to Nipmuck State Forest, an extremely popular place among black flies), I'd been saying two words in my head, over and over, repeating them like a mantra: Stafford Springs, Stafford Springs, Stafford Springs.
In college, there'd been a guy who lived on my hall whose hometown was Stafford Springs, Conn. I didn't know him at all, don't know what happened to him, but 20 years later, huffing and puffing through the pretty hills of nowhere, I conjured him up, remembered him as an affluent sort. And putting that memory together with the bold print with which the town was emblazoned on my wrinkled Connecticut road map, I concluded: there will be a motel in Stafford Springs. There will be an excellent restaurant there. 
 The sad punch line, of course, is that Stafford Springs is not a particularly affluent place; it's pleasant enough, but actually a little run-down. And more to the point, the closest motel is almost 20 miles away, in Enfield, at the exit off Interstate 91. Now, if you are in a car and tired of driving, 20 more miles to go is an irritation. On a bike, it is evil itself, the essence of unfairness.
So. As if on cue, a beautiful afternoon had suddenly grayed over. It was nearly 5, maybe two and a half hours before dark. I drank two bottles of grape Gatorade (a relatively new flavor, really good, I think) and, having no choice (I wasn't carrying a sleeping bag), pedaled on.
People tend to ask why I like to ride a bicycle over stretches more frequently traversed by planes, trains and automobiles. I usually say I like the idea of the bicycle as an implement of travel rather than of simple recreation.
The old saw about traveling by bicycle is that it's seeing the world at congenial speed; at 10 miles an hour, exposed to the elements, you're connected with the road and the scenery in a way you can never be in an automobile. All that's true. On a bicycle you can count roadside mailboxes and judge the quality of the hand-painted ducks and hunting dogs on them. Animals -- skittering chipmunks, barking dogs, grazing horses, the occasional fox or deer peering curiously from the woods at roadside -- become compatriots. I talk to them: "Hi, pal"; "Shut up, you ugly mutt!" Once, on a whim, I delivered Marc Antony's funeral oration at a herd of stupefied cows. (You feel worse about road kills, flattened raccoons and opossums, than you do in a car.)
But beyond that, leaving the house on a bicycle, I've always liked the idea of ending up somewhere else, traveling toward a place rather than circling back to where I began. And I've never been much of an advance route planner, preferring the love-hate relationship one develops along the way, in myriad foldings and unfoldings, with that cold bearer of both good news and bad, the road map.
There's something random and idiosyncratic about a trip like this, a series of solitary experiences tied together with a ribbon of road; even if they're mundane, they're singular and personal. And it's titillating; it feels a little unsafe. You can have an adventure and then, when it's over, you can actually measure your achievement in miles.
And part of the point of a long bike trip is to wear yourself out. It's the thing you banish from your mind as you begin but take the hugest pride in at the end of the day. The muscles that ache in weird places (your hands hurt from gripping the handlebars and absorbing the rattle of the road); the creakiness in your knees and ankles from hours of rotating in their joints; the odd strain in your backside; the thirst that goes on all day and lasts for hours into the night, and the sense of utter depletion you can feel, it seems, in your cells: this sounds torturous, I know, but I experience it as reward.
A day on a bike has purchasing power. You buy yourself a ravenous appetite and the freedom to indulge it. You buy a well-deserved, untroubled and renewing sleep. And because getting to a distant place on your own power is both a physically difficult task and a conceptually simple one, you buy yourself an unambiguous test. You reach your destination or you don't. Hard work toward a definite goal; it's easy to concentrate. How many things are like this in life?
 
Awkward Start? Good
 I'd taken my bike up on the train from Manhattan the previous day and started back from downtown Boston at chill dawn. Trying to slip through the door of the Omni Parker House Hotel, I accidentally caught one saddlebag on the jamb, and the bike nearly clattered to the sidewalk. It was an awkward start, but I wouldn't say inauspicious. The start of a journey should be awkward, because the pleasure -- and the achievement -- lies in finding a rhythm.
I rode through the Commons, then over Storrow Drive to the esplanade along the Charles. At Massachusetts Avenue I crossed the river to the north bank and followed it west. There were runners out, student types, and a couple of crews were already on the water. Wearing tights and a windbreaker, I was cold anyway, and uncomfortable on the bike seat. I felt like an unwelcome stranger, like a Yankee in Fenway Park. I had a discomforting moment of doubt: it's a long way home.
I turned south in the woodsy suburb of Weston. It was about 7 by then, and the sun had begun to burn away the early mist, dappling the road. Traffic was heading against me; it was Friday, a workday in the city.
South of Natick, where I stopped for breakfast with Glenn and Nina, some conveniently situated old friends, I found Route 16, an amiable state road with modest grades and modest traffic. It points southwest, almost right at New York City, and that was helpful. Though traveling by bike is by design a scenic meander, you need a straight shot now and then for the sake of psychic momentum. I put a couple of towns behind me, Sherborn and Holliston, and began to see the map of Massachusetts in my head from the vantage of someone who'd covered some distance on it. In Milford, Mass., I passed a bike shop and stopped to pick up some spare inner tubes, which I'd foolishly left without. And there, from a salesman, I got the first warning of the hills to come.
"Any way of getting around them?" I asked.
"Nope," he said, with an unkind trace of relish, I thought.
It was midmorning and I stripped to shorts and short sleeves. I rode through Hopedale, Menden, Uxbridge, quaintly stolid and unremarkable towns of the sort that pepper the nation, though in a dirt parking lot in Uxbridge, behind a convenience store, there was a slightly bizarre sight: a two-seater airplane, upside down, lying on its roof with its landing gear sticking up like the legs of a dead insect.
Just north of the tristate junction of Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island, the road bent west and grew rural. The land began to roll a bit; houses grew farther apart. Roadside delivery boxes declared that neighbors were getting different newspapers: The Worcester Telegram and Gazette and The Norwich Bulletin. Between Douglas and Webster, there's a body of water fantastically called -- no kidding, look on the map -- Lake Chaubunagungamaug. And to an outsider who just happened to be passing through, a smug New Yorker used to living at the center of the universe, it felt like a place between places, wonderfully nowhere.
Route 16 gave way to Route 197, which dipped into Connecticut, and at a crossroads I decided, for reasons as impetuous as thought through, to go west now and south later. The idea was to go around Hartford to the north, and the next day head down toward New York through Litchfield County; I'd been there and vaguely remembered it as lovely. Of course, it didn't quite happen this way, mainly because Route 197 turned out to be what the bike store salesman was talking about. An undistinguished squiggle on the map and in fact a beautiful rural byway traversing deep woods, the road has a number of hateful qualities, particularly if you're on a bicycle, pretty tired, nearly 40 years old and not in the shape you once were. Who knew Connecticut had a mountain range in it?
In the couple of hours that I spent trudging (as in walking and shooing away clouds of bugs) up the hills of 197 and gliding down, two things happened. It occurred to me that Litchfield County has similar terrain, so I began revamping my plan. And I started to think: Stafford Springs. Stafford Springs.
 
Rules of the Road
 Two good rules for the bike traveler. Get your miles in early, before the sun gets high and before a lot of cars hit the road. And whenever possible ride near water: river roads and beach roads are not only scenic; they're also flat.
At dawn on Saturday, I left Enfield and plunged south, along the Connecticut River. I was feeling good. There were miles behind me; I'd got through a tough day. It was a dewy and damp morning, but sunny, and the rhythm of the ride was warming. The state road, 159, passed through Windsor Locks, then over the interstate highway, snuggling against the river and through the town of Windsor, its wide quiet streets and large well-scrubbed houses yielding a picture of sturdy New England. It was a pretty stretch, 10 miles or so, a ride you'd take for pleasure if you lived near there and the kind of place you'd take bike trips to discover.
I turned west, away from the river, alas, to circumvent Hartford. I ate breakfast at a homey-looking cafe in Bloomfield -- unfortunately the waffles were disappointing -- and turned south again, passing through West Hartford, an affluent suburb. Meaning to angle to the southwest, I missed a turn -- the road was straight and easy and I had that feeling you get that traveling south you're somehow going downhill -- and by the time I discovered my mistake I was in the blue-collar neighborhoods of New Britain, a city with a despondent, recession-weary feel. But I was enjoying myself, pumping hard, and the road kept dropping to the south and I followed it. By late morning, I was in Meriden, and at a McDonald's I grabbed rest and sustenance: a chocolate milkshake for energy, a Coke for thirst and then, because I got goose-pimply as my sweat dried, a cup of coffee.
As it turned out, the afternoon was, once again, tougher. Eventually I would make it to Fairfield, on Route 1, along the Sound, but the day before had, in fact, taken a toll. From Meriden, zigzagging my way to the southwest on a number of pesky hills, grueling not so much in grade but in number, I needed frequent stops, at one point lying in the sun by a roadside picnic table and actually dozing until a dog licked my nose and woke me up.
The guy who owned the dog wanted to trade bicycling stories; half my age, he pulled up his pant legs and showed me his calves, which reminded me of cannonballs, and he said he'd ridden to Toronto and back that morning, or something like that.
"Yo!" he said. "Where'd you come from? Boston? What time'd you leave?"
It was maybe 3 in the afternoon; this was near Ansonia, Conn., maybe 75 miles from New York.
"You'll make it," he said, meaning that night.
I thanked him for the chat as I mounted and rode slowly off.
"Yo!" he said. "No problem."
From there it was slow and steady to Derby, where I made another wrong turn; instead of turning south along the Housatonic River, I turned north. I hadn't gone far before I realized my mistake, but I kept going anyway. Weary as I was, it was a great stretch of road. There was a slightly encouraging breeze, the pavement was brand-new, the vista along the river -- hills rose steeply from the opposite bank -- was inspiring and I was zipping along comfortably at speeds I hadn't hit all day. There were college crews racing on the river, and keeping up with them, coming toward me on the road, were several long-haired teen-age boys on Rollerblades.
"Go Yale!" they were shouting.
I paid for this interlude, of course. The road followed the river for five or seven miles, then crossed it, over a dam, and began to climb on the opposite side; at a crossroads, I consulted the map and learned, heartbreakingly, that I wanted Route 111, which pivoted directly into the slope.
It turned out to be the heftiest climb of the whole journey, an unrelenting mile. I didn't need this, nor did I need the friendly guy who lived halfway up and who was mowing his lawn as I passed.
"Hey!" he said, with a proud smile. "Killer hill, huh?"
 
Pain and Persistence
 In Fairfield Sunday morning I woke ready for the final sprint along Long Island Sound to the city, but getting out of the motel bed and planting my feet on the floor, I felt a razor-ish pain near the heel of my left foot. I couldn't rotate the ankle at all, and could barely hobble into the bathroom. Was my Achilles tendon torn? I had no recollection of a trauma; I hadn't twisted my ankle or inadvertently kicked anything. What can you do to yourself in your sleep? The sun was just up. I was 55 miles from home. Gingerly, I arranged myself on the bike.
Route 1, of course, gets a fair amount of traffic, but not at 6 A.M. on a Sunday. I covered some ground, but within an hour, the whole ankle was swollen; it had stopped feeling like a torn tendon and started feeling like a sprain. I made it about halfway to the city, to Cos Cob, Conn., and, sitting on the side of the road on a patch of grass in front of a tennis court, I thought about calling an ambulance.
I didn't. Playing with pain, as it were, I continued riding and made it to the New York line, then negotiated the suburban trail on Route 1 through Mamaroneck and Rye, the meaner streets of New Rochelle and finally the rugged Eastchester section of the Bronx. At high noon, as I checked a map on Boston Road, a cop stopped and directed me to the Gun Hill Road subway. I took the subway to Manhattan; so shoot me. I got home in time to see the Knicks whip Charlotte, my swollen ankle propped on a coffee table.
Two days later, I walked, easily enough, to the doctor. The ankle was still swollen but it didn't hurt. The explanation was simple: I'd overextended myself.
"You ever do 50 pushups after not doing any for six months?" the doctor said. "It doesn't hurt right away, but when you wake up in the morning . . ." He said it was likely that I hurt one ankle and not the other because I probably held my feet in slightly different positions on my bike pedals.
I know how this all sounds. You are thinking: Jerk! No wonder you got hurt. What kind of a stupid thing are you doing bicycling back to Manhattan from Boston in a weekend? And the best way I know to answer this is to go back to my moment of dejection in Stafford Springs.
The woman who gave me the sad news about the closest motel also said I would have to climb an enormous hill to get out of town. And she was right. I had to walk up most of it, mounting the bike again only as I neared the crest, but soon the road mercifully leveled for good.
It was just then that the sun came out again, directly in front of me because I was traveling west, and the sensation of moving toward the light was palpable and energizing.
I reached Enfield sooner than I'd expected. I napped (read: collapsed) in the motel, then went across the road to a Chinese restaurant in the strip mall there. Drinking beer and eating spare ribs, I was so tired that I realized when I'd finished that for 20 minutes or so I'd been reading and re-reading the paper place mat. According to the chart there, I was born in the year of the snake. The incredibly mundane conclusion of my weary mind was this: If I hadn't made it past Stafford Springs, I'd never know that.
Afterward, lying in bed, some other things I realized that day occurred to me. For one, things that seem torturous and tormenting don't stay that way; anguish isn't permanent. For another, I was going to make it home. Drifting off to sleep I thought, "Now I'm getting somewhere."
