HEADLINE: A Legal Thicket Amid the Redwoods

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EUREKA, Calif.

 BODY:
In a cluttered office overflowing with filing boxes and legal briefs, William H. Bertain is standing fast in his quixotic campaign to wrest back control of the Pacific Lumber Company, which was acquired in 1986 by Charles E. Hurwitz, a Houston financier.
A child of the lush redwood forests in this fog-shrouded country, Mr. Bertain has dedicated the last seven years to a legal fight that few believe can be won, returning the company to the Murphy family that had managed it since the turn of the century.
 
 
Seeking to Undo a Buyout
 Mr. Hurwitz's Maxxam Inc. bought Pacific Lumber for about $900 million in a buyout financed largely with junk bonds handled by Drexel Burnham Lambert, and three members of the Murphy family have retained Mr. Bertain to have the buyout undone, asserting that shareholders were defrauded. Maxxam also faces a barrage of lawsuits from employees, shareholders and environmentalists seeking to halt the harvesting of old-growth timber. 
 Despite demoralizing odds, Mr. Bertain says he carries on the crusade because outside investors -- whom he calls "corporados" -- are threatening to destroy a way of life.
"This was the crown jewel of the North American timber industry," he said. "I was just stunned for four months after the takeover, but then I set out by committing to do everything that was legal and moral to stop this."
Mr. Bertain's campaign has set him at odds with John Campbell, the president of Pacific Lumber and a 24-year veteran of the company, the world's largest holder of virgin redwood forests. "He's barking up the wrong tree," Mr. Campbell said in a telephone interview. "He's a zealot and he has his emotions and his ego involved."
Pacific Lumber is not practicing cut-and-run forestry, the Australian-born lumberman insists. Countering critics who charge that Mr. Hurwitz had to increase the company's cutting rate to pay nearly $800 million of debt incurred when it was taken over, Mr. Campbell says the company has shown that it intends to be a positive long-term economic force here in Humboldt County, on the Northern California coast nearly 300 miles north of San Francisco.
 
 
At Center of Regional Conflicts
 Seven years after Mr. Hurwitz's takeover, the dispute shows no signs of ending soon. Indeed, Pacific Lumber has increasingly found itself at the center of economic and environmental conflicts boiling over in the Pacific Northwest. In April, both sides of the Pacific Lumber hostilities were prominently represented at President Clinton's meeting in Portland, Ore., on forest use.
In this logging town of 27,000, the controversy has turned neighbor against neighbor and left the community bitterly divided over whether its future lies in timber or in diversifying into recreation and tourism.
And Pacific Lumber's unwillingness to compromise on environmental issues has made new enemies in this town, which once saw itself as having a one-crop economy.
"For a long time, the timber industry has controlled this area," said Phil Jurick, a Eureka developer. "They've had far too much influence."
For many residents of this community, the Pacific Lumber takeover has come to epitomize the social and environmental costs of the junk bond era of the 1980's. But beyond being vilified as a corporate raider, Mr. Hurwitz has never been charged with violating any laws, and in the short run at least, his company has increased employment in the region.
 Mr. Bertain's supporters include members of labor unions, community leaders and environmentalists. Nevertheless, it has not been a comfortable time for the bearded and outspoken 46-year-old lawyer, the youngest of 10 children who grew up in nearby Scotia, the company town for Pacific Lumber, where his family had run a small laundry since 1920.
Today Mr. Bertain -- who spends most of his time and much of his money on the legal battle with Mr. Hurwitz -- is more than a half-million dollars in debt. At times he has been unable to meet his house payments, and his health has deterioriated.
The dispute may soon move to a national stage. Legislation is expected to be introduced in Congress this month to clear the way for the Government to acquire more than 30,000 acres of Pacific Lumber's old-growth timber in an area known as the Headwaters. While company officials say that the fair market value is likely to exceed $400 million, Congressional staff members and environmentalists argue that because environmental restrictions prohibit logging there, the actual value may be much less.
Environmentalists have used Pacific Lumber's logging practices as the rallying point in their battle to save the remaining stands of California's old-growth redwood forests.
 "This is in-your-face forestry," said Joshua Kaufman, a Humboldt County paleontologist who helped form an environmental coalition after he saw Pacific Lumber trucks rolling up and down the road on which he lives. The group has brought suits against the company and hopes to force it to sell its remaining old-growth lands for a new national park.
Mr. Bertain maintains that returning Pacific Lumber to its original owners would be a perfect compromise between the environmentalists and the logging industry. Under its previous owners, the company cut about 2 percent of the trees on its land annually -- no more than the forest's annual growth rate.
In his lawsuits against the Pacific Lumber takeover, Mr. Bertain has asserted that Mr. Hurwitz conspired with other investors to defraud the company's shareholders when he acquired the company. To date, those suits have generally been rejected by Federal courts, but more than a dozen shareholder, employee and environmental suits remain to be settled.
Few people give the small-town lawyer much chance of returning the company to its former owners. But Mr. Bertain is optimistic that he will prevail in his $1 billion-plus claim against the dealings of Drexel Burnham Lambert and its fallen junk bond specialist, Michael R. Milken.
 
 
Words Unspoken
 Mr. Bertain and Mr. Hurwitz have testified at the same Congressional hearing, but they have never spoken to each other. Mr. Hurwitz, a Texan who rarely speaks to the press, refused to comment on Mr. Bertain.
Unfazed by the various lawsuits against his holdings, Mr. Hurwitz has forged ahead, moving to reduce the debt load of Pacific Lumber. He recently refinanced Pacific Lumber's $510 million debt and split the company into three concerns, leading many industry executives to say -- and even some environmentalists to concede -- that the Houston financier had pulled off a business coup.
"They got a phenomenal decrease in the cost of capital," said Craig Gilmore, a financial analyst at Gilmore & Company in Carlsbad, Calif.
In a daring stroke, Mr. Hurwitz shifted Pacific Lumber's timber assets to two new companies, Scotia Pacific and Salmon Creek, cutting back on the company's short-term debt, financed by junk bonds, and replacing it with bonds backed by 179,000 acres of redwood and Douglas fir timberland.
 
 
Many Lawsuits
 Nonetheless, Mr. Hurwitz still faces imposing legal challenges:
*Pacific Lumber and Maxxam are named in lawsuits in both Humboldt County and New York City by former Pacific Lumber shareholders seeking damages of more than $1 billion.
*The logging company faces at least 10 lawsuits brought by environmentalists who charge that its accelerated logging endangers species like the spotted owl and the marbled murrelet and damages forest watersheds.
*In 1991, the United States Department of Labor filed a civil suit against Pacific Lumber in response to the company's 1986 termination of its pension plan, which it replaced with annuities from Executive Life, an insurance company that Mr. Hurwitz controlled and whose parent later went bankrupt.
*In May 1992, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation indicated that it was moving toward suing United Financial Group, stemming from the 1988 collapse of the United Savings Association. Mr. Hurwitz once owned 24 percent of the failed savings and loan, which purchased $1.4 billion worth of Drexel's junk bonds in exchange for $1.8 billion in financing for the acquisitions of Pacific Lumber and Kaiser Aluminum.
*In April, Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, introduced legislation that would impose a 75 percent tax on the value of old-growth redwood timber that is used as security for bonds.
Through it all, Mr. Bertain has shown no signs of caving in.
"He's a bulldog of a human being," said David Harris, an author and researcher who is working on a book about the corporate takeover. "Nobody else would be where he is today, but he's still after these guys."
 The article also referred incompletely to Pacific Lumber's stance on issues that have angered environmentalists. The company said it had compromised on some matters.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about a legal battle for control of the Pacific Lumber Company misstated the relationship between Charles E. Hurwitz, chairman of Pacific's parent, Maxxam Inc., and the Executive Life Insurance Company, a California insurer that supplied annuities for Pacific Lumber's pension plan. Mr. Hurwitz did not control Executive Life.
The article also omitted attribution for allegations that the United Savings Association bought junk bonds from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in return for Drexel's financing of acquisitions. That assertion was made in a lawsuit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation against Michael R. Milken, Drexel's junk-bond specialist. Because Mr. Milken and Drexel Burnham settled the suit for $1.3 billion, no court ruled on the F.D.I.C. allegations.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: Serbs Feel Invincible;
Having Out-Bluffed the West, They May Now Press Their Bosnia Drive

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4

 BODY:
Serbian leaders here and in Bosnia are now acting with increasing confidence, sensing that they have out-bluffed Europe, Russia and the United States, and no longer see any major obstacles to their drive for hegemony in former Yugoslavia.
This is the conclusion of foreign diplomats here and a number of Serbs, who say recent events have made it clear that the major powers have no stomach for direct military intervention in the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 By this view, the United Nations proposal to carve out "safe havens" to protect Muslim civilians under siege by the Bosnian Serbs is largely camouflage to hide the hard truth: that an international consensus for strong action to roll back the Bosnian Serbs, who now control 70 percent of the republic's territory, simply does not exist.
Many believe that Serbian nationalism is not appeased by the gains in Bosnia but is feeding on them. They predict more war ahead, not less. The extremists who command pillaging armies of irregulars in Bosnia are not likely to stop with the ground they have won so far. The temptation to press ahead to create a "greater Serbia," uniting the two million Serbs living outside the borders of Serbia proper with the six million inside Serbia, seems more irresistible than ever.
 
Doubts About Enclaves
 If the six enclaves set up for the Muslims in Bosnia are quickly and thoroughly patrolled by international troops empowered to repel any aggression, then perhaps the Serbs would settle temporarily for a standoff. They might well use the lull to consolidate their control of areas outside the enclaves through "ethnic cleansing," as they did after a cease-fire halted the fighting with Croatia two years ago.
But if the enclaves are simply concentrations of Muslims without effective protection and with little means of survival or economic viability, then they could turn into what a diplomat called "magnets for attracting people so that eventually mass deportations or death will occur."
The threats earlier from Washington to lift the embargo on arms for the Bosnian Muslim fighters and to use air strikes to smash Serbian artillery have had a negative effect now that the Bosnian Serbs have remained defiant and the threats have proven empty.
A month ago, the Bosnian Serbs were feeling vulnerable, and the Serbian Government of their patron in Belgrade, President Slobodan Milosevic, was striking a compliant pose toward the West in the hope of ending the harsh economic sanctions.
Today, the Bosnian Serbs seem bathed in a glow of invincibility. And the Government here has smashed Serbia's tiny opposition movement, elevated hard-line nationalists to new influence and abrogated its pledge to place monitors on the border to prove it is not supplying the Serbian fighters.
 
Criticism of Karadzic Wanes
 It is uncertain whether Mr. Milosevic and Radovan Karadzic, the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, have patched up their differences, but certainly the orchestrated press criticism of Mr. Karadzic, whose constituents refused to go along with the international peace plan approved by Mr. Milosevic, has died down here in the capital of Serbia.
Another casualty is respect for Western resolve. "Perhaps it is true that Bosnia is the most difficult and complex problem on the planet," wrote a journalist in the outspoken opposition magazine Vreme. "It has shown that the world is led by people who are no different from our Balkan bluffers."
Essentially the militant nationalists believe that they are swaying the world to their view that the conflict is not international but a civil war and that Bosnia, with its crazy quilt of competing ethnic groups, was never a viable sovereign state to begin with.
There is also concern that the recklessness of leaders like Vojislav Seselj of the Serbian Radical Party, or Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military commander of the Bosnian Serb forces, who recently hinted at a tactic of unleashing terrorists in London and Paris, could destabilize other flash points in the remnants of former Yugoslavia.
When asked to predict events, a surprising number of diplomats, opposition politicians and independent journalists come up with the same scenario. Sooner or later, they say, Croatia and Serbia will vie for Bosnia and end up splitting it, either after fighting for it or by circumventing United Nations peace efforts and holding their own partition negotiations.
Few people doubt that if Serbia and Croatia fought over the spoils or divided them up over a table, the Muslims, who in the 1991 census made up the single largest group in Bosnia -- 44 per cent compared with 33 percent for the Serbs and 17 for the Croats -- would fare badly. At best, they might be given a slice of land somewhere in the center of the country. At worst, they would be driven out altogether.

HEADLINE: JOB GROWTH IN U.S. SURPRISINGLY HIGH WITH SURGE IN MAY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
In a surprisingly upbeat economic report, Government figures showed today that job growth picked up smartly in May as the unemployment rate edged below 7 percent -- to 6.9 percent -- for the first time since late 1991.
Analysts found much to cheer in the Labor Department data, which seemed to portray an economy finally shifting into a higher gear after two years of generally weak recovery, particularly in jobs. 
 - The employment figures, the first comprehensive look at the May economy, were stronger than the most optimistic professional forecasts. Coupled with other recent encouraging data, they inspired some rethinking of prospects for the balance of the year.
 
Payroll Job Growth
 Payroll jobs, today's report showed, grew by 209,000 last month, nearly double the typical expectation and even more impressive because the gain came on top of upward revisions for March and April totaling 145,000 jobs.
The May gain lifted payroll jobs to 109.99 million, exceeding for the first time the June 1990 pre-recession peak. Put another way, it took just over two years to recover the jobs lost during a recession officially reckoned to have lasted eight months.
Construction was especially strong, rising 67,000 with the aid of better weather, continued low interest rates and backlogged demand for new homes, the department said. Business and health services also expanded employment as did local governments.
 
Gains in New Jersey
 The surge in employment was particularly evident in New Jersey, where the unemployment rate fell to 7.4 percent. This followed successive jumps that had carried the state's jobless rate to 9.1 in April, the highest for any of the 11 biggest industrial states. The unemployment rate in New York State rose to 7.5 percent, from 7 percent in April, but New York City had a decline, to 9.5 percent, from 9.8 percent. [Page 49.]
Bond prices in the credit markets slumped on the news of greater-than-expected job creation, pushing up interest rates and fueling speculation about possible monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve. [Page 37.]
The employment figures follow a string of other economic indicators that while mixed have included some moderately hopeful signs. In the last week alone, there were reports that consumers raised spending sharply in April despite flat incomes and that sales of new homes soared to their biggest gain in more than six years. Sales of cars and light trucks were reported to be 15 percent higher in May than a year earlier.
But other reports this week showed that the first-quarter economic growth rate slipped below 1 percent, and the Government's main forecasting index reversed direction in April for the fourth straight month, posting a smaller-than-expected gain.
The Clinton Administration reacted cautiously, welcoming the job growth and the easing of the unemployment rate to 6.9 percent. But officials are aware that a sustained surge in the economy could undercut an effort to revive a scaled-down version of the economic stimulus package that failed to win Congressional passage.
In addition, higher interest rates might complicate prospects for the President's budget. It calls for tax increases and spending cuts, which would tend to restrain the economy as would higher interest rates. Moreover, in the longer run the budget plan relies on low rates to help keep Government financing costs in check.
"We are encouraged," Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said about today's results, noting that payroll employment has now climbed by more than 200,000 for two straight months, the first time this has occurred in more than three years.
But he added, "We must remain cautious and not put too much weight on a single month's numbers."
 
Optimism From Economists
 Private analysts reacted with less guarded enthusiasm. "The economy is growing at a higher rate than the general consensus has been expecting," commented Leif H. Olsen, an investment manager and economist who operates a firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Olsen predicts that gross domestic product will rise at an annual rate of 3 1/2 percent in the quarter ending June 30, well above the gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent posted in the storm-ravaged first three months of the year.
With the construction industry pulling out of the doldrums, the private- sector workweek at its lengthiest in more than four years and even teen-age joblessness easing, the May report had only one major negative.
This was yet another hefty decline in factory jobs, which fell 39,000, to bring the cumulative loss since February to 133,000. A separate Government report today said that orders to American factories fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the second straight decline.
Some analysts also fretted about a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in average hourly earnings last month, but others, citing a small decline in April, contended that wage inflation remained low.
Most analysts had anticipated a modest rebound in factory jobs and the decline was somewhat of a puzzle. In an interview, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chief economic adviser to President Clinton, advanced two competing explanations of what was occurring, calling it too soon to endorse either.
One is that American manufacturers first took steps to raise productivity, then met increased demand by expanding the hours of their existing work force: the private-sector workweek surged 24 minutes in May, to the highest level in four years, and factory hours are now the longest since 1966. This view holds that industry is now poised to hire new workers. .
The other explanation is that the overhaul of American industry has combined with new computer and other technology to change the relationship between output and jobs in factories, bringing permanently reduced work forces.
The department's survey of households posted an even larger -- though probably overstated -- increase of 857,000 jobs in May. The results of the household survey and the payroll survey tend to track each other in the longer run but month-to-month may diverge sharply. Thomas J. Plewes, an associate commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, attributed much of May's huge rise to heavy movement into and out of the labor market at the end of the school year, to self-employment of many who had lost jobs and to statistical "catch-up" following an April decline.
Before seasonal adjustment, the job gain was 1,345,000, the household survey showed.
The labor force also expanded sharply, by 790,000, so the ranks of the unemployed thinned by only a modest 67,000. While this trimmed one-tenth of a point off the jobless rate, which had stood at 7 percent for the preceding three months, only moves of at least two-tenths of a point are considered statistically significant by the department in this calculation.
Today's report also showed that the jobless rate for blacks eased to 12.9 percent in May from 13.8 percent in April while the rate for teen-agers fell a point, to 19.7. The latter rate was about half the 40 percent unemployment recorded for New York City teen-agers during the first three months of this year, the worst on record.
While there was little change in May, the number of hard-core jobless -- those out of work for 15 weeks or more -- has fallen 600,000 so far this year.
Despite the decline in factory jobs, the department's index of aggregate weekly hours surged to 124.7 last month from 123 in April, a gain that implies a sizable increase in industrial production, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Head of CUNY Drops Plan to Cut Course Offerings

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
The Chancellor of the City University of New York has abandoned a plan to eliminate or consolidate scores of majors at many colleges in the 21-campus system.
The action by the Chancellor, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds, came after the plan was sharply criticized by faculty members, students and legislators. In the end, the opposition proved so powerful that she was forced to scale back the proposal. 
 The debate between the Chancellor's office and several trustees on one hand, and faculty and students on the other, has involved abstract issues of governance as well as practical consequences, such as a loss of teaching jobs.
The program proposed such drastic steps as eliminating majors offered at several campuses, including philosophy at City College, history at York College and French at Brooklyn College.
Dr. Reynolds said the goal of the original plan, to save money and allow the university to strengthen its remaining programs, was still crucial.
So instead of pressing for the elimination of specific programs, she proposed instead that she be given more power to decide what programs each campus would offer, a power now held largely by each college.
Last December, Dr. Reynolds had embraced as excellent the recommendations of an advisory committee that called for the consolidation or elimination of programs with low enrollment across the university. There was an uproar on many campuses, where faculty members felt their authority was being challenged.
In the course of the debate the colleges did agree to eliminate some programs, which Dr. Reynolds hailed as a success. But they fought fiercely to protect many others that the committee had proposed to abolish, and in recent days Dr. Reynolds has circulated a new proposal that no longer focuses on specific programs.
In her new 20-page plan, which she is expected to present to members of the university board at a meeting on Monday, she calls for the chancellor to be given new powers to control and eliminate weak academic programs. Under the plan, the university would create a system of review and certification over which the chancellor would have ultimate control.
 
Fewer Credits
 The Chancellor's new plan also proposes a reduction in the number of credits a student needs to graduate from 128 to 120 for the four-year bachelor's degree and from 68 to 60 for the two-year associate degree. This would eventually compel colleges to eliminate minor course offerings such as physical education because they would not be needed.
A draft copy of the Chancellor's report was provided to The New York Times by an opponent of the new plan. Yesterday the university issued a statement saying that because the trustees had not yet had an opportunity to consider the report, the university administration "reserves comment" at this time, except to note that "the proposed policy establishes a framework to guide continuing academic planning" through existing college governance mechanisms.
The new plan met with mixed reviews from many leaders of the university faculty. Robert Picken, chairman of the University Faculty Senate, said he appreciated the fact that Dr. Reynolds had curtailed the original proposal to eliminate many programs immediately but cautioned that he had serious concerns about the Chancellor's new plan and would wait to see further details before making a comment.
 
Consolidation of Majors
 Dr. Reynolds first presented a plan to overhaul the university last December, when she released a 160-page report by an advisory committee that called for the university to consider the elimination of associate, bachelor's and master's degree programs that attracted few students and strengthen those programs where enrollment was strong.
A main feature of the original plan was that majors be consolidated across the university. For example, French, now offered as a major at six campuses, would be available only at Hunter College in Manhattan and at Queens College in Flushing. The new plan does not require such consolidations but calls on the colleges to collaborate on joint course offerings.
In her final report, Dr. Reynolds notes that the campuses have agreed to the elimination of only 45 programs in the next academic year, far less than the 200 originally suggested for possible elimination by the Chancellor's advisory committee.
Among the degree programs slated for elimination or suspension in the latest plan are a German baccalaureate at Lehman College, a baccalaureate in religion at Baruch College, a two-year associate program in medical records technology at Kingsborough Community College and a master's degree in political economy at Brooklyn College.

HEADLINE: THE GUINIER BATTLE;
Clinton Tries to Cut Losses After Abandoning a Choice

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
President Clinton today set about trying to deal with the political damage from his decision to drop Lani Guinier as his choice to be the Justice Department's new civil rights chief. But she remained defiant, saying the President did not understand her theories and should have given her a chance to explain them to the Senate.
Mr. Clinton sought especially to soothe new political irritations in his relationship with members of the Congressional Black Caucus, who were among the most angered at his decision to abandon the Guinier nomination in the face of mounting Senate criticism of her proposals to increase the political power of black voters. 
 He set up a meeting next week with several black members of Congress, Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Baltimore Democrat who heads the caucus, said today. And Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore conferred this evening at the White House with several black political figures in an effort to press the President's case that he had no choice but to withdraw the nomination.
In a news conference at the Justice Department, where she had hoped to work as assistant attorney general in charge of the civil rights division, Ms. Guinier said she continued to "respect" Mr. Clinton, whom she has known since they attended Yale Law School more than 20 years ago.
But she also refused to gloss over her disagreements with the President, making it clear that she believed her situation had been woefully mishandled by the White House.
 
Comments With a Sting
 Although she had largely appreciative words for Mr. Clinton on morning television programs, Ms. Guinier's message during her news conference carried an obvious sting.
"I think that the President and many others have misinterpreted my writings," Ms. Guinier said in a voice that sometimes quavered with emotion as she stood with her husband, Nolan Bowie, a Philadelphia lawyer, and their 5-year-old son, Nicholas.
"I think he has the opportunity to be a great President," she said, "and I hope he takes advantage of that opportunity."
Ms. Guinier said she was disappointed that she did not have a chance to argue her views before the Senate. "Had I been allowed to testify in a public forum before the U.S. Senate, I believe that the Senate would also have agreed that I am the right person for this job, a job some people have said I trained for all my life," she said, adding, "I deeply regret that I shall not have the opportunity for public service in the civil rights division."
Defending her views, she said: "I have always believed in democracy and nothing I have ever written is inconsistent with that. I have always believed in one person, one vote, and nothing I have ever written is inconsistent with that.
"I am a democratic idealist," she said, "who believes that politics need not be forever seen as I win, you lose, a dynamic in which some people are permanent monopoly winners and others are permanent excluded losers.
"I hope that what has happened to my nomination does not mean that future nominees will not be allowed to explain their views as soon as any controversy arises," she said. "I hope that we are not witnessing that dawning of a new intellectual orthodoxy in which thoughtful people can no longer debate provocative ideas without denying the country their talents as public servants. "
 
Praise for Reno
 She also carefully distinguished her views of Mr. Clinton from her evident regard for, and gratitude to, Attorney General Janet Reno, who steadfastly stood by Ms. Guinier.
"I had been excited about the opportunity of working with Janet Reno," Ms. Guinier said. She said that Ms. Reno's "strength and courage" had helped her withstand the criticism of the last few weeks.
On Thursday night, Mr. Clinton announced he was withdrawing Ms. Guinier's nomination because, he said, he had finally read her writings and had found much with which he disagreed.
He said he was not withdrawing the nomination simply because he was afraid to take it forward in the face of mounting opposition in the Senate, but instead because he could not defend many of her writings.
Had he read them earlier, he said, he would not have nominated her.
White House officials who conceded that the nomination of Ms. Guinier, a 43-year-old law professor at the University of Pennsylvania, had been mishandled, said that political damage to Mr. Clinton could come from two fronts: Mr. Clinton has clearly angered leaders of civil rights and women's groups that had once supported him.
Mr. Mfume, for instance, warned Thursday that dropping Ms. Guinier would be an unprincipled act that could cost Mr. Clinton black support as he tries to promote his budget.
Today, Mr. Mfume's anger seemed unabated as he said that "some people who worked to put Bill Clinton in office, who took to heart his pledge to bring about change, to some extent feel betrayed."
The episode has also been depicted as the latest instance of a White House unable to steer a sure course. Consequently Mr. Clinton's standing as a leader, which is crucial as he struggles to enact an economic program, may have been harmed.
"I'm disappointed in the Senate and the President," said Senator Paul Wellstone, a freshman Democrat from Minnesota. "I think they bailed out and really didn't give her a chance."
He said that Mr. Clinton did not strengthen his hand with the Senate but rather showed he could be easily rolled over. It was a sentiment shared by a Republican Senator, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania.
"I think President Clinton has made a mistake in withdrawing the nomination of Ms. Guinier," Mr. Specter said, adding that he had urged the White House to let Ms. Guinier appear before the Senate.
"There are some fights you have to fight even if you may lose them," Senator Specter said. "I think he misreads the Senate, and this is going to do him some harm as he faces a tough battle on the budget."
Ms. Reno was reported by her aides to have at first been unenthusiastic about Ms. Guinier for the post of civil rights chief. But when the nomination began to attract widespread criticism, Ms. Reno adopted the stand-tall approach that served her well after the assault and fatal fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex.
Ms. Reno insisted to reporters on Wednesday that she would fight to get Ms. Guinier confirmed.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said that at the meeting this afternoon, Mr. Clinton told the black politicians that he was sorry for the way the Guinier nomination had played out.
"What he said, first of all, is that we have a disagreement over principle," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. He told them, "I'm sorry about that, but that's the way it is. I hope you'll understand."
Among those attending the meeting, White House officials said, were Jewell Jackson McCabe, the founder of the National Coalition of 100 Black Women; Joseph Lowery, the director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference; Dorothy I. Height, the president of the National Council of Negro Women; Elaine Jones, the legal director of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, where Ms. Guinier used to work, and Eddie N. Williams, the director of the Center for Joint Political Studies, a black-oriented private research organization.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton after withdrawing his nomination of Lani Guinier to be the new civil rights chief. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The unemployment rate edged below 7 percent in May, for the first time since late 1991, and Government figures showed that job growth picked up smartly. Analysts found much to cheer in the data, which seemed to portray an economy finally shifting into higher gear after two years of generally weak recovery. The report showed that payroll jobs grew by 209,000 last month, nearly double the estimates of many experts. The gain was even more impressive because it came on top of upward revisions for March and April. [Page 1.] A surprising surge in employment after three months of economic deterioration cut New Jersey's jobless rate to 7.4 percent. Elsewhere in the New York region, the data showed little change. [49.] 
 The tobacco industry and antismoking forces have renewed hostilities over industry claims that a higher excise tax on tobacco products would devastate large parts of the economy. [37.]
An advisory committee issued two resolutions raising concerns about a plan to standardize a high-technology coding system that would permit wiretaps by law-enforcement officials. [37.]
 When the head of the National Association of Manufacturers was asked to form a coalition to lobby against the Administration's energy tax, he was not optimistic. But within weeks, about 600 companies and organizations had signed on. [37.]
The F.C.C. said it would stop handling customer complaints about cable television unless it got an extra $28 million. [38.]
 
Companies
Springs Industries' offer for Fieldcrest Cannon and Amoskeag has shareholders itching for a bidding war. [37.]
California's Insurance Department has temporarily barred 247 unlicensed insurers from writing policies in the state. [39.]
 BMW named a new chairman and chief executive of its recently organized BMW (U.S.) Holding Corporation. [39.]
 A tug-of-war intensified between creditors of the Canadian and U.S. branches of the distressed Olympia & York empire. [39.]
Officials of 3Com hope to help the company's stock recover from a steep plunge. [39.]
 The new president of Daniel, Mann, Johnson & Mendenhall intends to use his expertise in hazardous-waste cleanup to gain new business for the big architectural design firm. [39.]
Pratt & Whitney said it had tentatively agreed not to move 2,300 Connecticut jobs to plants out of state. [26.]
 
Markets
The strong employment report rocked the Treasury market. Yields moved higher on everything from bills to bonds. [37.]
Most leading stock indexes moved lower in lackluster trading. The Dow industrials closed at 3,545.14, up 0.27 point. [38.]
The dollar soared against leading European currencies. [48.] Sugar futures rose sharply after Cuba told customers it could not fulfill its shipment contracts. [48.]
 
Your Money
Some policyholders are turning to medical claims agents, who are used to handling filings of insurance papers and making follow-up calls. They also know how and when to challenge insurers over a rejected claim or paltry reimbursement. [35.]
Customers may finally be ready to open their wallets, and Wall Street believes many retailers may benefit. [35.]
Some high-income people are wondering what to do about their June 15 payment of estimated taxes. Tax professionals say to ignore the politicians -- for now. [35.]
Most working Americans desperately need to increase their retirement savings, benefits consultants say. [36.]

HEADLINE: Going for the Kill on the Energy Tax Plan

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
When Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, was asked by a large company in April to form a broad coalition to lobby against the Clinton Administration's proposed energy tax, he was not optimistic.
At the time, he had reason to worry. The Democratic Congress wanted to help the new President reduce the deficit, and the tax plan, which also promised to promote energy conservation, seemed to have a good chance of passage. 
 "We thought it was very long shot," Mr. Jasinowski said of the prospects of forming a coalition. But he and his staff drafted a letter that detailed what they saw as the tax's major drawbacks; they argued that it would add to the cost of producing goods, making American companies less competitive against foreign rivals.
To his surprise, the initial letter, which was sent to trade associations, provoked an overwhelming response. Within weeks, about 600 companies, trade groups and other organizations had signed on for a two-pronged lobbying effort. On one front, chambers of commerce and other local groups of business people would put pressure on legislators in their home districts; on the other, a swarm of lobbyists on Capitol Hill would barrage legislative staffs with information.
Many legislators listened to those campaigns, and pressed for changes that their constituents wanted. And when President Clinton was desperate for votes to get his deficit-reduction package through the House of Representatives late last month, he was receptive to horse-trading away some components of the energy tax.
The coalition, called the American Energy Alliance, has continued to grow and now includes about 1,650 organizations. About two-thirds are small businesses; other members include trade associations like the American Farm Bureau Federation and major companies like Goodyear, Gillette, Coors and Domino Sugar.
In its two months of existence, the coalition has helped to exempt several industries from at least some effects of the proposed tax. Coal, oil, aluminum and other industries -- as well as the agricultural sector -- have seen changes in the proposal, and other groups are fighting for more. Even if a tax plan survives, it may be pared down substantially from the President's proposal, which aimed to raise about $71 billion through 1998.
The first lobbying gains were made by energy industries, which used their teams to press the point that an energy tax, in any form, would be passed on to the consumer. The airline and trucking industries, as well as others that use large amounts of fuel, would in most cases adopt higher fares and rates.
The breadth and depth of the coalition, Mr. Jasinowski said, had a big impact when lobbyists began work.
"I have never seen as broad a response as on the energy tax" in 10 years of lobbying in Washington, he said, adding, "The diversity of the members was a major plus."
Not satisfied with all the changes it has already wrought, the coalition is now going for the kill. This weekend, it is sending a letter to each member of the Senate, urging rejection of an energy tax in any form.
 
A Grass-Roots Campaign
 Some coalition members, like the Citizens for a Sound Economy, a Washington group that lobbies against economic regulation, have led grass-roots efforts. The group, led by James C. Miller 3d, a former budget director for President Ronald Reagan, has a quarter of a million members who pay $15 each in annual dues.
It has organized protest rallies in several states, including one yesterday in Bismarck, N.D., where about 200 farmers, office workers and business people gathered in a hotel to hear Gov. Edward T. Schafer, a Republican, and others denounce the proposed tax.
The group is making a major effort in North Dakota because both of its Senators and its one Representative are Democrats. It has also held rallies in Oklahoma, home of Senator David L. Boren, and in Louisiana, home of Senator John B. Breaux, both of whom have been critical of the original proposal. Both Democrats are members of the Senate Finance Committee, which has a big role in determining the fate of the tax.
The Citizens for a Sound Economy has also sent out 9,500 information packets to business and political leaders and recently used phone banks to rouse opposition.
Through its local and national efforts, the coalition has helped to change the form and the impact of the proposed tax, which would be imposed according to the heat content of fuels, as measured in British thermal units.
Now, said Theodore R. Eck, the chief economist for the Amoco Corporation: "The B.T.U. tax has become like an old inner tube of a bicycle wheel. It's got so many patches in won't hold air anymore. Almost everybody has gotten an accommodation."
The first energy industry to get a major exemption was coal, in April, when it persuaded the Administration not to collect the tax at the mine but to have utilities collect it when they buy their coal.
John Grasser, the vice president of public relations for the National Coal Association, said the Treasury was convinced that it made more sense to collect the tax from the 154 utilities that use coal in large quantities. Of the one billion tons of coal produced each year, he estimated, about 80 percent is sold to utilities.
Then the utilities came to bat. They expressed their fears that utility rate regulators would not allow them to pass the tax on to consumers. In May, the industry prevailed, persuading the Administration to propose that the tax be included on utility bills.
Then the aluminum industry, a major user of electricity, won an agreement to receive a large exemption. The industry argued that because it used so much power and because demand for aluminum was relatively weak, it would be unable to push through a price increase and would be badly hurt by the tax.
The oil industry was also able to shift payment of the tax from the refineries to the terminals, where wholesalers buy various products, like gasoline. The industry argued that it was unfair to tax it for the energy used in production.
Earl Ross, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said the support of the coalition was a big help for his industry's efforts.
"When you show 1,650 signatures of different organizations, then people begin to think twice about it," he said.
A major exemption was also granted for home heating oil, following lobbying by legislators from the Northeast. They argued that because oil would be taxed at a higher rate than natural gas, the Northeast would bear a larger burden than regions like the Midwest, where homes use more natural gas for heat.
In the meantime, the coalition's lobbying efforts continue. With all the exemptions, what is left of the energy tax plan?
Basically, it would be a tax on transportation, said Larry Goldstein, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in Washington. "It's a tax on the highway user on diesel, gasoline and jet fuel," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: To the surprise of many who feared that the odds were against him, Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, has found growing enthusiasm for his coalition against the Clinton Administration's energy tax plan. At a staff meeting, he remained alert to his schedule. (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Details Emerge in Killing of Man in Police Custody

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Besides blows to the head and neck, a prisoner's inability to breathe while he was trussed up and left face down on a bed for more than a half hour may have been a major factor in his death while he was in police custody last week, a person familiar with the case said yesterday.
Many new details of the last hour of the prisoner's life emerged yesterday as the Manhattan District Attorney and the Police Commissioner promised thorough investigations, and civil rights advocates representing the dead man's family amplified on charges that the victim, a black man, had been beaten to death by white officers as they used racial epithets. 
 In another development, lawyers representing the wife of the dead man, Johnny Cromartie, filed a notice of claim for an $11 million lawsuit against the city, alleging his wrongful death. Mr. Cromartie, 40, of Harlem, had been arrested on a gun possession charge and was hospitalized after suffering an apparent epileptic seizure.
 
Dispute Over Circumstances
 Mr. Cromartie, an unemployed man who suffered from epilepsy and alcoholism, died at New York Downtown Hospital on May 25 under sharply disputed circumstances.
The Medical Examiner on Thursday ruled Mr. Cromartie's death a homicide, saying he died of repeated blows to the head, neck and trunk and of breathing problems after being restrained by officers for "agitated behavior consistent with delirium tremens," a symptom of alcohol withdrawal. An enlarged heart due to high blood pressure was also a factor, the coroner said.
But pending a grand jury finding, legal responsibility remained unclear. The police said necessary force had been used to restrain a violent man trying to escape. The man's mother, Laura Pruitt, and her lawyer, C. Vernon Mason, said that there had been no attempt to escape, that Mr. Cromartie was only agitated by a medical problem and that he was needlessly stomped, kicked and beaten to death.
Yesterday, Mr. Mason, the Rev. Al Sharpton, who is often critical of the police, and State Senator David A. Paterson, a Manhattan Democrat, met separately with Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly. Afterward, Mr. Mason and Mr. Sharpton reiterated their allegations that Mr. Cromartie had been wrongfully killed by the police.
 
Reports of a Witness
 Mr. Sharpton said he had spoken on Wednesday to a witness, whom he refused to identify but whom he described as concerned about his personal safety. Mr. Sharpton quoted the witness as saying that there had been no attempt to escape and that Mr. Cromartie had been beaten without provocation, apprently while suffering a seizure.
Mr. Mason said the witness, a person who has not been publicly identified and whom he acknowledged he had not spoken to, was under round-the-clock police protection and had provided accounts of what happened to the district attorney and the police Internal Affairs Division.
"It's our understanding that the witness said that Mr. Cromartie was beaten to death while handcuffed on the floor, literally beaten and stomped to death," Mr. Mason said. "They repeatedly called him 'nigger' while they were beating him to death."
Mr. Sharpton also reiterated his contention that the police were trying to cover up, and he criticized the authorities for not arresting the officers involved in the incident, who have been placed on desk duty pending the outcome of the investigations.
He said he would ask United States Attorney General Janet Reno for a Federal civil rights investigation and challenged Mayor David N. Dinkins and his probable opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, to take stands on the case.
 
Charges About Officers
 Mr. Mason quoted Mr. Morgenthau and Mr. Kelly as having said that seven officers had been involved, not five, as originally reported by the police. At least two of the officers were black, and a white sergeant supervised the group, the police said. But Mr. Mason contended that two white officers beat Mr. Cromartie.
Mr. Sharpton said that the other officers had a duty to intervene. "All the police in the room have some type of criminal exposure to varying degrees," he said. "None are innocent."
Mr. Mason had previously suggested that the key witness in the case was one of the black police officers. But the person familiar with the case, who provided many new details of what happened in Mr. Cromartie's last hour, said yesterday that the witness was not a police officer.
It was unclear whether any hospital personnel saw the confrontation, but Mr. Mason and Mr. Sharpton said that doctors had been cleared out by the police and only "heard a lot of what was going on."
Mr. Cromartie, who was arrested in Harlem three days before his death, was taken to the hospital on May 23 after suffering an apparent seizure and was admitted to the hospital the next day after another seizure episode. He was held under constant guard in Room 409.
 
Procedure on Handcuffs
 The confrontation that led to his death began at 12:13 A.M. on May 25, just as one officer was replacing another at a change of shifts. As is the practice, the departing officer removed his handcuffs from the prisoner so his replacement's cuffs could be put on.
According to the police version, when the first officer's cuffs were removed, Mr. Cromartie tried to escape and was subdued and recuffed with the help of other officers who were summoned.
In the account of the witness who spoke to authorities, two officers kicked and beat the prisoner and used racial epithets. But the person familiar with the case said it was unclear if the violence continued after the prisoner's wrists were cuffed again.
This person also said the bruises left by the blows were not readily visible and were discovered by the medical examiner only after detailed examination below the skin.
After subduing the prisoner, the person familiar with the case said, the officers placed Mr. Cromartie face down on the bed with his wrists cuffed behind him, with a Velcro wrap around his legs and with straps over his body to hold him down.
Mr. Cromartie, who was 5 feet 9 inches tall, weighed over 230 pounds and had a large belly, was left for 30 to 45 minutes in a position that compromised his capacity to breathe, this person said. Thus, in addition to the blows he sustained, the prisoner's inability to breathe was a significant factor in his death, the person said.
While Mr. Cromartie lay trussed on the bed, the police were waiting for an Emergency Medical Service crew to take him to Bellevue Hospital Center, which has greater security for holding prisoners. The crew arrived at 1 A.M. and soon afterward pronounced the prisoner dead.
In another development, Joel B. Savit, a lawyer for Mr. Cromartie's widow, Teresa Crawford Cromartie, filed a notice of claim to alert the city of her intention to file a wrongful death suit. Mr. Savit said that Mr. Cromartie had been separated for nine years from his wife, whom he married in 1980, but that he had provided support for her.

HEADLINE: Panel Sees Flaws in Plan For Encoding

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4

 BODY:
A Commerce Department advisory committee issued two draft resolutions today raising "serious concerns" about a Clinton Administration plan to standardize a high-technology coding system that would permit law-enforcement officials to tap telephone calls and computer data transmissions.
The resolutions call on the Administration to hold extensive public hearings on the new technology, known as the Clipper chip, and they urge that the technology not be deployed beyond the executive branch of the Government until the public review is completed. 
 The Computer System Security and Privacy Advisory Board, which was established by Congress under the Computer Security Act of 1987, held two days of public hearings this week to solicit industry and public reaction to the plan, which would create a national standard for telephone and data coding.
 
A 'Master Key'
 The system would permit law-enforcement officials to create a numeric "master key" to be held in "escrow." It could be obtained only by presenting a warrant to two separate agencies that would be charged with protecting pieces of the key.
 The idea is that splitting the key would make it more difficult for Government officials to abuse its powers.
But the proposal has generated widespread criticism from technology experts, industry officials and privacy advocates who argue that it is technically flawed and that it may be abused by Government officials and others. A number of industry executives and opponents of the plan said that today's resolution was a setback for the Government.
"This is a victory for the private sector and the privacy community," said Marc Rotenberg, Washington director of the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, a computer industry public interest group. "The board heard a strong set of witnesses this week saying, 'Don't do it.' "
A White House official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said today that the Administration was comfortable with the resolution and that the Government was not rushing to put its plan into effect.
The plan calls for the use of several chips, known as Clipper and Capstone, designed by the National Security Agency to encode voice and data conversations, but it will not outlaw the use of other coding systems. This has led critics of the plan to argue that the proposed technology will not be useful in listening to people suspected of criminal activities who wish to protect their conversations.
 The advisory board says that it sees these shortcomings in the plan:
*The Administration has not made a persuasive argument that a significant problem exists.
*Because it is a hardware-based solution, the Clipper/Capstone proposal does not address the needs of the software industry.
*The economic implications of the proposal have not been examined.
*Congress, as well as the Administration, should play a role in the conduct and approval of the review.
 Some industry officials have suggested that the Clipper proposal may backfire on the chip's designer, the National Security Agency, a secretive intelligence arm of the Pentagon.
"This could be a huge mistake for the National Security Agency," said Stephen D. Bryen, president of Delta Tech, which makes data coding gear. "Clipper will make it more difficult for the U.S. to do what it has to do on an international level, to deal with bad guys using coding gear."

HEADLINE: Haitian Rulers Are Target of New Sanctions by U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
In a tacit acknowledgment that its diplomacy has failed to restore Haiti's democratically elected Government, the Clinton Administration today imposed sanctions on supporters of the military-backed Government and said it would begin consultations on further economic measures, including a possible oil embargo.
Administration officials said the assets in the United States of 83 individuals and 35 institutions would be frozen, including cash accounts, real estate and other property. They will also be blocked from any financial transactions in the United States, and the individuals and members of their families will be barred from entering the country. 
 But some officials suggested that the sanctions might be of limited effect since most Haitian businessmen have probably moved their assets out of the United States by now.
The Administration said it would consult with the Organization of American States and the United Nations on ways to bring further economic pressure on Haiti's military rulers.
"It could include an oil embargo," said one of two midlevel Administration officials who discussed the American move with reporters today at the White House on condition that their names not be published. "That's certainly one of the measures under consideration."
The moves, the strongest American actions since a trade embargo was imposed after the overthrow of Haiti's President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in 1991, are intended to force the military leaders to accept Father Aristide's return to power.
The sanctions come two weeks after the collapse of negotiations between American and United Nations envoys and representatives of the military-backed Government in Port-au-Prince. The talks broke off over the failure of all parties -- including Father Aristide -- to agree to accept a 500-member United Nations police force intended to insure that no civil unrest would accompany Father Aristide's return to power.
 
No Concrete Results
 Father Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, is Haiti's first democratically elected President. In January, five days before his own inauguration, President Clinton reversed himself and ordered that Haitians fleeing the country's political repression and deteriorating economic conditions would be returned without being able to press a claim of political asylum. The Coast Guard says 551 Haitians have been picked up in the waters near the island since then.
At the time of the decision, Mr. Clinton said his Administration would step up efforts to bring about Father Aristide's return. But despite the appointment of a special envoy to Haiti, the step-by-step diplomacy employed by the Administration has failed to achieve any concrete results.
"Unfortunately, the parties in Haiti have not been willing to make the decisions or take the steps necessary to begin democracy's restoration," President Clinton said in a written state today.
The President added: "In light of their own failure to act constructively, I have determined that the time has come to increase the pressure on the Haitian military, the de facto regime in Haiti and their supporters."
The sanctions are aimed at 83 individuals and 35 institutions, including Haitian banks and Government agencies, with assets in the United States. Administration officials said notifications had already been wired to Federal Reserve Banks, which would notify financial institutions where those affected by the sanctions had accounts. The officials said they expected that the accounts would be blocked by the end of the business day today.
 
Premier on the List
 Among those listed by the Treasury Department are Marc L. Bazin, the country's Prime Minister and nominal ruler, though he is actually considered a figurehead. Also listed is Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the Chief of Staff of Haiti's 7,000-man army and the man considered to be the real power in the country.
Suggestions that further economic sanctions may be imposed on Haiti's economic elite have been swirling about for months, and Administration officials acknowledge that some supporters of the military-backed Government may have shifted their funds out of American financial accounts. But these officials say the order announced today goes beyond cash and other liquid assets.
"Presumably, large-scale Haitian businessmen long ago moved most of their liquid financial assets offshore," said a senior Administration official, who spoke only on the promise of anonymity. "But if they've got nonliquid assets -- companies, real estate, houses -- that can't be moved, that would be blocked. Plus, anything that moves through the financial system -- house sales, any sort of transaction whatsoever -- will be blocked."
While the President's order about entry visas applies to supporters of the military-backed Government and members of their immediate families, the freezing of assets and the blocking of financial transactions involves only the supporters themselves.

HEADLINE: From Powerful Pulpit, a Moral Warrior Takes Aim

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD

 BODY:
When the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d announced last month that he would unleash a campaign against explicit rap lyrics, he and his allies characterized the move as logical step for a charismatic pastor who increasingly uses his pulpit to speak out on moral issues in the black community.
But when that pulpit is at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, the 186-year-old, 5,000-member Harlem institution that was a springboard to political power for Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the sermons draw careful scrutiny. 
 So while a variety of high-profile black leaders and organizations have voiced support for his campaign, at least one Harlem church leader wondered whether Mr. Butts was drawing too much attention to a dispute that perhaps is better left resolved quietly among black people.
And his call to gather tapes and CD's at his church, at 132 West 138th Street, this morning and crush them with a steamroller seems to some to smack of the intolerance of book-burning crusades.
The scrutiny takes on even greater dimensions because of the leadership potential of Mr. Butts, 43, whose name is often floated in discussions of possible political candidates and who is known for his preaching skills, strong values and willingness to take controversial stands. That quality has earned him a shoot-from-the-hip reputation, and the campaign against explicit rap lyrics seems certain to be discussed in that context.
Mr. Butts prefers to view it all in simpler terms. "We've got to clean this up," he said. "We have to demand more of our children." As for the issues he chooses and his public image, he said, "I do what I think God is leading me to do."
Mr. Butts said his concern about rap grew after he subscribed to cable television last year and saw music videos that frequently included scantily clad women. He recalled driving in Newark and hearing a loudspeaker outside a store repeatedly blaring the lyric, "Any ho's in the house." Many rap songs refer to women as whores.
Mr. Butts has been a high-profile figure since joining the Abyssinian church in 1972 as a junior minister. He was a catalyst behind 1983 Congressional hearings on police brutality in New York. On different issues, he has been willing over the years to take on such prominent New Yorkers as John Cardinal O'Connor, Edward I. Koch and Robert M. Morgenthau.
 
Criticism Over Stances
 He endured criticism over his refusal to repudiate Louis Farrakhan's "gutter religion" remarks in 1986, and two years ago he criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to travel to Israel, saying the Mayor was "pandering" to Jewish voters.
And last year he agreed to serve as a state campaign official for Ross Perot's Presidential campaign, spurning a chance to earn political credits for supporting the eventual winner, Bill Clinton. He now calls the move "the biggest mistake I probably ever made."
But Bob Law, the WWRL-AM radio talk-show host, who is close to Dr. Butts, cites other activities that are perhaps more telling in the pastor's evolution, particularly his painting over billboards in Harlem to protest what he called the disproportionate amount of advertising of tobacco and alcohol in black neighborhoods.
Mr. Butts has also spoken in favor of youth curfews and enforcement of public nuisance laws, and he has proposed confiscating vehicles from drivers who blast loud music from their car stereos.
The rap issue "is consistent with the kind of mission Butts is on," Mr. Law said. "Butts has tried to raise some of the difficult questions, whereas some leaders have raised the obvious questions."
For instance, Mr. Law said, among black people, criticizing police brutality is a safe political position. "But can we also disagree with popular rappers?" In other words, is it all right to publicize a dispute in which blacks are at odds with other blacks?
In an interview, Mr. Butts said that rap came out of the best of the black oral tradition. He said his campaign, launched in a sermon on Mother's Day, was aimed only at "vulgar and negative images."
"To call oneself a nigger after our long history of struggle is not redemptive," Mr. Butts said. "It is not helpful to have black women bumping and grinding their almost-bare buttocks."
Mr. Butts's campaign has resulted in a number of talk-show appearances and invitations to speak to such organizations as the International Association of African-American Music and the National Association of Black Journalists. He met with some rappers on Thursday and said he hopes to establish a continuing dialogue.
Some people, like the Rev. Patricia Reeberg, executive director of the New York City Council of Churches, said they agreed with Mr. Butts's point but were uneasy over today's plan to crush offensive tapes and CD's. Where does one draw the line in terms of the right to speak freely?
In general, though, response from established black leaders and organizations has been overwhelmingly positive, whether it be from Representative Charles B. Rangel, state N.A.A.C.P. president Hazel N. Dukes or Muslim organizations.
Many black leaders noted that calls for family values have a strong appeal among black people and believe that C. Vernon Mason, an Abyssinian deacon and civil rights lawyer, was likely correct in saying, "The overwhelming majority of people in our community are not in favor of our women being referred to as bitches."
Even Cory Robbins, president of Profile Records, a rap label that features Run-D.M.C., DJ Quik and N2Deep, said he was sympathetic to Mr. Butts's point of view.
But Mr. Robbins cautioned that it was wrong to lump together all songs that have explicit lyrics -- some artists use them to make intelligent points, others don't. And "at the end of the day, if the artists want to say something in a certain way, they should be able to say it."
But, he said: "Rappers do have a responsibility to their audience. Whether they like it or not, they are role models."
 
Uneasiness Remains
 Which is not to say that Mr. Butts's campaign is welcomed by all. Even at Abyssinian, which by all visible indicators is thriving under Mr. Butts's leadership -- standing-room-only on Sundays, achieving its budget goals, running innovative economic-development and housing programs -- there have always been some who were uneasy with Mr. Butts's ventures, who preferred the low-key, nurturing leadership of his predecessor, the Rev. Samuel D. Proctor.
John Pennington, whose family's roots in the church go back several generations, commutes to Abyssinian from Long Island. "I don't understand why I have to pay $10 to come into the city to hear someone talk about rap music," he said.
The Rev. Preston Washington, president of the 58-member Harlem Churches for Community Improvement, said, "Wouldn't it have been a better solution to meet, to work out something in-house?"
Mr. Washington, who is pastor of Memorial Baptist Church in Harlem, said the complexity of problems facing black people argued for Mr. Butts's consulting with other ministers for a collective approach toward problem solving.
 
Hints of Political Interest
 Like Mr. Powell, who used the Abyssinian pulpit as a base to gain elected office, Mr. Butts has shown interest in the political arena. The pastor, who speaks supportively of Mr. Dinkins's re-election campaign, remains close to City Council President Andrew J. Stein and is at least cordial with the Republican-Liberal candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani. He is said to have considered a race for public advocate, the renamed office of the City Council president.
And there was his support of the Perot candidacy, which he said resulted from his conclusion that the Democrats had mistreated Jesse Jackson and that the Republicans offered no alternative for black voters.
Some find the various options and alliances confusing in terms of reading Mr. Butts's own aspirations.
Speaking of his future recently, Mr. Butts said: "If the people of this community, or the city of New York or the state of New York, were to come and say, 'You know, Rev. Butts, you really ought to consider becoming a United States senator,' or something like that . . . and the Lord says, 'This is another extension of what I'd like you to do,' then I'll do it."
For now, Mr. Butts is working with the public school system toward the opening this fall of the Thurgood Marshall Academy for Learning and Social Change, for grades 6-12, and says he feels challenged by the church's economic development projects.
Mr. Butts said he saw the consensus-building approach to addressing an issue like explicit rap lyrics as tantamount to doing nothing while conditions for black people worsened.
He added that he does not weigh the political ramifications before deciding to speak out on a moral issue. "I think the moment I do that, I've betrayed my calling," he said.
"I'm not called to be popular. I'm not even called to be successful," Mr. Butts said. "I'm called to be faithful to the struggle."

HEADLINE: Hartford Bill on Integration Is Approved

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 4

 BODY:
A bill promoting racial integration in public schools across Connecticut won final approval tonight in the State Senate.
Although weakened by its supporters to win passage, the bill is a significant step toward addressing the issue of segregated schools, by requiring the state's cities and towns to participate in regional talks and offering financial incentives if they create schools that draw students across municipal boundaries. 
 Spurred through a nervous General Assembly by a lawsuit that seeks a school desegregation order for Hartford and 21 surrounding towns, the bill sets a one-year timetable for towns and cities to draft plans to "reduce barriers to opportunity" and "enhance student diversity."
It offers financial incentives for cooperation in voluntary measures like building new magnet schools or interdistrict schools, or otherwise allowing children from one community to attend school with those from another.
But school desegregation is such a volatile issue in Connecticut, where segregated schools have resulted from whites moving to suburbs, leaving poor black and Hispanic residents concentrated in the cities, that the bill's supporters took out many of its strongest points to insure that it would be approved. The vote was 19 to 16.
 
No Goals or Forced Participation
 The measure makes no direct reference to integration, desegregation or race. It sets no goals. It leaves the final decision on each regional plan in the hands of local town councils and school boards, rather than state officials. And it does not require any town or city to take part in the plans that they draw up.
In its original form the bill set guidelines under which 70 percent of the state's schools, both city and suburban, would be considered racially isolated, and it established as its primary goal the reduction of racial imbalance. Supporters in the legislature congratulated each other on establishing what they said was a framework needed for significant change. But others who had sought passage of the bill said that it was simply more of what Connecticut had already done on school integration: talk, but no real action.
Republicans attacked the bill tonight as an assault on local control over schools and an opening to mandatory busing across town lines, as Democratic supporters stressed that any measures taken under it would be voluntary.
The bill is expected to be signed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who started the debate in the General Assembly in January by devoting his State of the State Message to the racial and economic segregation dividing Connecticut's cities and towns. Because of the failures of schools in the state's cities, he said, the state was building more prisons than schools.
Soon desegregation was the talk of the state as Mr. Weicker's Education Commissioner, Vincent Ferrandino, submitted legislation that set goals for reducing racial isolation in both city and suburban schools.
 
Threat of Court Order
 Many legislators credit the bill's passage to the threat of a court order in the Hartford lawsuit, known as Sheff v. O'Neill, in which lawyers for 18 schoolchildren contend that the racial and economic isolation in the city's schools denies their students equal educational opportunity.
The city's enrollment is 92 percent black and Hispanic, and nearly two-thirds of the children live below the poverty line; they produce the lowest scores on statewide tests in reading, writing and mathematics.
The suit, in effect, is seeking a ruling in state courts that de facto segregation, because of its effects on education, is unconstitutional. Federal courts have refused to act against segregation that has not resulted from intentional discrimination.
The state's lawyers, in defending against the suit during testimony this winter, argued that Connecticut was already addressing the disparities between city and suburban schools, and cited the legislation as evidence.
In some ways, the legislation, in requiring towns and cities to meet together to discuss public education, is a major step forward for Connecticut. But in other ways, critics said, it follows the state's history over the last 25 years: studying racial isolation but doing little about it.
"If the goal is to bring the districts together to talk, then it is highly successful, because it requires the districts to participate in regional forums," said John Brittain, a University of Connecticut law professor and a lawyer for the plaintiffs in the Sheff suit. "But the bill has no relationship to the Sheff suit whatsoever, because the goal of that suit is to produce educational and racial equity."
The weakening of the bill, however, took place within the Education Committee, as Senator Sullivan and his House counterpart, Representative Nancy Wyman of Tolland, negotiated with the Governor and Mr. Ferrandino for a version that could win Democratic support.
The result, legislation so carefully couched in euphemism that Mr. Sullivan defined "diversity" tonight without mentioning race, nevertheless was attacked by Republicans as an outright desegregation bill.
"I would like to view education with a blind eye toward race," said Sen. John A. Kissel, a Republican from Enfield who won a special election this winter in part by opposing Mr. Ferrandino's original proposal.
The bill outlines a process starting in 1994 for local elected officials and school boards to study the educational needs of their communities and then appoint representatives to regional forums. The forums would also include a few parents and teachers.
By the end of 1994, the governing councils and school boards are to vote on the plans, and the Commissioner of Education can then recommend them for construction aid based on how well they meet his criteria for improving student performance and promoting integration.
If the Legislature approves such aid, financing would be available for the plans in the 1995-96 school year.
Senator Thirman L. Milner of Hartford, the city's first black Mayor, angrily criticized the bill's mention of school choice, which some members of the House had demanded as the price for their support. Choice plans, he said, simply attract a city's best students to suburban schools, leaving behind those who most need an integrated experience.
Then he said: "I wish, Senator Kissel, I could be like you, could turn a blind eye to the issue of race. I wish that people would not judge others by skin color. I'm sorry you don't know what diversity means. That's regrettable. But I do."
