HEADLINE: Barrington D. Parker, 77, Is Dead; Trial Judge for Reagan's Attacker

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Judge Barrington D. Parker of the Federal District Court in Washington, who presided over the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., the would-be Presidential assassin, and in other major cases, died on Wednesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 77.
The cause was complications from a heart attack and stroke he suffered in 1989, a family spokesman said. Judge Parker lived in Northwest Washington. 
 Judge Parker, who was appointed to the bench by President Richard M. Nixon in 1969, was noted for his boldness. "He has no hesitancy in coming forth with unpopular decisions," a longtime friend and fellow Federal judge, Robert L. Carter, once said.
Until his appointment, Judge Parker, a Republican, practiced law as a partner in the firm of Parker & Parker. He retired from the Federal bench in 1985.
Judge Parker was born in Rosslyn, Va., on Nov. 17, 1915, the only child of George A. Parker and Maude Daniels Parker. His father was dean of the Terrell Law School in Washington, which has since closed. Judge Parker once taught there.
 
Chicago Law Graduate
 He went to Dunbar High School in Washington, where he met his wife, the former Marjorie Holloman. He graduated in 1936 from Lincoln University in Pennsylvania with a bachelor's degree in economics and, in 1938, he received a master's degree from the University of Pennsylvania. He earned his law degree from the University of Chicago in 1947.
In a 1973 ruling, Judge Parker barred the Nixon Administration's attempt to impose certain price controls, calling them "arbitrary and capricious." In another case, he ruled against a National Guard attempt to bar long-haired guardsmen from wearing short-cropped wigs when on duty.
And in 1978, in connection with a merger between the National Student Marketing Company and an insurance holding company, he ruled that Federal securities regulations did not require lawyers to disclose fraud by their clients.
At the 1982 trial of Mr. Hinckley, the jury found the defendant not guilty by reason of insanity of trying to assassinate President Ronald Reagan after Judge Parker told its members that they had to be convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the prosecution had proved the gunman was able to understand the wrongfulness.
 
Ordered Hinckley Committed
 Mr. Hinckley had shot and wounded Mr. Reagan and three other men, including the White House press secretary, James Brady, on March 30, 1981. After the acquittal, Judge Parker ordered Mr. Hinckley committed to a mental hospital.
When not in judicial robes, the judge liked to read historical fiction -- James Michener was a favorite -- and listen to progressive jazz and classical music.
In October 1975, Judge Parker was struck by a car while crossing a Washington street, and his left leg had to be amputated.
Besides his wife, Judge Parker is survived by two sons, Jason Parker of Manhattan, and Barrington D. Parker Jr. of Stamford, Conn.; an uncle, Grafton Daniels of Washington, and three granddaughters.

HEADLINE: THE GUINIER BATTLE;
President Blames Himself for Furor Over Nominee

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
His skin was ruddy as ever. He seemed resolute enough. But there was a star-crossed look on President Clinton's face when he joined his dinner guests Thursday night, two hours late, after what he described as "a brutal, heartbreaking day" wrestling with the fate of Lani Guinier.
He blamed neither Ms. Guinier, whose nomination as head of the civil rights division in the Justice Department he had just withdrawn, nor his staff. He blamed only himself for the hurt he had caused his friend and himself. 
 As he ate his dinner, and over coffee later, Mr. Clinton appeared quite willing, at times almost eager, to discuss how he had got into this mess, which stopped the momentum he had seemed to be gaining after his victory on taxes and spending in the House of Representatives and his appointment of David R. Gergen as Presidential counselor.
 
Acknowledges Mistakes
 He acknowledged that he had been wrong to nominate Ms. Guinier without first reading her legal articles carefully; wrong to assume, when they caused controversy, that she could still be confirmed because people would know that Attorney General Janet Reno, not Ms. Guinier, would set department policy, and wrong to let political pressures build to the bursting point before deciding what he ought to do.
Mr. Clinton, who has known Ms. Guinier since their days together at the Yale Law School in the 1970's, said that she had resisted his decision, "which must have hit her in the head like a two-by-four," but that she "was a champ."
"I love her," he said. "I think she's wonderful. If she called me and told me she needed $5,000, I'd take it from my account and send it to her, no questions asked. It was the hardest decision I've had to make since I became President, but you can't fight on and on when you don't believe in it.
"I really don't think what's in her articles matches what I stand for."
 
Possible Fallout From Decision
 One of those seated with him asked whether, on purely political grounds, he might not have been better off to let the nomination go forward, even if defeat in the Senate ensued, thus placing at least some of the onus on Capitol Hill. The President replied rather grimly that his questioner might be right.
But in his campaign last year, he said, he had talked about an inclusive society, in which everyone would be treated equally, and he found it impossible to support a nominee whose writings seemed to him to advocate different political mechanisms for blacks.
Mr. Clinton readily conceded that he might lose the support of the black caucus in the House of Representatives, with its 38 votes, as well as the backing of a significant number of women in Congress. He conceded that he could not afford to lose those votes on important issues like his health plan and campaign and welfare reform, to say nothing of his economic program.
And he spoke with ill-concealed bitterness about what he described as "a campaign of right-wing distortion and vilification" in the news media, mentioning with particular scorn an April 30 Wall Street Journal op-ed article by Clint Bolick, a longtime associate of Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court. Its headline branded Ms. Guinier a "quota queen," a phrase that was picked up and used by her critics and other newspapers.
Most of the 39 people at four round tables in the Green Room, a dining room in Jefferson's day that is now used mainly for receptions, were halfway through their beef Wellington, and some were on their second glass of Jordan Cabernet Sauvignon, when the President finally walked in and sat down. After a few moments, he slowly began explaining, in reply to a question, why he had decided to abandon the nomination.
 
Gore's Advice to President
 If not an historic moment, at least by the standards of the White House, where so many truly portentous decisions have been reached, it was a highly dramatic one, and many of the guests -- journalists, Democratic leaders, businessmen, figures from the capital's cultural life -- sensed how much Mr. Clinton had at stake as he struggles to get his Presidency back on course.
It was Vice President Al Gore, the President said, who had confronted him Thursday morning and told him he had to thoroughly study the three or four law journal articles that were causing trouble, then decide quickly what to do.
 
Matters That Troubled Clinton
 On the way to Frederick, Md., for a speaking date, and on the way back, Mr. Clinton said he read them. He had been leaning toward withdrawal, but they were the final element in convincing him, he said, that he must abandon the nomination. He discussed the crisis with Ms. Guinier for more than an hour, starting at 6:30 P.M. and continuing while his guests sipped cocktails on the Truman balcony and toured the Lincoln Bedroom and the Treaty Room with the President's wife, Hillary.
While there had been anti-Guinier pressure from the Senate in the preceding days, and the situation there was "horrible," the President said, on Thursday the pro-Guinier pressure, chiefly from blacks and women, was greater. The advice from his staff, Mr. Clinton added, "went both ways, yes and no."
Pressed to explain why he had not read the journal articles weeks ago, the President said that he had kept expecting people to focus on "what she has done in court, not what she has written." Far too late, he said, he realized that as in the case of Robert H. Bork, whose nomination for the Supreme Court in 1987 was defeated during the Reagan Administration, it was the paper trail that mattered most.
He mentioned two specific matters that troubled him most deeply.
In a Virginia Law Review article, Ms. Guinier spoke of "authentic black leaders" and suggested that black politicians who represented largely white constituencies were obliged to dilute the intensity of their concentration on issues of primary interest to blacks. In a footnote, she seemed to cite Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia as such a politician, but she and her supporters later said that she had not meant to single out Governor Wilder.
"I don't agree with any of that," Mr. Clinton said near the end of the dinner gathering, "but even if I cut her some slack on black leaders, I just can't agree with her on the Alabama case, as fine a woman as she is."
In a case from Etowah County, Ala., the white majority prevented a black county commissioner from exercising his powers. Ms. Guinier cited this as the sort of case that needed bold new remedies, such as cumulative voting, in one of her articles. In discussions with him, the President said, she said that such remedies should be used "only in extreme cases, but what she wrote was much broader than that."
The President acknowledged that power-sharing, or modifications of majority rule to assure participation by a minority, had been considered by the British in Northern Ireland and would probably be adopted in South Africa. It has also been used in a number of cases in this country. But he said the treatment of blacks and whites as two separate communities in the United States -- as "we and they" -- "runs completely counter to all of my ideas about a single society."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lani Guinier greeting Ginny Montes, national secretary of the National Organization for Women, after her news conference yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. 8)
 
Chronology: "Clinton on Guinier"
 On April 29, President Clinton nominated Lani Guinier to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's civil rights division. Here are some of his comments about her and the appointment since then.
 
May 11 (At an awards dinner of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights)
"I want to say a special word of support for Lani Guinier. I went to law school with her, and I announced at the Justice Department the other day, when we announced all of our assistant attorneys general, that she had actually sued me once. Not only that, she didn't lose. And I nominated her anyway. So the Senate ought to be able to put up with a little controversy in the cause of civil rights and go on and confirm her so we can get about the business of America."
 
May 14 (At a news conference)
"I nominated her because there had never been a full-time practicing civil rights lawyer, with a career in civil rights law, heading the civil rights division. I expect the policy to be made on civil rights laws by the United States Congress, and I expect the Justice Department to carry out that policy. Insofar as there is discretion in the policy, that discretionary authority should reside either in the President or the Attorney General in terms of what policies the country will follow. I still think she's a very well-qualified civil rights lawyer, and I hope she will be confirmed. And I think she has every intention of following the law of the land as Congress writes it."
 
May 14 (Following the news conference)
"I would never have appointed anybody to public office if they had to agree with everything I believe in. We wouldn't have a Cabinet. Based on my personal experience, you will believe me when I say I am confident that she will follow the Constitution and the laws of the United States. You have to swear an oath of office to that. She may wish the law were different in some areas, but I've had personal experience with her accomplishments as a civil rights lawyer. And I thought we ought to have a distinguished civil rights lawyer as head of the civil rights division. ... I never have associated myself with all of her writings, or all of anybody else's."
 
June 2 (During a photo opportunity)
"I think that I have to talk to some of the senators about it because of the reservations that have been raised both publicly and privately. I want to reaffirm two positive things about her. One is everyone can see she is a first-rate civil rights lawyer, and no real civil rights lawyer has ever held that position before, someone who's made a career of it. Secondly, I think any reasonable reading of her writings would lead someone to conclude that a lot of the attacks cannot be supported by a fair reading of the writings. And that's not to say that I agree with everything in the writings; I don't. But I think that a lot of what has been said is not accurate. On the other hand, I have to take into account where the Senate is, and I will be doing that and talking to them."
 
June 3 (Announcing the withdrawal of the nomination)
"At the time of the nomination, I had not read her writings. In retrospect, I wish I had. Today, as a matter of fairness to her, I read some of them again in good detail. They clearly lend themselves to interpretations that do not represent the views that I expressed on civil rights during my campaign, and views that I hold very dearly, even though there is much in them with which I agree. ... The problem is that this battle will be waged based on her academic writings. And I cannot fight a battle that I know is divisive, that is an uphill battle, that is distracting to the country, if I do not believe in the ground of the battle. That is the only problem." (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Job Surge Hurts Stocks, But Dow Gains Fraction

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Most leading stock indexes moved lower yesterday on a largely lackluster trading day, uninspired by strong jobs data issued yesterday morning.
An exception was the Dow Jones industrial average, which was down as much as 14 points but shot up 5.5 points in the last five minutes of trading. The Dow closed at 3,545.14, up 0.27 point for the day and up 17.71 for the week. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500, with a greater variety of stocks than the blue-chip index, closed 2.43 points lower at 450.06. The Nasdaq composite index, with more than 3,500 smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, closed down 4.21 points, to 702.01. The Nasdaq 100, made up of the largest of those stocks, declined even more precipitously, down 6.87 points, to 737.25.
 
Indexes Are Down
 The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index closed down 1.37 points, to 248.22. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was also relatively light for most of the session, possibly exaggerating the price declines. Big Board volume totaled 226.4 million shares, compared with 285.6 million on Thursday.
The American Stock Exchange market value index closed up 0.04 point, to 440.95, another record.
The May unemployment figures released by the Labor Department were better than generally expected. Traders were looking for a 7 percent rate, matching the April number, and the actual figure was 6.9 percent, the lowest level in 18 months.
But traders may have seen a cloud rather than a silver lining in the data. The jobs figure could put added pressure on the Federal Reserve Board, which voted last month to raise interest rates if necessary, to actually do so, diminishing the allure of stocks to investors. Bond prices fell in part out of traders' concerns that the Fed would raise rates.
 
Gains for Gold
 Gold prices rose strongly, a move that was partly followed by most gold stocks. Some money shifted from stocks to gold in the early afternoon, contributing to the Dow's decline.
Echo Bay Mines, which has regularly been among the most active stocks on the American Stock Exchange recently, closed up 1/8, to 11 3/4. Newmont Mining closed unchanged at 51 1/2.
No stocks dominated trading in today's session. Allstate, in its second day of trading after the initial public offering, was the most active stock, at 6.3 million shares. It closed down 3/4, to 28 5/8.
Wal-Mart was the second-most-active stock, with 4.83 million shares traded. It closed down 3/4, to 26 3/4, on concern among some investors that retail sales would remain sluggish.
Synoptics Communications Inc. dropped 12 1/4, to 106, after a downgrading of the stock by a Salomon Brothers analyst. Synoptics is a computer networking company that makes and markets equipment for both computer and telecommunications uses.
But if the economy remains sluggish, demand for such high-tech gear may slow significantly, analysts say. A Ladenburg Thalmann analyst, however, reaffirmed his buy recommendation for Synoptics.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Jobless Rate Down to 7.4%

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A surprising surge in employment after three months of economic deterioration cut the unemployment rate in New Jersey to 7.4 percent last month, according to Federal data released yesterday.
The May unemployment rate was the lowest since January and it was appreciably below the 9.1 percent in April, when New Jersey had the highest rate of any large industrialized state. 
 "One month does not make a trend, but the May numbers for New Jersey are very encouraging," said Jesse Benjamin, the assistant New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which released the report yesterday.
 
Leading the Nation
 While New Jersey's unemployment rate declined in May, both the number of people in the labor maket and the number who were employed rose sharply. Indeed, in a finding that baffled some economists in the region, the Federal agency said New Jersey added 130,000 jobs in May, more than half of the nation's entire job growth for the month.
Elsewhere in the region, the data showed little change from previous months.
In New York State, unemployment rose to 7.5 percent, from 7 percent in April. In New York City, it declined to 9.5 percent, from 9.8 percent in April. Connecticut is not among the states for which employment data are released with the national report each month.
"The numbers are consistent with what we know already: the region is in a long wide bottom of the recession," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Ms. Scanlon said she was skeptical of the May data showing an extraordinary increase in New Jersey employment. The numbers were derived from a Federal survey in which thousands of people are visited in their homes each month. "The greatest probability is that there was an unusual sampling result," she said.
Ray Bramucci, the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Labor, said the huge increase "is a ballistic missile move that has left the professionals on my staff in a quandary." As Ms. Scanlon did, he also said the May data might have been influenced by glitches in the Federal survey.
Still, after sharp unemployment increases in each of the three months beginning in January, when New Jersey's rate was 7.4 percent, Ms. Scanlon said the good news about May merely brought the state back in line with New York State results and with economists' expectations.
"Things haven't gotten worse, but they haven't got that much better either," she said.
The May report could have political repercussions in New Jersey, where Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, is being challenged in a heated re-election bid this year. The high unemployment rate that had been reported for the state for April could not have been good news for his campaign.
Yesterday, Mr. Florio responded to the May report by saying "the numbers are headed in the right direction." But Cary Edwards, a candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in the state's primary on Tuesday, said the employment data might have improved because employers are "reacting to the prospect of a fundamental change in state policy" and a new governor.
 
Weather May Have Helped
 One reason cited for the May improvement was good weather. Mr. Benjamin said the weather might have prompted employers to hire summer workers in recreational industries and students on summer vacation earlier than usual. Other analysts said construction activity had shown signs of picking up.
Mr. Bramucci of the state's Labor Department said no construction data were yet available for May, but that housing starts in New Jersey had increased by a strong 43 percent in March and that the increases appeared to have been sustained in the last two months.
Another indicator of improvement was in first-time claims for unemployment benefits, recorded by Mr. Bramucci's department. He said the number of new claims shrank 7 percent in May, to 11,172.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rise in Jobs Roils Bond Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury market was rocked by a surprisingly strong employment report yesterday, driving yields higher on everything from bills to bonds.
The surprise in the May jobs report was twofold. First, the increase in nonfarm payroll jobs of 209,000 in the month was higher than the consensus forecast of about 140,000, showing that the economy was spunkier than expected. The second surprise was the revision of the April increase, which was raised to 216,000 from the initial report of 119,000. 
 "The economy appears now to be accelerating some but to what level no one knows," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst for Chase Securities Inc.
 
3% Growth Seen
 Mr. Fine argued that the strong jobs report and the increases in income and consumer spending that it implied, taken with signs that car sales were accelerating, meant that the economy was on a track of 3 percent growth, which could mean inflation would rise. That is the outlook that worried the bond market.
Despite the sharp fall in prices, which sent yields surging, immediately after the 8:30 A.M. release of the jobs data by the Labor Department, the market reaction in longer-term issues seemed constrained. And that may be because the Federal Reserve indicated recently that it would move to contain inflation by pushing up short-term interest rates.
While the price of the 30-year bond dropped 20/32 and the yield jumped to 6.91 percent, from 6.86 percent Thursday, the yield was still well below the 6.98 percent of a week ago. In addition, the price of the bond was down almost a point and the yield up to 6.93 percent before rebounding a little in the afternoon.
 
Bills and Notes React
 The bigger reaction in the bond market was in Treasury bills and shorter-term Treasury notes. The yield on the two-year note jumped to 4.31 percent, from 4.13 percent Thursday. And the discount rate on the six-month Treasury bill, which was 3.15 percent Thursday, leaped to 3.27 percent yesterday.
The reason for this sharper response is that the stronger jobs growth, combined with the sharp rise in inflation so far this year, to a 4.3 percent annual rate, means that there is less chance for inflation subsiding in the second half of the year. If that is the case, it is more likely that the Federal Reserve will push short-term interest rates higher to try to restrain price increases.
Reports have already indicated that the Fed is ready to push the Federal funds rate higher if inflation does not subside. Its target for the Fed funds rate, which is the interest rate charged on overnight loans between banks, has been 3 percent since last September.
In addition, traders said the market might have been affected by a Reuters report yesterday, attributed to a Treasury official, that the Administration would not be too concerned by an increase in rates by the Fed to fight inflation.
In the report, Alicia Munnell, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy, said, "It really would be overreacting to become concerned every time the Fed moved to keep inflation within acceptable limits."
 
Inflation Data Coming
 What will happen to interest rates from here will depend in part on the inflation data for May, which is due in the next week and a half. If the increases for May are subdued and show the 4.3 percent pace of the first four months of the year is slowing, then the Federal Reserve could hold off from increasing short-term rates for now. This would take some pressure off both short and long rates.
But if inflation is up sharply again, than Mr. Fine of Chase Securities said he thought that the Fed would have to move right away. This could push short rates even higher, but the rise at the long end may be contained if the market believes that the Fed will continue to fight rising inflation by pushing up short-term rates.

HEADLINE: Squaring Off Over Cigarette Taxes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Never friends, seldom respectful of each other, the tobacco industry and antismoking forces have renewed their hostilities over industry claims that a higher excise tax on tobacco products, as part of the Clinton Administration's health-care plan, would devastate large parts of the economy.
Braced for the current tax of 24 cents a pack to at least double, and possibly amount to more than $2, tobacco interests predict those levels would cut consumption enough to kill hundreds of thousands of jobs in industries from farming to retailing, close businesses and deprive state and local governments of millions of dollars in taxes.
 
Another Point of View
 Yet opponents cite the industry's own behavior of the last 13 years to dispute those arguments. Until April -- when Philip Morris announced price cuts of up to 40 cents a pack on Marlboro, and other cigarette makers followed suit -- the companies had raised prices 33 times, by more than 350 percent, notwithstanding a tripling of the Federal excise tax. Yet jobs did not disappear at nearly the rate the tobacco interests are now predicting they will. 
 In fact, the companies have generated higher profits during those years largely by raising prices, importing greater amounts of less expensive foreign tobaccos for discount brands and improving technology.
"The numbers being thrown around by the tobacco industry bear no relation to reality whatsoever," Matthew Myers, counsel to the Coalition on Smoking or Health in Washington, said. "In effect, the tobacco manufacturers cloak themselves as white knights, fighting the evil tobacco tax that would attack jobs. What they're not telling people is that their own decision to raise prices, to import increasing amounts of tobacco and to use ever more mechanized equipment has caused the loss of more jobs than could possibly be lost with the levels of increase being talked about."
 
Black Market
 In either case, making cigarettes so much more expensive would likely expand the black market and could lead to increased crime. And such a big increase, if applied at once, could mean that past relationships of price, consumption and jobs no longer apply.
A study by Price Waterhouse for the Tobacco Institute, the industry lobby in Washington, concluded that a 48-cent tax would eliminate 114,117 jobs -- or 5 percent of 2.28 million jobs in the growth, manufacturing and distribution of tobacco products -- and $3.33 billion in payroll losses. A $2 increase would cost 776,056 jobs -- or 34 percent -- and $22.68 billion in compensation. A survey by the Tobacco Merchants Association, an economic information service in Lawrenceville, N.J., was even bleaker.
By comparison, the increase in the price of cigarettes over the last 13 years has caused job losses of only 1.33 percent annually.
Yet the Tobacco Institute projections, the industry points out, do not reflect lower consumption caused by state tax increases on tobacco products. This year alone, 28 states considered increases and three -- New York, North Dakota and New Mexico -- enacted them, bringing the national average of state taxes above 27 cents per pack of cigarettes.
The overall effect could easily drive the price of premium brand cigarettes up by about a third to $3 a pack from about $2.20 to $2.25 now. That prospect is causing all kinds of concerns for businesses that rely heavily on tobacco sales. For example, convenience store operators, which derive almost a quarter of their sales from cigarettes, more than any other product, are being asked by the National Association of Convenience Stores to put their concerns in writing in a major lobbying campaign.
 
Security Concerns
 Ron Bane, the owner of a distribution company in South San Francisco, Calif., that serves 12 Western states and four Canadian provinces, said he worries over the additional security measures he would need once new taxes make cigarettes more valuable. Already, he said, one of his trucks delivering cigarettes was hijacked at gunpoint in Canada, where excise taxes have pushed the price of cigarettes to more than $60 a carton, about twice the current price in America.
Equally worried are the tobacco growing states. Twenty-five House Democrats, mostly from Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee, wrote to President Clinton in March, saying they would "find it most difficult" to support a health-care plan that would harm their constituents.
Zane Hedgecock, a 10th-generation tobacco grower in High Point, N.C., said farmers in the area would "absolutely go out of business, no question about it" if the excise tax were raised.
Farmers' profit margins have declined while the major manufacturers' profits have risen, with Philip Morris's operating income for domestic tobacco doubling since 1986, to nearly $5.2 billion last year. Farmers have been squeezed by a combination of rising costs for labor, fertilizers and chemicals, and the relatively stagnant prices of tobacco leaves, depressed by an influx of cheap foreign imports. According to the Tobacco Growers Information Committee in Raleigh, N.C., flue-cured tobacco leaves generated about $1,200 an acre last year, a drop of 13 percent since 1988; burley tobacco brought $801 an acre, a 17 percent drop since 1989.
The Tobacco Institute study predicted that excise tax increases of 24 cents, $1 and $2 would eliminate 8,140, 27,654 and 55,308 farming jobs, respectively.
 
A Fine Line
 "We work on such a fine line of profit, any decline would have a dramatic effect on us," said Mr. Hedgecock, a 34-year-old farmer who has traced his lineage to William Hitchcock, an Englishman who began growing tobacco in the same area in 1652. Mr. Hedgecock said his greatest fear is that his 4-year-old son, Daniel, would become the first generation of the family not to grow tobacco.
Plant workers in North Carolina and elsewhere are also concerned about jobs. Ray Scannell, the director of research for the Bakery, Confectionery and Tobacco Workers Union in Kensington, Md., predicted that to preserve margins in the face of higher taxes, companies like Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds might expand operations in countries where manufacturing is cheaper. Since 1990, for example, Philip Morris has opened or improved plants in eastern Germany, Hungary, Russia and Lithuania.
Attrition also worries the sales and distribution sectors.
"If consumption falls by any significant degree, we would see 20 to 30 percent out of business almost overnight," said David E. Strachan, the executive vice president of the American Wholesale Marketers Association, whose membership includes 1,400 distributors and 300 retailers.
Some wholesalers, he said, would grow short of funds if retailers, their sales falling, could not pay promptly, forcing middlemen to carry less inventory, borrow more money or both.
Many retailers, like small-store owners in Massachusetts near the state line with New Hampshire, are already suffering. Massachusetts has a cigarette excise tax of 51 cents a pack, the second highest in the country after New York's, which became 56 cents on June 1; New Hampshire's excise tax is only 25 cents.
 
Other Sales Affected
 "Massachusetts is not only losing tobacco sales, but sales of everything else," said Cathy Flaherty, executive director of the New England Convenience Store Association. "People are not stopping to buy cigarettes, so they're not buying bread, gum or candy, either."
Those kinds of disparities in cigarette prices are also fueling a growing black market, particularly in Canada, where excise taxes have increased 600 percent since 1980. By last year one of every six packs sold in Canada was contraband, up from one in nine the year before, according to a recent report for the Canadian Tobacco Manufacturers Council.
An increase in excise taxes in the United States might stem some of the smuggling, but could invite other types of crime. Robert Parker, president of the Canadian council, said shootings, robberies, hijackings and murders related to cigarettes have increased in Canada. "We have not collected statistics that are reliable," he said, "but police agencies describe this as the fastest-growing type of urban crime in Canada."
Indeed, law enforcement authorities in the United States say black market cigarette sales have grown in high-tax states. One officer described an emergence of "mom-and-pop organized crime groups," but not yet an escalation of violence.
"The reason is simple," said the officer, John Meenaghan, the agent in charge of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms office in Buffalo. "The risk of going to jail if you get caught is probably nonexistent. Maybe you get a fine."
But many of these arguments, reasoned as they seem, are lost on anti-smoking factions who regard smokers as major contributors to rising health-care costs.
 
'No Evidence Whatsoever'
 "The revenue source used to fund any tax is going to have some affect on jobs," said Mr. Myers of the Coalition on Smoking or Health. "There is no evidence whatsoever that more jobs would be lost raising this tax than any other revenue-raising measure being considered. And this revenue-raiser also saves lives."
Both sides are adamant in their positions, as antismokers pit themselves against manufacturers as social villains and smokers as public nuisances. Already, several bills are under consideration in Congress, including one sponsored in the House by Representative Mike Andrews of Texas and in the Senate by Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey that would raise the tax by 76 cents, to $1, to improve health-care coverage.
Mr. Andrews flatly rejects predictions of economic chaos, saying industry officials "spin their numbers to make false points." His bill would designate the vast portion of revenues to cover medical costs but would also provide 3 percent of the revenues for programs that would help farmers convert their land to other crops and 10 percent to the states to offset losses in sales and excise taxes.
It is still far too soon to know what the new excise tax will be. A recommendation by the health-care task force will move to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee, prior to any Congressional and Presidential approval. Meanwhile, industries wait and worry.
"There probably will be an increase," said Marc Katz, director of Congressional Affairs for the National Association of Convenience Stores. "For us, $1 would be devastating. But even if it's less, I'm not sure what level we would consider a victory."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Following the Ways of an Urban Bird

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
"You take a flamingo -- you think a flamingo could make it in New York City?" asked Sithandivine Frazer, who is 10 years old.
"Nah," answered his brother Amos, 9. " A flamingo would probably get hit by a truck and break his skinny legs." 
 "But pigeons," said the oldest Frazer brother, Michael, 14, "pigeons do just fine here. They are really amazing birds even if nobody ever pays much attention to them."
The brothers had come to Saratoga Park in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, along with 13 other members of neighborhood 4-H clubs, precisely to pay attention to pigeons. They were starting out as the vanguard of a three-year scientific survey of pigeon social life sponsored by Cornell University with a National Science Foundation grant.
"The idea is for inner-city kids to learn about science and for all of us to learn about pigeons," explained Margaret Barker of the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology.
And while pigeons are as common as dust around here, the youngsters who gathered at Saratoga Park pointed out how the hardy, adaptable and strutting birds were in many ways the perfect emblematic creature for this city.
"They came here from Africa, Asia and Europe," said Maria Bethel, an 8-year-old setting off a flurry of volunteered pigeon facts from the other 4-H clubbers.
"They were brought here by the Colonial settlers."
"People used to eat them and race them but they got away and became free."
"They come in many colors, black, brown, red and white."
"They can live next to subways and can sleep under elevated tracks."
"They eat what we eat, bread, cookies and rice and beans."
"When you take them to the country they always come back to the city."
"They always know how to get home."
"Some people call them roach birds or flying rats."
"Their real name is rock doves."
"They like to hang out with their friends."
If there was much about pigeons that inspired admiration and identification, there was also much about the birds that was not fully known, making pigeons a tantalizing subject for study. For one thing, why was it that you hardly ever saw baby pigeons? How exactly did they navigate? What made a particular pigeon the dominant bird in a flock?
"Eventually we'll get our youngsters to observe pigeons to provide data on such questions," said Lucinda Randolph Benjamin, who is the 4-H Club representative in charge of setting up and maintaining the project. She explained that traditionally the 4-H worked with rural youngsters as part of cooperative extension programs intended to spread new agricultural findings. Since 1985 the organization has sponsored clubs in New York City, stressing environment, nutrition, health and economic development. The H's are all explained in the group's credo recited at all meetings.
"I pledge my head to clearer thinking, my heart to greater loyalty, my hands to greater service and my health to better living for my club, my community, my country and the world."
"In the pigeon watch project, the idea is for the kids to learn not only about science but to develop all sorts of skills and confidence as they become involved," Ms. Benjamin said. "Some of the older ones will be taking photographs, writing reports, doing statistical analysis, and some of them will be going to Cornell for meetings. Not all the children are fully aware of what research means and for the youngest ones its mostly fun, but even they are learning."
And indeed the younger children were having fun. Five of them performed a pigeon dance, bobbing their necks, strutting and flapping their elbows like people in a Chicken Tonight ad. This display attracted the attention of some freelance youngsters who came by and listened attentively as Ms. Benjamin described different subspecies of pigeons -- the bluish-gray blue bar, black or white spreads, spotted checkers, reds, red bars and pied birds. The children drew and colored the various types and then ran off to lure flocks with bird seed.
Meanwhile, the Frazer brothers confided that they had been observing pigeons on their own for a year, particularly a group that lived under the elevated line near Kosciusko Street. Michael, who wants to be a marine biologist, said the reason that people seldom see baby pigeons was that the young grew quickly in the nest and when they left they looked much like adults. The nests, he said, are mostly in out-of-the-way places, and the mother and father birds both feed their young by forcing a liquid called pigeon milk from their own stomachs into the beaks of the young. "Like I said, they are really amazing but most people just never notice."

HEADLINE: With State Concessions, Pratt & Whitney Accepts Jobs Deal

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 4

 BODY:
Pratt & Whitney, Connecticut's largest private employer, said today that it had tentatively agreed not to move 2,300 jobs to plants out of state in return for a package of tax cuts and other incentives.
Company officials said their final decision would be contingent on the state legislature's approval of the package, worth $32 million a year, in the next few days, and on the company's unions agreeing to concessions of about the same amount, or about $2 an hour. 
 But in a state where job erosion in manufacturing has become a nearly constant worry, even a hedged commitment by a company so intimately identified with Connecticut was hailed as a major victory. Jubilant lawmakers said the legislation enabling the tax-credit plan would sail through the House and Senate with bipartisan support. Pratt & Whitney, based in East Hartford, employs 17,200 people making jet engines and parts in plants around the state.
 
'Keeps the Eagle Flying'
 "This keeps the eagle flying," said Senator John B. Larson, Democrat of East Hartford, referring to the company's symbol, familiar to generations of Connecticut residents.
The package, which state officials say would also benefit other companies in the state, includes some provisions that have already become law. The State Senate early this morning, for example, approved an overhaul of the workers compensation system, which Pratt & Whitney officials had said was wildly out of line with employer assessment rates in other states where it has plants, especially Maine and Georgia. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said he signed the measure, which could reduce employer contributions by perhaps 19 percent, an hour before the agreement was announced.
The main plank of the package is a system of tax credits to encourage research and development by Pratt & Whitney and other Connecticut companies, in return for their continued presence in the state. It works like this: If a company spends $200 million, for example, on research in the state, it can receive up to a 6 percent tax credit on that amount, spread out over three years. But if the company has moved more than 2 percent of its wage base out of state over that three-year period, it forfeits part of the credit.
 
Bill Being Drafted
 Aides to Mr. Weicker said the tax credit bill was still being drafted, and would be rushed to the legislature in time for passage before the mandated adjournment on Wednesday at midnight.
Pratt & Whitney, which is a unit of the Hartford-based United Technologies Corporation, had said that manufacturing costs the company an average of $6 to $8 an hour more in Connecticut than at its Maine and Georgia plants and that sharply reduced orders for jet engines had made the disparity intolerable.
Pratt's president, Karl Krapek, said today that the state package goes one-third of the way toward resolving such cost differences. Another one-third will have to come from employees, he said, while the remaining one-third will be made up in productivity gains.
He declined to comment on the status of talks between the company and its largest union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, because he said both sides had agreed to keep silent. The chief negotiator for the union, Andrew D. Romegialli, could not be reached for comment.
 
Thousands Laid Off
 In recent years, Pratt has laid off thousands of workers in the state. After each reduction, company officials assured the remaining workers and state officials that, at last, the right level of costs and employment had been reached. Mr. Romegialli, along with some members of the legislature, has expressed deep cynicism in recent weeks that any package of concessions would foster a long-term commitment by a company with international ties and demanding shareholders.
But even if the legislature fails to pass the package and the unions cannot reach a compromise, today's tentative agreement would still represent one of the state's most aggressive and ambitious efforts to make companies happy and productive here, an effort Mr. Weicker calls the "New Connecticut."
As part of that campaign, Mr. Weicker today announced that United Parcel Service would expand a sorting facility at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks into a $27 million regional hub that could eventually employ as many as 1,000 workers.
 
Grant for Training
 One provision of Pratt's package's would bestow a grant of up to $3 million a year over the next four years to train each of the company's production workers in kaizen, a Japanese approach to increase manufacturing efficiency.
In recent weeks, the Legislature passed other pro-business provisions that are included in the $32 million package, including a phased reduction of the corporate tax to 10 percent over the next four years, from the current 11.5 percent rate. Another bill introduced by Mr. Weicker -- still awaiting legislative action -- would give property tax exemptions for certain commercial aircraft based at Connecticut airports. Pratt & Whitney has its own private airport for test flights in East Hartford.
Mr. Weicker said the state would also establish a new program to aid manufacturers like Pratt in sending their workers back to school, by providing, in some instances, loan guarantees to assist in tuition costs.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars After Report Of Gains in Jobs Last Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar soared against leading European currencies yesterday as an unexpected surge in the May employment figures seemed to clear the way for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
The dollar advanced only modestly against the Japanese yen amid lingering worries about the American trade deficit. 
 Gold continued to rise. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery advanced $2.20 an ounce, to $376.80. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $376.30 an ounce, up $2.
Currency traders said the dollar jumped more than a pfennig against the German mark immediately after the Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll jobs increased by 209,000 in May, exceeding many economists' estimates.
 
Interest Rates Climb
 The dollar climbed higher as the jobs report sent interest rates on short-term Treasury securities soaring, which in turn lured more investors to dollar-denominated financial instruments and bolstered the demand for dollars.
"Clearly the stronger-than-expected jobs report gave the dollar a pyschological boost going into the weekend," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. The momentum could help the dollar rise above the 1.6300-mark level next week, the upper end of its recent range, she said.
But, she said, "whether or not the dollar will be able to extend these gains will depend on the state of U.S. data" in coming weeks.
The dollar's gains were particularly pronounced against the British pound, which lost more than 3 cents in heavy trading.
Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at Bank Leumi Trust, traced some of the move to reports that British Telecom was selling pounds and buying dollars as part of its $4.3 billion investment to buy 20 percent of MCI as part of a global communications alliance.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5250, from $1.5425 late Thursday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the pound was worth $1.5090, sharply less than $1.5438 late Thursday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 107.26 yen, down 0.61 yen from the Thursday close. Later in London, it rose to 107.85 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was worth 107.75 yen, compared with 107.25 yen late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Thursday, included: 1.6260 German marks, up from 1.6003; 1.4635 Swiss francs, up from 1.4300; 5.4770 French francs, up from 5.3920; 1,479.50 Italian lire, up from 1,460.00, and 1.2795 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2753.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $376.25 an ounce, from $374.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to $376.25 an ounce, from $374.15 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $4.23 to close at a bid $373.05.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Summer Buying Sprees Could Lift Retail Stocks

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
AS summer approaches, Wall Street is preparing a favorable forecast for the stocks of many retailing companies.
The message is simple: after a long dry spell, customers may finally be ready to open their wallets, and retailers are poised to benefit from increased sales. As retail specialists see it, sales momentum will lead to higher earnings and to rising stock prices for selected companies. 
 That scenario would be a major reversal of fortune. Retail sales have been lackluster this year, as evidenced by the May reports that poured forth on Thursday. Earnings for the first quarter -- for most big retailers, that means the February-April period -- have been disappointing, and stock prices of department store companies plummeted at the end of April before recovering last month.
"On average, these stocks declined about 20 percent from their 52-week highs last December to May, and we think they'll gain 20 percent by the end of summer," said Wayne Hood, first vice president and senior retail analyst at Prudential Securities.
The reasons for this optimism, at least for the short term, are varied. On a year-to-year basis, retail volume should be up sharply in coming weeks, since the summer of 1992 was unseasonably cool and wet -- causing apparel sales to fall below retailers' projections. Housing sales are likely to be higher in the months immediately ahead than they were in the cold winter and spring, which would certainly benefit furniture and appliance merchants. In addition, if Congress passes a tax bill before adjourning for the summer, much of the consumer uncertainty over the law's effect on disposable income would disappear and spending might very well turn upward.
Also, just a few days ago, the Commerce Department reported a jump in personal consumption of 1 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.28 trillion. That increase was the largest in the last six months.
"This is not a bad time to invest in retail stocks," said Kurt Barnard, a New York retailing consultant. "But you have to select them very carefully. Generally speaking, stores presenting a large array of merchandise with moderate price tags will do the best."
With this kind of discriminating eye, some Wall Street analysts have tempered their praise for a number of retailers that have been success stories in recent years, like the Limited Inc., Gap Inc., Wal-Mart Stores and the Dayton Hudson Corporation. After reporting disappointing sales this week, Dayton Hudson watched its stock plummet $3.25 on Thursday to close at $66.125 and lose an additional 37.5 cents yesterday, to $65.75. Shares of Wal-Mart, which reported a rise in May same-store sales below the double-digit increases of past years, declined Thursday and yesterday.
 Much of the analysts' attention has shifted to lesser-known specialty stores. But just as shoppers have strong merchandise preferences, so do stock pickers.
Mr. Hood of Prudential upgraded his ratings last month from hold to buy on nine major retailing corporations, including May Department Stores, Dillard Department Stores and Nordstrom.
Edward Antoian, a portfolio manager for the Delaware Management Company, which manages institutional money and runs mutual funds, is concentrating on stores that are "quality oriented and conscious of value for the dollar." Among his favorites are Value City Department Stores, an off-price chain; Costco Wholesale Club, a membership warehouse, and Consolidated Stores, a retailer of close-out merchandise.
Another believer in the potential of price-conscious retailers is Edward Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service, a market report on the retailing business. His list of recommendations includes household names in the discount-store category like Bradlees, Caldor and Venture Stores, which he expects to have earnings improvement and good price appreciation.
An eclectic group of specialty retailers tops Mr. Barnard's list. He favors, among others, Circuit City Stores, an electronics chain that recently announced plans to enter the used car business, and Bed, Bath & Beyond, which he expects to prosper because "the home is once again becoming a center of family life."
Still another category with above-average prospects is the catalogue business, in the opinion of Walter Loeb, publisher of the Loeb Retail Letter. Noting that "Sears abdicated this business earlier this year," he thinks other companies in the marketing-by-mail category can move to fill the void, citing Spiegel and Lands' End as catalogue merchandisers with outstanding prospects for growth in the current retailing environment.
Even if the upbeat forecasts for the summer months prove to be accurate, investors in retail stocks will have to be nimble later this year. The all-important Christmas sales season will be measured against a spending surge that made the 1992 fourth quarter the best for retailers in the last four years, according to the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
"I think we're O.K. through September or October," Mr. Antoian of Delaware Management said. "After that, we'd better see an increase in consumer confidence if we're going to have a strong Christmas."
If confidence continues to languish and consumers appear hesitant to spend late this year, individual investors may want to follow Mr. Antoian's lead. "We'll probably be exiting the retail stocks," he said.

HEADLINE: RETIREMENT PLANNING;
Step Up Savings Goals, Pension Experts Urge

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
MOST working Americans desperately need to increase their retirement savings, benefits consultants say. Increased longevity and low interest rates are the primary reasons, but provisions of President Clinton's economic package create a new sense of urgency.
"Don't wait until a tax bill is signed" to review retirement savings, said Alan Glickstein, a partner in Kwasha Lipton, benefit consultants based in Fort Lee, N.J. 
 Although much uncertainty remains about the President's plan in Congress, "no one doubts that tax rates for individuals are going up," he said, and that a greater portion of Social Security benefits will be taxed. As a result, people will need a higher pretax retirement income than they may have projected even a few months ago.
For highly compensated employees, the House-passed version packs another punch: no more than $150,000 of salary can be recognized for pension, 401(k), profit-sharing and similar tax-deferred plans. That is down from $235,840 this year, and it means "you need to be socking away more on your own," Mr. Glickstein said.
How much should people be saving?
Andrew E. Zuckerman, director of employee benefits with the Washington office of the consulting firm Grant Thornton, said: "You need 80 percent of your preretirement income at the date of retirement to maintain your standard of living. You may not need it the day you retire, but in 10, 15 or 20 years you will."
In a recent survey by his firm of nearly 1,500 midsized companies, executives estimated they would need 50 to 60 percent of preretirement income, an indication that people are not saving enough, Mr. Zuckerman said.
To make personal projections, people need to estimate how much they will receive from employer-sponsored pension plans, Social Security and personal savings. Then, they need to project a retirement date and presumed earnings at that date, factoring in inflation, and see how their projected retirement income stands up.
The calculations may sound daunting, but help is available.
Howard Johnson & Company, Seattle-based benefit and compensation consultants and actuaries, offers assistance for such clients as Montgomery Ward, MGM Grand, Microsoft and Intel through its own computer program called Multiplan.
Employees at client companies are given customized diskettes to make their own insurance and savings choices in flexible benefit plans, make projections and play "what if" games. What if I save $50 a month more in the 401(k) plan? How much more will I receive if I retire in 20 years?
"Employees can construct a flex plan interactively," said Mr. Johnson, founder of the firm that bears his name. If employees decide to switch money in the 401(k) plan from one investment to another, they can do so immediately. At many companies, employees must visit the human resources office to change allocations, which may take weeks.
Increasingly, companies are turning away from defined-benefit retirement plans in favor of defined-contribution and 401(k) plans, which means employees are having to shoulder far greater responsibility for their retirement savings than did their parents' generation. For individuals, Mr. Zuckerman recommends Quicken, the personal computer software, to project retirement savings and create a budget.
"The new benefits programs offer significant opportunities to accumulate a supplemental nest egg," said Mr. Glickstein of Kwasha Lipton, but many employees are not participating at all or are being overly conservative in their investment choices.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Under the Umbrella
 
Q. What is meant by umbrella insurance?
 KEITH BALDWIN, Middletown, N.J.
 
A. If you are sued as a result of an accident involving your car or your home, liability insurance included in your auto and home policies will offer some protection. But this liability insurance usually has upper limits, typically $300,000. 
 "If people have assets with a total value that greatly exceeds $300,000, they should consider buying additional liability insurance in the form of an umbrella policy," said Sean F. Mooney, senior vice president and economist of the Insurance Information Institute. "It comes into play only when the other coverages are exhausted." Thus if you have an accident resulting in a $500,000 judgment with $300,000 of standard liability insurance and $1 million of umbrella coverage on top of it, the standard policy would pay up to the limits and the umbrella policy would pay the remaining $200,000.
Many insurance companies require that both your home and your car be insured with them before they will sell you umbrella coverage. A $1 million umbrella insurance policy costs about $200 a year.
 
Certificates of Participation
 
Q. I've heard of certificates of participation. What are they?
 MYLES FOX, Manhattan
 
A. Certificates of participation are used by state and local governments for financing property and equipment. Investors who buy these certificates -- which often receive a rating from a credit rating agency and are usually issued in denominations of $5,000 or multiples of $5,000 -- are entitled to receive a participation, or share, in the lease payments from a particular project.
"Lease payments are passed through the lessor to the certificate holders with the tax advantages intact," said Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association. The way it normally works is that the lessor assigns the lease and lease payments to a trustee, which distributes the payments to the owners of the certificates."
 
Kiddie Tax
 
I have two small sons who are earning interest on investments. Do they have to pay taxes on this interest or do I have to pay taxes for them?
 JON SPAET, Manhattan
 
A. Children under the age of 14 who have investment income this year of under $1,200 are taxed at their own rate. If their investment income is larger, they are taxed at their parents' rate when it is higher than their own, under a portion of the law known as the Kiddie Tax.
Children over the age of 14 pay tax at their normal rate. Included under the investment income category are interest, dividends and capital gains from the sale of securities.
"If certain criteria are met, parents can elect to include their child's investment income in the parents' tax return," said Harry J. Shlinger, tax partner of Weber Lipshie & Company. "However, if they are New York State residents, this irrevocable election can cause an additional state tax for the parent because the state standard deduction for the child is lost."

HEADLINE: The City Budget: Still Gimmicky

 BODY:
With a bow to reality, Mayor David Dinkins and his advisers have revised the New York City budget. They've deleted the worst examples of undue optimism and agreed to make deeper spending cuts. That's progress. But in what might be the administration's theme song, the revision doesn't go far enough. Like the first version, it relies too heavily on money that isn't likely to materialize, and on gimmicks that will raise money in the short run but cause pain down the road.
The Mayor's budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 now anticipates $150 million in Federal aid instead of $250 million, though even the $150 million is not guaranteed; $55 million from the sale of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, though no sale has been arranged, and $215 million from borrowing against property tax delinquencies, which robs the future to collect cash now. 
 Even with the new cuts of about $300 million and a partial hiring freeze, experts say the budget gap could range from $400 million to $700 million. Presumably the Mayor and the City Council -- both up for re-election in the fall -- will balance the budget after the elections, assuming it's still out of whack. By law, the budget must be in balance. But closing gaps on short notice forces the use of even more gimmicks as well as the imposition of hurtful cuts driven by panic.
How did City Hall get itself into this fix in an election year? The economy didn't cooperate. Albany, particularly Gov. Mario Cuomo, didn't cooperate by providing more funds. Even worse, he suggested foolhardy ideas, like a fire sale of the land under the airports. Circumstances didn't cooperate -- storms and the World Trade Center bombing boosted overtime costs.
The city didn't get the help it expected from a Democratic Administration in Washington. Most important, Mayor Dinkins did not take advantage of bad times and impose the structural changes the city must make if it is ever to live within its means. The only escape from the perennial crunch is to embrace difficult policy changes, from property tax reform to productivity savings from workers and even greater cuts in the labor force.
The administration has reduced the work force from a high of 225,000 to about 212,000, and made some management reforms. But it hasn't done nearly enough, and it hasn't won significant concessions from the unions. A state takeover of Medicaid would provide significant help, but State Senate Republicans balked and the Governor didn't work hard enough to move them.
Now, unfortunately, is not the time to make those reforms. Last-minute budget haggling cannot solve the city's fundamental budget imbalance -- the "permanent deficit" recently spotlighted by private members of the Financial Control Board. But it is not too late to make more service and staff cuts. Delaying tough decisions until the fall may be smart campaign politics, but it will not get the city anywhere.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clinton Worries Europe

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
President Clinton's rocky start and sharply dipping polls are beginning to cause serious concern abroad.
Nobody cares how much he pays for a haircut or who charters planes for the White House press. But if what Europeans see as trivia is undermining his Presidency, they worry. They have watched waffling on Bosnia, the need to twist the arms of a Democratic-controlled Congress for a narrow endorsement of the budget, the withdrawal of a Justice Department nominee whom Mr. Clinton might have known was unacceptable and the arrival of David Gergen, a former opposition spokesman, to be the voice of a tongue-tied White House. 
 Mr. Clinton hasn't been overseas yet, and people feel they don't know much about him, despite pleasant reports from foreign leaders who have gone to call on him.
But for America's partners, whether the President should be admired or scorned is less important than whether he speaks clearly for his country and his leadership makes the U.S. seem reliable and predictable.
Richard Nixon was respected even at the height of Watergate. Ronald Reagan was mocked as a cowboy. Jimmy Carter and George Bush had odd mannerisms to the foreign eye. But when they said where the U.S. stood, there it stood, like it or not, and that was reassuring.
The spectacle of a President not quite in charge troubles Europeans even more now than it did during the cold war. "Europeans feel orphaned," a French analyst said. "Not only the Soviet menace is gone as a mobilizer but so is our protector against the menace. We had a secret hope the Americans would lead us in the new era, even if we complained about the pretensions of a lonely superpower. Now there's a sense of emptiness."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher did just what the Europeans have long said they wanted the U.S. to do during his mission in May to consult about the war in the former Yugoslavia. He listened, he proposed, but he didn't insist. He sought consensus -- and it turned out to be unnerving, as if Washington were deliberately, even maliciously, out to demonstrate that the Europeans still couldn't get their act together.
There is nothing new about contradictory European grumbling that the U.S. is too much of a demanding Big Brother or not enough of an assertive leader. But the grumbling is exacerbated now by the painfully acknowledged fact that Europe isn't developing the political cohesion expected with the Maastricht treaty; it feels in danger of unraveling at a time of new and perplexing challenges and weak, uncertain governments.
Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff's statement that U.S. "economic interests are paramount" nowadays and that U.S. commitments abroad may soon be reduced rang ominously true. The European Community's decision to buttress reforms in its agricultural policy so as to avert the threat of a French veto and to ease agreement with the U.S. on the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade may well have been prodded by recognition that the warning has to be taken seriously.
There are no real complaints about Mr. Clinton's policies so far, even on Bosnia, although there was probably as much disappointment as relief that he didn't decide to drag the Europeans into a much more forceful intervention. Polls show 55 percent of people in the Community favor a military attempt to stop the fighting, but the unspoken condition is that the U.S. take the initiative, as in the gulf war. Some people ask, uneasily, what Mr. Clinton would have done if Iraq had invaded Kuwait after his inauguration.
The push on aid to Russia is basically welcomed, as is reactivation of the Middle East talks. And Europeans believe Clinton's plans to reinvigorate the U.S. economy and cut the deficit are in their interest, too.
What is bothersome is the odor of weakness coming from Washington. There is a suspicion that whether it is fair or unfair, the barrage of attacks on the Administration from the Washington media means that those close observers sense in the White House a fragility and a lack of solid support that translate into uncertain power.
Unlike Europe's parliamentary based leaders, the American President is sure to hold office for four years. Whatever he does, U.S. allies want him above all to keep a firm grip on that office.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Rain In Spain Stays . . .

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Instructions for a President:
1. Know thyself. You may not have peaked too soon, but you have certainly peaked very young. A man elected President at age 46 will be a mere 54 when he loses the job. That's if he is lucky. If he is not, the best job he can ever have will be over and done with when he is 50. Nowadays 54 is young and 50 is very young.
2. Act on this self-knowledge. In short, this is the whole ball game, right here and right now. After this, all else will be small cheese unless you think spending the final 30 or 40 years of your life reading history's judgments will be tons of fun. You must do something to make the historians respect you. Quit dawdling and do it now. 
 3. Quit reading public-opinion polls. A year before George Bush was defeated, the polls showed he was unbeatable.
4. Quit reading the newspapers. Over recent years the press has acquired a vested interest in the failures of Presidencies. (Bad news sells better than good news.) As a result, press people now compete fiercely for the honor of having been the first to put the knife into the latest President. Why depress yourself?
5. Quit worrying about Ross Perot. Trying to humor people like Perot only increases their contempt for you and their admiration for themselves. Perot may possess nobility of spirit inconceivable to Machiavelli, but that's not the way to bet it. Chances are, his aim is to show himself off as a better President than you.
6. Quit appointing people who attended Yale Law School. Sure, it is a splendid law school, and you and Mrs. Clinton made many fine friends among its excellent graduates, but it is bad news politically, and has been ever since it hit the TV screen during the melodrama about Clarence Thomas and Anita Hill. In politics as in life there are some things that are so obviously jinxed that smart people avoid them for no defensible reason. The Yale Law School is one.
7. Cut out the talk about "moving to the center." No two people agree on where the center is. As a result, half your critics will say you've moved all the way over to the right of center and the other half will say you've stayed far to the left of center. Outside the Beltway the audience for this kind of talk is slightly smaller than the audience for a lecture on the origins of the Peloponnesian War.
8. Quit doing George Bush's things. Moving to the center was George Bush's thing. He moved there from the Reagan right, and the righties hated him, which would have been all right if he had been able to hold the lefties and the centries. (Centries, people who hover around the center without giving it a thought, are not to be confused with centrists, a tiny group of intellectual heavyweights occupying the narrow zone between Zbigniew Brzezinski and Henry Kissinger and rarely seen outside Washington newspaper columns.) Bush moved to the center and the voters retired him. A new President should assume the voters want him to move somewhere different.
9. Remember the vision thing. George Bush made it sound like something he didn't take seriously. This is already being said of your campaign promises. Pick at least one thing to stand for with iron determination, and say, "Just like a tree that's planted by the river, I shall not be moved." Americans like the idea of a vision thing guiding their destinies. That's why reading the Declaration of Independence on the Fourth of July still stirs our juices. You can't abandon campaign promises galore without making people think, "Jefferson he ain't." Stand for something. Just one thing. One thing you're ready to fight and die for. Phone whoever composed the immortal line "the economy, stupid," and beg for help.
10. Remember Harry Truman. When he left office, he was abused and ridiculed as a failed haberdasher too small for the Presidency. Most people have forgotten that. Nowadays he is a political giant of such grandeur that even campaigning Republicans claim to have Trumanian blood flowing in their veins. Truman knew who he was. He trusted his own knowledge of American life, the value of his own judgment and the men he brought to the White House to advise him. Bring in advisers as wise and clever as Marshall, Acheson, Harriman et al. Listen. Know thyself (see Point 1), be thyself, stand for something. Age 50 is closer than you think, but meanwhile you are still the boss.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.E. PLANNING TO ADD TO COST-CUTTING MOVES

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The General Electric Company may cut another 1,000 jobs from its embattled aircraft engines division and abandon the largest building in its manufacturing complex in Evendale, Ohio, near Cincinnati, according to a report in The Cincinnati Enquirer. In its report, the newspaper said an internal G.E. cost-cutting study had recommended moving final engine assembly operations to other plants in Kansas and North Carolina. The moves could eliminate another 1,000 jobs in the Cincinnati area, on top of the 2,500 hourly and salaried positions the company cut in February.

By Brian Boyd. Princeton University, $15.95 and $16.95, respectively.
Biographical volumes showing Nabokov's influences.
WAITING TO EXHALE
By Terry McMillan. Pocket Star, $5.99.
A novel about four black women in Phoenix.
WILDERNESS TIPS
By Margaret Atwood. Bantam, $6.99.
Short stories about men and women's private fictions.
WISE CHILDREN
By Angela Carter. Penguin, $10.
The author's last novel, the story of the irrepressible illegitimate twin daughters of a classical actor.
