PUB-DATE: June 6, 1993

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 3179 words

HEADLINE: STAGE VIEW;
A New Generation on Old Broadway

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
"All About Eve," the smartest movie ever made about Broadway, begins and ends with a glamorous awards ceremony at which decorous theater people speak fondly of their art and one another while accepting trophies and preening for the cameras. During the two hours of flashback that come in between, the characters, including a dyspeptic drama critic, are revealed as a bunch of back-stabbing schemers at worst and childlike dreamers at best. When the Broadway of "All About Eve" gives birth to a prize-winning performance or play, it does so despite its own denizens' mean-spiritedness and whimsical artistic instincts.
Much about the street has changed beyond recognition since 1950, the year Joseph L. Mankiewicz's masterpiece was sent forth by Hollywood. Not even Addison DeWitt, the critic in "All About Eve," could have foreseen a season like that of 1992-93 in which two hits (one of them starring an extant sensation of the 1950's, Chita Rivera) offer uncloseted gay protagonists and onstage scenes of simulated defecation. Nor could anyone have predicted 40 years ago that Broadway's rate of production would slow to a trickle by the 1990's -- from 60 productions as late as the 1980-81 season to only 32 this season -- or that most important new American dramas would only play Broadway as if it were another stop on the road or even bypass Broadway entirely. 
 Yet the human comedy remains eternal, many of the same gilded playhouses endure, and certain show-biz rituals won't die even if a stake is driven into their heart. Tonight's Tony Awards, to be broadcast by CBS from the Gershwin Theater at 9, will be the time-honored kiss-kiss affair, though produced for the first time by Gary Smith, the man who did such a flashy job with the biggest television spectacular to play New York this season, the Democratic National Convention. And, as always, the reassuringly glitzy surface will mask festering hostilities that may be more lethal than any Mankiewicz might have imagined.
The hostilities have increased because too many Broadway theater hands are competing for a share of a vastly reduced pie: fewer shows, smaller audiences, fewer jobs. And increasingly, the battle lines are drawn along a fierce generational divide, as youth tries to have its day in the sole branch of American show business where executives in their 20's and 30's are almost unheard of. "Angels in America" and "Tommy," the two Broadway productions that made the most noise this season, are both the work of younger artists, producers and theater management who are challenging the older Broadway establishment that has run the steadily eroding commercial American theater for the last 25 years. Not for nothing have four important recent American plays -- "Six Degrees of Separation," "The Sisters Rosensweig," "Jeffrey" and "Angels in America" -- invoked the longest-running Broadway hit of the 1980's, "Cats," as comic shorthand for commercial theater culture at its most mindless. "Cats" is not the brand name that major American playwrights want to define the best-known artery of their theater anymore.
The transition from an old Broadway to a new one is essential if Broadway is to attract emerging theater artists of the first rank and remain even the showcase for imported attractions it has become. While tonight's likely Tony winners (and, for that matter, most of the runners-up) are highly gifted, they are a lonely group, in need of larger audiences and a more active Broadway scene if they are to prosper. There is no time to waste. After the false high of last season, in which some first-rate musicals camouflaged the paucity of American plays, this season almost did not happen. All but one of the four Broadway productions that most excited the public and the critics opened in the season's last two weeks (as marked by the May 5 cutoff of eligibility for Tony Awards consideration). As has been typically the case for years now, none of these esteemed shows were created by Broadway but were instead reworkings or direct transfers of productions that first achieved success elsewhere: whether Off Broadway ("The Sisters Rosensweig," from Lincoln Center Theater), or in London ("Kiss of the Spider Woman") or at nonprofit institutional theaters beyond New York ("Tommy" and "Angels in America").
There is some faint hope in this sorry picture, paradoxically, and much of it centers on the tumultuous public response to "Angels in America" and "Tommy." As theatrical works, both these shows are radical challenges to Broadway establishment thinking. Both were produced independently of that establishment in California and are as far removed from bloated establishment Broadway dinosaurs like "The Goodbye Girl" as theater can get. As they both reflect a younger theatrical generation behind the scenes, they tempt a younger audience into Broadway's increasingly empty seats.
"Angels" does not fit any traditional Broadway formula for a sure thing; quite the reverse, it sounds like a madman's recipe for a sure flop. Three and a half hours long and told in part in the oblique imagery of dreams, Tony Kushner's drama isn't even complete in itself but is only the first half (titled "Millennium Approaches") of an epic in progress. (Part 2, "Perestroika," is promised in the fall, when it is to join Part 1 in repertory.) The play deals graphically with AIDS and, more demandingly, asks that the audience open its minds and hearts to what the playwright calls "a gay fantasia on national themes." Mr. Kushner's work is nothing less than a radical vision of American society, politics and religion as written in the uncompromisingly extravagant voice of a homosexual leftist intellectual who will try anything (except conventional social realism) to turn original ideas and life-and-death emotions into gripping and often ferociously funny theater.
THOUGH NOT REMOTELY intellectual in its intentions, "Tommy" bends Broadway's rules about mass commercial entertainment as strenuously as "Angels" does its staid dictates about what constitutes high drama. "Tommy" is Broadway's first real collaboration with a rock composer (Pete Townshend of the Who) and its first intelligent accommodation with rock music itself, an inexorable cultural force that has stolen away much of the Broadway musical's audience since rock-and-roll first usurped Broadway pop music on the hit parade in the 1950's.
Through the years, Broadway has tried ridiculing rock (in "Bye Bye Birdie"), simulating rock (in "Hair," "Jesus Christ Superstar") and promoting cheesy, Las Vegas-style rock-concert facsimiles ("Beatlemania," "Buddy"). Finally in "Tommy," an authentic rock score has been turned into a roller coaster of musical theater that fuses the angry and searching late-1960's undertow of the Who's original composition with the exhilarating choreographic storytelling techniques of advanced Broadway musicals (notably Harold Prince's "Evita" and Michael Bennett's "Dreamgirls"), the eye-opening experiments of modern poetic theater imagists like Robert Wilson and the cinematic rush of MTV.
While "Tommy" and "Angels in America" have little else in common, they do share an unconventional approach to dramatic storytelling, a faith in spiritual revelation and an appreciation for abstract and hallucinatory modes of stage language. As "Angels" does not follow the logic of the traditional well-made play and its easily parsed message, so "Tommy," which has virtually no dialogue, takes a "Peter Pan"-like fairy tale and transposes it to a new theatrical key that challenges the Broadway status quo. Like the other two Broadway musicals that have tried to redefine the form in the post-"Chorus Line" era, "Dreamgirls" and "Sunday in the Park With George," "Tommy" may well not win the Tony Award. The likely winner is Mr. Prince's beautifully staged "Spider Woman," a show that is itself far more adventurous than most recent Tony-winning musicals but, in its traditional mix of show-biz flash and liberal sentimentality, far more accessible to Tony voters than "Tommy."
"Angels in America" and "Tommy" have a language barrier to cross because they are the creation of young, though highly sophisticated, theatrical hands well below the median age of the Broadway industry and its target audience. Tony Kushner and George C. Wolfe, the author and director of "Angels," are both in their 30's. Des McAnuff, who co-wrote "Tommy" with Mr. Townshend and directed it, is 40. What's more -- and what may be most terrifying to the Broadway establishment -- both "Angels" and "Tommy" were wooed and won for Broadway by the youngest and smallest of Broadway's theater-owning organizations, Jujamcyn Theaters.
With only five houses at its disposal, and not the most desirable ones at that, Jujamcyn should not be a formidable competitor to the Shubert Organization (16 theaters) and the Nederlander Organization (9 theaters), the companies that have dominated Broadway for most of its modern history. Yet Jujamcyn -- whose president, Rocco Landesman, 45, is more than two decades younger than even his youngest rival -- has defied those odds and defined the Broadway landscape for two seasons running; last season its prime bookings were "Jelly's Last Jam" and "Guys and Dolls." The youngest Broadway management, perhaps only naturally, is more in touch with the rising creative stars of the theater than its competitors.
Demographically comparable audiences follow. Thanks to the iconoclasm of Jujamcyn, there may be more diverse audiences at Broadway hits right now than at any time in memory: more young people, more black people, more gay people. Still, even two theatrical phenomena as potent as "Angels" and "Tommy" cannot, as the perennial wish goes, "save Broadway." The diversity of these audiences is inevitably shallow, given the steep price of a Broadway ticket, and Jujamcyn's very success puts a cap on its ambitions, since four of the chain's five theaters are now unlikely to change tenants for many months, if not years, to come.
So entrenched are Broadway's traditional reflexes that no single organization, however successful, can ameliorate the industry's many systemic problems, starting with those that have led to high production costs and commensurate ticket prices. Does Broadway want to change? When President Clinton announced his new economic plan in February, one of its first and most vocal critics was the League of American Theater Owners and Producers, the Broadway trade organization, which declared the President's plan "devastating" because of its proposal to trim the deductibility of entertainment expenses.
Despite all these years of decline, the Broadway establishment still sees as its meal ticket the expense-account ticket buyer who entertains clients at taxpayers' expense. The league may be right, depressingly enough, but that audience is shrinking, not growing, and will indeed collapse if the entertainment deduction is knocked down. Then what? Is anyone thinking about the future that increasingly looks inevitable? (At the very least the league might try to turn the Clinton tax bite into a virtue by lobbying for a plan that might funnel revenues from a reduced entertainment deduction to government subsidy of theater tickets for audiences who cannot afford them.)
A Broadway theater establishment that is most vocal about preserving the tax break for tired businessmen in search of cheesecake at "The Will Rogers Follies" is not likely to know how to keep the new audiences attracted to Broadway by an "Angels" or "Tommy." If these new theatergoers seek another play, they are more than likely to seek it Off Broadway, just as most seasoned theatergoers do, and why shouldn't they? For each good play that reaches a Broadway house (at most two or three even in a vintage season), there are several more American plays of comparable artistic vitality that pop up at a lower ticket price elsewhere. Just this season alone, and a recession-battered season at that, Off Broadway's prominent productions included, among many others, David Mamet's "Oleanna," Anna Deavere Smith's "Fires in the Mirror," Jon Robin Baitz's "Three Hotels," Paul Rudnick's "Jeffrey," John Leguizamo's "Spic-O-Rama," Stephen Sondheim's "Putting It Together," Horton Foote's "Roads to Home" and Larry Kramer's "Destiny of Me."
None of these shows will be celebrated on the Tonys tonight because the Broadway establishment, in yet another typical display of the tunnel vision that has brought it to its current low estate, still refuses to let Off Broadway plays compete for the theater's most prominent award. Imagine if this year's Academy Awards had eliminated from its nominations all movies not financed by major Hollywood studios: "Howards End," "The Crying Game" and "Enchanted April" would have been struck from Oscar consideration. This is the exact equivalent of what the Tonys are doing, and who benefits beside the few blockbusters that can unfairly limit their competition?
So determined is the diminished Broadway establishment to hold on to whatever economic prerogatives it retains -- starting with the mammoth free publicity of the Tonys -- that it would rather shut out many of the theater's best artists than share the wealth in the only nationally televised theatrical event of the year. It says much about the ludicrousness of the system that Arthur Miller is eligible for a Tony tonight for "The Price," a 1968 play that happened to be revived on Broadway this season, and is ineligible for Tony consideration for his latest play, "The Last Yankee," which was produced Off Broadway.
Then again, not all Broadway shows are really eligible for Tonys, either: "Fool Moon," another surprise success of the Broadway season, received no Tony nominations because the classic clowning of David Shiner and Bill Irwin does not fit the anachronistically rigid Tony categories that have plenty of room for nominees in forgotten shows like "Anna Karenina" and "Ain't Broadway Grand."
The Tonys, supposedly an event to promote Broadway, may in fact be helping to kill Broadway. Not only is the awards show underselling the artistic content of the New York (and American) theater by refusing to be inclusive in its prizes, but it is also encouraging a one- or two-month Broadway season, as opposed to the nine-month season of the "All About Eve" past. Because Tony Award nominations are thought to be essential for box-office success, few plays or musicals venture to open on Broadway before the spring, when the nominations are announced. A late-season opening is also supposed to increase the chances of winning a Tony, on the theory that the Tony Award voters, not the youngest of constituencies, are too doddering to remember the contenders they saw as far back as the previous fall. Even so, business is so poor for all except the top hits that late-season dramatic arrivals with respectably mixed reviews like "The Song of Jacob Zulu," "Redwood Curtain" and "Wilder, Wilder, Wilder" closed abruptly anyway, days before or days after they received the Tony nominations that were supposed to resuscitate them.
A Broadway theater so ungenerous to the rest of the American theater, so overpriced for the audience and so self-destructive in its internal business practices cannot be saved by its artists alone, however brilliant, or by one great play or any number of hit musicals. Major reform is called for. If the audience for "Angels in America" doesn't stick around, after all, the artists who created it will go where that audience is: George Wolfe can direct his next play at the New York Shakespeare Festival, which he is newly in charge of reviving, and Tony Kushner can write his next play for companies like the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles and the Eureka Theater Company in San Francisco, where "Angels" began its life. The American theater and its audience can live without Broadway; most of the time they already do.
But can New York City live without Broadway? Even if the old Broadway now exists only in fantasy enshrinements like "All About Eve" and "Guys and Dolls," the illusion that a fabled Broadway is still out there somewhere, however straitened, is an essential part of the city's image and self-image. If the Broadway community cannot keep the mostly dark straight-play houses in the West 40's lit by attracting the new wave of American theater artists and their non-expense-account audiences, chances are that these theaters will sooner or later pass out of theatrical use. Sure, landmarking will save these architectural gems from the fate of so many lost Broadway theaters; they will not be razed for parking lots and skyscrapers. Instead they'll become churches or nightclubs or television studios like such theatrically dormant (and in some cases landmarked) venues as the Mark Hellinger, the Hudson, the Miller, the Hammerstein. Something in the city's character will have died.
This has been such a slow year on Broadway that the whole apparatus of the commercial theater seems asleep; even the much-touted plan (the Broadway Alliance) to attract new dramas to Broadway at reduced prices has rusted with disuse. Then, like a lightning bolt, came "Angels in America," a play that audiences carry around with them for days after they see it and cannot stop talking about. Speaking as a theatergoer who reached voting age just after the heyday of Miller and Williams and Albee, I feel that "Angels in America" is the most thrilling new American play of my adult lifetime. It lets in gusts of fresh air, and, like the last dramas I recall causing so large a stir on Broadway, "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" and the Peter Brook/Peter Weiss "Marat/Sade" of the 1960's, it looks glorious in an old Times Square house. The possibilities Mr. Kushner opens up for the stage -- in his challenging fusion of the epic and the intimate, the verbal and the visual, the intellectual and the fabulous -- will in time influence and perhaps attract a new generation of American playwrights. But though his play indeed boasts an angel descending from above, that angel brings only a prayer, not a miracle. "Angels in America" asks that we follow the example of its most inspiring human character, a young gay man with AIDS, and try to make our own miracles to change a country where plague runs wild and the democratic faith is frayed.
Next to the vast, spiritually troubled America that Tony Kushner surveys in his huge theatrical canvas, the theater industry presenting his play has relatively simple and mundane problems. They, too, can only be solved with hard work, fresh ideas and leaders with some vision larger than their own immediate business interests. For far too long, Broadway has depended on show-biz miracles to fall from the heavens and salvage its increasingly leaner seasons. While the success of "Angels in America" isn't going to save Broadway, you have to hope that its message will have some parochial resonance. Broadway will only be saved, after all, if it decides to save itself.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
On the Hudson, Launching Minds Instead of Ships

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Building on its fine tradition of training first-rate minds, New York City's Stuyvesant High School has begun to groom a crop of young architecture critics. Stuyvesant has just ended its first year in its new building, an impressive $150 million complex in lower Manhattan, and some students give the place low marks. They say the light switches don't work. The pool is always closed. The building smells too new.
Hang in there, kids. This is what a shakedown year is supposed to be like. 
 Other Stuyvesant students have the makings of astute social critics. They like the new building just fine, and that's the problem. Many of them have friends who go to schools that resemble armed fortresses with crumbling walls. Why should Stuyvesant students be so fortunate? Why ask why? You would think that the school had added a course in Guilt to its already impressive curriculum of sciences and arts.
If it is any consolation, it should be said emphatically that Stuyvesant's 3,000 students are not the only, even the major, beneficiaries of their new building. The whole city gains from it. For the new Stuyvesant High School does something more than set a high standard for the design of public schools. It gives the city's waterfront a renewed sense of purpose. Located where Chambers Street meets the Hudson River, at the northern edge of Battery Park City, the school looks back to the city's industrial past and forward to its post-industrial future.
Stuyvesant has opened at a time when New York is looking for ways to reinvent the waterfront after decades of decline. Planners speak glowingly of the "green necklace" they hope to create around the city, a grand promenade of parks. It is a lovely vision but not a complete one. The waterfront does not want to be put out to pasture. It wants to be productive as well as scenic. If it can no longer support shipping, why can't it launch minds?
What a great place for a school -- especially this one! For Stuyvesant's history parallels the city's economic shift from manufacturing to information. Founded in 1904 as a manual training high school with courses geared to engineering, it went on to become one of the public school system's academic stars. In its new location, Stuyvesant joins nearby P.S. 234 and Manhattan Community College in a scholastic triumvirate. With these schools flanking its western end, Chambers Street now feels like a true urban axis, a boulevard stretching toward promise.
Designed by Cooper, Robertson & Partners, with Gruzen Samton Steinglass, as associate architects, Stuyvesant resembles a campus all on its own. Though actually one structure, the school looks like a group of five buildings clustered together on its one-and-a-half-acre site. Dominating the group is the academic tower, a 10-story block of classrooms. Twice the height of most high schools, the block is in effect two schools stacked atop each other, with a library sandwiched between them. Four smaller structures, of varying height and size, rise on the eastern and northern sides of the classroom block. These contain gymnasiums and an auditorium (both available for community use), and large halls for ceramics and carpentry shops.
This is a frankly contextual design that seeks to reflect both the industrial vernacular of the TriBeCa waterfront and the residential character of Battery Park City. In contrast to SoHo, with its small-scale cast-iron buildings, TriBeCa is filled with massive masonry factory buildings with classical proportions and detailing that give them the power of civic monuments. Stuyvesant, with its monumental scale, its walls of tan brick accented with grids of contrasting color, and the symmetrical proportions of its main facade, is their post-industrial descendant.
Alexander Cooper, chief architect for the school, was co-designer of the 1979 master plan for Battery Park City, and he has naturally followed the plan's design guidelines. The result is that the building shares the strange clash of ends and means characteristic of Battery Park City as a whole. It is torn between the progressive desire to reach beyond modern architecture toward a more urbane form of expression and the tired belief that urbane forms should be borrowed from the past.
The building's weakest moment -- and, alas, one of its most conspicuous -- occurs on the north side, where the auditorium is screened by a false facade capped with a classical pediment. The pediment, which was not included in the architects' earlier schemes, is supposed to say "theater" and to recall a beloved feature from the school's former building. Either way, the form contradicts Stuyvesant's progressive spirit. Why do minds racing along the information highway look to architecture to put on the brakes?
Stuyvesant's identity as a work place is revealed more fully inside the building. Tools get great play here. With chem labs, energy labs, robotics workshops, drafting rooms and batteries of computers, the school is a shrine to the art of industry. The interiors adhere to what Mr. Cooper calls a subway esthetic. Though fine granite lines the spacious lobby and the auditorium is paneled with wood, the building is ready for rush hour with walls of structural ceramic brick and floors of resilient tile.
The post-industrial ethos is not the rigid order of the assembly line, and Stuyvesant's design encourages individual expression within a group structure. The building expresses that idea in the contrast between the strict symmetry of the main facade and the formal diversity of the north side. Classrooms are standardized in form, but the social spaces are flexible, arranged informally around the central circulation core of stairways and escalators.
If one part of the building sums up the whole, it is the cafeteria, housed in a penthouse atop the shop block on the building's northwest corner. Designed for multiple uses, the room is irregularly shaped -- a rectangle that dissolves on two sides into a free-form configuration -- and it commands spectacular views of the river and the city. On a recent afternoon, a dance class was practicing there, and the movements of the dancers, individually expressive within a collective body, offered an idealized portrait of New York. What made the portrait so moving is that, by placing a public school where luxury housing was originally intended to rise, New York has moved measurably closer to that ideal.
Stuyvesant is the first building to be constructed by the Battery Park City Authority in its own right, instead of by private developers, and it is the first that truly imbues the site with the public dimension to which its architecture has always aspired. The Authority has long championed the ideal of connecting New Yorkers to the waterfront. Stuyvesant High School connects the waterfront to the city's future.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stuyvesant High School, with the river in the background -- An eye to both past and future. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
When Rivers Run Amok, Who's at Fault?

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AT 5:30 A.M. last June 6 Laura and Richard Raynor were awakened in their second-floor bedroom by frantic phone calls from neighbors telling them to get out of the house before the Quinnipiac River rose any higher than the ground floor.
One neighbor had been awakened by strange noises from the furnace and realized that Garden Road, a new street of neat, year-old houses about 75 feet from the river, was under water. 
 "We had to carry the kids out on our shoulders through water that was hip deep," said Wendy DeForge.
"It was so powerful it pushed the door right in," said Darrin Della Vecchia. Like everyone else, he had three feet of water in his kitchen and living room, and the furniture was floating upside down.
"We are still dealing with it," he said. A new kitchen floor, carpeting, furniture, accessories, stove, sheetrock and other items required taking a $15,000 loan.
The 14 affected families, new to Wallingford, were first-time home buyers. In the months since the flood they have been unsuccessful in negotiating for compensation with the town, the developer and various government agencies.
Indications that the devastation could have been foreseen and avoided are coupled with a bewildering array of happenstances for which it seems everyone and no one can be blamed.
The families, in financial difficulty and fearful of another flood, blame the developer for building houses with living space below grade level, and the town for allowing that.
Darrin and Susan Della Vecchia sued the developer in Superior Court in New Haven last Dec. 30, charging negligence, breach of contract and unfair practices, and the town, charging negligence. A hearing is set for tomorrow.
"These people were told by the developer and the town that they did not need flood insurance because they were not in a flood zone," said the Della Vecchias' lawyer, Joanne Heslin Laverty of Miniter and Associates in Hartford.
"Based on the reality of the situation," she added, "flood insurance should have been a condition of closing."
Indeed it was, but only in the few instances involving Government-backed mortgages.
"I thought they were being overcautious," said Jill Connolly about the Federal Housing Adminstration, which holds her mortgage. "They said that the living room was half a foot below flood-plain level and therefore I had to have flood insurance."
The homes were built with the utilities, living room and kitchen -- or in some models the utilities and family room -- below grade level.
"It was a method of keeping costs down to produce an affordable project," said Joan Molloy, the developer's lawyer.
David Shaw of Farren and King, a New Haven law firm, is representing the Raynors, DeForges and five other families who are about to file similar suits against the town, the developer and engineering firms.
"The houses are worthless," said Mr. Shaw. "The best bet for these people is a buyout by the entities responsible for their loss. This is a case where you have a whole development which, through a series of errors, was basically built under water."
Exactly 10 years earlier, on June 6, 1982, the Quinnipiac overflowed the same banks and flooded the same area, which was vacant then. But based on maps from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which indicated that the river's flood plain did not reach the building sites, the subdivision of 18 homes got town approval in 1989.
It was built by Donald Ahearn, a well-known local developer and owner of Factory Built Homes Inc. He paid $720,000 for the six acres and several existing foundations built by Hanover Wallingford Associates, builders from whom he bought the property and the approved plans. By early 1992 14 homes had been sold for $124,000 to $135,000. Two remaining foundations, one vacant lot and one unsold house are currently in limbo.
"Until this is cleared up we will not issue building permits or a certificate of occupancy to the developer," said Janet Small, the town attorney.
"The town is in fact liable for the whole mess," said Diane Lord of the Marcus Law Firm in New Haven, representing the developer in the Della Vecchia suit.
It seems there were two sets of flood elevations -- the FEMA maps, which the town and the developer used, and those of the Soil Conservation Service of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection.
"WE did a study in 1989 for the original developer," said Philip A. Renn, water resources coordinator for the Soil Conservation Service, "showing that the property was flood-prone and not suitable for residential development."
Ms. Molloy said that Mr. Ahearn "never received that study" and that if he had "he would not have bought the property."
Compounding the problem, Linda Bush, Wallingford's town planner, noted that "we relied on FEMA's flood elevations, which were in error by about two feet."
Kenneth Horak, public information officer at FEMA's regional office in Boston, said "the error was made by a contractor who developed the maps in the late 70's."
"The United States Geological Survey is now considering what impact that may have had," he said. "Their report is expected this month."
"Development within watersheds plays a role in situations like this, especially when combined with heavy rainfall," said Charles E. Berger, assistant director of water resources at the D.E.P. in Hartford. "The more you turn vacant land into pavement and rooftops the less chance you have for rainfall to infiltrate the ground. It runs off into the rivers.
"Attention to the Soil Conservation study could have prevented this. Had we been consulted by the town the study would have had an impact on our opinion, which is advisory, not mandatory. However, the town acted in accordance with its legally adopted flood insurance map and regulations."
Remedies suggested for Garden Road include raising the houses and building a dike, requiring displacement of the homeowners, possibly at their own expense. Mr. Berger indicated that the project did not qualify for Federal buyout funds. And based on appraisals of similar houses in the area, reduced in value by the recession, buyouts would fall short of the residents' expectations.
"I guess the cautionary tale here," said Mr. Shaw, "is that you can do everything you're supposed to do as an informed consumer and still get burned."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Last June, the Quinnipiac River flooded Wallingford, affecting 14 families on Garden Road with living space below grade level. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: New Canaan

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN much of the 19th century, New Canaan was a community of farmers, blacksmiths, carpenters, weavers and coopers. One day in 1830 the owner of Hoyt's General Store on Main Street had an attack of temperance and smashed his stock of liquor on the roadway. An astonished citizenry watched as all that good rum, gin and bourbon sank into the dust.
"The general store was where you bought liquor," said Mary Louise King, historian of what is now part of Connecticut's Gold Coast. "The town would vote to be wet or dry, back and forth every few years. We used to have more liquor stores than groceries, and until 1915 we had more Democrats than Republicans." 
 Some 18th century houses are still scattered around town, vastly improved as prized antiques. One remaining commercial building, the 200-year old sawmill by the waterfall on Jelliff Mill Road, continues to crank out fancy wood moldings.
Shoemaking was a principal industry for more than a century, but in the 1870's the 50,000 handmade pairs produced annually could not compete with new machines in the big cities, and local workers started moving elsewhere to earn a living.
By that time wealthy New Yorkers had begun trickling in to build summer homes. The trickle became a flood of year-round residents during the 1950's exodus from the cities.
A recent Forbes Magazine article about corporate America's most powerful people "reads like the New Canaan telephone directory," according to the The New Canaan Advertiser, a local weekly. Resident chief executives include Paul Allaire of Xerox, Robert D. Kennedy of Union Carbide, John W. Johnstone Jr. of the Olin Corporation and Andrew C. Sigler of Champion International.
Not surprisingly, the town is a mecca for architects. Currently for sale is a house designed by Marcel Breuer, priced at $2.35 million, and one for $1.25 million by Philip Johnson, who still occupies his own famous Glass House. A Frank Lloyd Wright house sold last year for $3.5 million. "I try to promote the contemporary style," said Barbara Cleary, owner of The Realty Guild, a local agency, "because we have some beauties."
Except for an occasional unwanted visitor breaking into David Letterman's house, life in New Canaan is relatively quiet, and that's how people like it. "My city friends are shocked when they realize that I don't lock my car," said Richard Mishkin, a broker with Coldwell Banker Realty on Elm Street.
"Change here is evolutionary, not revolutionary," said Daniel Foley, the town planner. "There is still land to develop, but in small pieces of six to eight acres," he said. Zoning was devised decades ago to confine nonresidential development to the center of town.
Apartment-building rentals and condominiums (mostly town houses and comprising 25 percent of the housing) are clustered around the business district of Main, Forest and Elm Streets and zoning radiates outward. Minimum one-family-home lot sizes range from 0.25 to 4 acres.
The 100 independent downtown shops aim for unusual clothing, silver, sporting goods, art, books, housewares, antiques and gourmet foods. The International Herald Tribune can be found on the newspaper racks of gas stations.
RESTAURANTS have increased at a rate of two or three a year. Now there are 27 establishments, compared with two luncheonettes in the early 1970's.
The Roger Sherman Inn, built in 1740, serves a continental fixed price dinner for $44, excluding wine, and L'Abbee, rated one of the top three restaurants in the Zagat suburban survey, has a signature shrimp and lobster entree at $23.50.
Unlimited play at New Canaan's 13 town tennis courts costs $43, and $20 covers a family at Kiwanis Park, where a pond for swimming and ice skating and a children's playground are available. There are six paddle tennis courts, the 40-acre Nature Center, six bird sanctuaries and five parks with baseball diamonds, hiking and fishing, all free. There are also several private country clubs and sports clubs.
Among some 100 civic, cultural and professional organizations are the Audubon Society, Alliance Francaise, Gentlemen Songsters, Embroiderer's Guild, Americares (a locally based international relief organization), National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Business and Professional Women's Club and New Canaan Bar Association.
The Town Players has its own theater in Waveny Park, a 300-acre public facility where mammoth Fourth of July town picnics are held, and the prestigious Silvermine Guild Arts Center, a 71-year-old gallery and art school that presents concerts and lectures.
A new auditorium was just completed at the public library, where, says David Bryant, its director, "we have a per capita readership of 17 books a year, about the highest in the state." For executives who have been victims of corporate downsizing, a job-search service with reprints of classified ads in 64 newspapers across the country has been installed.
There have been some recessionary foreclosures, but the economy caused barely a ripple in housing sales, except to cut prices around 20 percent. Construction and sales of homes priced from $500,000 to more than $1 million has continued, but "young couples have been buying resales in the $300,000 range with a 10 percent down payment," said Mr. Mishkin of Coldwell Banker Realty.
At Broad Brook Farm off Ponus Ridge Road, customized five-bedroom homes at $700,000 to $1 million are being built by Robert and William Feeber on 1- and 2-acre lots, while large homes on quarter-acre lots are available at Canaan Meadow for $495,000.
Out of a total of 6,948 dwellings in town, 267 houses and 45 condominiums are for sale. Some 62 houses are listed at over $1 million, and 116 are priced from $200,000 to $500,000. Luxurious summer rentals can cost up to $32,000, but rentals start around $1,000 a month.
The highly rated public school system's 2,605 pupils attending three elementary schools, Saxe Middle School and New Canaan High School, 93 percent of whose graduates went on to college last June. The latest addition to the high school curriculum is Japanese Language and Culture, a two-year program culminating in a trip to Japan.
Plans are afoot for a fourth elementary school to accomodate a baby boomlet, and a seven-year physical ugrading of all school buildings is under way. The combined estimated cost is $37 million.
ST. LUKE'S, a college preparatory school, and the k-9 New Canaan Country Day are independent private schools where tuition reaches a high of $11,000. St. Aloysius, a k-8 Roman Catholic School, charges $1,800 a year.
Among six nursery schools and five day-care facilities, the Y.M.C.A. offers programs for children 6 weeks old through 5 years. Maximum hours are 7:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. five days a week and fees range from $140 a month for part-timers to $910 a month full-time, year round.
An equestrian school for children and adults is run by The New Canaan Mounted Troop, one of the last junior cavalries in the country. Children may start at age 5 and horse shows are presented periodically in a large indoor ring with a glass-fronted viewing room. Fees start at $127 a month for weekly lessons, or $20 an hour without instruction.
New Canaan's Historical Society, on Oenoke Ridge, "is more like a Colonial village," said its director, Janet Lindstrom, with a schoolhouse, the studion of John Rogers, a popular turn-of-the-century sculptor: the first town hall, a tool museum, library, restored homes and a printing press. A new building will soon be added to accommodate an overflowing collection of antique costumes, books, artifacts, art and furniture, and the archives.
On Christmas Eve the town is ablaze with lights and resonant with caroling at God's Acre, the historic district overlooking Main Street. It was so named because it has three churches, built between 100 and 200 years ago, surrounding a small park that once served as the first settlers' burying ground.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Regional Planning Conference;
Workshops on Making the Area Work

 BODY:
Anyone who believes that "united we stand" is as applicable to states as to people might enjoy the Regional Plan Association's day-long conference this Tuesday. The association, which is dedicated to getting New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to set joint policies that can improve the quality of life in all three states, says that by day's end a blueprint will have emerged for turning this area into "The Region That Works."
The meeting will offer a series of workshops dealing with such subjects as rebuilding and expanding the region's infrastructure, protecting its environmental resources, training its labor, and ways of wooing companies -- and jobs -- to the area. 
 There will be specific workshops on how to turn the region's seven unconnected railway systems into a coordinated regional one, as well as on how to best develop land adjacent or close to transit. Another workshop will discuss the impact that immigrants have had on the region in the last decade or so and what the expected impact of future immigration will be.
The meeting's ultimate goal, according to H. Claude Shostal, the association's president, is to "show how thinking regionally will strengthen our position in the emerging global economy."
The meeting, which costs $85 (including lunch) for association members and $100 for others, will be held from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the New York Hilton. For more information, or to reserve a spot, call (212) 398-1140, ext. 201.

HEADLINE: The Quest to Conserve Electrical Power

 BODY:
It is unfortunate that "Lilco Ends a Homeowners' Rebate Program" [May 16] further confuses a complicated issue. There are two central issues facing those of us active in the fields of energy analysis, conservation and demand-side management. The first concerns are the quality, cost-effectiveness and long-term viability of utility demand-side management programs. The second is the methodology that the New York State Public Service Commission uses to allow Lilco and other New York State utilities to recover energy-conservation costs through the rate base. And while these two issues affect each other, it is important to make distinctions between the two. 
 According to recent filings with the P.S.C., Lilco's Residential Energy Cooperative was budgeted at $2.2 million for 1993, as the most expensive of Lilco's residential programs; was expected to reduce capacity or demand by 16.3 megawatts, the largest reduction of Lilco's residential programs, and was predicted to save 334 megawatt-hours of energy or customer use. This kilowatt-hour, or dollar savings, to customers is one of the smallest, second only to the Residential New Construction program, with a 248-megawatt-hour savings. The P.S.C. has been directing Lilco to scale down the Residential Energy Cooperative for several years and has recently asked Lilco to review the Residential New Construction program. Lilco had removed almost all the switching boxes from electric hot-water heaters by the end of 1992 and was in the process of curtailing other segments of the cooperative program. As well it should, since the cooperative program was based on load control or peak shaving, not energy conservation.
It is further unfortunate that none of your sources were able to produce a viable alternative to the program. An enlightened energy service company like the Conservation Services Group might have seen that having access to 22,000 customers with 5,500 electric water heaters and 16,500 central air-conditioners was a golden opportunity. Retrofitting or replacing inefficient equipment, duct work or control systems would produce considerable long-term energy savings.
The Conservation Services Group is the parent organization of the Energy Federation, the supplier of 139,282 compact fluorescents to Lilco customers in the past two years. Fortunately the $6 rebate is now available through local retailers, and if 1993 sales on Long Island match the Energy Federation's efforts, an additional $1.2 million in retail dollars might stay within the Long Island economy.
Mr. Kessel, as executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, has a public duty to object to Lilco's surcharge request. But as chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, a group that has put more effort into converting the Shoreham plant than implementing energy conservation, his motives are questionable. The Citizens' Advisory Panel was formed in 1989 through a Federal court decision, "to study and advise Lilco and the public concerning ways to improve electric service, to mitigate rate increases, and to assist ratepayers to conserve energy." I know Mr. Chaleff is committed to energy conservation, but it has taken the panel several years to realize the enormity of the work ahead.
It is relatively simple to replace or retrofit lights in the commercial sector, estimating savings is straightforward, and the dollars saved are impressive. Interestingly enough, there are some 66,162 residents, or 7 percent of the Long Island population, that have no access to demand-side management or energy-conservation projects from their utilities. As customers of municipal electric systems, the New York Power Authority or the Fishers Island Electric Corporation, there are no mandates nor directives from the P.S.C., and as the New York Power Authority has learned in several upstate municipal electric systems, conventional energy-conservation methodology does not have a great success rate in the residential sector.
This is not to say that Long Island homeowners cannot have energy conservation and demand-side management projects that routinely reduce energy bills by 30 to 40 percent, just that conventional methods won't do it. Conventional is what we have now, and while I do not disagree with Lise Marshall from the New England Sustainable Energy Association, Long Island is not New England, and it is indicative of the predicament of our knowledge and resources that there is no local group to contract for the equivalent information.
 
FRAZER DOUGHERTY
Greenport
 
The writer heads an energy-retrofitting business.

HEADLINE: 'This Town Will Die Without Our School'

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

DATELINE: KENILWORTH

 BODY:
THIS Union County borough is a self-contained place. Most of its 7,574 residents are employed nearby and shop in the strip of stores along Kenilworth Boulevard. "It's the kind of town where you're born, you go to school, get married, raise a family and die," said Janet Glynos, a Kenilworth native.
Now, forces inside and outside the community have combined to endanger its way of life. Since 1970, the population has declined by almost 1,600 people. A new shopping center and supermarket are going up on one end of town, threatening the downtown businesses. And David Brearley Regional High School, which Charles Vitale, a former school board president, calls "the social and civic hub of the town," is scheduled to be closed at the end of the 1993 school year. 
 The threatened closing of the school and dispatch of its students to another school in the regional district reflects concerns that are felt in many parts of the state where enrollments have been falling and school costs skyrocketing. The pressure to save money by merging school districts, for example, inspired the recent enactment of state legislation to provide incentives for such "regionalization."
But the prospect of losing their high school has led many of Brearley's parents to mount an intense campaign to save the school. In the process, they have sued the school district. They have also inspired a bill now before the State Legislature that would actually make it easier to dissolve existing regional districts and permit member schools, like Brearley, to go their own ways.
Ever since the 1930's, Kenilworth and the nearby towns of Berkeley Heights, Clark, Garwood, Mountainside and Springfield have been linked by participation in Union County Regional High School District No. 1. The district's four high schools are supervised by a district board and superintendent.
Socially and economically, Kenilworth and Garwood, whose students also attend Brearley, have little in common with the four other towns in the school district. Kenilworth has a median family income of $45,774, while the wealthiest of the district's towns, Mountainside, has a median family income of $80,699. About 9 percent of Kenilworth's residents are college graduates, as opposed to about 33 percent in Berkeley Heights and Mountainside, and 27 in Springfield.
"We're blue-collar people," said Mrs. Glynos, one of the leaders of S.O.S. (Save Our School). She characterizes Kenilworth as a town of small family-owned businesses, where houses are passed down from parents to their grown children.
Over the last 20 years, enrollment in the four regional high schools has gone from a high of 5,798 in 1972-73 to the current enrollment of 2,163. The yearly average cost per pupil has risen from just over $3,000 in 1980-81 to about $15,000 in 1992-93.
In the spring of 1990 and again in 1991, voters rejected the district's school budget proposals. After the budget defeats, the board began to examine ways of cutting costs, including the closing of one or more of the four schools, and in September 1991 the Brearley parents organized to fight such a move. "We didn't want to see it happen to anyone," Mrs. Glynos said.
In the spring of 1992, S.O.S. campaigned in behalf of the district school budget in the belief, Mrs. Glynos said, that Dr. Donald Merachnik, the district Superintendent, had promised that Brearley would stay open if the budget was accepted. (Tom Long, the spokesman for the district, denies that any such promise was given.)
Among the voters the organization pursued were the borough's elderly residents. Charles Vitale, who is now president of the Kenilworth Senior Citizens, said that by far the majority of elderly residents supported the idea of keeping the local school open.
"Our taxes will go up anyway," he said, adding that the members of his group had backed S.O.S. because Brearley is such an integral part of the close-knit community's way of life.
The 1992 school budget was passed. Then, in October of that year, Dr. Merachnik presented a 27-page report that recommended, among other things, that Brearley High School's 400 students be "reassigned" to Jonathan Dayton High School in Springfield. The Brearley building would then be leased, the report said, possibly to another district, with its classrooms, auditorium and playing fields to remain available, if possible, to the Kenilworth community.
In November, the district board voted to carry out Dr. Merachnik's recommendations. Only the board representatives from Kenilworth and Garwood voted against the proposal.
 
'We Were Devastated'
 "We were devastated by the decision," said Linda McMenamin, president of the Brearley High School Parent-Teacher Association. Mrs. McMenamin also said she thought the Kenilworth school had been "targeted" for closing because Kenilworth and Garwood are the least affluent of the six towns.
The day after the November board vote, S.O.S. hired a lawyer, Robert P. Glickman, a former New Jersey Superior Court administrative law judge, who sued the regional district in Superior Court to stop the closing. He charged that the decision to close Brearley was "capricious" and made without sufficient time for the board to study alternative solutions.
While Mr. Glickman prepared for trial, S.O.S. began enlisting community support and sponsoring cake sales and auctions to raise money for legal expenses.
The trial last month produced a cavalcade of lawyers and expert witnesses and boxes of documents. Experts on both sides testified on the physical condition of all four buildings, the economic and educational advantages and disadvantages of high schools with 400 students (like Brearley) or 800 students (the approximate number of students in the three remaining high schools after the closing of Brearley), and the effect that Brearley's closing would have on Kenilworth property values. As of June 2, no decision had been rendered.
 
School Budget Rejected
 Though only Kenilworth and Garwood face school closings, voters in all six of the district's towns rejected the proposed 1993 school budget because of the growing school costs.
There is also substantial support in several of the towns for Assembly Bill No. 2294, introduced in February. Sponsored by Union County legislators, the bill would permit the dissolving of a regional district with an average per-pupil cost of $15,000 or more a year if approved by the majority of the member towns. Current law requires a unanimous vote. A companion bill has been introduced in the State Senate. S.O.S. has lobbied for the bill with an extensive letter-writing campaign.
If the parents' organization succeeds in its effort to prevent the closing of Brearley, Mrs. Glynos says, the goal will be to remove the school from the regional district and to enrich its course offerings by making arrangements with neighboring educational institutions like Union County College.
But the central issue for her and the other members of S.O.S. is to save Brearley and its special relationship to Kenilworth. "This town will die without our school," Mrs. McMenamin said.

HEADLINE: ART;
Photography That Is Immune From the 'Romance' of Labor

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
IT seems to be getting closer, the utopian heaven in which machines do all the work, leaving people free, as it were, to produce art or go sport fishing. Yet, to judge from Sebastiao Salgado's photographs at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, hard labor is still the lot of the majority.
At the port of Chittagong, in Bangladesh, for instance, there are beached ships to be demolished manually by blowtorch and sledgehammer. In Java, livings are made harvesting sulfur from the lake boiling in the crater of a volcano. But with the seven-hour climb up to the crater and the return trip loaded down with 155 pounds of the mineral, not to mention the fumes encountered on the way, each gleaner has to rest two days for every one worked. 
 Alternatively, there is, maybe, a fortune to be made prospecting for gold at the Serra Pelada gold mine, in the photographer's native country, Brazil. During the relatively dry winter, 50,000 men descend daily into this strip-mine-sized cavity. Looking like dung beetles from afar, they fill sacks with earth and lug them back up to the top by way of ramshackle ladders. One of the many homosexuals working in this hell hopes to find the nuggets that will get him to Paris for the silicone breasts that, he says, are the best in the world.
These facts are taken from an essay written by Mr. Salgado and Eric Nepomuceno for "Workers: An Archeology of the Industrial Age," the Aperture book that shares its title with the show. Hefting this eight-pound paperback is basic training for any of the occupations documented by the photographer.
Mr. Salgado's art is informed by his early training as an economist; his comments about the wealth made on commodities exchanges versus the wages paid for the growing, extracting and processing of these raw materials are most enlightening.
Still, it is hard to imagine him making the same impact with his writing as he does with his black-and-white pictures. He delivers his points laconically and, unlike many photojournalists with a mission, seems immune to the "romance" of labor and, far from inciting his viewers to mount the barricades, leaves them to infer what they will.
There is enormous power in these images. How could there not be with subjects like the woman laboring over a canal in northern India who hacks at desert, her upraised arms with bangles from wrist to elbow? There is also beauty bordering on the picturesque, as in the well-known scenes of Texans cleaning up the oil disaster in Kuwait -- an omen of "the fire next time" if ever there was one.
Although the photographer is said never to pose them, his compositions are astonishingly clean-cut, and at least one, the scene of Cuban cane cutters resting, looks like a movie still. More than anything else, the prints have the look of early 19th-century French Realist painting -- there is even a "Carmen" making Cuban cigars -- and it may be this that prompts criticism from younger, less successful photographers.
Although most of the action takes place in third-world countries, the first world is not omitted. Among the Channel Tunnel shots is one of the workers on the English side that is noteworthy for including Australians but no one from the African or Caribbean part of the Commonwealth.
In the catalogue, Mr. Salgado mentions fears that are often voiced in pubs but seldom in conventional news coverage: "For the first time since 1066, the English have been invaded from the Continent -- from France, no less" -- and by a tunnel bringing "barbarians." The photographer believes that English sandhogs "cannot admit that deep down they feel like accomplices to a frightening defeat."
France, Poland, Russia and Ukraine are represented by heavy industry; the conveyor belt in the picture reproduced moves coal and iron ore to Dunkirk. The only thing to speak for the United States is the slaughterhouse in Sioux Falls, S.D. One butcher hoses down a bull's head complete with one open liquid eye; another eviscerates pig corpses that look human. But as ghastly as any is the image of a barn packed with live pigs getting their last shower -- from a sprinkler system. One thinks not only of the terror coursing through their plump bodies but also of concentration camp inmates getting their "last shower" in the gas chambers. 
Though many of the photographs are ostensibly about nothing but beauty -- the view of razor-sharp peaks on the island of Reunion, for example -- this huge exhibition is guaranteed to leave its beholders as alarmed for the globe as for its insatiable inhabitants.
The closing date is July 11. Museum hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday, until 8 P.M. Wednesdays.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Photograph by Sebastiao Salgado showing conveyor belt moving coal and iron ore. (Philadelphia Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Roy Gillian;
Lessons in Running an Amusement Park

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE

DATELINE: OCEAN CITY

 BODY:
Roy Gillian followed his father into the amusement park business, and he has, in turn, brought his three sons, Jim, Steve and Jay, into the operation of Gillian's Wonderland Pier. It is something of a landmark in this seaside resort, which was founded as a summer colony for vacationing Methodists at the turn of the century.
And Mr. Gillian himself, at 63 years of age, has achieved considerable stature -- in Ocean City, where he was once the Mayor; in Trenton, where he has often appeared before the Legislature as a member and former president of the 200-member New Jersey Amusement Association, and in the councils of the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions, an organization with more than 3,000 members in 54 countries, which he now serves as president. 
 Among other duties, he is leading the organization's drive to create an international amusement park museum. A feasibility study is under way for a Virginia site just outside Washington, that Mr. Gillian hopes will be complete with a Hall of Fame, a 50-seat theater with robots, a panorama depicting the history of amusement parks, a roller-coaster simulator and an area where different parks around the world could set up booths to display videos and mementos.
Meanwhile, Mr. Gillian is taking his amusement park through its first month of operation this year. "There are always happy faces out there," he said in a recent interview, looking toward the most prized possession among his 33 rides: the No. 75 carousel, hand carved by the Philadelphia Toboggan Company in 1922.
There are only two others in New Jersey, he said -- one at Seaside Park and the other at Great Adventure in Jackson Township.
"Sometimes when young married people have children, they just can't wait to give them their first merry-go-round ride," Mr. Gillian said. "And they get on there, and they have as much fun as the kids."
Mr. Gillian and his wife, Patricia, an apartment-house manager, live in Ocean City.
Q: Are you praying for a hot summer?
A: Well, I think everybody in the amusement business prays for that. Without a doubt, this spring has gotten off to a great start. So everybody is very happy.
Q: Will beach erosion be much of a problem for business this year?
A: I flew down along the beach when I came home from visiting amusement park owners in New England, and I noticed North Jersey got hit pretty good. But it wasn't nearly as bad as Long Island.
You know, some people say it's a waste of money to keep refilling the beaches, but when you think about all the property that's here, you know, it's definitely a good insurance policy, which is our way of thinking.
Q: Do the amusement park owners work with the police departments in the summer?
A: Yes, we do. As an association, we also succeeded in getting a bill through the Legislature this year that protects us against civil suits if we put somebody off a ride because they're under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Here in Ocean City, though, we're lucky because the town is dry.
Q: Has the recession had much of an impact on the amusement business?
A: You know, in all fairness, even last year I beat the year before.
Q: You did?
A: I've heard that expressed by a number of the parks. My father's favorite saying is, "No matter how bad times are, a father will always have some money to spend on his kids for a merry-go-round ride."
I think that always holds true, and this is 29 summers coming up, and for the 28th, or I would say 27 out of 28 years, I've increased my gross each year. Parks that are constantly trying to update and add new equipment each year seem to do just a little bit better.
Q: What's the edge you have over the huge theme parks?
A: I've been lucky here. People come for the ocean and the beach. We do most all our business at nighttime; when the people are off the beach, they come to the boardwalk.
But I think Disney set the pace years ago for the theme parks. They're beautifully laid out and landscaped. They handle the customers as guests. They've been a great inspiration to all the small parks in trying their best to make their own surroundings pleasing. And to increase their level of safety.
Q: Are you concerned at all about Time Warner buying out amusement parks?
A: Time Warner is the controlling interest in all the Six Flags Great Adventure parks. Paramount, Disney, Universal, Cedar Point -- they're all on the New York Stock Exchange -- major conglomerates that are into the amusement industry. They have so much money behind them that they can afford to do a lot. But people when they go to them, it's like an outing they plan on.
With us, see, we're different because people come to the seashore. But I guess if enough big parks come around and they saturate a certain area, well, the little guy is going to be the one to suffer.
Q: Do you think they will make you an offer you can't refuse?
A: I've been asked what would I do. And I don't think I would ever sell, because I have three sons that are coming up, and they're in the business and I'm doing well now and I don't think money would change that around.
My youngest son, he just loves it. I mean, he sleeps and eats it, and I think he will be the one to carry it over the 100-year mark. My father started in 1930, so we're over the 60-year mark. And I think by the time I'm really ready to retire and my youngest boy carries it on, we'll be celebrating that 100 years.
Q: Have you seen the clientele change?
A: It depends on location. Seaside gets a lot of the New York traffic that comes down. We get the suburban Philadelphia, Cherry Hill area. I haven't really seen much of a change.
I know some of the parks have people out taking information as they come through the gate. A lot of them use zip codes. They like to see where the people come so they can know where to spend their money in advertising.
Q: Have you added any new rides for this year?
A: Well, the only thing that we did new this year is this one kiddie ride, and that was Willy the Whale -- that's right out on the front of the boardwalk here. Last year was the Log Flume, and that was the big addition.
Q: Is your City Jet Roller Coaster still the biggest money maker?
A: No. It's the Log Flume. It really did well.
Q: What rides did your father, Dave Gillian, start out with?
A: A merry-go-round, a Ferris wheel and a tilt-a-whirl -- most every park has one, or every carnival. They're the standard.
Q: You can build a park on those three?
A: Yes. Know why? Kids and adults will go on them, and that's the key to success. Getting something that appeals to both ages. I don't even buy a kiddie ride now unless the adults can get in the car with them. Even the little whales will hold adults.
We got a couple of rides out here where just kids get in, and the gross just never matches with the one where you can get the adults in there with them. Because I still think the adults like it as much as the kids.
Q: How about bungee jumping -- will that still be popular this year?
A: I think it hit its peak last year. The state is going to stop them from jumping off cranes. By the time the legislation gets through the chain of command, requiring that you build a tower and at a certain height, with a pillow underneath, it'll be late in the season. Bungee jumping is like the trampolines and other fads. You do it for a little while, but it's not a repeat thing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roy Gillian near Gillian's Wonderland Pier, which he owns and operates. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Susan Webb, Jean Dreyfus

 BODY:
Susan Patterson Webb, a managing principal at Paribas Capital Markets, was married yesterday to Jean Francoise Dreyfus, a vice president at Credit Suisse Financial Products Inc., both in New York. The Rev. David T. Lowman, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Covenant Presbyterian Church in Petersburg, Va. Cantor Fernand Peres took part in the ceremony.
Mrs. Webb-Dreyfus is the group head of the equity derivatives department of the New York securities branch of Banque Paribas of Paris. She graduated from the University of Virginia, from which she also received an M.B.A. She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Webb of Petersburg. 
 Mr. Dreyfus received an M.B.A. from l'Ecole Superieure des Sciences Economiques et Commerciales in Paris and a Ph.D. in finance from the University of Pennsylvania. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Germain Dreyfus of Paris.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Dollar Gains In Finland

 BODY:
American visitors to Finland this year will find many prices dramatically lower than two years ago, thanks to a sharp drop in the value of the Finnish currency and a recession in that country.
According to a study conducted at the end of 1992 by Suomen Gallup Oy, a Finnish polling organization, which compared the prices for such staples as hotel rooms and a McDonald's Big Mac in 12 Western European capitals, Helsinki fell below the median on all types of lodging and most restaurant purchases, as well as train travel and airline tickets. Exceptions included taxi fares, car rental and food bought at a grocery. 
 The Finnish markka was devalued twice in the last two and a half years, for a total of 30 percent. In the spring of 1991, the markka was worth about 27 cents in United States currency; late last month, it was about 18 cents.
Inflation has remained low and, in some cases, prices have actually gone down. At the elegant Hotel Klaus Kurki, on the fashionable Bulevardi in downtown Helsinki, prices for a double have declined from $230 in 1991 to $153 on weekdays or $90 on weekends in 1993. At Restaurant Lord, Lonnrotinkatu 29 in Helsinki, telephone 680 1680, which was awarded one Michelin star this year, the three-course Finlandia menu -- salted salmon in cognac, reindeer in cepe sauce and cloudberry crepes -- including tip and taxes, costs about $32 a person, compared to $52 in 1991.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
New Curves in the Currency Game

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
FOREIGN markets provide at least 40 percent of the profits for the nation's 500 largest companies, so those companies are always desperate to find shelter from currency trading tempests. The more so now that the world's mightiest currencies are getting bumped around like a bunch of biotech stocks. Several leading manufacturers are feuding with securities and accounting authorities over proposed rules that, they say, would compound the risks of competing abroad, discouraging investment.
To the authorities, the issue is whether accounting standards can be twisted to disguise currency risks from investors. "How well do we serve investors in those situations by working up some accounting conventions so things look nice and stable?" said Halsey G. Bullen, a manager at the Financial Accounting Standards Board. "How well does that reflect economic reality? Life is volatile sometimes." 
 But manufacturers say that, when it comes to currencies, they can smooth out many of life's bumps. Merck and Company, for example, reaps about half its nearly $10 billion in sales from about 40 foreign countries. To keep declining currencies from hurting earnings as they are converted into dollars, Merck buys options that rise in value as currencies fall. (Options afford the right to buy or sell a certain amount of currency at a fixed price until a specified date.)
Other companies likewise hedge the cost of foreign investments and materials, including supplies imported to the United States. For many, including Eastman Kodak, currency risks even influence plant locations.
As the dollar strengthened during the early 1980's, hedging strategies were still in their infancy, and many companies were left naked. With each pound or franc worth fewer dollars, the value of Merck's foreign sales and profits fell by as much as a third. Annual increases in research spending, calibrated to the likely returns, fell by almost half.
Now, many manufacturers have their own currency strategists and traders. But glowering behind them, threatening to spoil all the fun, are the regulators.
When a currency hedge creates a loss today, they say, why should accounting rules let a Merck avoid reporting it on the mere anticipation of recouping with foreign sales? Many officials favor strict accounting of such losses, which would inevitably discourage currency hedging.
The value of options and other means of hedging bounce around with the underlying currencies. Having to figure the gains and losses into quarterly earnings could make a stable company seem more like a risky offshore hedge fund. Stock investors award premiums for consistent earnings growth but penalize zigs and zags.
As long as currency hedges offset signed contracts or deals to be completed within three months, companies can keep them off their earnings reports. Merck and many others, however, want to plan perhaps five years out. Hedging can produce sharp short-term gains or losses, but can help assure that profits expected in the long term -- from the building of a new plant or research on a new drug -- aren't swallowed up in interim currency turmoil.
"Foreign exchange can throw a ringer into a lot of good plans," said Judy Lewent, Merck's chief financial officer. A member of the accounting board's advisory panel, she has rallied other companies and brought in accounting board members to hear Merck's case. "The core capabilities of a company are its business and that's the risk a company should be focused on," she said. "Foreign currency swings can be hedged away."
By early last year, the accounting board's corporate advisers wanted to let the corporate currency doctors try a whole new range of treatments. Riskier, long-term hedges were to be permitted without having to report the direct quarterly consequences, on the assumption that the hedges and the eventual foreign sales or purchases would balance out in the end.
Then the S.E.C. stepped in.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has made the accounting board the master of ceremonies, reserving the right to stop the party if things get too raucous. Accountants are seldom a wild bunch. But about a year ago, Walter P. Schuetze, the S.E.C.'s chief accountant, not only forestalled the loosening of the rules, but also forbade companies from keeping some complicated option hedges off their quarterly results.
Mr. Schuetze rejects Merck's argument that, because foreign drug sales are bound to offset today's hedging losses, earnings statements need not reflect those losses. "These products are going to be produced a year from now, three years from now, five years from now," Mr. Schuetze boomed through a speaker phone. "They exist only in the mind of the plant manager."
Early this year, the accounting board tentatively proposed a requirement that losses and gains from even the simplest options be reported. A decision awaits the arrival of two new board members (out of seven).
Executives at McDonald's, which opens new restaurants overseas at the rate of more than one a day, say that the accounting board's rules keep them from hedging their currency risks as much as broad business considerations would dictate. "The real purpose of accounting should be to reflect the true economics of the situation," said Michael L. Conley, McDonald's controller. "That gets short shrift." The company is apparently operating as if the latest restrictions were already in effect.
Not that corporate credibility on accounting issues is all that high. Witness the refusal until recently to provide any consistent valuation of executive stock options -- options often worth many times as much as salaries.
But maybe there is a course to satisfy both sides. Abraham M. George, a leading consultant on foreign exchange matters, would let corporations hedge all they want with simple options, but keep the tougher reporting standards for riskier methods. Which creates no more risk than the rules allow today.
