HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 30 - June 4

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Go Ahead, Cheer: People Are Going Back to Work 

President Clinton would probably have liked it to go this way: pass a stimulus package, then cheer the resulting job growth. But job growth came first -- a surprisingly strong report last week showed unemployment below 7 percent for the first time since late 1991 -- at 6.9 percent -- and payrolls up smartly. This could make a pared-down stimulus package harder for Congress to swallow, though, so the Administration was cautious, with Labor Secretary Robert Reich warning not to "put too much weight on a single month's numbers." But the numbers were good, and since those numbers mean people with paychecks, that's what really matters. The Labor Department's household survey, in fact, put last month's job growth at 857,000, the largest gain in nine years. And New Jersey got good news: its jobless rate had soared in recent months, hitting a grim 9.1 percent in April, but in May it glided back to 7.4 percent.
 
A Higher Wage? Uh, Not Just Yet
 
The numbers tell it: In the 70's, the minimum wage notched upward, tagging along behind average wages. But in the Reagan years, it didn't budge, falling steadily behind reality. George Bush vetoed one increase, later accepting a compromise. The result, noted one non-Republican, Edward M. Kennedy: "a steady erosion" in real wages for many. "No one who works full time in America," he said, "should have to live in poverty." Enter candidate Clinton, waving his sword, vowing glittering justice -- a $1 rise, to $5.25. But that, like many of his heroic vows, has become a hem and a haw. Not yet, Administration officials said last week, tiptoeing around the conservative dragon on the White House lawn. The time isn't right. The calendar is full. Business doesn't like it. So, the center holds; full-time poverty does, too.
 
Indexes Are Weak, Cars Aren't
 
So when the snows melted and the tulips erupted, did the economy warm up or not? Once again, it's pick-your-statistic time. While job data looked better, one heavy-duty index, the leading indicators, looked feeble last week. But Americans don't live in indexes or drive indicators, and, looking further, there were better tidings. Sales of new homes hit a six-year peak, snapping back from a bleak winter. But there was true strength in car sales, which rose 10 percent in late May, continuing a string of increases. And Detroit's amazing comeback continued, as the Big Three grabbed back a bit more of what they had given up to imports. Even lumbering General Motors did better, having had a novel idea: Don't raise prices.
 
If Hospitals Are Paid, They'll Pay
 
There will be winners and losers if the Clinton reformers give health insurance to all Americans. Those now uninsured will be winners; those who must pay the bill, the losers. But the White House sees other winners: Since hospitals will shed nonpaying customers, it says, they'll get a windfall, and last week officials said the President was considering a tax on hospitals to help pay for reform. For their part, hospitals say they now raise prices for paying patients to offset losses on free care, so the windfall will disappear when they must lower prices to compete.
 
Meanwhile, this whole idea of health care reform seems more remote than ever. Hillary Rodham Clinton's task force quietly closed up shop last week, its task incomplete. And when will the cosmic overhaul be unveiled? Well, July, maybe September. Some top priorities, it seems, are not quite top priorities.
 
The Gift Horse That Wasn't
 
People want everything instantly these days -- instant information, instant movies, instant calls on a pocket phone. A child learns it early. If a shady character menaces, he doesn't call the police -- he zaps him with a Nintendo button. So on the instant-gratification front, everything was up to date in Chicago last week at the Consumer Electronics Show. No sooner had Nintendo set up a domino-like display of Mario cassette boxes, to mark the recent 100 millionth sale of that game, than the crowd, clearly well schooled in the ways of greed, decided to help themselves. But the last zap was on them: the boxes were empty, the faces soon red.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Ganging Up on Poor A.T.& T.
 
How the mighty have become a bit less so. Just listen to A.T.& T., so recently the only game in town, saying it "deserves the same freedom as this giant BT-MCI alliance enjoys." What prompted this it's-not-fair-he's-got-more-pie wail? Last week British Telecom said it would buy a fifth of MCI for $4.3 billion. These global days, companies want one-stop shopping for private networks providing telephone and computer links, and this deal is a challenge to A.T.& T., which has been seeking greater British access.
 
A Trade Pact? Could Be
 
A worldwide trade pact -- it's been a maddeningly elusive goal, as leading nations keep getting sidetracked in their efforts to lower global barriers. But negotiators keep plodding on, as the GATT talks move into their seventh year. And last week, meeting in Paris, the United States and other big powers said they were actually close to a key breakthrough, ending or reducing tariffs on many products. Stumbling blocks remain -- Japan's persistent trade surplus, the spat with Europe over farm subsidies -- but officials insist that a formal pact is now possible by year's end. Stranger things have happened.
 
Real Trouble in Germany
 
The German economy is in real trouble; it isn't just some cyclical malaise. If there was any doubt about this, it vanished last week when Bonn reported that western Germany's economy had its worst period since such tallies began in 1968 -- a 3.7 percent first-quarter contraction. And economists now say that this recession could be the worst since the end of World War II. "It would be too simple" to call this cyclical, one economist said. "There are fundamental structural problems."
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
G.E. Cedes a Bit of Midtown
 
Could it be a trend? A century ago, Columbia University moved uptown, with advancing New York commerce hot on its heels. But smug commerce overreached itself, building offices that now gather dust, and last week Columbia tiptoed back into the vacuum. Perhaps on the theory that if you can't rent it, give it away, General Electric donated a 50-story Art Deco tower in Manhattan to Columbia. G.E. has swapped a building that's two-thirds vacant -- it's at 51st and Lexington -- for a $40 million tax deduction. And Columbia, bursting at the seams, gets a much-needed annex. If this goes on, commercial New York will be right back where it started, hugging the foot of the island, and cattle will be grazing lazily in Times Square.
 
Dose of Reality at Tambrands
 
Once again, corporate directors have said "Enough!" The facts were easy to size up, for the company, Tambrands, makes only one product, tampons. And not only was Tampax steadily losing its powerful hold on the market, but company managers kept saying that things weren't too bad. Shareholders, in fact, had sued in April, saying that the chairman, Martin Emmett, had made rosy forecasts, driving up the stock price and enabling him to cash in stock options. So last week at a board meeting, when reality yet again proved a distant stranger to Mr. Emmett's promises, directors sent Mr. Emmett packing.
 
Kazarian Lashes Out at Sunbeam
 
Paul B. Kazarian is gone from Sunbeam-Oster, but he does not plan to be forgotten anytime soon. He was ousted in January, accused of being erratic and irrational -- and thus an ultimate danger to the company -- and he and his former partners have been at each other's throats ever since. Last week he stepped up the battle, filing a $3.2 billion lawsuit contending that he had been a victim of a conspiracy, that he had been denied the earnings he was owed, and that his partners had tried to smear his reputation.
 
Plenty of Buyers for Allstate
 
Even after Hurricane Andrew, investors still seem to love insurance companies. Allstate lost $2.5 billion to that storm, which may have been why Allstate's owner, Sears, Roebuck, needed to raise a bit of cash. And it had no trouble doing so last week. In the biggest initial offering ever, Sears -- which wants to get its mind back on retailing anyway -- raised $2.43 billion by selling Allstate shares. That easily topped the previous record for an offering, the $1.65 billion that Conrail raised in 1987. The Allstate shares, initially priced at $27, rose quickly in hectic trading, ending the week at $28.75.
 
Miracle on Channel 34?
 
A lot of people want to liven up their living rooms -- with a new couch, perhaps -- but there are limits. Here's what Myron Ullman, Macy's chairman, proposes: "a 24-hour-a-day, 7-day-a-week department store in your living room." Sounds hectic, but it's coming. Macy's said last week that it would start a cable channel next year to sell its wares. To top it off, one partner in the venture is Don Hewitt, executive producer of "60 Minutes." Does that mean Mike Wallace will be sitting across the coffee table from you, asking penetrating questions about whether those $24.95 pants really won't shrink? Macy's, by the way, hopes to be assigned channel 34 -- to evoke memories of "Miracle on 34th Street."
 
Outgrowing Federal Express
 
Federal Express may have been victimized by its own success. It has lost several top executives in recent years, and last week two more resigned, battering the stock. One possible explanation for the exodus: because of options they were granted on a stock that has soared over the years, these executives made sizable fortunes. And since the founding chairman, Frederick Smith, is just 48, none of them saw the top job in their future -- and could well afford to live other lives.

HEADLINE: U.S. Gives Up on a Chip-Making Tool, but Does It Matter?

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
A strenuous effort by the United States Government and the American semiconductor industry to save American manufacturers of a vital type of machinery used in making computer chips is ending in failure.
One of the last two major American manufacturers of that equipment, the GCA Corporation, went out of business last month. The other, the Silicon Valley Group Inc., has concluded that it cannot continue on its own and is negotiating an agreement to license what is considered highly promising technology to an important Japanese competitor, Canon Inc., in exchange for financial assistance. 
 The agreement comes only three years after a controversy arose when the same technology was almost sold to another Japanese company, the Nikon Corporation.
Together, the developments mean that American semiconductor companies will continue to depend almost completely on Japanese suppliers for the chief tool used to make future generations of computer chips.
THAT multimillion-dollar equipment is for a process known as photolithography, in which microscopic circuit patterns are imprinted on silicon wafers. Canon and Nikon control 80 percent of the market. Most of the rest is held by ASM, a Dutch company.
"The U.S. effort to create an independent lithography business has failed," said G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research Inc., a market research company in San Jose, Calif., that specializes in semiconductor manufacturing equipment.
American semiconductor industry officials have long feared relying on Japan for lithography equipment because Japanese competitors would have first access to the latest machinery. Indeed, one of the primary goals of Sematech, the American semiconductor industry consortium that is partly financed by the Federal Government, was to preserve American ability to manufacture chips, and it poured tens of millions of dollars into GCA and the Silicon Valley Group.
But Sematech, although it is given good marks overall for helping the American semiconductor industry, failed in the lithography area. It helped both lithography companies improve their technology, but it could not solve their financial problems.
Now that the battle has mainly been lost, however, American executives say it no longer matters. Competition along national lines is waning, they say. Canon and Nikon, suffering from Japan's recession, cannot afford to turn away American purchase orders.
"I don't sense that anyone is paranoid anymore," Wilfred J. Corrigan, chairman and chief executive of the LSI Logic Corporation, a Silicon Valley chipmaker, said during a visit to Japan Friday.
That contrasts sharply to the situation in late 1989 when concern spread that Nikon was considering buying the lithography business of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. To keep the technology in American hands, the Silicon Valley Group bought the Perkin-Elmer business with help from the International Business Machines Corporation, Perkin-Elmer's largest customer. Sematech contributed $30 million to help Silicon Valley Group perfect the technology.
But last month, the Silicon Valley Group said it had signed a letter of intent with Canon to form a "global partnership." Canon would gain exclusive rights to sell the Silicon Valley Group's equipment in Japan and most of the rest of Asia in exchange for contributing manufacturing assistance and financial support. The Silicon Valley Group would sell the machines in the United States and Korea. The two companies would split the manufacturing.
Papken S. Der Torossian, chairman and chief executive of the Silicon Valley Group, said the agreement, far from being a sale of technology, would ensure that the Silicon Valley Group continued to manufacture in the United States and to share in any improvements made by Canon.
Mr. Der Torossian, who in the past has been a vocal critic of American companies' licensing technology to Japan, said the Silicon Valley Group, with revenues of $200 million, was too small to continue supporting development costs of $30 million to $40 million a year. Moreover, he said, American semiconductor companies are reluctant to buy equipment from a company they are worried might not be able to survive over the long run.
"Semiconductor companies are not going to tie up their billion-dollar factories on a little company," he said. Getting Canon's support "lends credibility to this technology."
So far, the agreement appears to have raised little concern in Washington. William Spencer, Sematech's chief executive, had a telephone conference call on the matter late in May with Laura Tyson, the head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and John Gibbons, the President's science adviser.
Dr. Spencer, on a visit to Japan last week, said that he argued in the conversation that the agreement with Canon would be better for the United States than letting the Silicon Valley Group's efforts fail.
"If I had to figure out a way to make S.V.G.L. successful, this would be the best way I could think of," he said, referring to Silicon Valley Group Lithography Systems, a subsidiary. "If you want to keep a company like this alive for three years and continue to develop the technology, it's going to cost a lot of money."
Dr. Spencer said that even though the Silicon Valley Group is ceding rights to sell its machine in about half the world market, "I don't think S.V.G.L. can get into the Japanese market without a joint venture with Canon or Nikon."
JON IWATA, an I.B.M. spokesman, said his company also supported the deal, which is a joint venture, not an outright sale, as would have been the case with Nikon. "Our intent has always been to have a source here in the United States of this kind of product, and we still have that," he said.
Still, the deal will make Canon a stronger future competitor than it otherwise would have been, Mr. Hutcheson of VLSI Research said. In addition, he saw risks that Canon, being much bigger and richer than the Silicon Valley Group, could eventually control the technology.
GCA, of Andover, Mass., has been struggling for years since it fell behind in technology to Canon and Nikon. It was purchased in 1988 by the General Signal Corporation of Stamford, Conn., which decided to sell the semiconductor equipment business. But no buyer has been found for GCA's research and manufacturing business, so it is being shut.
GCA also suffered from American semiconductor companies' reluctance to risk buying crucial equipment from an endangered supplier.
One reason for the present lack of concern among American semiconductor companies with these developments is that most of them now have their own joint research or manufacturing agreements with Japanese companies. Development of a new generation of chips can cost more than $100 million, and an advanced factory, more than $1 billion, making cost-sharing necessary.
Moreover, in the last few years the American semiconductor industry has regained the lead in market share from the Japanese industry, so the American industry no longer feels threatened with extinction.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 6, 1993

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 497 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
If the Polo Is Free, Are Rates Headed Up?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
ARE banks starting to get more friendly? Do they actually want to lend more money, and to attract the deposits needed to make those loans?
If the answer to those questions is yes, it represents a big change from the situation that prevailed over the past couple of years. In the wake of loan debacles, banks decided to get smaller. Would-be borrowers found credit standards were tougher, and the interest rates offered to depositors tumbled. 
 Some banks went even further. Citibank, a trend-setter in good times and bad, urged owners of maturing C.D.'s to move the money into mutual funds. That suggestion was made even to depositors who seemed happy to stay despite the lower rates. The banks simply did not want the money.
But do they now? While banks, in a quarterly Federal Reserve survey, report that they have eased credit standards in recent months and want to make more loans, statistics on loan volume do not prove it. "There is absolutely no evidence that loan demand is picking up," said David Jones, the Fed watcher at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. And the average rate paid by banks on savings accounts is still about 2.5 percent, a rate that has not risen even as Treasury bill rates have climbed in recent weeks.
But there are signs of economic improvement -- notably a surprisingly high level of job growth in May -- which ought to translate into credit demand. The Labor Department says more people are working than ever before in this country.
And perhaps Citibank is signaling a change. In a mailing last week -- sent only to "our best customers," a bank spokeswoman said -- it offered the 1990's equivalent of free toasters for aging yuppies. A new deposit of $5,000 is good for a pair of Yankee tickets. (No offer for the hapless Mets was included.) Deposit $75,000 and you get a weekend in Newport, R.I., with tickets to a polo match. And $125,000 gets two tickets to the U.S. Open tennis tournament finals or semifinals, plus a chance to volley with John Newcombe and Pancho Gonzales, a couple of tennis stars from the past.
When queried, the spokeswoman said nothing had changed. Citibank is "building relationships," she said, just as always. She would not discuss trends in deposit levels or borrowing demand. And a cynic could note that if Citibank really wants more deposits, it could offer higher rates.
Maybe that will come. At a minimum, Citibank's offer is evidence that it wants more deposits and will spend money -- U.S. Open tickets are not free -- to get them. Perhaps, as Chuck Clough, Merrill Lynch's chief equity strategist, suggests, it will just buy more Treasury securities. But maybe it senses that it can profit by lending more.
In any case, it is a straw in the wind that does not point to lower short-term interest rates. Financial stocks lost their status as market leaders a couple of months back, even as they were reporting huge profits. Perhaps that, too, was a warning that rates have bottomed for this cycle.

HEADLINE: Advertising's Marathon Auditions

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

DATELINE: TEANECK, N.J.

 BODY:
Enter a woman in a white bathrobe. Smiling at the men and women watching her, she turns so that her back is to them, then drops the robe to the floor. She wears nothing but body paint -- a living representation of a bottle of vodka.
Performance art in SoHo? A rehearsal for an avant-garde drama Off Off Broadway? 
 In fact, this is no artistic endeavor. Rather, it is part of an annual spectacle that reveals a lot about the American advertising business amid one of the worst recessions in media history.
Every spring for five years, Carillon Importers Ltd., which has surfed to success on an ocean of an imported Swedish vodka called Absolut, has invited representatives from the nation's magazines and newspapers to its Teaneck headquarters just west of Manhattan. As if in a Madison Avenue version of "A Chorus Line," the publications' advertising sales executives -- and, occasionally, their top editors -- audition for executives of Carillon and TBWA Advertising, its agency.
Like the eager dancers singing "God, I Hope I Get It," they are seeking to sell themselves in an extremely competitive business. In this case, it's to win part of the $25 million to $30 million spent each year on the witty, stylish advertising that has made Absolut's one of the best-known, most effective brand campaigns ever. In what is now a big trend in publishing, the publications hope to improve their chances by creating ads and promotions customized for the advertiser.
In they come for these "Media Meetings," 7 to 15 publications a day, 2 to 4 days a week, from April through June, in what has been nicknamed the Media Marathon. All told, some 200 (including The New York Times Magazine) pass through. Each publication gets 30 minutes to sell its ad ideas to the executives from TBWA, Absolut's agency since the campaign's inception 13 years ago, and to Michel Roux, Carillon's president and chief executive. Mr. Roux combines the hardnosed directness of Zach, the director-taskmaster in "A Chorus Line," with a Gallic charm and playfulness.
For the first time, Carillon and TBWA allowed a reporter to attend a session of the Media Marathon. What most intrigued this outsider was the lengths to which publications will go to attract Absolut's ad dollars. The painted woman, part of a presentation by Vanity Fair magazine on a recent morning, had shock appeal. But perhaps more striking was the sight of smart, confident and aggressive people from prestigious magazines genuflecting before the mercurial godfather of liquor advertising. They flattered their host, some to the point of being obsequious. They cheered suggestions they didn't like. They spent heavily on mockups and on gifts meant to curry favor. In some cases, they even hinted at shaping their editorial content to satisfy the advertiser.
Was there really once a time when advertisers had to beg to make it into some publications? That seems a distant memory now.
 
Audition One
 On this day, the first auditioners -- four women representing Vanity Fair, the trendy Conde Nast monthly -- enter the room at 8:40 A.M. Taking the lead role is Kathy Neisloss Leventhal, wearing a blue scarf decorated with Absolut bottles. As her colleagues titter, she describes herself as "the brand-new publisher of Vanity Fair." Just three days earlier she had replaced Ronald Galotti.
As Jolie Schaffzin, an account manager, begins discussing Vanity Fair's circulation strength, she is interrupted by Claude P. Fromm, TBWA's executive vice president and media director. The price of an annual subscription -- initially $12, now $15 -- is "less than the cost of a bottle of Absolut," he complains. "You're asking the advertiser to pick up the freight."
Ms. Schaffzin, trying to resume her pitch, is interrupted by Mr. Roux, who asks about 1994 ad rates, which have not been set.
"So you think there's some way we could get a rate guarantee?" he asks, referring to a guarantee of 1993 rates in 1994. It would be the first in a series of inquiries from him throughout the morning, cajoling the magazines' representatives for concessions.
Ms. Leventhal dampens his speculation, saying, "I wish that were the case."
Annie Williams, the Vanity Fair advertising manager, then presents the magazine's three proposals, all of which are executed in mock-up form and pasted into copies of the June issue. The first is "Absolut Vanity," a sheet of silver Mylar in which the reader sees his or her reflection.
"We've done that," Mr. Roux says.
"This is a different execution," Ms. Williams replies.
"We did it in Spy magazine," says Richard Lewis, a senior vice president and management supervisor at TBWA.
Ms. Williams then unveils "Absolut Ornament," a silver-colored Christmas-tree ornament in the shape of the Absolut bottle, to be bound into copies of the magazine.
"I'm going to collect this one," Mr. Roux says.
Ms. Leventhal describes a promotional event tied to "Absolut Ornament": a tree-trimming party the magazine could sponsor for subscribers. Mr. Roux asks what each ornament costs. Told 97 cents each, he exclaims: "Ninety-seven cents for that? It's a very expensive proposition."
The third proposal requires the woman in the bathrobe. The idea is "Absolut Gair," after Joanne Gair, the artist who painted a body suit on the actress Demi Moore for the cover of Vanity Fair last August.
The woman in the bathrobe, Etta Valeska, then disrobes.
"Now who in this room still needs coffee?" asks Mr. Lewis, ever the comedian.
"Can I see that closer?" Mr. Roux asks.
"She'll have to move backward," Ms. Schaffzin answers. "Her front is not painted." Ms. Valeska stands still.
Ms. Schaffzin, calling "Absolut Gair" a "memorable and stirring execution," explains that it would consist of a six-page insert in which Ms. Gair would paint a model to resemble the four varieties of Absolut.
Mr. Roux has problems. "You know how many letters we'll get from the women's movement? How degrading this is to women?" As Ms. Schaffzin begins discussing the positive response to Ms. Moore's cover, he contrasts the editorial use of a painted nude woman with doing it "in a commercial way."
"I think it's a terrific idea," he adds, "but if I were a woman, I'd see a woman degraded in some way, naked, painted."
"Maybe we should paint a man," Ms. Williams says.
Ms. Valeska dons her robe and leaves.
Ms. Schaffzin segues to suggestions for ads for Grand Marnier, a liqueur also imported by Carillon. TBWA's campaign for the brand features illustrations that play off the word "Grand." Ms. Schaffzin proposes "Grand Anniversary," with a Grand Marnier bottle and an orange together forming a "1" and a "0" to mark the 10th anniversary of the reintroduction of Vanity Fair.
"Are you taking up some of the cost of this?" Mr. Roux asks. "It's your anniversary." He adds, "It's the 50th anniversary of Carillon. Will you do an ad for us?"
The bell of a white kitchen timer goes off. "Your time is up," Mr. Roux says. "Thank you." As the Vanity Fair representatives file out, he reaches into boxes filled with swimsuits bearing the Absolut name, giving one to each woman. It is a ritual that will be repeated at each group's departure.
 
Audition Two
 Ten minutes later, at 9:20, four representatives of Self, a sibling of Vanity Fair's at Conde Nast, enter the room. Three of the four are women; of the 25 magazine staffers auditioning this morning, 17 are female, reflecting the industry's preponderance of female executives; half of the 6 Carillon and TBWA executives are women.
"C'mon, let's sit down," Mr. Roux urges. "It's not a cocktail party. Time is running."
The Self team butters up the Carillon and TBWA executives by mentioning biographical tidbits amid their spiels. (For instance, Lawrence C. Burstein, Self's publisher, addresses Mr. Fromm "as a fellow Stuyvesant High School alumnus.")
"So you have some ideas for us?" Mr. Roux says, interrupting.
Beth Fuchs Brenner, Self's advertising director, proposes a promotion for Grand Marnier that would involve "creating an entire meal around the product." Mr. Roux is interested, but only if the recipes dovetail with Carillon's efforts "to give it a more youthful appeal" rather than the more formal image the liqueur now has among drinkers.
Ms. Brenner also proposes "Absolut Expression," a contest inviting Self readers to "tell us your thoughts about romance"; "Absolut Awareness," which would feature a red ribbon, for AIDS awareness, draped around the bottle, and "Absolut Protection," with a condom stretched over the neck of the bottle, inspired by a new book written by Alexandra Penney, Self's editor in chief, called "How to Make Love to a Man (Safely)."
Ms. Brenner and Mr. Burstein then distribute signed copies of the book and samples of "Absolut condom holders," which resemble small change purses. Ms. Brenner jokes that Mr. Roux has taken four of them.
While Absolut has not advertised in the magazine, Mr. Roux says after the group leaves, "We could be in Self soon."
 
Audition Three
 At 9:55 A.M., four women from Metropolitan Home, recently acquired by Hachette Filipacchi, enter, bearing a big basket of strawberries, baked goods and other treats.
Donna Warner, Met Home's editor in chief, describes editorial changes she is making. "It's a positive magazine," she says. "Everything in here is positive. We don't go around panning things."
Deborah O'Brien, account manager, describes "Absolut Color," an ad centering on painting rooms in the colors of the varieties of Absolut -- original, Citron, Peppar and Kurant. Anne Triece, ad director, says this would cost Carillon $309,000.
Mr. Roux breaks in. "Do you ever do anything with dinnerware, glassware, silverware?" he asks, adding that tablecloths and napkins with Absolut designs "are in the works." Ms. Warner says yes. She comes up with "Absolut Dinner" and "the courses of Absolut, the drinks of Absolut . . . ."
"Can you come back with that?" asks Mr. Roux, who often proposes ads for the series. Some of his suggestions turn out better than the magazines' or TBWA's; it was his idea to ask artists to create their versions of the Absolut bottle, which has resulted in scores of distinctive ads like "Absolut Warhol."
When Ms. Triece asks, "Do you have any concerns about Metropolitan Home?," Mr. Roux shoots back, "You should have the concerns, not us." But he quickly adds, "It was a good meeting."
 
Audition Four
 Two men and a woman file in from American Express's Food & Wine.
Lynette Latiolais, Food & Wine's senior account supervisor, exudes a presence that has been absent from the sessions so far. It is as if at a "Chorus Line" audition, Gwen Verdon has tried out.
"There's nothing more absolute than the need to protect our Earth and her natural resources," she says. "So we present, for your consideration, 'Absolut Earth.' " As she holds up a board, she says that Food & Wine will create an advertorial feature -- an ad produced to resemble editorial matter -- on the subject of conservation; it will take up a third of a page adjacent to the full-page ad.
"You're guaranteed the impact of a spread," she adds, referring to a two-page ad, "for the cost of a page." She also proposes an ad that "takes a little liberty with the usual order of your tag lines: 'The World is Absolut.' " Then she suggests an ad for Grand Marnier that would involve "a dessert created in Food & Wine's kitchens with Grand Marnier" called "Grand Finale."
Mr. Roux approves.
"I have the most crazy idea," Mr. Roux says later. "I'll write this one down," replies Doug Fierro, the magazine's vice president and publisher, who is wearing a tie with an Absolut design. It is what Mr. Roux told the Self group about contemporization: "Grand Marnier souffle, crepes suzette, duck a l'orange -- all this is out."
"Grand Marnier and baked potatoes," he proposes. "Maybe it tastes good."
Ms. Latiolais catches on instantly. "You're looking for less traditional uses," she says. "We have a column, 'Dinner for a Busy Weeknight.' We might fit something into that like Grand Marnier-flavored butter; flavored butters are all the rage."
Mr. Roux then says slyly, "We'd like to run it in your editorial."
"I bet you would," Mr. Fierro retorts, adding, "I'd like to, too, but our editor in chief would have a problem with that."
The audition ends on a high note, as the Carillon and TBWA executives express their pleasure with the Grand Marnier proposals. But as for the Absolut ads with environmental themes, "I don't get it," Mr. Lewis says after the Food & Wine contingent leaves.
 
Audition Five
 At 10:55 A.M., two women enter the room representing Victoria, a Hearst Magazines title that celebrates all things Victorian. Mr. Roux welcomes them by enthusing, "Victoria's Secret!"
Katherine W. (Kitty) Mountain, the magazine's vice president and publisher, replies, "We have some secrets."
Jenny Fontes, Victoria's liquor account manager, hands out elaborately prepared booklets with the magazine's proposals for promotional programs for Grand Marnier.
Mr. Roux praises the proposals, including a "Grand Victoria" reader recipe contest, as "very good." Eagerly, he shares another idea. Referring to paintings of the four seasons brought into the room earlier, he says, "I think this would fit into your magazine."
"These are really interesting," Ms. Mountain quickly replies, then scrutinizes the paintings. Mr. Fromm asks whether Victoria would pick up the production costs involved in a four-page, four-season ad.
Mr. Roux has another Victoria-appropriate idea. "Maybe there's something you can do with a sachet of potpourri glued to the bottle," he says. "See what I mean?"
Ms. Fontes muses. "It could be messy."
Mr. Roux keeps going: "The bottle would be there, made out of flowers -- wisteria, violets, purple flowers. The background would be white and, in the middle, a little sachet, colored the same as the bottle, and it would be a sachet of potpourri."
"I am not charging you," he adds.
Mr. Lewis interjects: "Today."
Ms. Fontes scribbles notes. Ms. Mountain promises to get back to Mr. Roux.
Ms. Fontes removes blue Tiffany boxes from a Victoria shopping bag and distributes them to the Carillon and TBWA executives. When Mr. Roux gives her an Absolut swimsuit, she kisses him.
 
Audition Six
 The youngest contingent -- two women and two men from Conde Nast's Bride's & Your New Home -- enters the room at 11:25 A.M. (By this time, things are running about 25 minutes behind schedule.)
The group offers themed proposals that are probably the most on-target of the morning. Lorraine Levinson, the magazine's marketing and promotion director, introduces an ad mock-up called "Absolut Ceremony," a clever contraption with a cardboard couple at the top of the page; pull a tab, and the couple heads down the aisle to the strains of the wedding march, played by a microchip. The proposal was embraced warmly.
Kevin Jones, the magazine's creative coordinator, then presents "Absolut Love," combining an ad, for which artists would "create different messages pertaining to love, to tie in to Valentine's Day," and a promotion, an "Absolut Love Party."
Mr. Roux is impressed. "Good, nice idea, great."
Ms. Levinson and Steven L. DeLuca, an account manager at Bride's, then present "Absolut Honeymoon," also combining an ad, in which the bottle would be drawn in the sand on a beach resort, and a promotion, a contest in which readers of Bride's would compete to win a free honeymoon trip. That is followed by "Absolut Engagement," combining an ad, a bottle in which a ring floats, and a promotion, a sweepstakes to win a diamond engagement ring.
"You should have a diamond in the shape of the bottle," Mr. Roux advises.
After seeing a mock-up that gathered "Absolut Engagement," "Absolut Wedding" and "Absolut Honeymoon" into a single ad insert, he proposes another: " 'Absolut Divorce.' " (Giggles.)
 
Audition Seven
 Minutes before noon, George Wayne, founder, editor and publisher of a magazine called R.O.M.E. -- "It really doesn't mean anything," he confides -- strides into the room for what would prove the morning's most unconventional session.
"I just came to see the pope," he announces, "to genuflect and to pay homage and beg and plead for my endowment. Michel, you know what I mean."
Mr. Wayne, whom W magazine has called "downtown's deepest disher" of gossip, says that the frequency of his unusual magazine, which is printed on a copier machine on copier paper, is "every five months" and/or as soon as he pays his bills for the previous issue. He adds that he cannot publish more often "because you're so mean."
"You know I run the best of Absolut advertising, the classics like the Keith Harings," he adds, referring to his practice of copying ads from the pages of other magazines and using them on his pages.
Mr. Roux finally interrupts. "O.K., what do you want, George?"
"I need $15,000. I'm tired of the crumbs off the table."
Mr. Fromm teases him that Mr. Roux is "very generous today."
"I've always respected the pope," Mr. Wayne says, then drops his figure to $10,000.
Mr. Fromm, and later Mr. Roux, counter with $5,000.
Mr. Wayne's response: "Six?"
"George, don't push your luck here," Mr. Roux says.
As Mr. Wayne leaves, he calls out, "Michel, can you take me to dinner next week?"
 
Audition Eight
 At 12:10 P.M. the most stylish group arrives, three representatives of South Beach, a magazine covering Miami Beach.
Mr. Roux asks whether South Beach would keep its ad rates at current levels. The publisher, Paul Arthaud, replies, "For you."
Mr. Roux proposes a two-year contract. Mr. Arthaud says, "I would appreciate it, since I am giving you all my back covers, if we can at least double the business." He then proposes Carillon's participation in a jeanswear show for apparel buyers in Miami Beach. He suggests that Carillon help underwrite a benefit for Camillus House, an organization for the homeless.
He and Mr. Roux go back and forth on details of a promotional program Mr. Arthaud calls "Absolut Denim," but fail to reach agreement. Mr. Fromm says that the $20,000 to $30,000 donation being sought by Mr. Arthaud would probably be a better idea for jeans manufacturers than for Carillon.
Mr. Arthaud then declares, "That's it. Do we want to contract this for two years?" Mr. Fromm says that it would begin in the fall, to coincide with Carillon's 1994 fiscal year.
Mr. Roux says, "Good luck with your magazine. It's a good book."
At 12:20 P.M., the South Beachers file out, swimsuits in hand, and another of Carillon's marathon auditions has ended. Who will get picked? Check your magazines this fall.

 
 
A HALL-OF-FAME ADVERTISER
 The annual advertising budget for Absolut is usually the largest of any liquor brand sold in America. More than that, though, an Absolut ad can lend a publication a certain cachet, particularly if it is struggling to establish itself.
Michel Roux, president and chief executive of Carillon, which brings Absolut to America, has long sought out new publications for Absolut ads, on the philosophy that a product appearing in a hip magazine or newspaper can be perceived as hip, too.
That is just one of the shrewd strategies that have helped Absolut sales explode, from 54,000 cases in 1979 to 2.9 million last year. The brand is now America's best-selling imported vodka, with almost three times the volume of Russia's Stolichnaya. The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association has honored Absolut by making it one of the first three brands named to its Marketing Hall of Fame. The other? A couple of brands called Coca-Cola and Nike.
Still, Absolut's momentum has slowed. As recently as 1988, case sales were soaring at 33.5 percent annually. But from 1991 to 1992 they rose only 3.6 percent.
In the course of a year, 24 to 36 specially customized Absolut ads will appear. Among recent examples are "Absolut Americana," a portfolio of works by American contemporary folk artists, in Country Home magazine, and "Absolut Cartoon," a draw-your-own-cartoon contest, in The New Yorker.
Those customized ads are mixed with all-purpose ads, which run in a lengthy list of magazines and newspapers. They are selected from a pool that includes the first ad in the series, now 13 years old -- "Absolut Perfection," the bottle with a halo above it.

 
 
PUBLICATIONS, START YOUR ENGINES
 Just as car buffs customize their automobiles in hopes of standing out from the crowd, so, too, do publications, intent on attracting attention amid a traffic jam of sales pitches, offer to customize ad programs for advertisers.
"What we're searching for right now is to tailor ads," says Michel Roux, president and chief executive of Carillon Importers Ltd. "An ad should be blended with the editorial, to make the reader comfortable with the product you're selling."
That philosophy troubles people who worry about the implications of ads that too closely resemble the editorial content of the publication in which they appear. The line between the editorial content of a publication and its advertising is supposed to be drawn as sharply as any line surrounding its table of contents or masthead. But in recent years, a weak economy has made the pursuit of ad dollars more frenetic, smudging that line.
For instance, readers of the May issue of Harper's Magazine saw the monthly's familiar "Harper's Index" feature on page 9 followed on page 11 by "Absolut Index" -- an ad using the same type face and format of the magazine's index to produce an image in the shape of the Absolut bottle.
Media companies are also appealing to advertisers with other customization strategies. One is to assemble "cross-media" packages that combine ad messages in the various outlets owned by a single company. Time Warner Inc., for instance, has signed Sega of America as the title sponsor of a "Sports Illustrated Sports Fest," at which the weekly magazine will present a photo exhibition. The summer-long festival will be held at seven of the company's Six Flags and Great Adventure amusement parks.
A second is to create and produce a magazine sponsored entirely by one advertiser. For General Motors this fall, Hachette Filipacchi will publish a customized magazine called Know-How, carrying ads from G.M. Other marketers with their own magazines include Chanel, Sony, the Target discount-store chain and A.&P. supermarkets.
A third is to put together so-called integrated marketing efforts, which combine traditional advertising venues like print ads or television commercials with sweepstakes, displays in stores and coupons. Land O'Lakes and Country Living, a Hearst Magazines title, will join for a program called "Imagine a Taste That Takes You to the Country." It includes a seven-page advertorial section in the magazine's July issue, a recipe contest and a coupon insert in newspapers.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1275 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
It Wasn't as Easy as 1-2-3, but Lotus Has a Winner

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
LIKE Wayne Gretzky, Lotus 1-2-3 for Windows, Release 4, is emerging as a leading candidate for the Comeback of the Year award. The impressive new version of the spreadsheet will reach stores later this month after having been previewed at the recent Spring/Comdex computer show in Atlanta.
Much easier to use than earlier versions of Lotus 1-2-3, this new version -- why don't we call it 1-2-3-4 -- adds features and powers that will be especially interesting for executives who frequently collaborate on financial plans with other workers. The Lotus Development Corporation has long espoused the gospel of work-group computing, but 1-2-3-4 is the first clear example of how the concept can be applied to basic business applications. 
 Lotus 1-2-3 is believed to be the single most popular personal computer business application in the world, with millions of customers. But Lotus fumbled the transition to Windows, arriving late and with an inferior product, and many users of the DOS version of 1-2-3 switched to the Microsoft Corporation's Excel or Borland International's Quattro Pro for Windows.
Now Lotus finally has a Windows spreadsheet that holds its own with Excel and Quattro Pro, and even surpasses them in some areas. Of course the competition is not standing still; at Comdex, Borland showed off a very impressive prototype of its next release of Quattro Pro for Windows, and Microsoft told of plans to bring out a new Excel this fall.
"It's going to be a horse race," said Peter Rogers, software industry analyst for the San Francisco investment firm Robertson, Stephens & Company. "One company may come up with something new, but in a couple of weeks the gap closes. The advantages don't last very long."
Lotus, for example, has "borrowed" some ease-of-use features from Excel and some organizing tricks from Quattro Pro. Excel and Quattro Pro are expected to borrow some data analysis tricks from Lotus's other spreadsheet, Improv for Windows.
Improv, originally developed for use on Next Inc. computers, provides users far more power to analyze data than most spreadsheets. While some companies rely on it, Improv is more often employed as a useful supplementary tool. And this poses a tactical problem for Lotus, because its rivals are likely to combine the best of both types of spreadsheets while Lotus remains committed to separate programs.
Lotus's new program "is at least on par with Excel in terms of attention to detail, fit and finish" and features, said William J. Higgs, vice president of software research for Infocorp, a market research company in Santa Clara, Calif. "There are points where one is better, and points where the other is better. Having a better product in some ways, but not in all ways, doesn't automatically make you the dominant player."
Creating successful software "is much more a marketing effort than it was 5 or 10 years ago," Mr. Higgs said, adding, "Certainly Microsoft has had good products, but its success is at least as much due to marketing as to programming."
To meet the market challenge, Lotus is trying some new tricks. While its previous version of 1-2-3 for Windows was Release 1, it decided to skip 2 and 3, and go straight to 4. The reasoning? The company says this puts the spreadsheet more in step with other Lotus products, but the real reason is probably that rival spreadsheets had higher numbers. Lotus has put 1-2-3-4 in a bright yellow box (a color that will be standard for all Lotus products from now on). Yellow is the most eye-catching retail color, marketers note, and in the boring world of computer software packaging, Lotus will now stand out.
But such marketing details alone are not going to win the spreadsheet wars, and ultimately 1-2-3-4's new features will be the test of its appeal.
The most important advance is something that Lotus calls version manager, which allows several different people in a group of workers to create their own versions of the same spreadsheet, without overwriting someone else's changes.
For example, in sales, "Mr. Owl" may construct a spreadsheet showing past, current and projected sales of a company's products, while "Ms. Bear," in the executive office, may feel the recession will re-emerge, making even Mr. Owl's dreary forecast far too optimistic. "Mr. Bull" in marketing, on the other hand, may feel that sales will soar to record levels. In the old days, three different interpretations required three different spreadsheets.
But with 1-2-3-4, a single spreadsheet can provide multiple scenarios, each annotated with the name of the person who created it and the time and date it was most recently done. The version manager maintains a master copy of the spreadsheet and displays, in menu form, all the different scenarios and ranges associated with the file. The viewer can then choose a scenario or review them all.
A separate comment box on the version manager window allows workers to add remarks on why they made changes or created scenarios. Ms. Bear might wonder why Mr. Bull was so optimistic. In version manager she will find his explanation: "I think sales will be spectacular in the third quarter because the Sun is ascending in Taurus."
On a local area network with a shared file server, several workers can view the same 1-2-3 spreadsheet, including the different scenarios, at the same time. Only one worker can modify the file at a given time, however.
The true power of 1-2-3-4's new networking features become apparent when the spreadsheet is shared within an environment created by Lotus's Notes program. Notes is Lotus's ambitious network software that connects workers within an organization and allows them to share and organize information in ways not possible using conventional network software.
When a 1-2-3 for Windows spreadsheet is shared under Notes, several users can make changes to the same spreadsheet simultaneously without overwriting the others. Notes notifies each user, through a sound cue and screen message, when someone else modifies the spreadsheet. The spreadsheet will also flag the worksheet if there are any modifications that the worker has not read.
Lotus is expected to add similar abilities to its other applications, including its Ami Pro word processor. Writers and editors would then be able to work on a document concurrently.
Networking aside, 1-2-3-4's other features are impressive. Many complex functions have been reduced to a mouse click or two, and new context-sensitive menus offer only those choices that make sense for what the user is doing at the time. Drag-and-drop editing now makes redesigning worksheets far easier, and Lotus has created better help and tutorial screens. (For experienced 1-2-3 users, a new pull-down menu provides quick access to as many as 250 of those pesky "@" commands, mostly mathematical formulas that process data in different ways, from addition to far more complicated tasks.)
Another improvement is something Lotus calls in-cell editing, which lets the user enter information and edit it directly in the worksheet, without having to move the cursor to a command line at the top of the sheet.
And charts can be created anywhere in the spreadsheet simply by highlighting a range of numbers and text; 1-2-3-4 will build the chart automatically, including legends. The charts can then be edited and restructured as desired, while any changes in the underlying data are automatically reflected in the chart.
Lotus 1-2-3 for Windows Release 4 has a suggested list price of $495, but is available to anyone with an earlier Lotus spreadsheet -- or competing spreadsheets -- for $129.

LENGTH: 879 words

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Looking Ahead, Long and Hard

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Some wrenching changes are ahead for the mutual fund industry, Prof. Michael E. Porter of the Harvard Business School warned in the keynote address to more than 1,000 mutual fund executives gathered in Washington at the end of May for their annual meeting.
Some of these changes will come from the impending shakeout in an industry that, he said, has peaked -- or will soon do so. Other changes will come as banks, with their own new offerings, continue to grab market share from mutual fund companies. And others might come from the panicked reaction of first-time investors to a market correction or interest rate spike. 
 Are fund companies prepared for the coming changes? The questions put to Professor Porter from a tightly packed audience showed about two-thirds of the respondents had an appreciation of the situation. "They know that their companies have to be more cost-effective and add real value to their customers," the professor said, "and they're struggling with how to accomplish that, given that many companies have long histories in a gentlemanly, stable kind of industry."
The problem he sees is a kind of homogeneity that makes it difficult for customers to distinguish among companies. Companies unsure of their strategies strive to be all things to all customers. The result: customer confusion.
Compounding the confusion is a byzantine pricing structure that seems to worsen with time. First, there were "A" shares, which carry a front-end sales load. Then came "B" shares, with contingent deferred sales charges (or back-end loads), usually combined with annual 12b-1 fees taken from fund assets to pay marketing expenses. Then there are "C" shares, often specially priced for special groups.
Now, investors must grapple with "D" shares, also called "level loads." Sponsors pitch them as having no sales charges, often not mentioning that the share price includesunusually high annual expense charges.
Paine Webber, which pioneered D shares last July, says that they now account for two-thirds of its fund sales, mainly bond funds. "Our brokers like the new pricing," said Thomas Eggers, senior vice president of Paine Webber and a panelist in the meeting's discussion of distribution and pricing issues. "They combat the 'no-load' mentality."
Confusing? You bet. Even fund executives are beginning to rebel. The pricing innovations are "just a repackaging of what already exists, and clients end up in the same place," said Gregory E. Johnson, vice president of Franklin Resources, in San Mateo, Calif. Moreover, replacing a front-end sales fee with a less obvious one "removes the value of the sales professionals' fee from the equation" and conditions investors to expect advice for free, he said.
Banks, which are moving into the fund business sufficiently to have commanded their own panel discussion at the conference, are grappling with pricing issues, too.
Nationsbank, for instance, opted for the alphabet soup of fund shares, sold by full-service brokers. But Fleet Bank decided to go with low-cost, no-load shares, an unusual strategy for banks so far. Fleet's approach is based on a simple premise, said Thomas Howe, managing director of Fleet Investment Services: "In the 90's, prices won't be camouflaged by high returns."
Indeed, if any one theme darkened the atmosphere of the fund conference, it was the possibility of a market break -- or, more likely, a rise in interest rates -- that might spook first-time fund investors.
"It is essential that we stop and think about how best to educate these investors about the risks, as well as the rewards, of investing in long-term funds, particularly the impact of interest rate changes on bond funds," said Matthew P. Fink, president of the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund trade group that sponsored the conference.
Bond prices have risen as interest rates have tumbled, but if rates spike, prices will fall; and the longer a bond's term, or the smaller its coupon, the farther the fall.
This lesson, and other investment basics, are becoming critical to more and more people as funds command a growing share of individual investors' capital. As companies continue to switch to 401(k)-type retirement plans, employees must make investment decisions -- and bear the concomitant risk.
Even fund companies concede that things are out of hand. There is an "enormous amount of confusion with 3,800 funds out there," said Robert A. Leo, executive vice president, mutual funds, for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., in a panel discussion. Added Michael J. Downey, chairman of Prudential Mutual Fund Management, "The industry has been product-driven. I don't know if we've paid enough attention to our customers' needs."
To Professor Porter, the prescription is clear. In the long run, the fund industry will be better off providing investors with clear information. And while following the latest trend is natural to get business in a growing industry, "Product proliferation and imitative strategies will have to decline," he said.
In the end, change "will be a very good thing for individual investors," Professor Porter concluded. They will benefit "as expenses fall, companies get more efficient and the poorer performers are squeezed out."

HEADLINE: Average Americans, Given the Facts, Understand Tax Increases

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The American people want reductions in spending before any increase in taxes," say Republicans and conservative Democrats in Congress. Doubtless, most Americans, asked "Do you want your taxes raised?", will answer no. But ask: "Do you want cuts in Social Security, Medicare and other entitlements? To have no money for police, for fixing roads, education and research? To have the United States sink to mediocrity, with the good life for only the wealthy?" The answer would also be no.
By all indications, it isn't possible to pay no more in taxes, or to reduce nonmilitary public expenditure, and still have a country with first-rate social institutions. The last 12 years of conservative claims that these things can coexist by cutting the fat out of our Government have been refuted by a quadrupling of the national debt in that period. After 12 years of trying, conservative fat cutters found little waste, but put a lot of worthwhile activities in a state of chronic malnourishment, which will cost us a lot more than what we save by starving our institutions. The cost of the savings and loan bailout is the most spectacular result. 
 What Americans really want is a first-rate country -- with cities as safe and pleasant as those in other advanced countries. With schools graduating students who score at least as high on standardized tests as their foreign counterparts, so they can build products the world will prefer to foreign-built ones. With medical care guaranteed and accessible to all. These things cost money.
The other advanced countries have come to terms with this. The United States pays about 31 percent of its gross national product in taxes, compared with 33 percent in Japan, 38 percent in Germany and 56 percent in Sweden -- despite far higher military expenditure in the United States.
For the last 12 years, Americans have pursued the fantasy, led much of that time by a master of fantasy, that we can pay Hyundai prices and still get a Mercedes. It isn't leadership to sustain this delusion.
The average American doesn't know how much it costs to provide a dignified retirement for the elderly, or to keep our research cutting edge. Maybe average Americans should, but they've got their own jobs and families to tend to. They're relying on Congress to handle that and to make sure we buy what is necessary to keep us on top.
 
HARRY E. MYNICK
Princeton, N.J., May 26, 1993

LENGTH: 204 words

HEADLINE: No Need to Celebrate A 'Record High' Dow

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Stocks and Bonds Surge; Dow Hits 3,500" (Business Day, May 20) reports a "record high." I suspect that many readers not familiar with finance or economics would, quite sensibly, take this to mean that the dollar value of the Dow on May 19 had greater buying power than at any previous closing. Such readers would be justified in feeling confusion when record highs coincide with decreasing buying power (as they often do, because inflation increases the price of both stocks and groceries).
In other words, a Dow of 3,000 when an automobile costs $12,000 is not in any meaningful sense as high as a Dow of 1,000 when an automobile costs $3,000. 
 The "record high" that is not corrected for inflation is an incoherent measure of some unstated combination of market performance and inflation, which can imply that times are good when times are bad.
It is understandable that stockbrokers would find this statistical sleight of hand agreeable. Optimism, even false optimism, leads people to buy stock, and stockbrokers get their commissions whatever happens to the stock.
 
STEVEN GOLDBERG
New York, May 25, 1993
 
The writer is chairman of the sociology department, City College, CUNY.

LENGTH: 1147 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Using Taxation In a Good Cause Often Backfires

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
RESIDENT CLINTON has given his proposed energy tax a healthy environmental twist: he wants to tax some "dirty" fuels such as oil to the hilt, but he would exempt "green" sources of energy, like solar and wind power and the burning of garbage to generate electricty, from any tax at all. The Government gets $72 billion over five years; pollution gets pummeled. Who could resist?
Try environmentalists. Every year, paper recyclers pulp and press nearly 40 million tons of would-be trash into cardboard, fiberboard, auto dashboards, egg cartons and so on. The profit margin is, well, paper thin. A tax break for garbage burning, the recyclers fear, could eliminate it. 
 "Our concern is that you don't want to create an incentive to burn paper instead of recycling it," said Jim Davidson, a lobbyist for the Paper Recycling Coalition, a trade group. "The wise thing to do is not to plunge into a new tax system that would distort the market."
Wise, maybe. But it is so hard for a President -- especially a new, activist President with an agenda thicker than the Encyclopedia Britannica -- to resist temptations to use the tax code to promote good and punish evil. Mr. Clinton succumbs in his new budget, which the Senate Finance Committee considers this week. He reopens the tax laws to propose changes -- an energy tax, a bigger break on capital gains and enterprise zones -- that are social and economic policy as much as revenue raisers.
There is a long and distinguished history to this. By Congress's reckoning, the deductions, exemptions, loopholes and credits built into the current tax code will cost the Treasury $401.8 billion this year, and would cost $526.9 billion by 1997 if they remain in force then. Many of these breaks -- for charitable donations, low-income housing, corporate research, the working poor -- are aimed at inarguably good causes and pressing social needs.
But for a President who has staked much of his remaining political credibility on the success of his economic program, this is no small risk. All too often, the history of tax incentives (and disincentives) is that they come to town full of ideals, fall in with a national political crowd that whispers that a minor change or two won't harm anything and wind up beyond redemption.
Mr. Clinton's package of spending cuts and new taxes has barely passed the House, and some of his proposals already have been recast. Chief among them is the energy tax. Conceived last winter not just as a money raiser, but as a prod toward energy efficiency and clean air, it was something less than that even before it arrived on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Clinton's concept became muddied by a desire to balance regional interests. So one dirty fuel, oil, faces a stiff surtax, but an even dirtier one, coal, does not.
 
Quid Pro Quod
 Similarly, the bill grants economically insignificant fuels like solar energy a total exemption from the tax. But it taxes hydroelectric power, a pollution-free energy source, to insure that the heavily dammed Northwest carries its share of the freight.
Last month, the House took up where Mr. Clinton left off, giving aluminum smelters a tax break on electricity and farmers a tax break on diesel, among other changes. Next comes the Senate, where Rocky Mountain politicians already are pushing for an even greater break for their coal, as opposed to coal from the Appalachians, and Gulf senators are taking aim at the burden shouldered by oil. Many expect the energy tax to emerge in Swiss cheese form, pulling in $40 billion or so rather than the hoped-for $72 billion, and shorn of most incentives for conservation.
"The problem the Clinton Administration is having now is that its principles got lost early on in the scramble for revenue and political appeasement," said a former Treasury Department tax official, requesting anonymity because he remains in public life, "and once that happens, it becomes very difficult to say no to someone else who wants a piece of the pie."
History is only repeating itself. And that, some experts would argue, is the point: the Government can rarely fashion a tax incentive so airtight that politicians cannot divert it to the unintended benefit of their constituents, or that the wily constituents themselves do not eventually subvert.
"My preferences are toward conventional economics," said Jane G. Gravelle, a senior tax specialist at the Library of Congress. "Unless you can identify some really good reason to involve yourself in the allocation of resources, all of economic theory tells us that leaving it to the market is the best thing to do."
If the tax code is such a risky instrument of policy-making, why do politicians dote on it so? One obvious explanation is that tax breaks are, at heart, just a way of spending money without routing it through the Treasury Department. Whereas no one likes the Government to spend more, everyone likes a tax deduction or credit, and so the tax code gives politicians a way to finance the agendas without the pain of finding the money.
The problem is that the politicians often end up financing other people's agendas as well, intentionally or otherwise.
History offers some telling lessons. Off and on since the Kennedy era, administrations have sought to lure businesses into pumping up the economy by giving them a credit on their taxes -- say, 10 or 15 percent of everything they invest in expansion or remodeling. The goal is noble: the modernization of factories makes industry more efficient and competitive, employs workers, pumps money into the economy and makes the country strong.
 
A Yawn and a Cut
 Targeting even the best tax break is an inexact art. The Individual Retirement Account, which originally allowed anyone to deduct up to $2,000 of his retirement nest egg from his income each year, was supposed to spur savings. But it also prompted millions of Americans to borrow money or shift cash from their savings accounts into IRA's, creating no new savings but costing the Government plenty in lost tax revenues.
Mr. Clinton tried proposing his own investment tax credit this year, directing his brightest economic minds to seal the loopholes and eliminate the waste that had plagued tax breaks in the past. One immediate result was that companies reacted with a yawn, and the House cut the provision from the budget.
The President's budget does contain some tax breaks that even the surliest economists applaud. Most experts believe that the earned-income credit, which rewards the working poor with a tax cut, is a social and fiscal success, and the White House has substantially expanded it. The House has tightened the rules for claiming charitable-donation deductions, another clause many economists say is demonstrably worth the expense. Together, they amount to one-twentieth of the $401 billion in tax breaks in the 1993 budget.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: Conversations/Herbert Jose de Souza;
A Hard Look at Brazil's Surfeits: Food, Hunger and Inequality

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
BOOSTERS of Brazil like to point out that during the 1980's this enormous nation became the world's third largest food exporter, outranked only by the United States and France.
Herbert Jose de Souza likes to point out that during the 1980's, the legions of Brazilians who live with hunger expanded from 25 million people to 35 million people. 
 With his sad eyes, bulbous nose, rubbery mouth and tufts of gray hair on a balding dome, this frail, diminutive 57-year-old sociologist has a bit of the air of a retired circus clown. But his message is serious and his appeal persistent; and with these, he has become the conscience of Latin America's largest nation.
"Looking at the human and natural resources of Brazil, I have never found any scientific reason why we cannot feed our 50 million people," he said in a recent conversation, touching on a subject that economists generally tiptoe around. "The problem is that the Brazilian elites don't see the poor. It's a problem of negation of other people."
Campaigning against hunger in this rich agricultural land, Mr. de Souza has won an unexpected ally in President Itamar Franco. Brazilian presidents have usually taken a laissez-faire attitude toward problems of malnutrition. One military president in the 1970's even remarked: "Brazil is doing fine. It's the people who are doing poorly."
But many Brazilians are losing their patience with trickle-down economics. In fact, according to World Bank figures, the distribution of wealth in Brazil is among the most inequitable in the world. And in a country where the per capita income is now $2,920 a year, the United Nations says the number of Brazilians living on less than $1 a day increased by 40 percent to 35 million during the 1980's. And the portion of the population living on less than $2 a day increased from 34 percent to 41 percent in that decade.
President Franco, borrowing heavily from Mr. de Souza's ideas, has announced what may prove the most important initiative of his Government, the National Food Security Council. With the elfin sociologist standing by, Mr. Franco quoted Josue de Castro, a social critic from half a century ago: "Brazil has a population of insomniacs: those who can't sleep because they are hungry, and those who stay awake out of fear of those who don't have anything to eat."
Skeptics have derided Mr. de Souza and his anti-hunger campaign, saying he does not have a magic wand to create jobs or to redistribute Brazil's wildly skewed income.
 
The Society Responds
 But judging by society's response, Mr. de Souza and his anti-hunger campaign have hit on a deep-seated longing among Brazilians. Telephones never seem to stop ringing at his private study group here, the Brazilian Institute of Economic and Social Analyses. Television stations and newspapers carry frequent interviews with him. Auditoriums quickly fill up when he travels to inaugurate a new "Citizenship Committee Against Misery and for Life."
Mr. de Souza says many citizens shifted their energies to the anti-hunger campaign after popular outrage succeeded last year in forcing the ouster of President Fernando Collor de Mello, who was impeached on corruption charges.
"There is a deep desire among people to get out of their state of resignation, of inaction," he said. "This is a continuation of the ethical wave that started with the impeachment movement."
So far there has been little concrete action. Eight restaurants in Rio have started feeding leftover food to street people. A state-run food company has been forced to explain why 35,000 tons of corn, beans, rice and manioc flour are rotting in warehouses. The federal Government has promised to spare school lunch programs from austerity cuts.
"What has happened that is concrete in the struggle against hunger?" Mr. de Souza asked. "The concrete is this: a beginning of a change in consciences. Brazilian society is beginning to realize that misery is not acceptable."
"We either have to definitively accept that poverty and misery are part of our culture, and, therefore consolidate our social apartheid," he said. "Or we have to review our history, our vision of the world. There is no reason, no argument, no theory that justifies the existence of this misery."
Mr. de Souza, in other words, still holds to the socialist convictions that underlay an essay he wrote in 1956 that was titled "Capitalism and Misery." He argues that in this century, Brazil has moved straight from feudalism to "savage capitalism."
On one hand, Brazil is the world's second largest market for executive jets, after the United States. On the other hand, at least one-quarter of the nation goes to bed every night hungry.
"This is cultural -- there still is the plantation house and slave shanty mentality," he said of the social chasms that divide rich and poor in Brazil.
 
'Highly Inhuman'
 Noting that the nation's largest soybean producer never responded to an invitation to contribute to the anti-hunger campaign, Mr. de Souza said: "The Brazilian elite is highly inhuman, highly insensitive. The elite is not able to elaborate a concept of humanity that includes the poor."
As he talked in a soft, melodic Portuguese, the cries of hawkers from a street food market penetrated his office on the ground floor of a house in a middle-class neighborhood here. Outside, food stalls were piled with pyramids of oranges, pink stacks of boned chicken breasts, and melons sliced open to the sun.
Recognizing that the core of Brazil's malnutrition problem is not food supply, but purchasing power, Mr. de Souza said that jobs are the solution.
"We have to go back to the basics, to common sense," he argued. "The principal goal of an economy should be to generate employment. And an employed person has to be earning a decent salary."
The anti-hunger campaign was inaugurated with optimistic calls for "A New Millennium Without Misery," and the veteran activist bravely maintains that "despair is the disease of the elites."
But Mr. de Souza has special reason to doubt that he himself will ever see the goal achieved. For four and a half years, he has been taking AZT to hold off the ravages of AIDS.
As he talked, a bulky sweater vest and a shirt buttoned to the neck did little to disguise the fact that his weight has dwindled to 105 pounds. And even as he reviewed his hectic travel schedule for the weeks ahead, a note of fatigue entered his voice.
Mr. de Souza and his brother, Henrique, contracted the virus that causes AIDS while undergoing blood transfusions for hemophilia. Five years ago, Henrique de Souza Filho, better known as Henfil, died of AIDS.
"Henfil drew this 13 years ago," Mr. de Souza said, tearing a cartoon out of his monthly agenda book. "It shows how little things have changed."
The doodle showed a worried child listening as his equally worried mother read a report card: "Zero in Vitamin C, Zero in Vitamin D, Zero in Vitamin A."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Brazilian elites don't see the poor," says Herbert Jose de Souza. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)
