HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Serbians Veer Closer to Their Extreme Edge

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
FOR Vojislav Seselj, it was a restrained performance. Barely two days before, this Serbian extremist had the pleasure of watching two detested political rivals being ground into the dust. One was the President of Yugoslavia, Dobrica Cosic, summarily dismissed by parliamentary intrigue that ended in a vote of no confidence. The other was Vuk Draskovic, the wild-eyed opposition leader whose long hair and beard summoned up for many Yugoslavs the image of Jesus Christ, now prostrate in prison with injuries from police beatings and facing charges for having led a protest that turned violent.
So Mr. Seselj (pronounced SHESH-el) was holding a press conference, his heavy frame squeezed behind a table in the headquarters of his Serbian Radical Party. On the walls around him were the icons of the cause -- the Serbian tricolor, portraits of saints, a mystical canvas of a bedraggled Serbian soldier and, at center, a likeness stamped in brass of the World War II Chetnik leader, Draza Mihailovic. Though the crowded room was as cramped as a coffin, he shouted replies in full voice: Serbia was under siege. Her people were being demonized by the media. No, he would never accept a peace plan with Lord Owen's signature. 
 Red-faced and gloating behind his glasses, he had the appearance of someone sitting in the catbird's seat, which is exactly where he is these days. Last week marked a turning point in the bizarre and paranoid world of Serbian politics and in the fortunes of Mr. Seselj -- Serbia's foremost ultra-nationalist and a man commonly called a psychopath by Western diplomats.
With Mr. Cosic a has-been, a voice of relative moderation has disappeared. With Mr. Draskovic out of commission after the demonstrations that followed Mr. Cosic's ouster, and with his party unable even to mount a protest over his beating, the opposition is shattered. Suddenly Mr. Seselj looms as the second most powerful person in the country next to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia.
That does not augur well for an end to the savagery in neighboring Bosnia and Herzegovina, where Serbian fighters aligned with Mr. Seselj renewed attacks last week on Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, and besieged Muslim enclaves. The United Nations Security Council on Friday tried to do something to hold the Serbs in check, by voting to authorize air strikes and send additional troops to protect such enclaves, but the plan is widely viewed as only a stopgap. Moreover, the United States and its allies still disagree over when air power should be used and it will be months before the new troops are actually deployed.
 
Changing Fortunes
 Just weeks ago, the Western powers were able to take some encouragement from Serbian political developments. There was hope that Mr. Milosevic could be prodded down the path of peace with the whip of sanctions. When he did a U-turn and embraced the United Nations-European Community peace plan for Bosnia, Mr. Cosic, 72, the intellectual patriarch of Serbian nationalism, was there alongside him. He, too, traveled to Pale, the self-styled capital of the Bosnian Serb "republic," to try to persuade legislators there that they had no choice but to go along.
Mr. Seselj went there also, however, and unfortunately for his rivals he fought against the peace plan with every weapon at his command. If the West intervened militarily, so be it, he argued. But more cunning was his assertion that the Clinton Administration was just bluffing and that the Bosnian Serbs could reject the peace terms and get away with it. That is precisely what happened, a Western diplomat here observed, and that more than anything else has strengthened the hand of Mr. Seselj. Thus policy-makers in Washington and Europe have been made painfully aware that their decision not to act more forcefully has repercussions not just in Bosnia but in the internal politics of Serbia as well.
President Milosevic has a track record of turning against his allies when expediency calls for it. From this perspective, the ouster of Mr. Cosic, which could not have happened without Mr. Milosevic's blessing, was a sign that he was reading the local political winds. To recoup the prestige he lost at Pale and with outside pressure off, he decided to align himself with Mr. Seselj's Radicals.
The swing to the fringe complicates Western attempts to cajole Mr. Milosevic into cutting off the Bosnian Serb militias. He withdrew his offer to allow international monitors to check on the passage of goods across the border. The Government's rationale is "internal political considerations" -- meaning that the monitors would inflame and strengthen the Radicals.
Signs of Mr. Seselj's rise are not hard to find. During the weeks in which he was critical of Mr. Milosevic, the ultra-nationalist found himself denied access to state-run Serbian television. But now he is back on the screen. And in this land where persecution is a part of the national mythology, even the damage to the economy wrought by sanctions seems to have strengthened Mr. Seselj.
 
Scarred by Prison
 More ominously, he appears to be jockeying for control of the army. In recent weeks he has mounted a bizarre series of attacks on officers, especially the Chief of Staff, Gen. Zivota Panic. He has charged among other things that the General's son obtained a lucrative contract to sell potatoes to the army at an inflated price. A few days ago, the son was apprehended at the border with 12,000 German marks, an event that was seen as the harbinger of the General's downfall. Mr. Seselj predicted that he would be out within days.
Mr. Seselj belongs to a crop of current leaders among the remnants of Yugoslavia who were jailed for nationalist sentiments in the Communist era. He was born in 1956 in eastern Herzegovina, a hotbed of Serbian fervor, and became a political science professor at Sarajevo University. In 1984 he was arrested on a charge of trying to overthrow the Yugoslav state and sentenced to eight years in prison. The sentence was reduced and he ended up serving two years, but six months of it was in solitary confinement, and during that time he is believed to have been beaten and tortured. Acquaintances say the experience scarred him deeply.
Remarkably, Mr. Seselj and Mr. Draskovic were once close; in fact, Mr. Draskovic is the godfather of Mr. Seselj's son. Together they founded the Serbian Renewal Movement, still Mr. Draskovic's party. But in 1990 Mr. Seselj broke away and Mr. Draskovic began his soulful transformation to dissident and pacifist.
It is difficult to overestimate Mr. Seselj's passion. He shouts insults in Parliament, where his party is now the second-largest. He once proposed breaking into Tito's tomb to send the Communist leader's corpse to Croatia, since he was half Croat.
Some local journalists and pundits here believe that it is only a matter of time until the President and the Radical leader face each other down in a struggle for primacy. If the arena is "greater Serbia," including Serbian areas of Bosnia and perhaps even Croatia, then the advantage would swing to Mr. Seselj, whose appeal is stronger outside Serbia proper. But the consensus is that Mr. Milosevic is too crafty to allow that to happen. In the meantime, the alliance with the hard-liner seems to suit him.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICAN GAINS TEXAS SENATE SEAT

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 5

 BODY:
Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Texas State Treasurer and a Republican, was overwhelmingly elected to the United States Senate today after campaign in which she relentlessly focused on opposition to tax increases proposed by President Clinton.
Mrs. Hutchison, a 49-year-old former state representative, easily defeated Bob Krueger, the Democrat who was appointed to the seat earlier this year by Gov. Ann W. Richards after Lloyd Bentsen resigned to become Treasury Secretary. 
 With 99 percent of the state's 6,496 precincts reporting, Mrs. Hutchison led Mr. Krueger by more than 2 to 1, with 1,174,966 votes, or 67 percent, to his 567,414, or 33 percent.
With her victory she becomes the first woman the state has sent to the Senate and gives the state two Republicans in the Senate for the first time since Reconstruction. Her victory also was seen as a political setback both for President Clinton and Governor Richards. The Republican victory cut the Democrats' lead in the Senate to 56 to 44 but will surely have a symbolic value that transcends the importance of a single new Republican vote. It is expected to embolden the Republican minority, which was already successful this year in blocking major portions of President Clinton's economic stimulus package.
Mrs. Hutchison takes her place with six other women in the Senate, the fifth to be elected in the last year.
But because all but one are Democrats, Mrs. Hutchison could quickly become a Republican star as the party seeks to prove that it can be just as successful as the Democrats in recruiting female candidates that can win. Mrs. Hutchison favors abortion rights, though she was not as vigorous in her support as Mr. Krueger, who often noted during the campaign that she also favored the rights of states to impose limits on the procedure.
 
'Important Message' to Clinton
 Mrs. Hutchison, appearing before jubilant supporters at a Dallas hotel, said her election would send "a very important message" to Mr. Clinton. "The people are tired of taxes," she said. "They want someone to get serious about cutting government spending, and that's exactly what I intend to do."
In Austin, Mr. Krueger, who now has the unfortunate distinction of being the only politician in Texas to lose a campaign for the Senate in three different decades, was self-deprecating in a concession speech tonight. "If you cheer loud enough, we may make it to 40 percent," he told supporters.
Other Republicans in Texas wasted no time in crowing over Mrs. Hutchison's victory, portraying it as a humiliation not just for Mr. Clinton, but for Democratic leaders in Texas, including Ms. Richards, who is up for re-election next year.
"If Bill Clinton and Ann Richards can put a pretty face on this devastating defeat, they ought to be morticians instead of politicians," said Phil Gramm, Texas's other Senator.
For Mr. Clinton, Mr. Krueger's loss is a clear political blow. Republican leaders, including the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said a decisive Republican victory would amount to a clear indication of dissatisfaction with the President's proposed budget.
Democrats in Texas and in Washington rushed to argue in recent days that the election was not really a referendum on the President because Mr. Krueger had taken pains to emphasize his independence from Mr. Clinton on some issues and his opposition to his proposed energy tax, which has proved to be political anathema in much of Texas.
The election was the fourth time since 1961 that the state has chosen a new senator.
After Lyndon B. Johnson resigned his Senate seat to become Vice President in 1961, Democrats fell into fratricide, and John G. Tower won a free-for-all special election, becoming the first Republican to win a Senate race in Texas since Reconstruction.
Mr. Gramm, won the election for Mr. Tower's seat seat in 1984. Mr. Bentsen defeated the liberal Democrat Ralph Yarborough in a 1970 primary.
 
Democrats Saw No Difficulties
 This time around, Democrats were hoping to mirror the Tower race. With Governor Richards, able to select Mr. Bentsen's interim successor and three major Republicans battling among themselves, many Democrats predicted that the party would have no difficulty holding onto the seat.
But party leaders squabbled over who the interim senator should be, and a host of well-known Democrats, including the former Mayor of San Antonio, Henry G. Cisneros, and Ms. Richards herself, passed up the opportunity to take the seat.
The Governor finally settled on Mr. Krueger, an Elizabethan scholar and former Congressman and Ambassador to Mexico, who had failed in two previous bids for the Senate and whose major virtue was that he had no big enemies in Texas politics.
 
Living Up to Stiff Image
 Mr. Krueger quickly lived up to his image as a stiff campaigner, and he was further damaged when he appeared to vacillate on some issues, including whether homosexuals should be allowed to serve in the military. He also had a wary political relationship with President Clinton.
At times, Mr. Krueger argued that it was important for Texas to elect a Democrat with access to the White House, but he also made a point of his independence from the President on issues like the proposed energy tax, which Mr. Krueger opposed.
On the Republican side, Mrs. Hutchison shocked nearly everyone in the race by placing first among 24 candidates in the first round of voting May 1, leading Mr. Krueger by a hair despite facing opposition from two Republican Congressmen, Jack Fields and Joe L. Barton.
 
Accusations Don't Stick
 She also appeared to have escaped largely unscathed from accusations by two former state workers that she had public employees perform personal errands on state time. One of the workers, Sharon Ammann, a daughter of former Gov. John B. Connally, also said Mrs. Hutchison had once struck her with a notebook in a fit of pique.
In the runoff two local Democratic officials in rural Central Texas contended that Mrs. Hutchison had traded the promise of a state job for a political endorsement during her 1990 race for State Treasurer.
In relentlessly seeking to capitalize on those issues Mr. Krueger ran the risk of turning off the voters or being perceived as too negative.
 
G.O.P. Lead in Fund Raising
 In any event, the perception that Mr. Krueger was behind in the race clearly had an effect in one important area: fund raising. In the most recent reports filed with the Federal Election Commission, covering the period from April 12 to May 16, Mrs. Hutchison reported receiving $1.98 million, nearly twice the amount collected by Mr. Krueger.
And the gap was even starker for the two-week period after the first round of voting on May 1: Mrs. Hutchison reported pulling in $1.4 million, while Mr Krueger collected $350,000.
Mrs. Hutchison consistently sought to focus the campaign on one issue: taxes. Virtually everywhere she went, she told rallies: "We do not have a deficit because people are taxed too little. We have a deficit because Washington spends too much."
Toward the end, focusing on health care, Mr. Krueger tried to capitalize on the same kind of concerns that propelled a Democratic victory for Harris Wofford in the Senate election in Pennsylvania two years ago. He called for a one-year price freeze on medicine and health-insurance premiums while Congress debated health-care reform. Mrs. Hutchison has opposed the move, saying it could curb medical research and force cancellation of some insurance policies.
Moreover, Mr. Krueger had difficulty selling his own image. At one point, he released a television commercial seeking to spoof his reputation as a stodgy professor. In it, he dressed up as Arnold Schwarzenegger and asked the camera, "Was it Shakespeare who said, 'Hasta la vista, baby?' " Mrs. Hutchison quickly responded with a television commercial of her own that said: "Hasta la vista, Bobby."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Republican, celebrating in Dallas last night after defeating Bob Krueger, the Democratic candidate, in the race for the Senate seat vacated by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Top Graduates in Science Also Put Dreams on Hold

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.

 BODY:
These are unsettling job-hunting times, even for the certifiably brilliant progeny of the nation's top schools in science and engineering.
Seniors who had their hearts set on creating the technologies of the next century are having trouble just lining up job interviews, and fresh new Ph.D.'s are settling for temporary teaching jobs offering little prospect of the security of tenure. 
 People graduating from colleges and universities with degrees in the humanities have been facing similar disappointments for four or five years.
But the phenomenon is now reaching the young scientists and mathematicians who have survived the rigorous schooling of places like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Harvard, Stanford and the California Institute of Technology here as Government support for space and weapons development continues to wither.
 
Caltech's Special Place
 Of the top schools, Caltech is especially exposed because it is the most specialized. It has been the cerebral cradle of Southern California's aerospace industry, feeding alumni and research to companies like Northrop, Rockwell International, Lockheed, McDonnell Douglas and Hughes.
But by the week before Caltech's June 11 commencement, only six of the 225 Caltech graduating seniors had received job offers from those companies, while more than half their classmates planned to go to graduate school in September.
One Caltech student, Stephen Turner, a second-year graduate student in mathematics, was sitting alone on a low concrete wall outside Caltech's Firestone Flight Sciences Laboratory one recent day. Mr. Turner, 25, said he once expected to spend a career in the aerospace industry, and like many students here, he started early. For five summers, he worked with engineering teams at the Lockheed Corporation. But he said he would not reapply.
"I found it difficult to walk around there while people with families were being let go," he said. And, he said, the same thing could happen to him.
In the meantime, he is engaged in a waiting game he calls "recession surfing." Financial aid provides his subsistence while he considers whether to follow the lead of many Caltech graduates -- earning a Ph.D. so he can teach.
But that option, too, is fading. Of Caltech's 70 Ph.D. graduates last year who chose to teach or do research at a university, 55 accepted a type of professorship known as a "post doc," a temporary fellowship typically for one to three years and often part time, with neither health insurance nor the right to earn tenure.
Sally J. Asmundson, the career development director at Caltech, said more than half of Caltech's graduating seniors are heading to graduate school. In addition, she said, 20 will be going to medical school. Last year, two did. Students who get good jobs are finding them outside the aerospace industry, often with computer and computer programming concerns. Or they are going further afield, into management consulting and investment concerns.
 
Influence Exceeds Size
 Caltech is tiny, with just 850 undergraduates and 1,100 graduate students. But its influence exceeds its size. The institute runs the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, the nation's foremost center of solar system research.
It has produced 21 Nobel Prize winners, including Linus Pauling, who won two, and four are now teaching at the university. The freshman class that entered last year had an average score on the Scholastic Aptitude Test of 1,430, the highest in the nation.
As in industry, cuts in military spending are forcing universities into some soul searching about their fundamental missions. At Caltech a faculty committee is re-examining the core of the university's mission, the 72-year-old tried-and-true curriculum that requires two years of physics, two of mathematics, one of chemistry and one course each term in the humanities.
Thomas E. Everhart, a physicist and president of Caltech, said, "We are now thinking, 'Do we have the right courses?' " But he did not expect a big change.
Unlike competitors that have schools of humanities, business, law and medicine, Caltech's fortunes are tied almost entirely to science, engineering and mathematics. It has few real financial worries as yet. For its size, it has an enormous endowment, about $600 million. But it depends on Federal money for half its operating budget.
With the end of the growth of the aerospace industry, David Goodstein, the vice provost, predicted a shakeout among universities that produce the nation's Ph.D. scientists. "There will be very few who survive," he said, "and among those few will be Caltech."
But "the mood is darkening," he said, adding, "Professors are now spending more time appealing to Government agencies for funds than teaching." Caltech has so far succeeded in keeping the financing stable, he said. "We're very good at it," he said. "But we don't like it."
Students admitted here have backgrounds of hard, slogging school work. Michael Klitzke, 24, is typical. Here on a full scholarship, Mr. Klitzke grew up in Oshkosh, Wis. His mother, divorced, is a factory worker there. His father is an auto mechanic in Phoenix.
"I wasn't good in elementary school and junior high," he said. But frightened by warnings that the work would be hard in high school, he buckled down and earned all A's the first term.
"Then in sophomore year," he said, "I got placed in honors classes with kids from college families. Their parents' expectations were, 'Of course you're going to college.' " Inspired again, he kept piling up A's. He graduated second in a class of 356.
Some students have abandoned thoughts of aerospace careers with ease. Mr. Klitzke, drawn to Caltech by a little-boy fascination with aviation, said the contraction of the industry gave him pause. He is leaving in June with two degrees, in physics and mechanical engineering, and going to the University of California at Los Angeles for a Ph.D., where he plans to continue his study of a new technology for processing materials as small as a speck of dusk, called micromachining.
With it he thinks he can develop a device that he can slip into a human artery and plow out the fat that inhibits blood flow, causing heart attacks. After his schooling, he said he and friends at Caltech want to start a company to exploit the technology.
David Krider, a senior, is fleeing aerospace, too. "My freshman year," he said, "I was going to be an aeronautical engineer." He then spent two years as a Mormon missionary in Chile, where he was impressed by the power of national economic policy.
"Americans have no idea what force economics can play in someone's life," he said. He abandoned aeronautics and will graduate next month with a double major in economics and computer science. Mr. Krider is going to work for an institutional money management concern for a year or two and then may go to one of the five graduate schools that have accepted his application to pursue a Ph.D. in finance.
But the more common attitude here is dismay. Julien Chen, a senior and chemistry major, said he had sent job applications to 11 employers. Just one, a private high school in New Jersey, made an offer. He wants a better paying job, and one that is more cerebral, in industry, so he is going to the University of California at San Francisco to study biophysics. That might lead to a job in a biotechnology company.
Michael Anshelevich, 21, a Russian, emigrated to Texas three years ago, entered the University of Texas and switched to Caltech, where he is completing his sophomore year majoring in mathematics.
He said he is planning to become an American citizen and wants to start a university career doing basic research in mathematics. Such pure research has no clear purpose beyond the joy of discovery, but discovery sometimes becomes the stuff of Nobel prizes and the seeds of new industries.
 
'Helpful to Start at Top'
 "I want to work in mathematics to satisfy my own curiosity," Mr. Anshelevich said. "History proves that people who work for themselves will produce applications that are useful to society." Caltech, he thought, would be his launching pad. "It's very helpful to start at the top," he said.
To his chagrin, however, Mr. Anshelevich has noticed that Caltech mathematicians are struggling to find jobs in academia, and now, he said, he might have to seek work in a business in which jobs are plentiful -- computer programming. "I prefer not to think about it," he said.
Still, a few students remain so hooked to the dreams that brought them here they think they can beat the trends of the job market. "I want to be an astronaut," said Rhonda Morgan, who is completing her sophomore year and majoring in electrical engineering.
"I think we will always have some sort of space program," she said. "If there's one astronaut left, I'll be it. If the space program is not available for me to be an astronaut, I will make sure it is available for someone else."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rhonda Morgan and Michael Klitzke, students at California Institute of Technology. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Like Caesar, Clinton Gets No Praise

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, June 5

 BODY:
At the 20th Street Cafe, where biscuits and gravy costs $1.99 and political banter is dished out for free, customers this morning were grousing about Bill Clinton as if they had been given the wrong plate of breakfast.
"This wasn't the guy we voted for," said Gilbert Castellano, a 59-year-old postal worker, as he leaned over a steaming cup of coffee. "What happened to the old Bill Clinton?" 
 As a candidate, Mr. Clinton had been seen by the 20th Street customers as a down-to-earth Arkansan, a friend to working people, a politician willing to put some Washington sacred cows out to pasture.
But voters here said they were not quite sure how they see Mr. Clinton anymore. And that troubles them.
 
Counting the Retreats
 "He's not willing to fight for anything to the bitter end," said Scott Little, a 52-year-old bus driver, who said his elation over Mr. Clinton's election had withered into deep disappointment. "He's a people pleaser to a ludicrous extreme. And people aren't taking him seriously anymore."
The diners ticked off the issues on which Mr. Clinton had seemed to take a position, only to retreat: homosexuals in the military, higher minimum wages and grazing fees on ranchers.
Discussing the latest reversal, voters expressed exasperation over the handling of the nomination of Lani Guinier to lead the Justice Department's civil rights office. While most people here said they did not know much about Ms. Guinier's politics, they said Mr. Clinton seemed to lack backbone.
"If he wanted her, he should fight for her," Mr. Castellano said. What was most troubling, he went on, was that Mr. Clinton "didn't seem to have done his homework."
 
Poor Judgment Seen
 Many voters here said they had believed that by electing Mr. Clinton, they would get a more conservative Democrat. "Whatever happened to welfare reform?" asked a waitress with a grimace.
Now many said Mr. Clinton had lost touch with everyday workers.
"Conservatives don't get $200 haircuts," said Don Utesh, a retired meatpacker.
Others complained that Mr. Clinton had been guilty of poor political judgment.
 
Adding to Frustration
 "First thing out of the gate, what does he push? Gays in the military and higher taxes," said Brian Bunch, 43, as he rolled his eyes. "I could have given him better advice than that."
Some voters said Mr. Clinton's problems had only worsened their frustration with Government.
"People wanted something different," said Rod Okuno, a 40-year-old cook, as he broke eggs into a bowl. "But we've got the same old problems. It seems like nobody can get it together in Washington."
Mr. Castellano said his faith in Mr. Clinton had rested largely on his modest background. "But now every time you look up," he said, "he's with some movie star."
To those who had voted for Mr. Clinton, what hurt most of all was that the President seemed to have become an object of ridicule. "People will come up and ask, 'Have you heard the latest Bill Clinton joke?' " Mr. Bunch said. He recalled that a friend had recently given him a paper clip attached to a penny.
"What's that?" Mr. Bunch asked.
"A Bill Clinton money clip," the friend answered with a laugh.
Not everybody in the coffee shop was ready to dismiss Mr. Clinton. "He just got in; give him some time," said Tony Solano, 65. "I know people are getting aggravated with him. But the Republicans had 12 years. He's not going to change things right away."
But behind the counter, a 49-year-old waitress, Marie Struck, talked about her fading hopes for Mr. Clinton and shook her head.
 
Hopes for Economy Fade
 "He's changed since he became President," she said. "I don't know what it is. Maybe it's being in the White House. But he's different."
As the high hopes for Mr. Clinton have faded, so too have the hopes for the economy. "I don't expect things to get much better anytime soon," Ms. Struck said.
Mr. Little, the bus driver, said the President seemed to have forgotten the issues that elected him.
"He was elected to fix the economy," Mr. Little said. "But he's not focusing on that."
As a union member, Mr. Little said he had initially hoped Mr. Clinton would move to strengthen organized labor. "Now I just hope he steers clear of union issues," he said, "since he seems to botch everything he touches."

HEADLINE: Black Lobby Group to Include Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
With a celebration more reminiscent of a movie premiere than a staid research group, TransAfrica, the lobby best known for its anti-apartheid campaign, opened its foreign policy institute here this weekend.
In a city with dozens of research institutes offering intellectual grist for everything from urban policy to the arcana of international affairs, another "think tank" would seem superfluous. 
 But Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, said United States policy toward Africa and the Caribbean, subjects of particular concern to black Americans, often got short shrift because there had been no center providing analysis of Washington's foreign policy in these areas.
"This town produces policy as a result of a competition of policy ideas," Mr. Robinson said during a tour of the institute a few days before its opening. "We have never competed evenly institutionally in the area of foreign affairs. That's why we wanted a fully fleshed out think tank to grind out the analysis that represents the interest of our community."
Mr. Robinson said TransAfrica Forum, the official name of TransAfrica's research institute, would provide that counterpoint.
Those sentiments were echoed by many of the 500 guests on Friday as Bryant Gumbel, the NBC News anchor, served as host at the dedication of the institute in a newly renovated historic building that once housed the German Embassy. Among the guests were Donna Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services; the news anchors Ted Koppel and Bernard Shaw, and Iman, the Somalian-born model.
Arthur Ashe's widow, Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, said the institute focused on issues that had concerned her husband. The institute's library is named for Mr. Ashe, who served on the board of TransAfrica since its founding in 1977.
TransAfrica, a lobbying group of black Americans on African and Caribbean issues, was the driving force behind the campaign for United States economic sanctions against South Africa. The sanctions were lifted in 1989 as the result of South Africa's move toward abolishing apartheid.
Much the way Israel courts American Jewish opinion, African and Caribbean leaders have increasingly tried to influence United States policy toward their countries by courting black American opinion. During Angola's civil war, both sides in the conflict competed for black American support. The exiled President of Haiti, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has also sought support from black Americans; he was among the guests at the institute's ceremony on Friday.
Equally, many prominent black Americans have shown an interest in exercising their influence.
Among those contributing to the institute are Bill Cosby, who raised $430,000 at two dinners with the help of the actors Robert Guillaume and Joyce Deep, and the former boxer Sugar Ray Leonard contributed $250,000. Corporations that do substantial business with blacks have also shown interest in supporting the venture.
TransAfrica has 20,000 or so members in 12 chapters around the country and many prominent black members. There is no precise way to gauge whether its policy positions on Africa and the Caribbean reflect the views of most black Americans. Some critics of the organization argue that it is too liberal and too sympathetic to third-world leaders.
"As long as they're not the exclusive voice, this institute is a wonderful thing," said Sanford Ungar, dean of the school of communications at American University and a longtime commentator on Africa. "They've sometimes tended to ignore the domestic record of some African leaders."
The institute's new five-story headquarters in the Dupont Circle area, where many lobbies and research groups make their homes, includes a 6,000-volume library, a computer center, a public reading room and space for meetings, administrative work and a scholars' advisory council.
The forum will offer programs including one that works with historically black colleges to train students for the Foreign Service.

HEADLINE: Differing Views on Human Rights Threaten Forum

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 5

 BODY:
Deep divisions between developing and industrialized nations threaten the success of a conference this month on strengthening human rights. At issue is a contention by many third-world nations that Western standards of justice and fairness do not necessarily apply to other cultures.
Those countries are also seeking assurances that the West will not use their records on human rights to withhold aid or other economic benefits that the countries say would violate their right to development. 
 Increasingly, aid donors like the United States, as well as international institutions like the World Bank, are making assistance contingent not only on prudent economic policies, but also on the adoption of democratic systems that encourage human rights.
 
Mistake in the Making
 The conference, which opens on June 14 in Vienna, appears to be in serious trouble before it begins. The meeting is the first that the United Nations has called on the issue since a session in Teheran, Iran, 25 years ago, and many Western officials and human rights agencies say it may be a mistake.
Western diplomats and organizations say outright failure would be preferable to a compromise that would weaken their strongly held beliefs not only that human rights have already been defined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which the General Assembly adopted in 1948, but also that those standards apply equally to all the peoples of the world.
"It is the strong purpose of the Clinton Administration to side with the worldwide movement for universal human rights against any effort to undermine it," the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, John Shattuck, said in an interview. "This conference does not have to agree on a final statement."
Many representatives of third-world countries contend that the declaration was drawn up by the founding members of the United Nations, most of which are Western industrialized countries, and that it reflected their values at a time when most African and Asian countries were still colonies.
 
'Mainly Be Damage Control'
 Delegates at the fourth and final preparatory committee meeting for the conference, which ended in Geneva on May 7, failed to produce a consensus on a draft declaration. They issued a 50-page document, most of which is in brackets, meaning that some delegates disagreed with what it said.
The deputy director of the Human Rights Watch in New York, Kenneth Roth, said: "Vienna will mainly be damage control. Our primary goal will be to defend the principle of universality that has been central to human rights advocacy for 40 years."
A failure to approve a new declaration would show that the governments cannot agree on what constitutes justice and fairness. But Felice Gaer of the Jacob Blaustein Institute for Human Rights in New York, said, "No result at all would be better than a bad one."
 
Insistence on Assistance
 At three earlier meetings -- in Bangkok, Thailand; Tunis, and San Jose, Costa Rica -- Asian, African and Latin American nations adopted statements implying in part that different cultures have different human rights standards while insisting that developing countries have an absolute right to assistance with their economic development.
The most objectionable stand in Western eyes may be an Asian statement that says concepts of fairness and justice should be measured against "regional particularities and various historical, cultural and religious backgrounds." The statement was made under the influence of countries like China and Indonesia, which have been accused of serious rights violations.
In assessing abuses, the Africans stressed a need to take account of "the historical and cultural realities of each nation," but they also insisted that "the right to development is inalienable," implying that aid should not be linked to a county's human rights performance. The Latin Americans see their foreign debts as an obstacle to observing human rights conventions.
The Geneva document does show a consensus on new steps to protect women's rights. But the disputes over the universality of human rights and the right to development have prevented further agreement. Delegates could not even agree on condemning torture.
Western countries refused to hold a regional preparatory meeting before the conference or to draw up a statement, saying human rights should not be subject to further negotiation. The purpose of the conference, they say, is to decide on better enforcement. The Clinton Administration has made one concession, dropping a distinction made by the Reagan and Bush Administrations between civil and political rights on the one hand and economic, social and cultural ones on the other.
 
Acceptance of Argument
 To avoid "a sterile debate at Vienna," State Department officials say the Administration is ready to accept the third-world contention that it has economic, social and cultural rights. The Republicans argued that conceding third-world economic, social and cultural rights encouraged developing countries to weaken the United Nations by using it as a platform for demanding economic policies that shift wealth from rich to poor and would be unacceptable to Western countries.
But State Department officials now say although the Administration accepts both groups of rights, it still thinks that civil and political rights have to be observed immediately and that economic, social and cultural rights can be achieved only "incrementally, in step with development."
The Administration will also press for the creation of the post of High Commissioner for Human Rights to monitor nations in the same that way the High Commissioner for Refugees oversees refugees. But the United States suggestion that the commissioner be in charge of the United Nations human rights center in Geneva has aroused controversy. Some monitoring organizations would prefer a more independent commissioner in New York, close to the Secretary General and the Security Council.
For the the head of the center in Geneva, Ibrahima Fall, the conference in Vienna should have one objective, to give the United Nations the resources and machinery to respond quickly to human rights abuses around the world.
"At present, less than 1 percent of the United Nations budget and less than 0.75 percent of its staff are dedicated to human rights," Mr. Fall said. "We have less money and resources than Amnesty International, and we're the arm of the United Nations for human rights. This is clearly ridiculous."

HEADLINE: Aspin Meets Russian in Bid to Take Ukraine's A-Arms

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARMISCH, Germany, June 5

 BODY:
Stepping up the American campaign to persuade the Ukrainians to give up their nuclear weapons, Defense Secretary Les Aspin came here today to discuss with Russia a new plan to dismantle Ukraine's nuclear missiles and place their warheads under international supervision.
Mr. Aspin met with the Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev. The plan is intended to resolve a Russian-Ukrainian dispute on how to deal with the warheads that would be removed from Ukraine's missiles if Ukraine gave up its nuclear arms. 
 Under the plan, the warheads would at first be put under the control of international inspectors, then sent to Russia for dismantling.
Mr. Aspin discussed the Ukraine issue with General Grachev today. He did not present the plan, but he may do so on Sunday. Mr. Aspin is also expected to take up the question of joint American-Russian military exercises, as well as issues of nuclear testing and the setting of targets for nuclear weapons.
 
A Major Concern for Clinton
 With Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine telling members of his Parliament that their country should retain some of the 176 nuclear-tipped missiles left on its soil by the former Soviet Union, the Ukrainian issue has become a central concern for the Clinton Administration.
Though other Ukrainian leaders disagree with Mr. Kuchma, Gen. John M. Shalikashvili of the United States, NATO's commander, said it was "frightening" that a Ukrainian leader of Mr. Kuchma's standing had called for retaining any nuclear weapons.
After completing talks with General Grachev on Sunday morning, Mr. Aspin is to fly to Kiev to meet with the Ukrainian Defense Minister, Konstanin Morozov.
American officials say the nuclear debate in Kiev is fueled by deep-seated concerns of Ukrainians that their independence might be short-lived and their country absorbed in a new version of the Russian empire.
The breakup of the Soviet Union left three countries besides Russia with nuclear weapons on their soil. Belarus has agreed to give up its nuclear weapons by the end of next year, and Kazakhstan has ratified the 1991 strategic arms reduction treaty known as Start 1 but so far has not agreed to renounce nuclear arms. Ukraine has taken neither step.
 
Effect on Arms Treaties
 While Administration officials say Ukraine's reluctance to dismantle its nuclear arsenal is understandable, the position has had serious costs. It has aggravated Kiev's relations with Moscow and led Russia and the United States to delay the arms cuts agreed to under the Start 1 and Start 2 treaties.
Administration officials are also worried that Ukraine's stand may hurt efforts to control the spread of nuclear weapons.
American officials say Ukrainian officials can be grouped into three camps. Those who favor the dismantling of the nuclear arsenal include President Leonid Kravchuk, Foreign Minister Anatoly Zlenko and Defense Minister Morozov.
In another category are Ukrainians who favor holding on to the weapons for the time being so Kiev can trade them for more generous economic aid and some sort of security assurances. In the third category are legislators and nationalists who want to hold on to the weapons at all costs.
The Clinton Administration's strategy is to try to strengthen the first two groups against the third.
 
Plan for Warheads
 The new warhead plan is a means to this end. Under the plan, the warheads would be removed from the Ukrainian missiles. They would be put under the control of international inspectors.
The warheads would then gradually be sent to Russia. There, the highly enriched uranium from the warheads could be removed and sold to Washington. American officials estimate that Ukraine could earn several billion dollars from such transactions.
Alternatively, the highly enriched uranium could be converted to low-grade uranium and returned to Ukraine for civilian use.
The plan is meant to ease worries of the Ukrainians that they might not be fairly compensated if they handed their nuclear warheads directly to Russia. It also addresses their concern that Russia might put the warheads on Russian missiles and aim them at Ukraine.
Not all of the technical details have been worked out, so the Administration intends to present it in only the most general terms.
The plan also poses some political difficulties for both sides. Mr. Aspin's team is carrying a draft charter that would be issued if Ukraine agreed to ratify the strategic arms treaty and give up its nuclear arms. The charter would express American support for Ukraine's independence, but Washington remains adamantly opposed to giving Ukraine NATO membership or extending the American nuclear umbrella to protect it.

HEADLINE: Current Crop of College Graduates Finds Job Market Painfully Tight

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
As the nation's 1.3 million college seniors graduate this year, they face what economists and demographers call one of the harshest job climates in a quarter-century. The recession's lingering effects are chilling new job creation, while corporate cutbacks are altering the type of jobs available.
"Clearly, the recession has been tough," said Richard J. Murnane, a Harvard economist who has studied the job market. "Companies are using overtime instead of hiring, and line workers are increasingly college graduates." 
 The turbulence created by the recession and job reductions is not exactly what students and parents had in mind four years ago, when most of this year's graduates began preparing for what they thought would be careers in business, engineering, health or other vocations. But college and university job placement officials say the outlook is grim.
"In the past, there would always be some fields, like engineers, that did well, regardless of the economy," said Thom Rakes, assistant director of the planning and placement center at the University of Missouri at Columbia, "But the engineers are right there with everyone else at this point."
 
Waiting Out Bad Times
 Mr. Rakes said many college graduates were taking lower-paying jobs to wait out the bad times.
As the economy improves, even though unevenly and slowly, economists say, the job outlook will improve slightly. But long-term job prospects look less encouraging: corporate shrinkage is expected to continue through the 1990's and beyond.
An estimated 24.6 million new jobs are expected to be created for the 15-year period ending in 2005, according to a projection by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, down from the 33 million new jobs created from 1975 to 1990.
Among the occupations expected to grow rapidly through 2005 are nursing and other health-care specialties as well as computer programming and other computer-technology-related jobs, according to the bureau's projections.
This year's graduates are increasingly filling jobs like sales representative posts in service industries, jobs that were filled by people with only high school degrees 15 years ago. These positions have been altered by corporate cutbacks, and these lower-rung employees are being given more responsibilities in many companies, Mr. Murnane said.
The availability of a whole class of jobs, too, is declining, said the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Those jobs include assembly-line work, clerical and support staff, and electrical and electronic equipment service. High school graduates normally fill these jobs, but now college graduates are competing for the dwindling number of positions.
Even the encouraging job growth reported in May is unlikely to improve the immediate prospects for this year's graduates, economists says.
Perhaps most disturbing to graduates is the salary outlook. Wage increases grew in the 1980's at annual rates of 2 percent to 3 percent, but economists say such increases are likely to be rare this decade. In 1990, the average annual salary for all workers was $29,912 as against $6,845 in 1967; when the 1967 sum is adjusted to account for inflation, it becomes $26,786.
Expectations for continuing salary increase have been dashed, Mr. Murnane said, adding, "There is no evidence that is going to change very fast."

HEADLINE: Trustees Back Shift of Deans At Columbia

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
Columbia University's Board of Trustees yesterday approved an administrative shake-up that the university's incoming president said was his first step to eliminate the university's $15 million operating deficit and to establish stronger control over its sprawling arts and sciences faculty.
The new president, George E. Rupp, presented the changes, which include the replacement of three deans and a vice president, to the Columbia trustees at their quarterly meeting. Mr. Rupp, who is now the president of Rice University in Houston, made clear in an interview before the meeting that he was planning further restructuring after he succeeded Michael I. Sovern on July 1. 
 "This is not the only step I'm going to take at Columbia, but it seemed an important place to start," Mr. Rupp said.
The shake-up was a bold move by Mr. Rupp, even before his formal installation, to take control of an Ivy League university that has recently suffered not only from problems like crime and campus crowding that are consequences of its urban setting, but also from administrative problems like a substantial budget shortfall, low faculty morale and interdepartmental rivalry.
 
Some Grumbling Hinted
 Henry L. King, a lawyer who is chairman of the University's board, hinted in an interview that there was some grumbling among the 24 trustees during their meeting in Low Library yesterday about the sudden manner in which two deans were replaced, which some professors said broke with long traditions of faculty consultation.
But Mr. King said the trustees approved the changes "with unanimity and enthusiasm," indicating that Mr. Rupp has managed to achieve consensus quickly behind his plans for an overhaul.
One of the administrators who was replaced, Jack Greenberg, dean of Columbia College, said he had received messages of support from faculty members skeptical about the wisdom of Mr. Rupp's moves. But many other professors interviewed in the last few days strongly endorsed the changes as a promising effort to bolster campus unity and confront the university's fiscal difficulties.
Mr. Rupp went to work first on the arts and sciences faculty, he said, because he considers its well-being and cohesion to be central to the health of the larger university, which has about 20,000 students.
The arts and sciences faculty, which operates alongside the university's health sciences faculty and its six professional schools, includes 28 departments and oversees Columbia College, which is the center of undergraduate life, as well as four other schools.
"When you say arts and sciences, you're talking about a hell of a large chunk of the university," Mr. Rupp said. "And that's why it's been so Balkanized. It's been going in every possible direction. Somebody has got to pull it together and get it walking in a direction that makes sense for Columbia as a whole."
 
An Aggressive Look Promised
 In the shake-up, Steven Marcus, an English professor, replaces Mr. Greenberg as college dean as well as replacing Martin Meisel, vice president for arts and science, one of the university's seven vice presidents, who had earlier said he was resiging.
Caroline Walker Bynum, a history professor, becomes dean of the School of General Studies, and Eduardo Macagno, a neurobiologist, replaces Roger Bagnall as dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. Ms. Bynum and Mr. Macagno were also named associate vice presidents.
Mr. Rupp's decision to give all three deans vice presidential duties has aroused controversy.
"I was concerned, on the financial side, about structuring the faculty so that any unnecessary duplication and bureaucratization could be resolved," Mr. Rupp said. "And I wanted to put a leadership team in there that would look aggressively at the faculty of arts and sciences as a whole."
The changes, which are to become effective when Mr. Rupp takes formal control, surprised many on the Morningside Heights campus, especially because at Rice and as dean of the Harvard Divinity School, Mr. Rupp built an image as a cautious administrator.
 
'A Take-Charge C.E.O.'
 "I'm not uncomfortable with viewing myself as a take-charge C.E.O. -- that's what a president ought to do," he said. "But it's not my usual practice to move into a new situation and make abrupt personnel changes."
He said that he had undertaken the moves so quickly only because a number of faculty posts had been left vacant since Mr. Sovern announced his retirement last year and because it made no sense to fill them without beginning a more extensive restructuring.
Mr. Rupp, who flew to New York from Houston on Thursday for the trustees' meeting, said that since his selection in February he had made a dozen similar trips to study Columbia's problems. In addition, he said, he read through a year's back issues of The Spectator, the student newspaper, boning up on the texture of recent campus life.
At their meeting, the trustees approved an annual budget of $1.05 billion that includes a deficit of about $15 million, which Mr. Rupp said he hoped to eliminate within a year.
"There's been significant progress toward reducing this deficit, but significant financial restraints remain," he said. "The institution is still spending more money than it's taking in."
 
Personnel Cuts Possible
 "We're not talking about a Draconian budget ax hanging over the institution," he said. "I think we'll be able to manage a transition to a completely balanced budget over the next year without having to make substantial personnel cuts."
Later he added: "I don't want to go into print saying there will be absolutely no cuts in personnel."
Mr. Rupp said he hoped the three professors he appointed as deans and as vice presidents would "command the respect of their colleagues so they can collectively take responsibility for ways of achieving economy and basically living with their means."
The main thrust of the restructuring, however, was not financial, Mr. Rupp said, but rather to counteract what he called the "centrifugal forces" tearing at university cohesion.
Ms. Bynum said those forces have intensified as professors have emphasized their own research over teaching.
 
Competition for Professors
 "Professors will think of publishing a paper to impress the physicists at Boston University rather than sitting down with the chemists at Columbia to resolve some problem between their fields," Ms. Bynum said. "Or a medieval historian might be more interested in relating to the Pontifical Institute in Montreal, rather than talking to Columbia's English Lit people about teaching a joint course."
Competition between Columbia's rival institutions is another problem, she said, since professors on the arts and science faculty generally teach in more than one of its five schools, each of which has its own schedule and makes competing demands on professors' time.
"As one person you can be pulled apart by different administrations," Ms. Bynum said. "This is is not only a centrifugal tendency; it wastes everybody's time."
Mr. Bagnall, a professor of ancient history, questioned the wisdom of loading the three deans with vice presidential responsibilities. Both deans and university vice presidents already labor under extraordinary workloads, he said.
"Obviously, as a citizen of the university, I hope this works," Mr. Bagnall said. "But it's a dramatic change from the way things have worked here in the past."

He spoke with Herbert Pardes, a vice president, yesterday after a meeting of the trustees. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON FAULTED ON HAITI SANCTIONS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 5

 BODY:
Even as the Clinton Administration adopts new sanctions to punish the military-backed Government of Haiti, officials of other nations and American analysts of Haitian affairs say Washington has failed to apply the type of pressure needed to restore the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power.
On Friday, with senior Administration officials' saying that they were imposing "a very high price" for the continued defiance by the military leaders of Haiti against international demands for a return to democracy, President Clinton signed an executive order freezing the assets of and barring travel to the United States by backers of the coup in September 1991 that overthrew Father Aristide. 
 Critics of Washington's diplomatic approach say although the measures are the first punitive actions by the Clinton Administration against the leaders in Port-au-Prince, they are far from new. As with President Clinton's decision to continue the Bush Administration policy of summary repatriations of Haitians fleeing their country at sea -- a policy that the President had harshly criticized when he was a candidate -- the critics say Mr. Clinton is again adopting tactics of his predecessor, which proved ineffective in settling the crisis.
President Bush, too, banned travel to this country by people thought to be important supporters of the coup leaders, although he later dropped the ban. Likewise, the Bush Administration froze Haitian state assets and repeatedly warned that individual assets might be seized, as well, if progress was not made toward a return of democracy.
 
Protection of Holdings
 Clinton Administration officials have declined to estimate publicly the value of the private assets they expect to freeze but concede privately that with the possibility for such an action being waved for a long time before the tiny but economically potent Haitian elite, many, if not most, of its members had already acted to protect their holdings.
Even before the latest measures, analysts, including supporters and opponents of Father Aristide's return, were discounting their potential effects and saying that by following such a studiously gradualist approach the Administration was unlikely to secure Father Aristide's return.
"The Clinton Administration team has treated this thing like suburban social workers, when in fact what they've needed is someone used to dealing with Chicago gangs," said a former senior Haitian official who insisted on anonymity. "Nothing can happen until there is a meaningful threat from Washington. So far the culprits here are completely unimpressed."
Reinforcing such impressions has apparently been a reluctance by the Clinton Administration to proceed quickly toward harsher sanctions. Those include an enforced oil embargo against Haiti and a suspension of ordinary air travel to the United States, measures that most observers say are the only ones, short of the unlikely use of military force, that would provide hope of quickly ending the resistance to a democratic settlement.
Although diplomats of Canada, France and Venezuela, all nations that have been highly engaged in the talks involving Haiti, have long urged that a global oil embargo be imposed, the announcement on Friday was the first time that senior United States officials have been publicly willing to even entertain the possibility of global oil sanctions.
 
Punishment of the Poor
 "It's not always the best tactic to use all of your tools all at once at the beginning," one senior Administration official told reporters on Friday when he was asked why an oil embargo was not being applied. "You use them in some kind of measured way to try to keep driving the process forward."
Under Mr. Clinton, as under Mr. Bush, another prominent rationale for the slow ratcheting of pressure has been concern that sanctions not punish the poor, who overwhelmingly support Father Aristide. But 20 months after his ouster, critics say it is clear that the poor rather than rich supporters of the coup have paid the highest price for the defiance by the country's de facto leaders.
If the newly announced sanctions fail to produce quick political changes, observers say the Clinton Administration has been warned that it will itself be faced with high new costs in the form of the embarrassing withdrawal of the United Nations from its leading role in brokering an end to the crisis. The changes include the Haitian Government's acceptance of a proposed settlement that would include a pardon for military officers for their roles in a harsh campaign of repression and of an international police force to help create a climate of security.
"The United Nations entered these negotiations at the behest of the United States, and will carry on as long as we have strong backing from Washington," said one diplomat who has closely followed the negotiations. "They really want to play ball with the Administration, but in the absence of something stronger, they won't want to pretend that they can produce any miracles in Haiti."

HEADLINE: MORE PEOPLE VIEW CLINTON AS LIBERAL AS HE SEEKS CENTER

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
As President Clinton struggles to return to the centrist policies that won the election, an increased number of Americans view him as a liberal, and many say his economic plan relies too heavily on raising taxes and would do little to help the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Most Americans do not appear convinced by Mr. Clinton's repeated efforts to show that his economic remedies will place a heavier burden on rich people than on the middle class. And they have grown increasingly skeptical about the fairness and effectiveness of the plan. 
 The optimism many Americans had early this year that the economy would improve has largely dissipated, with only 13 percent now saying the country is on the rebound. Recent economic data offer only spots of encouragement. Job growth jumped in May, and sales of autos and new homes have climbed, but retail sales have been disappointing. Consumer and business confidence have declined markedly.
 
What Troubles Americans
 Clearly troubled by the President's call for new taxes, by his series of seeming political blunders and by a perception that the economy is in terrible shape, Americans have been more critical of Mr. Clinton than of any President since World War II at equivalent points in office. Mr. Clinton, of course, was elected without a majority of the popular vote in a three-way race.
His rating stands at 38 percent of the public approving how he handles his job, with 47 percent disapproving. Half the people say the President, who campaigned as a populist and vowed to end the status quo in Washington, has lost touch with average Americans.
Mr. Clinton's latest political stumble -- the uproar over his nomination of Lani Guinier to be the Justice Department's civil rights chief and his withdrawal of the nomination on Thursday -- did not appreciably alter his basic standing, the poll found. Of the nearly 7 in 10 Americans who had heard that Mr. Clinton dropped the nomination, 47 percent said he did the right thing and 30 percent said he did not. And 65 percent of that group said Mr. Clinton was wrong to nominate Ms. Guinier in the first place, echoing what the President himself said, while 21 percent said they approved of the nomination.
 
View of Nomination Uproar
 Over all, 32 percent of Americans familiar with the episode said they had a worse opinion of Mr. Clinton because of his handling of it, 11 percent said they thought better of him, and 53 percent said it had no effect on their views.
The telephone poll was taken Tuesday through Thursday with 1,347 adults nationwide. On Friday night, 565 of the respondents were interviewed a second time, after Ms. Guinier's nomination was withdrawn. For results based on all respondents, the poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Seeking to erase the perception that he is turning liberal and failing in the job, Mr. Clinton has in recent days hammered at the theme that his economic program calls for significant spending cuts, and he appointed David R. Gergen, a senior aide in the Reagan White House, as a top adviser. But those moves have not raised the President's popularity, nor did the narrow victory of his economic plan in the House of Representatives 10 days ago.
Though many Americans are clearly troubled by the early days of the Clinton Administration, the good news for Mr. Clinton is that they are still willing to give him a chance. Sixty-nine percent said Mr. Clinton was learning from the problems he has encountered and will do better, the same number who said he had a vision of where he wants to lead the country. And 62 percent said they believed that Mr. Clinton "cares about the needs and problems of people" like themselves, although 74 percent held that impression in January.
 
What Worries Clinton
 Mr. Clinton insisted last week that he was not worried about his low popularity ratings, but he did remark that he was concerned that people had distorted views of him. "The only thing I worry about is if I think people have an inaccurate impression, which I think is certainly the case today, or if it undermines my ability to do things," he told reporters.
One big challenge facing Mr. Clinton is turning around the perception that he has moved to the left since taking office. Roughly half of registered voters said they thought of him as liberal, and 31 percent thought of him as moderate. Throughout the campaign, Americans were evenly divided on whether they saw him as a liberal or a moderate.
Voters are also split on whether Mr. Clinton is a "different" kind of Democrat, which is how he presented himself during the campaign. About half say he is different, while 42 percent say he is a typical Democrat, which many probably associate with high taxes and big spending.
 
Not More Efficient
 Many Americans had expected Government to function better with the White House and Congress controlled by the same party, as Mr. Clinton promised during the campaign an end to gridlock. But only 35 percent said Government was working better, while 45 percent said it was not.
Mr. Clinton may take some solace in that the poll found many Americans are critical of Congress and Ross Perot, who has emerged as one of the President's most stubborn, and certainly most public, detractors.
Just 27 percent of the public approve of the way Congress is handling its job; while 60 percent disapprove. While those favorable ratings are even lower than those for Mr. Clinton, they do not reflect a new trend; the public has for years rated Congress very low.
Half of Americans credited Mr. Clinton with being more serious about reducing the deficit than Republicans in Congress, who have sought to make it their rallying cry. Only 31 percent said the Republicans were more serious on the deficit.
 
Trust in Congress
 But the figures were reversed on the question of who is most capable of making overall decisions about the budget. Half of Americans said they trusted Congress -- Democrats and Republicans -- more in budget decisions, while 30 percent said they trusted Mr. Clinton more.
The survey also found that Americans opinions of Mr. Perot are cooling off once again. Thirty-five percent of registered voters hold a favorable opinion of Ross Perot, while 29 percent have an unfavorable opinion. But as recently as March, Mr. Perot's favorable rating was 42 percent, and in January it was 45 percent. This pattern was evident when Mr. Perot emerged during last year's Presidential campaign; the public seems to rally to Mr. Perot initially, but then some people turn against him as they watch him more closely.
The public perception of Mr. Clinton may stem partly from reactions to his economic proposal. Though Americans are slightly more optimistic about his plan than they were just before it passed the House, 46 percent said it relied too much on taxes increases, while 7 percent said it relied too much on spending cuts. Another 37 percent said the balance between taxes and spending was about right.
 
Growing More Skeptical
 Americans are also more skeptical about Mr. Clinton's economic program than they were when he proposed it three months ago. Thirty-four percent now say the proposal, if adopted, will help the economy. But in February, 53 percent expressed optimism that it would help the economy, with the figure dropping to 45 percent by March.
Despite the slight economic upturn since the House voted on the plan, people are concerned that the economic plan is unfair to them. Forty-one percent of Americans said the economic program is "fair to people like you," but in February, 59 percent perceived such fairness.
Though the notion of higher taxes continues to make people nervous, 59 percent said they were willing to take on that burden for a health-care reform package, even over and above new taxes to reduce the deficit.
But Americans agree with Mr. Clinton's announcement last week that he was putting off unveiling his health-care proposal until his economic plan wends it way through Congress. Forty percent say health-care reform is so important that Congress and the President should act on it this year, while 56 percent say the problem is so complicated that they should take another year to work out the details.
 
Controversy Over Haircut
 Mr. Clinton's highly publicized Hollywood haircut probably contributed to the perception among half of Americans that he has lost touch with average Americans. But those people were divided on who to blame; half said it was "Bill Clinton's fault," and the other half said it reflected "a part of the job that a President can't do anything about."
While the President chided reporters for unfairly zeroing in on his haircut and his other political missteps, 54 percent of Americans said the news media have treated Mr. Clinton fairly; 30 percent said the coverage has been too harsh and 12 percent said it was too soft. And 56 percent said Mr. Clinton's treatment is no different from his predecessors.
But clearly, Mr. Clinton's job rating this early in his tenure is lower than other Presidents. In nearly a half century of polling the only other new President who came close was Gerald R. Ford, whose popularity sunk to 42 percent after four months in office and to 37 percent after five months. Mr. Ford's tumble was precipitated by his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon for his involvement in the Watergate scandal.
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Tuesday through Thursday with 1,347 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, on Friday night many of the respondents were re-interviewed briefly to gather their impressions of President Clinton's withdrawal of the nomination of Lani Guinier to be civil rights chief in the Justice Department. One thousand respondents were called back and 565 were successfully re-interviewed; for this group, the margin of sampling error is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. For instance, the results of the callbacks made Friday night are subject to additional error because of the limited time available to pursue hard-to-reach people.

HEADLINE: School Bill Is Viewed Many Ways

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 5

 BODY:
The State Senate gave final approval on Friday to legislation that requires every community in Connecticut to discuss the desegregation of public schools across town lines, but even in the last hours of debate, the expectations of what might result from those talks varied wildly.
Through the distorted glass of race politics, the opponents of the bill expect -- or fear -- the most from it, while many of the legislators who voted for it did so because they expect very little. 
 Republicans denounced what they described as the bill's emphasis on race, the unchecked power over local schools granted to state officials, and the inevitability of forced busing. Democrats, who stripped explicit references to race from the bill as the price for their support, played down the state's ability to make communities do anything more than talk with each other.
 
Incentives, but No Penalties
 "If we reach the point where asking communities to talk is asking too much, I really fear for the future of this state," said Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a Democrat from West Hartford, who had introduced the bill in the Senate.
The bill, approved by the House last Friday, sets a one-year timetable for towns and cities to draft plans to improve public schools by reducing barriers to opportunity and enhancing student diversity. It also offers financial incentives for cooperation. But there are no penalties for declining to implement the plans.
However euphemistic and vague the legislation is, everyone knows its origin was Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s call this winter for Connecticut to start breaking down the racial and economic divisions between cities and suburbs, before a court orders a desegregation plan. Connecticut is divided into cities made up of poor minority groups and towns that are overwhelmingly white and middle class. A lawsuit in state court is challenging the unequal public schools that result from that division.
How the segregation came to be did not matter, Mr. Weicker said in his State of the State message in January. "What matters," he said, "is that it is here and must be dealt with."
 
Quality of Education Stressed
 To many people, however, it matters a great deal that the state has white schools and black schools because whites and blacks live in different communities, not because of Jim Crow segregation laws. Since the segregation is not the result of discrimination, they argue, race shouldn't be the issue; the quality of education should be.
Because of that widely held belief, Governor Weicker's original legislation to achieve a "significant reduction in racial isolation" was replaced in the Education Committee by a bill that first of all "seeks to improve the quality of school performance."
Of Republicans' efforts to label the bill a desegregation bill, Mr. Sullivan, a co-chairman of the Education Committee, said in an interview, "I do not subscribe to the notion of legal segregation in Connecticut, so I cannot present this as a desegregation issue."
After the Governor's call for action, he said, "The message came back loud and clear from everybody that the underlying issue is opening access, improving opportunity and improving performance."
 
Intent Remains Clear
 The legislation's original intent remains clear in that all of the devices named in the bill for improving the quality of schools require students to cross town lines and are commonly used in desegregation plans, including magnet schools, interdistrict schools, school choice and regional programs.
But towns and cities are required only to take part in regional planning forums. The towns of each region, not the state education commissioner, accept or reject the regional plan. If a town refuses to take part in the plan, there is no penalty.
Many people, therefore, see the legislation as mainly encouraging, on a larger scale, the kind of voluntary cooperation that some cities and towns are already undertaking.
"We have had the wherewithal to do voluntarily any of this," said Rep. William R. Dyson, a Democrat from New Haven and one of many city legislators disappointed with the bill's weakening. "You can see how far we've come -- no place. So now we've legalized voluntary action."
Others who were also disappointed by the weakened bill say the worst outcome, however, would have been for the Legislature to do nothing.
"There was a time when we were concerned that might be the case," said Stephen Tegarden, who as school superintendent in Glastonbury helped establish a magnet school with neighboring East Hartford. "The fact that they have at least passed a piece of legislation that addresses the issue of economic and racial segregation within our state is certainly a positive step."
