HEADLINE: Dinkins and Council Face Fiscal Maw's 300 Million Sharp Teeth

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The sky was dark and menacing over Lower Manhattan yesterday, but it was no match for the gloom inside City Hall, where New York's political leaders worked behind closed doors to scale back the size of the municipal government by a hefty $300 million.
Cutting funds for valued services like day-care, summer school and homeless drop-in centers is never appealing to elected officials. But Mayor David N. Dinkins, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the 50 other members of the Council no doubt feel particularly vulnerable doing it now, just months before they will ask voters to re-elect them. 
 New York's elected leaders find themselves in this predicament because of two sets of overlapping problems, one short-term and the other long-term. The Mayor, in a spending plan he proposed last month, counted heavily on $530 million in additional aid from Washington and Albany to help balance his $31 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.
Mr. Dinkins was forced to acknowledge on Thursday that more than half of the requested aid is unlikely to materialize, and he said he would now have to reduce spending by about $300 million to balance the budget. The Mayor's retreat set off the final round of budget negotiations between Mr. Dinkins and the Council. Both sides hope to complete the talks by late tomorrow or Monday.
 
Faulting the Republicans
 The Mayor and his advisers have sought to place blame on the Republicans in the State Legislature and Congress, implicitly implicating as well his Republican-Liberal mayoral opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"We fought for it and we have not gotten it, to a great degree because of Republicans," the Mayor said on Friday during an interview on WFAN-AM radio. "They filibustered in the Senate on the President's economic stimulus package. Stopped that cold."
But some Republicans, including Mr. Giuliani, and many independent fiscal experts contend that the Mayor has not made enough decisive changes to the local government to achieve long-range fiscal stability.
In fact, some fiscal experts argue that even if Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone agree on how to trim $300 million, there are enough other uncertainties in the Mayor's proposed budget that it is likely to unravel over the next six months.
 
Further Cuts Predicted
 Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, said he had identified as much as $700 million in questionable, one-time revenues in the Mayor's plan, including $215 million from a bank loan backed by delinquent property-tax payments and $55 million from the sale of the financially troubled Off-Track Betting Corporation.
Mr. Proctor said he was convinced that more spending cuts would be necessary during the next fiscal year. "It's not an issue of if, it's only an issue of when and how," he said.
Mr. Proctor, Councilman Charles Millard, a Manhattan Republican, and other critics insist that the city will lurch from crisis to crisis on the budget because, after four years of recession, New York's tax base cannot support all the services the government provides. They fault the Mayor for not making the politically risky decisions that they think the circumstances require.
Mr. Proctor noted, for example, that Mr. Dinkins reduced the size of the city work force by nearly 11,000 people, to 209,902 from 220,505, between June 1991 and June 1992, a shrinkage that won the Mayor praise from fiscal monitors and Wall Street and that helped him to put together a budget a year ago that added a few modest but innovative programs.
But then the Dinkins administration eased up on the effort to shrink the government, adding about 2,600 jobs over the last 12 months. And that is a prime reason the Mayor is struggling now to balance his new budget, Mr. Proctor said.
Mr. Dinkins is now proposing, among other things, to eliminate 4,000 jobs over the next year through attrition; among the proposals floated yesterday by the Council was trimming the Department of Cultural Affairs and making it part of the Parks Department.
 
Promises That Failed
 Several mayoral aides admit privately that they had been counting heavily on President Clinton and a slight economic upturn to help them avoid spending cuts. They also said that Mr. Dinkins had believed firmly that his Democratic allies, Mr. Clinton and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, would loyally help him.
Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said that structural reform was not possible unless the city's relationship with the state and Federal governments was also reformulated. He contended that a major reason for the city's plight was that a promise two years ago by the Governor to pick up the city's portion of Medicaid, a $2 billion-a-year burden that few other cities must bear, had not been approved by the Legislature.
Mr. Steisel also argued that it was easy to talk generally about eliminating city services, but much harder to be specific. "Should we stop giving subsidies to cultural institutions, as some have suggested?" he asked. "Should we close the hospitals, or should we not have come up with $100 million to save the subway fare?"
"Hindsight is easy," Mr. Steisel said. "But it is hard to make decisions in a dynamic environment. The question is how do you deal with the plate you have before you at the time."
"It's a safe course in a gloomy environment to be even gloomier," he added. "It's a comfortable position. But the city has demonstrated time and time again that it can overcome the pessimism of the savants."

HEADLINE: Whites May Decide Mayor In Multi-Ethnic Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 5

 BODY:
In its final days, the race for mayor of Los Angeles has become a slugging match whose closeness embodies the paradox of this multi-ethnic city where the white electorate has a disproportionately decisive voice.
The next mayor will confront immediate budgetary and public safety problems, and also long-term questions of the city's evolving ethnic identity, yet the campaign has been reduced to an exchange of name-calling, with neither candidate offering much in the way of a broad vision. 
 Most public opinion polls and political analysts agree that the nonpartisan race between City Councilman Michael Woo, a 41-year-old Democrat, and Richard Riordan, a 63-year-old Republican millionaire businessman, is too close to call.
They also agree that turnout will be a decisive factor, with Mr. Woo leading in polls representing all registered voters but Mr. Riordan appearing to have an edge among people who are likely to vote.
 
Riordan's Deep Pockets
 In Los Angeles, this means Mr. Riordan has a solid base among white and Republican voters, many of whom live in the San Fernando Valley. Mr. Woo has greater appeal among minorities and the poor, groups that traditionally vote in lower numbers.
Mr. Riordan's campaign is by far the best-financed: he has poured $6 million of his own money into the race, and potential voters have been inundated by impressively produced mailed appeals.
Perhaps in response, Mr. Woo has mounted the sharpest attacks, keeping Mr. Riordan on the defensive. The Councilman has also won the endorsement of President Clinton and other Democratic officials, though there is some question as to how helpful these endorsements have been.
There has been a brief lull in the final days as Mr. Riordan traveled to New Rochelle, N.Y., to attend his mother's funeral on Friday. But Sunday and Monday nights could be decisive as the candidates face each other in televised debates.
 
'Enormous Revenue Problems'
 Within his first weeks in office, the winner will face painful budget decisions that could color his entire term in office.
"The success or failure of either one is going to be determined rather quickly," said Larry Berg, a political scientist at the University of Southern California. "He is going to be faced with enormous revenue problems and he's going to have to deliver, and deliver quickly. There's not going to be any honeymoon."
The election for the four-year term is a runoff between the two top finishers in an April 20 vote among 24 candidates. It marks a watershed in Los Angeles, which has been transformed into a major metropolis, now sinking under the weight of urban problems, during the 20-year leadership of the retiring Mayor, Tom Bradley.
As it has grown to a population of 3.5 million, with black, Asian and Hispanic residents making up the majority, the city has been struggling to redefine itself. But although roughly two-thirds of the residents are member of minority groups, more than two-thirds of voters are non-Hispanic whites.
Recent data from the Census Bureau and the Registrar of Voters show that whites make up 37 percent of the city's population, but 64 percent of its voters. Hispanic residents are 40 percent of the population but only 11 percent of voters, partly because many are not citizens. Blacks make up 14 percent of residents and 20 percent of voters. Asians are 9 percent of residents and 3 percent of voters. The remaining 2 percent of voters are listed as others.
 
'High-Propensity Voter'
 The profile of Mr. Riordan's supporters is the profile of what political analysts call the "high-propensity voter": older, more moderate or conservative, better educated, well-off, white. Many of Mr. Woo's backers are minorities, poor, younger and less educated.
"It's astounding to think that the voters who are making the decisions for the city will not be the people most needing the services and policies made by the elected leaders," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political scientist at Claremont Graduate School.
To catch the attention of the voters, both candidates have hammered away at the simple themes of public safety and the economy, and at each other.
"I think I have the right to call Mr. Woo a liar," Mr. Riordan said in a recent radio debate during which Mr. Woo called Mr. Riordan "the epitome of unbridled '80s greed."
Both men have promised to increase greatly the size of the police force, Mr. Riordan by selling off Los Angeles International Airport, Mr. Woo by trimming government budgets. Independent analyses have raised doubts as to whether either of these plans would generate the needed revenue.
 
Called for Gates's Resignation
 A cornerstone of Mr. Woo's campaign is that he was the first City Council member to call for the resignation of former Police Chief Daryl F. Gates after the March 1991 beating by police officers of Rodney G. King.
Mr. Riordan offers himself as a can-do businessman whose campaign placards visually imitate those of Ross Perot. He asserts that he has saved thousands of jobs in company restructurings, while Mr. Woo asserts that Mr. Riordan has instead cost thousands of jobs.
The major event of the campaign in its climactic week was the disclosure by Mr. Riordan that he was arrested twice in the 1960's and 1970's for drunk driving and once for interfering with a police officer in an alcohol-related incident.
Mr. Woo has pounded away at the issue, demanding that Mr. Riordan "come clean with the full truth about his criminal record."
Mr. Riordan has responded: "There is no cover-up. I've had three arrests. I've revealed that to the public, and the public now has to make up its mind about Dick Riordan."
A more effective response has been Mr. Riordan's endorsement by the local police union and by the Los Angeles County Sheriff, Sherman Block.
 
Endorsement Game
 Mr. Woo has also reminded voters of a flippant remark by Mr. Riordan in 1988 in which he was quoted as saying, "I'm taking lessons in learning how to wave to poor people."
Mr. Riordan's most effective response has been to enlist the aggressive support of Stan Sanders, a black lawyer who ran in the first round of the election for mayor and who now appears in a television advertisement saying, "Dick Riordan doesn't have a racist bone in his body."
Mr. Riordan has also gained the endorsements of five of Mr. Woo's colleagues on the City Council, while only three have endorsed Mr. Woo. Some of those who back Mr. Riordan have struck some of the lower blows on his behalf, one of them calling Mr. Woo "a snot-nosed kid" who is "not ready to be mayor."
Although the race is officially nonpartisan, it has become one of the most politically partisan here in recent years. High-profile Democrats, including President Clinton, have traveled to Los Angeles to endorse Mr. Woo.
The President's endorsement, however, was lukewarm as he took pains not to criticize Mr. Riordan, who counts a number of strong Clinton supporters on his staff. "I endorsed Mike Woo, not because I have something against his opponent; I don't," Mr. Clinton said as Mr. Woo stood beside him. Polls show that the endorsement appears to have had little effect on voters.

HEADLINE: Germany's Young Turks Say 'Enough' to the Bias

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 5

 BODY:
A 22-year-old Berlin woman who is pursuing a degree in business administration reflects one of Germany's greatest resources and, at the same time, one of its most troubling challenges.
She is bright, articulate and opinionated, and looks forward to a productive career that will be both lucrative and socially responsible. But although she was born and raised in Berlin and has never left her homeland except for vacations, she remains an outsider, viewed suspiciously by many Germans and with outright hostility by some. 
 The woman, Senay Kocadag, is the daughter of Turkish immigrants. Her birth here did not entitle her to German citizenship, as birth in the United States entitles a person to American citizenship. And the application for citizenship that she filed more than a year ago is languishing somewhere in the bureaucracy.
 
'Completely at Home'
 "Of course it's frustrating," Miss Kocadag said as she reflected on the difficulties of living between two worlds. "I'm completely at home here, and when I visit Turkey I feel like a foreigner. But this society doesn't want to recognize me or accept me as German."
Hundreds of thousands of Turkish workers were invited to Germany in the 1960's and 1970's, and their labor helped make this country one of the world's economic titans. The sons and daughters of these migrants are now emerging as a new class, no longer truly Turkish but not fully welcome in the land that they consider home.
There are more than 1.8 million Turks among Germany's 80 million people, making them the country's largest minority. Two-thirds have lived here for at least a decade, and of those, nearly 350,000 have been here for more than 20 years. Their largest and best-established community is in Berlin, where 140,000 live and work.
But German law and custom, which is based largely on principles that date from the late 19th century, make it very hard for Turks or other foreigners to obtain German citizenship. An ethnic German who lives in Russia and has had no contact with Germany for generations is entitled to citizenship almost automatically, as is a child or grandchild of Germans living in Africa or South America. But applicants with no German blood face a host of obstacles, even if they have lived their whole lives here.
 
A Display of Outrage
 For years this anomaly posed no great problem to Turkish workers here, because most never stopped thinking of themselves as Turks. They sent money to relatives at home, returned regularly to visit their native towns, and had little or no interest in becoming part of German society.
But the sons and daughters of these "guest workers" are now coming of age, and the experience of growing up in Germany has made them quite different from their parents.
Their growing assertiveness was illustrated after the firebombing in Solingen last Saturday, which left five Turkish women and girls dead. Groups of young Turks, joined by Germans who support them, rampaged through the streets for several nights, breaking shop windows and smashing parked cars in an unusual display of outrage.
Like many children of Turkish parents here, Miss Kocadag thinks the violent protests were justified.
"When I saw the TV pictures, I thought, 'Thank God, finally people are reacting,' " she said. "This is the only way we are ever going to be noticed or taken seriously. The candlelight processions and petitions haven't produced results.
"Suddenly people are talking seriously about our situation here. That isn't because of the bombing. It's because we're finally saying that we're fed up. If you're positive, you never get anything. Nothing happens in this country without pressure from below."
Although there were periodic outbreaks of violence against foreigners in both East Germany and West Germany, the current wave began after the two nations were unified in 1990. According to police statistics, assaults by rightists led to 17 deaths in 1992.
Many Germans came to believe that tensions would ease if the country's liberal asylum law was tightened, and Parliament responded to their pressure last month by adopting a more restrictive law. But the Solingen attack came less than a week later, making the five Turks who died there the first fatalities of 1993.
 
Parents Are Shocked
 Behind the protests that followed the Solingen firebombing lie a complicated and often contradictory mix of emotions that shape what is called the "second generation" of Turks in Germany. Their parents came here as laborers, and earned a reputation as hard working, quiet and grateful for the chance to live here. They almost never mixed in politics, and many are shocked to see the assertiveness that their children are beginning to show.
"My father is worried because I'm giving interviews and making public statements about what happened in Solingen," said Zehra Cirak, who came to Germany as a 3-year-old in 1963 and has become a prominent German-language poet. "He's afraid something might happen to me, and he would like me to stay quiet. But my generation feels that we have a right to participate in every aspect of German life. We aren't as timid as our parents."
Miss Cirak was able to obtain German citizenship several years ago. The application procedure took nearly two years, and fees totaled about $800, but she was finally successful because she fulfilled the strict criteria set by German law and immigration rules.
Between 1977 and 1990, the last period for which statistics are available, about 13,000 Turks were granted German citizenship. Most had either been born here or come as small children, and had attended German grammar schools. They had to show that they had mastered the German language, had never been in trouble with the police, and had steady jobs and permanent residences.
But even some who fulfill these qualifications are turned down. Immigration officials have considerable leeway, and can reject applicants without giving detailed explanations.
Ozgur Bozkurt, a 20-year-old student who came here at the age of 8, is among the lucky ones who has obtained German citizenship. But his 7-year-old sister, who was born in Berlin, is considered a foreigner.
"I feel that she has been the victim of a racist attack," Mr. Bozkurt said. "She is stamped as an outsider, even though she speaks perfect German and feels completely at home here.
"People of my generation are caught between two cultures. Our parents identify with Turkish culture, but we don't. We're in the middle. We don't feel really Turkish, but Germany doesn't want us."
 
Going Back Loses Its Appeal
 Neither Mr. Bozkurt nor anyone he knows has ever been physically threatened, and although he prefers not to walk alone through certain neighborhoods after dark, he rarely feels uncomfortable or endangered. Worse than the threat of being attacked, he said, is the discrimination he and others who do not look like typical Germans endure at the hands of government officials.
"The police are the worst," he said. "If you go into a police station to ask for something, they automatically assume that you're some kind of criminal. You see the same thing when you go into a housing office or a welfare office. The way they treat you is completely different from the way they treat people they consider to be 'real Germans.' "
Mr. Bozkurt's father came to Germany in 1972 to work as a machinist at a Siemens plant. After a few years he moved to a smaller company, where his fellow workers have elected him their union shop steward.
"Ninety percent of us came here with the idea that we would go back to Turkey after a couple of years," the elder Mr. Bozkurt said. "But we brought our families here, we got used to living in an orderly and disciplined society, and we began to like going out to the theater and concerts and films. We earn good money. Our kids don't feel especially Turkish. The appeal of going back begins to fade. I may go back after I retire, but not before."
Although almost all of the Turks who came here in past decades were laborers, the "second generation" has produced a group of sophisticated intellectuals who are pressing Germany to change its policies toward residents who have foreign backgrounds. Several are now campaigning for a new law that would allow Turks to be granted dual citizenship without the obstacles that now exist.
"Our generation identifies very strongly with Germany, and we want to make this a more multicultural society," said Zafer Senocak, an essayist and social critic. "We are systematically excluded from every aspect of German political life. For the last 10 years, politicians have been talking about the 'foreigner problem,' and that has created the climate we are living through today.
"I don't hold the kids responsible, even the ones who set fire to houses. The Government in Bonn is responsible. Even now, we aren't seeing any real change in attitude. We are systematically discriminated against, and the kids are starting to react aggressively."

HEADLINE: DENTAL COVERAGE URGED BY EXPERTS

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
As the nation ponders what to do for 37 million Americans who lack medical insurance, many health experts say it is also time to extend basic dental benefits to the 150 million Americans who lack such coverage.
That would be a break with tradition. The last time the country passed sweeping health programs, in the mid-1960's, dentistry was all but ignored. Medicare, the program for the elderly, provides no dental care while Medicaid, for the poor, offers only spotty and shrinking coverage. 
 But experts have warned that failure to provide preventive care exacts larger future costs as Americans, especially the poor, the elderly and immigrants, needlessly suffer tooth decay, gum disease and loss of teeth. "Dentistry is part of comprehensive care," said Dr. Edward G. Kaufman, dean of the New York University College of Dentistry.
This time, President Clinton's advisers are listening, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, head of the President's Task Force on Health Care Reform, said on May 25 that she hoped to include some dental benefits in the core package of health benefits the Administration will propose for all Americans. Mrs. Clinton's group wants to cover all dental needs of children and partial care for adults. The President has not made a final decision.
 
Many Political Snares
 But as usual in the health field, what may sound simple and sensible is complicated and full of political snares for the White House as the final plan is prepared.
Even as they criticize the lack of coverage for poor people, practicing dentists say they would rather not be part of any national health plan, in part because they fear the Government controls and managed care to which doctors may be subjected.
And while including basic dental benefits in the health plan would help the poor, it could also leave many middle-class people with less coverage than they have now.
"If, as a result of health reform, employees lose dental coverage they have now, or have to pay a lot more, they'll be unhappy," said Frank B. McArdle of Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm.
In recent years many companies have begun to offer dental benefits. Today about 95 million people, or 40 percent of the population, have private dental insurance of varying generosity, according to the Public Health Service.
 
Much Neglect Is Reported
 Still, most Americans must pay dental costs out of pocket. Although many poor people can get free medical care for the slightest illness, they often find it almost impossible to get a cavity filled. Some elderly people, especially in nursing homes, have inadequate care too, surveys show. Even some uninsured middle-class people put off routine dental visits because of the cost.
Public-health groups, dental colleges and some specialty groups, joined in a Coalition for Oral Health, have urged Mr. Clinton and Congress to include basic dental care in a standard health insurance package. Prevention and treatment of common dental disease for both children and adults would cost about $7.1 billion a year, the coalition estimates.
But the American Dental Association, which represents private dentists, has argued against wrapping dentistry into the health package. While it supports Government aid to poor people, it wants dentistry outside the medical plan, perhaps using vouchers that allow people to use private dentists.
"We don't think you should go out and disrupt something that's working very well for most people," said Dr. John S. Zapp, executive director of the association.
 
Prevention Pays Off
 The Clinton health-care group especially wants to insure that children are covered, said Linda A. Bergthold, a leader of the working group on benefits. "If we really cover children well now, then in the future we won't have the kind of dental problems we see in adults," said Ms. Bergthold, an officer of William M. Mercer Inc., a benefits consulting firm.
To the extent adults were not covered by the Federal plan, she added, they would be free to get extra coverage from their employers or to buy it themselves. But then another issue arises: Will dental benefits beyond those in the official plan remain tax deductible, as they are now? Or would they be taxed, as Mr. Clinton may propose for extra medical benefits, meaning many workers would pay more to keep existing coverage?
No matter how care is extended, dental professionals make a powerful case that in this field, even more starkly than in medicine generally, prevention saves money and pain.
A transformation of dental care has created huge disparities in oral health between generations and economic classes. More than one-third of the elderly have no teeth. People now in middle-age are less likely to lose their teeth, but grew up with many cavities and require extensive repair work.
But today with proper maintenance including professional cleaning, fluoridation and use of plastic sealants on biting surfaces, many children grow up without any cavities at all.

HEADLINE: As Thousands Cheer Him On, Perot Presses Familiar Themes

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 5

 BODY:
Taking aim at some of his favorite targets and repeating familiar themes from his Presidential campaign, Ross Perot touched down at a small airport here today to exhort thousands of his enthusiastic supporters to stay active in politics.
The rally, organized by the New Jersey branch of Mr. Perot's grass-roots voter group, United We Stand America, was billed as a get-out-the-vote rally in anticipation of the gubernatorial and legislative primary elections in New Jersey on Tuesday. But judging from the rousing reception that Mr. Perot received when he appeared on the stage in the cavernous hangar at Allaire Airport here, about 40 miles south of New York City near the Jersey Shore, it seemed more like a get-out-and-see-Ross rally. 
 Between 2,500 and 3,000 supporters, some wearing buttons proclaiming "Perot in '96," filled the seats to hear Mr. Perot rail against lobbyists and government bureaucrats, criticize the budget deficit and vilify American companies that move operations to other countries. He also used his appearance as an opportunity to attack some of the policies and initiatives favored by the Clinton Administration, such as the North American Free Trade Agreement and the President's proposal for the establishment of a trust fund to reduce the deficit.
 
Continuing Popularity
 "How many of you have heard of the deficit trust fund?" Mr. Perot asked his audience. "Is there anyone in this giant hangar who thinks it will work?"
"No!" the crowd thundered back.
It is a measure of Mr. Perot's continuing popularity here -- he won 16 percent of the New Jersey vote in the November presidential election -- that his rally not only attracted dozens of people who described themselves as independents running in legislative primaries on Tuesday, but also the three leading candidates for the Republican nomination for governor.
The contenders, Jim Wallwork, Christine Todd Whitman and Cary Edwards, all worked the crowd at the back of the hangar before Mr. Perot's arrival. Some of them tried to align themselves with the aphorisms and ideas that Mr. Perot embraces about government reform.
"Ross Perot says you have to get under the hood and fix the engine," Mr. Edwards, a former state attorney general, said as he pumped hands in the hangar. "I can lift the hood and I can fix the engine because I know how it works."
 
Not Backing Candidates
 C. J. Barthelenghi, executive director of United We Stand America in New Jersey, said her group had asked Mr. Perot to speak to help motivate members to vote in the primary, even though neither Mr. Perot nor United We Stand is backing any particular candidates.
"Our goal is to get people into the primary process," she said. "A lot of decisions get made at the primary level. We are trying to draw awareness to that."
In fact, some members of the organization became so motivated as a result of their volunteer work for Mr. Perot last year that they decided to run in this year's State Assembly and Senate races. Mrs. Barthelenghi said that those in leadership positions in United We Stand who chose to run were asked to step down from their posts in the organization, although they could remain members of the group.
Today, dozens of those candidates, running as independents or for the Democratic or Republican nominations in various legislative districts, came to the rally seeking support. Each was given one minute to speak, and waited, like supermarket shoppers on a long checkout line, for their moment at the podium. Among them, the common themes seemed to be the need to reduce spending and to make government more responsive to citizens.
 
'I Don't Want a Job'
 One such candidate was Adrian K. Stevens, who served as Monmouth County campaign manager for Mr. Perot last year and is now seeking the Republican nomination for an Assembly seat. "I don't want a job. I don't want a contract. I want responsible government," said Mr. Stevens, who added that it was Mr. Perot who inspired him to run.
At the podium, Mr. Perot was jocular, relaxed and at times hard to follow as he leapt from one topic to another during an address that lasted for more than an hour. At one point, he announced, without providing any source for his assertion, that one of four Americans now wanted to be members of United We Stand. At another point, he said Mr. Clinton's economic program would add another $1 trillion to the nation's deficit.
In an apparent allusion to recent reports of dissension within the ranks of his organization, Mr. Perot said he relished the attacks because they only increased interest in the group. "Every time they hit us, the membership just zooms up," he said, as the audience roared its approval.

HEADLINE: Signs of Blast Fading, but Tremors Remain

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
The spacious elevators, stuffed with executives and camera-toting tourists, are once again gliding like zippers up and down the towers of the World Trade Center. New windows have replaced shattered ones. Fresh paint covers smoke-stained walls.
Except for a few posters referring to "repairs" and a phalanx of guards checking new identification cards, there are few signs that just three months ago, a huge explosion ripped through the trade center's underground garage, killing six people and sending tens of thousands scrambling down smoke-filled stairwells to safety. 
 But while most workers in the complex have returned to their desks, interviews with dozens of men and women make it clear that impact of the Feb. 26 explosion lingers on.
Some people talk of emotional scars that have not yet healed. A man smells burning rubber and dissolves in tears. A woman feels pangs of anxiety each time she passes the office water cooler that she used to wet towels to hold over her mouth during the evacuation. And now, tucked inside countless employees' bags and briefcases are newly acquired flashlights, cellular telephones or smoke masks. Just in case.
 
An Aching Vulnerability
 "My flashlight fits right in my purse," said Joanne Mannarino, an accounting clerk who says she still has sinus problems from the smoke she inhaled while groping down 50 flights of stairs. "I will not go down in the elevator without it. Not now."
Others describe unexpected bonds forged between colleagues and even among strangers who helped each other hobble down the dark stairwells or scratched their collective way out of stalled elevators.
After the blast, hundreds of people sought treatment for injuries or attended counseling sessions provided by their employers or the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns and operates the trade center. Others sought help through city services or private doctors.
And while only a few patients remain in treatment, counselors said, laborers and top executives alike say that for almost everyone, fallout from the attack still lingers.
Kathleen A. Carney, a 32-year-old office worker at Dai Ichi Kangyo Bank, has flashbacks to the panic she felt just moments after the blast when she rushed down a smoky stairwell to a door that was always open and found it locked.
 
Long Echoes of Panic
 Patricia S. Barbanti, 44, a legal secretary, spent 10 days edging her way back into the building -- moving a few steps closer each day until, accompanied by a counselor, she crept through the door. Now she regularly checks the back entrance to the trade center for signs of danger. She says that since the mob scene on the stairwells that day, she has become claustrophobic and had to give up a planned airplane trip this spring to visit her ailing father-in-law.
And Eugene J. Fasullo, director of engineering with the Port Authority, who pried open the doors of a smoke-filled elevator and clawed his way through the wall of the elevator shaft, said he feels rushes of anger toward the bombers -- an emotion that didn't surface until weeks after the blast.
"Looking around, you'd never know a bomb went off here," said Charles J. Maikish, director of the World Trade Department for the Port Authority. "But you can feel the aftereffects."
Mr. Maikish says loud noises still make him jump. And during meetings about budgets and business plans, he said, he finds his mind drifting to matters of repairs and safety that have to do with the bombing. "I have to make myself focus," he said.
 
'The Incident'
 Yet others find themselves shaking their heads at how quickly things have returned -- or appear to have returned -- to normal.
"It is amazing to me," said Oscar E. Correa, a 33-year-old transportation planner who was working for the Port Authority at the time of the blast and who walked through the lobby on a recent afternoon. "The bombing is referred to now as 'the incident.' It's as if it never happened. It's very strange."
At the time of the explosion, dozens of workers vowed never to return to the Twin Towers. But so far few have actually quit or asked for transfers, according to individual company spokesmen and their employees.
Renee Amgar, a Trans World Airways ticket agent who was forced to crawl along the lobby floor to safety, says that her concerns about returning to work in Tower One lasted only a few days. "After that," she said, smiling over the lobby's ticket counter, "routine takes over."
Experts who specialize in post-traumatic stress syndrome, a disorder for which symptoms can take weeks or months to emerge, say such routines either help people recover or become tools to suppress anxieties, depending on the personality.
"Most are doing better," said Dr. Leslie Baliff, supervising psychologist at Beth Israel Medical Center, who is still treating several people as a result of the blast. "But those who are doing worse fit into two categories -- those who were up close to more traumatic aspects of the blast, who lost co-workers or supervisors or who saw the building coming down, and those who had some anxieties or fears to begin with. For people who would ride anxiously in the elevators before, obviously it is more anxiety-provoking now."
 
Disturbing Dreams
 Sara Kahn, a social worker from an industrial psychology consulting firm, who is still counseling some trade center workers, said some employees still talk about nightmares (one woman dreamed her son's wedding was on top of Tower One and she had to walk up thousands of steps with the guests). Others have flashbacks to family deaths, the campus disturbances of the 1960's or other traumatic events.
One woman, said Ms. Kahn, flashed to a time of revolution in South America, where she was born, when she was forced to hide in a basement for weeks. "She said that it was a horrendous event to be in the middle of a revolution," Ms. Kahn said. "But she said that wasn't nearly as stressful as the World Trade Center event. She said that when you live in Latin America, part of the landscape is an occasional revolution. She didn't expect to be sitting at her computer and experience a terrorist bomb attack."
Dr. Baliff, Ms. Kahn and others say that some workers have struggled with the relatively quick reopening of the trade center and the resumption of business as usual.
"Employees have said they felt a pressure to perform as if nothing happened, and that adds an additional stress," said Ms. Kahn. "Especially for employees who are in power positions, like executives or lawyers, the imperative is that they look invincible and invulnerable. It's very difficult to maintain that facade when inside you are the victim of a tragedy like everyone else."
Whatever the lingering impact on employees, the trade center and its tenants have largely rebounded. Although some experts had predicted that companies would drop their leases because of the bombing, Mr. Maikish, who oversees the complex, said that occupancy is up, from 88 percent before the blast to 92 percent, and 70 to 80 percent of companies who had to decide whether to renew their leases since the bombing are staying -- no more or less than usual.
Louis Cavalera, a vice president for marketing with Gray Line New York Tours, said that the tide of 5,000 to 7,000 yearly visitors to the trade center's observatory, which reopened April 17, has not ebbed. The attack is not mentioned during Gray Line's daylong tour of Manhattan, he said. "It's like someone died," he quipped. "Why keep talking about it?"
 
Help, Help and More Help
 He and others point to efforts by the Port Authority and others to deal with the psychological, physical and economic impact of the blast.
The city's Department of Mental Health, in conjunction with the Greater New York Red Cross, maintained a 24-hour telephone line for more than a month, with six counselors who answered questions and made referrals to clinics and doctors who offered pro bono services to blast survivors.
The Port Authority offered free flashlights, gas masks and counseling to all workers in the buildings. Its special recovery program gave tenant businesses $150 per employee and paid all moving expenses to temporary office space. Last month, the authority underwrote a weeklong sale for local retailers, called the "Spring Back Celebration" and has paid for newspaper and magazine advertisements for those companies as well. All paid, it was a $15 million goodwill effort.
Inside their offices, executives have tried to focus on the positive, and they and employees point to unexpected side effects of the blast. In one sense, they say a kind of bunker camaraderie has developed, a bond that has helped quiet sniping around the water coolers.
In some companies, middle managers, forced to make high-level decisions on the spot, performed so well that several top executives say they are re-evaluating some decision-making procedures. Office heroes have been given bonuses, all-expense paid vacations and the unbounded gratitude of colleagues -- or strangers -- whom they helped to safety.
Mr. Fasullo speaks with deep respect of the eight men and women trapped for hours in Elevator Car 70 with him. They used a nail file, key and money clip to pry open the doors of the dark, smoky elevator, then scratch their way through the wall of elevator shaft into a bathroom on the 58th floor. Lights from their beepers illuminated their work.
"We expanded who we were," he says. "We were nine of us in this elevator and let me tell you it was scary as hell. But no one panicked. No one said anything inappropriate. Some people sat down and were quiet. But everyone was supportive."
Like several other high-level employees, Mr. Fasullo said that at the time, he was too busy with work to seek professional counseling. In fact, it was not until weeks after the bombing that he watched the first news of the event. That night, he recalled, he and his wife sat and cried.
 
'I Feel Anger'
 "I never talked to a counselor, though at this point in time, it probably would have been smart," he said, his voice still scratchy from the smoke inhalation. "But I'm kind of a street kid from Brooklyn, and we never dealt with life that way. Everything we met, we had to cope with. And at this point in time, I feel perfectly fine. I feel anger at the bombing itself. But I feel fine."
What has changed, he said, is his gratitude for having survived.
"What's different is that saying 'it's a pleasure to be here' really means something to me now. I delegate more to my staff. Things that I used to try to handle myself because I thought they were so important, now I realize are not so important. And with my children, when I say that I love them, it's no longer words."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Few visible signs of the explosion at the World Trade Center remain, but the impact is lingering on. New identification cards and lines of people waiting for visitors' passes are part of the new security. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times) (pg. 42)

HEADLINE: A Packager's View of Recycling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We commend the article "Who Foots the Bill for Recycling?" (April 25). As long-time packaging consultants, however, we see somewhat different problems and note that all the interviewees are members of the waste management and environmental faction, rather than of the packaging community. 
 Newspapers, magazines, telephone books and fourth-class mail constitute the major proportion of household and business waste, but these items appear to be exempt from the environmentalists' allegations. Paper can be and has been truly recycled for more than a century, but the current situation is appalling. So much scrap paper is collected that the market price has collapsed.
Packaging is indispensable to the delivery of goods to consumers, plastic has reduced its mass significantly, and when there are true (not government-imposed) economic incentives for recycling, it will occur. Some of our brethren suggest that the environmentalists be isolated without packaged goods so that they might experience the spoilage, filth and illness of the 19th century to which they seem to want to revert. The mass of scrap and their significantly shortened lives might cause them to alter their opinions.
 
AARON L. BRODY, Ph.D.
Eagan, Minn., May 21
 
The author is managing director of Rubbright/Brody Inc.

HEADLINE: Currency: The Real Problem Abroad

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was startled to read "What Hasn't Worked Abroad . . ." (Viewpoints, May 2), in which it was claimed that high taxes and social programs were responsible for European budget deficits running 5.4 percent to our 4.3 percent of gross domestic product. 
 Startled because I was about to mail to my Swedish relatives a chart from the Jan. 23 Economist covering budget balances as a percentage of G.D.P. for 19 countries for 1989 and the forecasts for 1993. Seven countries were in surplus in 1989, and of all of them Sweden -- that high-tax country with extensive social programs and 2 percent unemployment -- led with a surplus of 5.6 percent of G.D.P.
In 1989, the United States deficit was less than 2 percent and yes, at 4.3 percent it is getting worse and we should be doing something about it. But the most dramatic fall from grace is Sweden. In 1993, it is projected to have a deficit of around 12 percent. How did that happen? It wasn't high taxes or social spending.
In the autumn of 1991, during Sweden's elections, both the Conservatives and the Social Democrats indicated a desire to join the European Community, which meant aligning currencies with the European monetary unit, i.e. the German mark. But the costs of German unification and Bonn's failure to raise taxes led the Bundesbank to raise interest rates to control inflation. That pushed up the mark. The straw that broke the camel's back was when Finland, devastated by its loss of trade with Russia and Eastern Europe, was forced to devalue. The next weak link was Sweden.
Now, world money markets have been deregulated and computerized, with daily round-the-clock electronic transactions totaling $1 trillion or so. So when the currency speculators homed in on Sweden, it had to capitulate. It devalued.
The European countries are all in recession and all in debt and none more so than Sweden. Who got the money? Not the recipients of social programs, although they will be asked to pay for it. The international currency speculators had a good day.
 
HELEN MYERS
Claremont, Calif., May 13

HEADLINE: A Victorian Jewel That's Also a Mine for Musical Theater

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
WHEN the announcement was made to preserve rather than demolish the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in 1959, Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff declared: "This to me is very important for the country's soul."
A whirl of musicales, soirees and benefits of all sorts, even plaster ripping parties, followed for the purpose of raising the $500,000 required to restore the many splendored showplace, then being used by the State Highway Department as a storage depot. And for the four years it took to complete, the restoration of the four-story Opry House -- a frequent spelling at the time it was built in 1876 -- on the banks of the Connecticut River was the talk of eastern Connecticut. Sightseers paid 50 cents for a tour of the work in progress on Saturdays between 2 and 4 P.M. By varying accounts, about twice the amount needed for the restoration came in, and the reopening of Goodspeed, a victory for esthetics and for civilization, took place on June 18, 1963. And the show that marked its rebirth in Victorian splendor was "Oh Lady! Lady!" by Jerome Kern. 
 But it took Michael P. Price to transform a community arts and summer stock center, with a grab bag repertory, to a musical theater with a mission, and to place the Goodspeed Opera House in a singular spot on the national musical theater map.
Now Goodspeed is celebrating its 30th anniversary as a prototype of grand architectural preservation, and Mr. Price his 25th as executive director. And as it becomes increasingly commonplace to complain about the decline of traditional American musical theater, evidenced by the meager assortment of best musical nominations for the Tony Awards, being broadcast on television tonight, the Goodspeed Opera House is flourishing. And Mr. Price is not complaining.
For the 398-seat theater with a structure that has inspired writers to metaphors of wedding cakes, dollhouses and jewelboxes -- gemlike may be the most recurring adjective -- has made an indelible name for preserving musicals, too. That was acknowledged by a special Tony Award in 1980 for Goodspeed's "contribution to musical theater in general and its contribution to the Broadway theater." By then, 10 musicals -- most famously, "Annie" -- had traveled from East Haddam to New York; the number is now 14.
Three musicals -- usually two in revival, one in emergence -- are produced in a season that has been expanded from 8 to 36 weeks since Mr. Price took over.
And Goodspeed's stature -- which prompted Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to say that the theater rivals any in the United States -- has, as well, come to encompass the development of musicals. Its tryout theater, five miles away and 10 years old next year, carries the unwieldy name Goodspeed-at-Chester/The Norma Terris Theater. (The theater was named in honor of the musical comedy star and local philanthropist who died in Old Lyme in 1989.)
A continuation of "Annie," then called "Annie 2" and now scheduled for an August opening Off Broadway under the title "Annie Warbucks," had one of many ever-changing tryouts at the 200-seat Chester Theater, a renovated factory whose opening show, "Harrigan 'n Hart" moved to Broadway.
The auxiliary theater has been significant to lyricists like Sheldon Harnick, who had Goodspeed Productions of two of his musicals, "Fiorello" and "She Loves Me," and who said: "Goodspeed has been important to our country's musical theater's past -- and with its second stage in Chester, it is just as important to its future."
In a sense, Mr. Price is accountable for Goodspeed's second rebirth, just five years after its first. After putting on little operas, Gilbert and Sullivan, vaudeville and musicals of convenience like "The Fantasticks," Goodspeed, under Albert Selden's managing direction, was once more imperiled, after five years.
When Mr. Selden departed, Mr. Price -- hired for the first season as general manager, then discharged because of artistic differences -- was brought back, this time, and so it still seems, for keeps.
 
Maybe 'Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'?
 "The musical is alive and well here -- and it sends greetings from East Haddam -- and will continue to do that," said Mr. Price, estimating that Goodspeed receives 175 new musical scripts a year and reeling off oldies on his wish list for revivals: "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" and "Mack and Mabel."
"We haven't had a decline," Mr. Price added, conceding that the theater plays at 95 percent capacity -- the figure has been up to 97 percent -- "But it's nothing worrisome."
While the Goodspeed repertory remains conservative, the theater's younger audiences are reflecting a change in ticket-buying patterns. "People buy tickets on shorter notice instead of weeks in advance," Mr. Price said. "It used to be thought that you could never get a ticket but now we're selling out day by day," he said, referring to the non-subscription seats that account for 50 percent of the theater's capacity.
For all the attention lavished upon the Goodspeed moves to Broadway -- "Shenandoah" and "Very Good Eddie" were two of the more successful ones in the 1970's -- Mr. Price remains adamant about the theater's priority: To remain a repository of vintage musicals for local audiences, even though it was one of the notions of his predecessor to use the theater as a spawning ground for New York, especially after the success of "Man of La Mancha," which had a Goodspeed premiere during Mr. Selden's tenure in 1965.
More important, particularly for the economic survival of musical theaters countrywide, are Goodspeed's shared or co-productions, Mr. Price said. Productions of "Bells Are Ringing" from East Haddam and "Abyssinia" from Chester, for example, went on to other theaters in Michigan, in Washington, D.C., and elsewhere. "In Connecticut, we're like an industry that exports," Mr. Price said.
After the current production of "On the Town," the Goodspeed anniversary season is to consist of "Heartbeats," a new musical that had a preliminary run in Chester last season and is returning to East Haddam after a run at the Cleveland Playhouse. It is to be followed by a new production of "Promises, Promises" -- a 1960's musical that represents a rare foray into what, for a Goodspeed revival once linked with the 20's and 30's, might well seem like post-modernism. In Chester, "Das Barbecu," a country Western spoof of Wagner's Ring cycle, is to run through June 27.
Asserting his position, above all, as an aficionado of musicals, Mr. Price said, "We're more diversified than we were at the beginning. And I can't wait to see 'Promises, Promises.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Among the plays that have been presented over 30 seasons at the Goodspeed Opera House are "Little Johnny Jones," top, "Going Up," center, and "Annie" (Photographs by Wilson H. Brownell) (pg. 1); Michael P. Price, executive director of the Goodspeed. (Diane Sobolewski)

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Clinton Coattails Debated After Senate Loss in Texas

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Has President Clinton become such a political pariah that he drove hordes of Texans to the polls on Saturday to vote for a Republican, Kay Bailey Hutchison, to the United States Senate?
Probably not. The Democratic incumbent, Senator Bob Krueger, had problems of his own, like being such a dreadful campaigner that his campaign produced television commercials extolling that fact. Besides, analysts warn against making too much of whether any President has "coattails" that significantly affect a local election for better or for worse. 
 But Mr. Clinton's plunging popularity certainly did not help matters, as Mrs. Hutchison's campaign was waged as much against Mr. Clinton as against Mr. Krueger. At every turn, Mrs. Hutchinson, who is the Texas State Treasurer, attacked the President's proposal for tax increases.
 
Unexpected Margin
 To the Republicans who call the election a referendum on Mr. Clinton, the Democrats' response is hardly reassuring to the President: How could it be a referendum, they ask, when even Mr. Krueger stayed clear of Mr. Clinton and derided his proposed energy tax?
While it is debatable how much Mrs. Hutchison owes to Mr. Clinton, it is clear that the outcome is another big embarrassment for the President at a time when nothing seems to be going right for him. Mrs. Hutchison's victory was the first that gives Republicans both Texas Senate seats since Reconstruction.
Though she entered the race as the heavy favorite, the degree of Mrs. Hutchison's rout was unexpected: she drew 1,183,766 votes, or 67.3 percent, to Senator Krueger's 574,089 votes, or 32.7 percent.
Armed with those percentages, Republicans today wasted no time in seizing on Mrs. Hutchison's victory as a public repudiation of Mr. Clinton's economic program, and White House officials lamented the loss of what could have been a critical Democratic vote for the President's economic package. Mrs Hutchison, who will take office in the next few days, has vowed to fight the plan.
Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, was so delighted that he called up reporters after the votes were tallied Saturday night to tell them that the outcome will "send shock waves" through the Senate. "Texas voters," he said triumphantly, "may have saved the economy by getting Clinton to back off on his tax package."
Democrats close to Mr. Clinton were hard pressed to explain Mr. Krueger's defeat -- except to insist that Mr. Clinton had nothing to do with it. Robert Slagle, the Texas Democratic chairman, was one of the few in his party to publicly suggest that the President bears some responsibility: "It was a lot like trying to swim with a battleship anchor strapped on your back."
After a protracted search during which everyone seemed to turn down the job, Gov. Ann W. Richards picked Mr. Krueger to replace Senator Lloyd Bentsen after he was appointed Treasury Secretary. Little did she know that the woman who will serve the remaining 18 months of what was Mr. Bentsen's term will now devote herself to opposing the economic package that he helped create.
"I am going to make sure that I sign on for everything I can do to kill the taxes in the Clinton economic program," Mrs. Hutchison told reporters today in Dallas. "That will be my first order of business."
Short of not pulling Mr. Bentsen out of the Senate in the first place, Mr. Clinton's advisers said there was little they could have done to keep the seat Democratic. They said Mr. Clinton had not played any direct role in urging Governor Richards to pick Mr. Krueger, and that there was a paucity of formidable candidates.
Although Paul Begala, an adviser to Mr. Clinton, traveled to Texas to help the beleaguered Krueger campaign, neither he nor anyone at the White House made an all-out effort to help. White House officials said they viewed Mr. Krueger as a loser early on. And, from the start, they said Mr. Clinton's influence was limited because he was never wildly popular in Texas. In last year's elections, President George Bush won his adopted home state with 40 percent, followed by Mr. Clinton with 37 percent and Ross Perot with 22 percent.
"I don't know if anything short of divine intervention could have made a difference," said James Carville, a close political adviser to Mr. Clinton.
 
Luke Warm White House
 It would have been even more damaging had Mr. Krueger wanted the President to stump for him in the state, according to a poll published by The Dallas Morning News in May. The survey of 888 voters who had said they planned to cast ballots found that only 7 percent said they would be more likely to vote for Mr. Krueger had Mr. Clinton campaigned there; 28 percent said less likely. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Knowing the outlook was glum for Mr. Krueger, Mr. Clinton offered a half-hearted endorsement of the Texan several weeks ago. Then, he quickly sought to put as much distance from Mr. Krueger as Mr. Krueger kept from him. "I've always been skeptical about the question of whether any of us can have any impact on anyone else's races," Mr. Clinton said.
Yet it was only two years ago that Democrats were gloating that the upset victory of Senator Harris Wofford, a Pennsylvania Democrat, over former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was evidence of a public outcry against President Bush. Mr. Wofford seized on domestic issues like health care and relentlessly attacked Mr. Bush as out of touch, issues that Mr. Clinton used successfully in last year's election.
 
Admitting a Bad Campaign
 Mr. Carville, who orchestrated the Wofford campaign, disputed the idea that there were similarities between the two races, insisting that the notion of a President influencing a local election was overblown. Referring to Mr. Wofford's race, he said, "I don't think I ever said it was a referendum on Bush."
While he disagreed that the Texas results could be a "wake up call" to Mr. Clinton to change his policies, Mr. Carville could not offer an overriding reason for the outcome, except that Mr. Krueger was a lousy campaigner. "There's no way I could see the President embarrassed by this," he said. "But he's probably disappointed."
Mr. Bentsen also sought to steer any blame from the Administration for losing his old seat. "As he himself admitted," Mr. Bentsen, interviewed on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," said of Mr. Krueger, "he's a poor politician, and that showed up in this particular race. That's the bottom line."
After all, Mr. Krueger, a former Congressman and Texas railroad commissioner, now has the distinction of being the only politician in Texas to lose a campaign for the Senate in three different decades.

HEADLINE: In Startling Shift, Guatemala Makes Rights Aide President

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, June 6

 BODY:
In a turn that astonished many Guatemalans even after days of political turmoil, the Government's crusading human rights ombudsman, a frequent critic of the military, was sworn in as President early today.
Less than two weeks ago, the former ombudsman, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, was sneaking out the back of his home to escape a squad of military policemen who arrived as Jorge Serrano Elias, then the President, seized nearly dictatorial powers.
 
In a Delicate Position
 The armed forces overthrew Mr. Serrano on Tuesday with support from business leaders, politicians and others, including Mr. de Leon Carpio. But when the Attorney General of Human Rights, as he was formerly titled, first emerged as a candidate to finish the remaining half of Mr. Serrano's five-year term, politicians said they discounted him as unacceptable to the army high command. 
 The eventual triumph of Mr. de Leon Carpio, 51, seemed to mirror the situation of Guatemala's civilians in their long struggle with the political weight of the armed forces, which ruled the country almost continuously from 1954, when the elected Government was overthrown by a Washington-backed military coup, until 1986. It was hopeful and resonantly symbolic, but also incomplete and perhaps unstable.
"His position is extremely difficult and delicate," said Tracy Ulltveit-Moe, a researcher who has long monitored Guatemala for the human rights organization Amnesty International. "You can't be very sure whether, first, he's going to be able to stay in office. But there's also the difficulty of responding to all of the hopes that this has raised."
As late as Saturday afternoon, business and political leaders said they were confident of having obtained the votes in Congress to elect a more moderate candidate, Arturo Herbruger Asturias, the 81-year-old head of the federal electoral court.
But with Mr. de Leon Carpio's name ringing from the galleries of the somber stone chamber built by one of Guatemala's many military dictators, legislators gave him a narrow majority on their first secret ballot. He was still more than a dozen votes short of the required two-thirds vote in the 116-seat legislature. But as congressional leaders recessed to negotiate, Mr. Herbruger telephoned to withdraw.
Before the Legislature voted again on Mr. de Leon Carpio, two representatives said, the telephone rang on the podium where the President of Congress sat. They said it was a senior military official, calling to say the army would accept its former antagonist as its new Commander in Chief. The Congress president, Jose Lobo Dubon, said he did not take such a call, but had received the same message from the Defense Minister earlier in the day.
Pulling on the blue-and-white presidential sash, Mr. de Leon Carpio insisted in his inaugural speech to Congress that "the feeling of living in democracy is rooted in the Guatemalan people."
But the events of the last two weeks have called such beliefs sharply into question, and the hard choices that Mr. de Leon Carpio will face began to present themselves immediately.
As he arrived at the neo-classical Congress building nearly an hour past midnight, his audience was no more contained than the crowd at a wrestling match. Students and union members shook the chamber with demands for the dismissal of corrupt officials of Congress, the courts and the former Serrano Government.
"Depuracion!" the crowd chanted again and again, using the Spanish word for purification or purge. "Resign! Resign! Resign!"
They shouted as well for the prosecution of military leaders who supported Mr. Serrano's seizure of power and then ousted him, then backed an attempted takeover by his Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero, only to force Mr. Espina to resign.
In his inaugural, Mr. de Leon Carpio mentioned neither the military nor the proposed laws that would give amnesty to various groups of the officials under public fire. And as he emerged from the legislative chamber, buoyed on a mass of supporters and police guards, he quickly backed away from the demands for prosecution that he had supported in days past.
"After a crisis like the one we have just come through, we cannot have revenge," he said.
Mr. de Leon Carpio's speech drew only one strong ovation, when he vowed to do away with the tens of millions of dollars in confidential discretionary funds budgeted to the presidency, money that Mr. Serrano and his predecessor, Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, were widely accused of having plundered for their own gain.
Several analysts predicted that Mr. de Leon Carpio's political strength in Guatemala would depend partly on his success in bringing the country a more democratic reputation abroad. Although civilian leaders declared a final victory over the military when Mr. Espina was forced to resign and Mr. de Leon Carpio was chosen, the last two weeks also laid bare the military's continuing political power.
Mr. de Leon Carpio's remarks seemed to reflect the same analysis. He called on foreign governments to renew and increase the aid to Guatemala that they suspended after Mr. Serrano -- who was elected to a five-year term in January 1991 -- dissolved Congress and the Supreme Court on May 25. Mr. de Leon Carpio also asked that the countries lift their threats of economic sanction.
United States officials responded almost immediately. "We welcome a legal and peaceful constitutional resolution of this crisis, and we're looking forward to working with this Government," the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, told reporters.

HEADLINE: Japan Is Rallying Asian Nations Against New U.S. Trade Policies

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 6

 BODY:
In Japan's most direct attack yet on the Clinton Administration, Japanese officials have swept through Asia in recent weeks to rally opposition against America's new trade policies, arguing that while Japan may be Washington's target now, other Asian nations will be next.
The intense diplomatic effort, coming before next month's summit meeting here of leaders of the seven richest industrial nations, underscores a fundamental and widening philosophical split between Washington and its Asian trading partners. 
 At its core is the Administration's insistence on numerical targets for gaining market share and other quotas that would assure American products' access to Japanese markets. This adds up to what the Japanese and others call managed trade, as opposed to free trade.
To the chagrin of many American officials in the Pacific, the debate in recent months has permitted Japan to take the moral high ground, allowing it to portray itself as, of all things, a free trader and the United States as a meddler in the world's trading system.
 
Asia Backing Japan
 While many in Europe are reluctant to join with the Japanese, one by one countries throughout Asia -- from Indonesia to Malaysia to Australia -- have been denouncing the Clinton Administration's approach as a dangerous strategy that ultimately will undermine market economies by mandating who buys how much, and from whom.
"The Japanese are calling in their chips," an American trade official based in Southeast Asia said. "They are going to countries where they have invested billions of dollars in recent years, far more than we have invested, and essentially have said, 'If they make this work against us, sooner or later they will get you, too.' "
Japanese officials deny they are orchestrating a campaign against the Clinton Administration's strategy. Instead, they say that the denunciations from Asia are rising from spontaneous outrage.
"Our neighboring countries are telling us that if Japan concedes and allows the United States to set numerical targets, then they know that will be the fate of the rest of East Asia tomorrow," said Noboru Hatakeyama, the Vice Minister of International Trade and Industry and Japan's top trade negotiator. "We, of course, agree with them."
Mr. Hatakeyama insisted in an interview that "we are determined never to accept" a "results-oriented approach that leads us to managed trade." Mr. Hatakeyama is heading to the United States for a critical set of negotiations in which the Clinton Administration plans to lay out a broad new framework for trade talks with Japan.
Japanese leaders have been increasingly, and openly, contemptuous of the Administration's approach. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, during a taped television interview earlier this week, attributed American trade policies to the new Administration's inexperience, saying that "they've just come to the Government, so they probably don't understand very well."
Mr. Miyazawa later persuaded the network, TV Asahi, to delete the remark before broadcasting the interview, saying he feared it could be interpreted in Washington as "rude." Newspaper reporters who watched the taping reported it anyway.
A taste of the differences spilled over in Paris last week at the meeting of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown openly sparred with their Japanese counterparts, contending that the American determination to measure the openness of the Japanese market by clear numerical indicators -- not just market share, but the number of new contracts signed, or "design-ins" of American parts in new Japanese products -- was specifically aimed at solving America's peculiar and seemingly intractable problem of reducing its trade deficit with Japan.
 
Denies Managing Trade
 "We're working hard to try to open up these markets," Mr. Bentsen said. "In no way is that managed trade." At the conclusion of the meeting, the United States headed off a Japanese effort to include a passage in the meeting's final statement in opposition to managed trade.
Mr. Brown in particular has pointed recently to the irony that Japan -- a country that has managed, measured and controlled its imports and exports with more skill than any other nation in recent decades -- should suddenly portray itself as what Mr. Hatakeyama calls "the flag-bearer for free trade."
Mr. Brown has repeatedly accused Tokyo of "disingenuousness," telling The International Herald Tribune that "those words have very little credibility coming from the Japanese."
Even the Japanese now readily concede that they were once masters of the art. But they describe themselves as something akin to reformed sinners, who have now dedicated themselves to warning the world of the hazards of following the same path.
"There is no hiding that in the 1960's and through the mid-1970's we did have managed trade," Mr. Hatakeyama said. "But what I have to tell Mr. Brown is please don't mix past history with current phenomenon."
 
Japan's Argument
 Japan also argues that it has never sought what the Clinton Administration now seeks: a virtual guarantee that a foreign country will set aside a specific share of its market for Japanese goods.
Indeed, it has not. But Japanese officials concede that they have undercut their position over the years by agreeing to forms of managed trade -- restrictions on the export of Japanese cars, machine tools and steel, for example. And the model for the Clinton Administration's strategy is the 20 percent target agreed on in the late 1980's for America's penetration of the Japanese semiconductor market. Japanese officials now say that their agreeing to such a target was a big mistake, because it set a precedent that the Administration is now trying to enlarge.
The campaign against the Clinton Administration's strategy began overtly in April, when Mr. Miyazawa traveled to Australia where he emerged with a fairly strongly worded statement in favor of free trade from Prime Minister Paul Keating, who heads one of the few countries in the Pacific that actually sells more to Japan than it buys. (But what it sells, many critics point out, are raw materials, minerals and food, not manufactured products.)
Later Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, Yoshiro Mori, took a swing through Southeast Asia that yielded even more strongly worded critiques of America, particularly from Indonesia, which this year heads the Non-Aligned Movement, a group of 108 smaller nations that first banded together in the cold war as third world countries.
 
Criticism From Malaysia
 Perhaps the loudest critic outside of Japan is the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad."Mr. Miyazawa says that it is not acceptable for countries to have to tell their companies how much of what they should buy," Dr. Mahathir said in a speech in Tokyo last month. "Yet managed trade has advanced. And there are now respectable Western scholars who even advocate it as a legitimate model for the conduct of future world trade. There are politicians who openly advocate it without blushing with shame."
Dr. Mahathir, a nationalist who has called for an East Asian trading group to counter the North American Free Trade Agreement and other regional blocs, is no doubt speaking from the heart. He has never made a secret of his distaste for what he terms Washington's proclivity to view "the North Atlantic community as the center of the world," and Asia "as the periphery."
Like many Asian leaders, he finds his interest and Japan's are closely tied. Japan is easily the largest investor in his country; it has provided the technology to build a national car, now being exported, and turned Malaysia into the world's largest producer of room air-conditioners.
So in Malaysia, as in many neighboring countries, Japan can make the argument that any effort to limit Japan's exports would eventually limit those of countries manufacturing products for Japanese companies.
