HEADLINE: SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: The Immigrants -- 7 Die as Crowded Immigrant Ship Grounds Off Queens;
One Failed Voyage Illustrates Flow of Chinese Immigration

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
The freighter that ran aground off Rockaway Peninsula in Queens yesterday was part of a recent surge of illegal Chinese immigrants who have made their way to Hawaii, California, Guatemala, Florida and now, for what is believed to be the first time by boat, to the shores of New York.
Why the immigrants chose a tortuous route that took them around the Horn of Africa and north again into the cold waters of the North Atlantic is not clear, but officials said that a highly organized network of smugglers around the world probably provided assistance in stops along the way. 
 The increase in the number of boats with Chinese intercepted in American waters in recent months has coincided with a sudden, sharp increase in the number of Chinese who turn up at immigration offices to seek asylum, officials said yesterday.
"The number of Chinese that have applied for asylum has grown astronomically in the last few months," said Gregg A. Beyer, director of asylum at Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington. "These are people who are already in the United States," he said. "We don't know how or when they got here, if they got in legally or if they were smuggled in."
At the immigration service's Newark office, which handles cases for New York, New Jersey and New England, 2,853 Chinese applied for political asylum in April and May, more than the total number of Chinese applicants in all of 1992, Mr. Beyer said. In October, he said, 186 Chinese applied for asylum in Newark; in May the number was 1,560.
Since August 1991, boatloads of Chinese immigrants have made their way to the United States, most of them in search of economic opportunities that do not exist at home, officials said. Twenty-four boats have been intercepted by the American authorities, who have sharply increased their efforts to monitor the vessels.
Last year, American officials traced the journey of a ship carrying 151 Chinese from China to Mauritius in the Indian Ocean and then to Cape Town, from where she sailed across the South Atlantic to Brazil and, finally, to Haiti, where the passengers came ashore before dawn on a Sunday.
The boat that reached Queens yesterday, the Golden Venture, was the first carrying smuggled Chinese immigrants to be intercepted in the New York area.
"What we are witnessing is the continuation of a deplorable trend," said William S. Slattery, the director of the New York office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
If the immigrants who came ashore in Queens follow a pattern that has become common, they will seek asylum in the United States by claiming that they face persecution in their homeland because of China's population-control policies, which generally restrict couples to only one child, immigration officials said.
But if the immigrants had succeeded in sneaking into the country, as they apparently planned to do, they might have chosen another increasingly common tactic for winning a legal place in the United States -- a false claim that they had been here since the 1989 uprising in Tiananmen Square, the officials said. Government policy allows those people to remain in the country.
Like the group yesterday, a large number of Chinese immigrants come from the Fujian Province, a coastal region opposite Taiwan.
Immigration and police officials said the immigrants typically agree to pay smugglers tens of thousands of dollars for the trip and end up in a system of indentured servitude operated by Chinese gangs. Law-enforcement officials said many illegal Chinese aliens worked off their debts in Chinese restaurants in New York and New Jersey.
Two weeks ago, 57 illegal Chinese immigrants were found in a warehouse in Jersey City, where they were being held by smugglers as they waited for relatives to come up with the $25,000 to $30,000 per person demanded for their release. Some told the police they had entered the United States on foot from Mexico; others said they entered by airplane, and some said they came by ship, but were unable or unwilling to say where the ship had dropped them off.
 
Effect of a Crackdown
 Immigration officials said yesterday that most Chinese immigrants eventually make their way to the New York area, because of the large and long-established Chinese population in the area and because New York is the base of strong Chinese gangs that control the smuggling operations.
But the officials could not explain why the group yesterday was entering the country on the East rather than the West Coast, which would have spared them thousands of miles of travel.
A crackdown by immigration officials in the West may have prompted a switch to East Coast ports, said Theodore Ruthizer, the president of the American Immigration Lawyers Association. After several shiploads of refugees arrived on the West Coast in 1991 and 1992, immigration officials there began detaining passengers for long periods instead of releasing them to await hearings, Mr. Ruthizer said, and smuggling traffic has fallen off.
For those on the Golden Venture, the odyssey to a home in the United States stands a good chance of success, in part because Chinese refugees's applications for political asylum are treated more favorably than others, immigration lawyers say.
About 80 percent of Chinese refugees who formally apply for asylum are granted it, compared to about 35 percent overall, according to Arthur C. Helton, director of the Refugee Project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights in New York City.
Immigration lawyers attribute that favorable treatment to the Government's inclination -- particularly strong since China's government crushed a pro-democracy movement in 1989 -- to give credence to claims of political persecution in China.
And under a 1989 order by President Bush, immigration agents must give special consideration to those who claim to be fleeing China's harsh population control policies, which sometimes lead to compulsory sterilization and abortion.
Government officials and immigration lawyers said that many Chinese refugees are well versed in what they must say to gain asylum. "We get 18-year-olds who've never been married who tell us they want to have two kids and that's why they're here," said Ralph Thomas, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington.
But the immigrants' odyssey may continue for months or even years. Officials said yesterday that there was a backlog of 18 months or longer for processing asylum claims.
The people who were aboard the ship are to be processed over the next few days at an I.N.S. center on Varick Street in Manhattan, then transferred to detention centers.
On orders from the White House, the immigration service will keep the Rockaway Beach group in detention centers outside of New York City -- in Pennsylvania, Maryland and Texas -- as their cases make their way through the system, Mr. Thomas said.
"When we have large groups arriving, we feel we have to make a response, otherwise we're inviting others to try this same thing," he said.
Typically, asylum seekers are freed pending the outcome of their cases. Many then disappear. In the last six months, Mr. Thomas said, 30 percent of the aliens claiming to be seeking asylum in the New York area failed to appear for their court dates.
The crew of the Golden Venture could face Federal charges of alien smuggling and conspiracy, with a maximum penalty of five years in prison for each undocumented alien aboard the ship. Prosecutors said they had not yet decided whether any crew member would be charged.
In the New York metropolitan area, the I.N.S. handles more than 20,000 asylum applications a year -- and thousands more cases of people who say they intend to seek asylum, but disappear without formally applying -- but it has room to hold only 100 people until their applications are approved or denied.

HEADLINE: Energy Tax Puts Senator In Tough Spot

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, June 6

 BODY:
Senator John B. Breaux once joked that his vote could not be bought but that "it can be rented."
That was during the Reagan era, when the Louisiana Democrat was a lowly backbench Congressman unabashedly seeking sugar subsidies for his farm constituents. 
 Now Mr. Breaux is one of two swing votes on the Senate Finance Committee who can make or break President Clinton's economic plan, which includes an energy tax widely unpopular in this state heavily dependent on the energy industry.
The stakes are higher now, and pressure is coming down on Mr. Breaux from all sides. And as he tries to find wriggle room by striking a compromise with the White House, his humor is turning as black as the oil his constituents do not want taxed.
 
Return to Louisiana
 During the Memorial Day recess, Mr. Breaux crisscrossed the bayous and marshes of southern Louisiana's oil patch to meet with constituent groups about the economy and health care. Wherever he went, he was handed stacks of petitions demanding that he oppose the President's proposal for a $72 billion tax on the energy content of fuels, as measured by British thermal units, or B.T.U.'s.
The state's newspapers and airwaves are saturated with advertising calling on Mr. Breaux not only to vote against that tax but also to drop his compromise proposal for a gasoline tax, which would fall more heavily on consumers than on producers.
The advertising campaign is led by Citizens for a Sound Economy, a group financed by oil interests and lobbies against economic regulation.
At a dinner with oilmen on Wednesday night in Houma, Mr. Breaux was introduced by an engineer wearing a button decrying the B.T.U. tax. "We have many concerns with the direction of the new Administration," the master of ceremonies said pointedly.
Beginning his speech, Mr. Breaux said, "I see the buttons," then compared himself to an Indian seen in the cross hairs of a cowboy's rifle.
At a lunch on Thursday in Westlake, he requested that the gathered businessmen refrain from throwing food at him. And at a party inaugurating his new Baton Rouge office that evening, he peered out his window, pointed toward Huey Long's flood-lighted tomb and told guests, "After this vote, I'm going to have one right next to it."
Because all nine Republicans on the Finance Committee are expected to oppose Mr. Clinton's budget plan, the Administration needs all 11 Democrats. Two of the 11, Mr. Breaux and Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, have pledged to vote nay as long as the B.T.U. tax remains intact.
 
Break With Boren
 Mr. Breaux, however, broke with Mr. Boren by quietly lobbying the Louisiana Congressional delegation to provide the votes that nailed down Mr. Clinton's narrow victory in the House last month. He promised the lawmakers he would see to it that the B.T.U. tax was stricken in the Finance panel.
"I was trying to be helpful," he said in an interview. "If we lost in the House, we'd lose the chance for deficit reduction this year."
Mr. Clinton expressed gratitude to Mr. Breaux, but the Senator's offices have been deluged with telephone calls calling on him to stand tough against the President.
Like many moderate and conservative Democratic lawmakers, Mr. Breaux finds himself in the uncomfortable position of either backing the President and paying a heavy political price at home, or deserting him and doing severe damage to Mr. Clinton's Presidency and the Democratic Party.
Mr. Breaux defines the dilemma this way: "Bill Clinton ran as a new Democrat, and he has to give us a new Democratic Administration. If he doesn't succeed, the people won't trust the party. And if we get something passed that doesn't work, we'll get blamed -- and rightfully so."
The President's B.T.U. proposal would cost Louisiana $1.2 billion a year, say the oil lobbying groups pushing their case in the local news media.
But Mr. Breaux must also calibrate personal stakes that may conflict with his state's. As chief deputy whip of the Senate Democrats and as chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, he is trying to carve out a place as a national party figure. Breaking with the President now would damage that effort even if he won points at home.
 
Seeking Middle Course
 "I want to be a statesman," the Senator said, "but I don't want to be a crazy statesman." So he is trying to navigate a middle course, publicly declaring his opposition to the B.T.U. proposal while he negotiates with the Administration to pare it. He is proposing as an alternative an 8-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax and $30 billion in further spending cuts, a proposal that Administration officials say could cost vital votes from the party's liberal wing.
The gasoline tax, Mr. Breaux argues, would spread the pain of an energy levy more evenly around the country, and he is telling his constituents that they should prefer to pay a few cents more at the pump than lose their jobs.
In his public addresses, Mr. Breaux tries to embrace the President's economic policies, even as he attacks the energy tax that provides a linchpin for those policies.
At the dinner in Houma, he criticized the B.T.U. tax as "more complicated than the Egyptian hieroglyphics to interpret." But he went on to praise other provisions of the Administration's economic plan, like the investment tax credit for small businesses and the earned-income tax credit for families that earn less than $28,000 a year.
His talk made some oilmen uncomfortable. "I would have liked to hear him say he was against the B.T.U. tax one more time," said Robert Bordes, a purchasing agent for Marathon Oil. Referring to one of the representatives whom Mr. Breaux had lobbied to vote in favor of the President's program, Mr. Bordes added: "Billy Tauzin used to be very popular. Now he wouldn't win a race for dogcatcher."

HEADLINE: Christian Right Splits G.O.P. in South

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, June 5

 BODY:
The Christian right is on the political move again in the South, pushing hard to win offices and influence in the Republican Party at a time when many of the party's national leaders are urging that it become more moderate and centrist.
Here in Richmond this weekend, Christian conservatives dominated the convention that nominated candidates to represent the party in this fall's elections for governor, lieutenant governor and attorney general. 
 And in South Carolina a few weeks ago, Christian conservatives captured control of the executive committee of the Republican Party, including the chairmanship.
In both Virginia and South Carolina, Christian conservatives have also recently won control of some county Republican organizations, mostly by packing local caucuses with political novices who have been energized by an evangelical fervor to restrict abortion, limit homosexual rights, defeat gun-control measures and control what children learn in school.
 
Ideological Wedge
 Christian conservatives are not a new political phenomenon in the Republican Party in the South nor, for that matter, elsewhere in the country. Four years ago, the television evangelist Pat Robertson, head of the Virginia-based Christian Coalition, made a run for the Presidency. And in last fall's elections, Christian conservatives showed considerable political muscle, winning hundreds of seats from coast to coast on school boards, city councils, water district boards and the like.
What appears to be new is a concerted move to capture control of state parties and put forward candidates for top state offices. It is an effort that threatens to drive an ideological wedge into the heart of a party whose national leaders, mindful of the defeat of the national ticket last fall, are trying to erase a perception that Republicans are emphasizing the religious right's social agenda at the expense of bedrock economic issues.
"Joining religious conservatives and traditional Republicans is the single greatest problem that the Republican Party faces nationally," said Whit Ayres, an Atlanta poll taker and Republican consultant.
 
Divisive Search for Unity
 Indeed, divisiveness was the first issue addressed by Patrick M. McSweeney, the chairman of the Virginia Republican Party, when he took the lectern to close the no-quarter-given convention here.
"Unity!" he cried out.
It may be hard to come by. The 13,000 delegates who filed out of the Richmond coliseum tonight certainly did not leave united.
Their slate is the most conservative put up by Virginia Republicans in decades, no small accomplishment since the party here has long been one of the most conservative in the nation. Come November, they will face a trio of moderate Democrats running in a state that is increasingly moderate and has not backed a Republican slate for governor for the last 12 years.
Ann E. W. Stone of Alexandria, a founder of Republicans for Choice, a national group that advocates abortion rights, lamented that the state party had been taken over by "crazies" who were driven by emotion rather that reason.
"It's going to bring the whole ticket down," she said. "A top Democrat asked me the other day: 'Are you guys going to commit political suicide? We're licking our chops.' "
Another delegate, Steven Read of Fredericksburg, a strong proponent of abortion curbs and of greater parental involvement in the education process, argued that Ms. Stone missed the point.
"The win-ability aspect should be second to personal principles and character," he said. "It's the easy way out -- the liberal way out -- to nominate someone who's 'electable.' "
 
'In the Hands of Kooks'
 Nonpartisan political experts in Virginia tended to agree with Ms. Stone.
"The Republicans have shot themselves in the foot," said Mark J. Rozell, a political scientist at Mary Washington College who specializes in following state election developments. "They're more interested in being right, way right, than in winning. Of the seven candidates running for three offices, they chose the three most conservative, including one who's so conservative that the Democrats are going to cite him, for sure, as proof positive that the party is in the hands of kooks."
Mr. Rozell was referring to Michael P. Farris, a lawyer whom the convention nominated for Lieutenant Governor. He is a leader of the national movement to restore "traditional family and Christian values" in American life by educating children at home. He is also the author of "Where Do I Draw the Line?" He calls it a handbook for fighting back in "situations where Christians' rights are ignored."
Though Mr. Farris ran for the No. 2 spot on the ticket, he controlled more delegates than any other convention participant. Many of his delegates were also followers of Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the other well-known Virginia evangelist.
In fact, Mr. Farris's dominance of the convention was so complete -- his supporters began packing local delegate caucuses months ago -- that the nominee for governor, former United States Representative George F. Allen, and the nominee for attorney general, James S. Gilmore 3d, a Richmond-area prosecutor, both took pains to find a few kind words about him and his agenda and not to anger him or his supporters.
 
Right and Further Right
 Convention speakers who did anger those supporters, especially the speakers who called for political moderation, were invariably booed and shouted down.
Mr. Allen and Mr. Gilmore are both rock-hard conservatives. Mr. Farris, by way of comparison, is diamond hard.
His opponent for the nomination, Bobbie Kilberg, a White House aide in the Nixon, Ford and Bush Administrations, had the backing of former Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, "Mr. Conservative" within the party. But that was not good enough for the Farris delegates.
In the fall, Mr. Farris's Democratic opponent will be the incumbent Lieutenant Governor, Donald S. Beyer Jr.
In the governor's race, Mr. Allen will face Mary Sue Terry, the state's attorney general for the last eight years.
In the attorney general's race, Mr. Gilmore will face William D. Dolan 3d, a Northern Virginia lawyer.
All of the Democrats are moderates.
The state electorate is evenly divided among Republicans, Democrats and independents.
The current Governor, L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat and the first black elected the governor of a state, cannot run for a second consecutive term under Virginia law.
"The Republicans chose to continue to lose," Mr. Wilder said of the convention.
In South Carolina, Carol Khare, the vice chairman of the Democratic Party, takes a similar view of the internecine Republican squabbling there.
"It's wonderful," she said. "They have been such a homogenous party and don't have a real perspective on diversity. This might be an opportunity for the typical, white, moderate voter who doesn't follow the agenda of the religious right to rediscover a more centrist Democratic Party."
The Republican divisiveness in South Carolina reached something of a nadir the other day when Barry Wynn, the outgoing party chairman, sent a letter to some of the party's biggest contributors, suggesting that they might want to end their financial support of a party that had become "intolerant, un-American and un-Republican."
 
No Compromise on God's Word
 "The individuals running the party," he wrote, "do not represent our beliefs, and we should not subsidize them."
He complained that groups of evangelical Christians were descending on local Republican caucuses all over the state, monopolizing delegate seats and excluding people who did not attend the right church often enough.
Richland County's Republican Party chairman, George Shissias, compared dealing with the Christian right to "going to bed with Dracula."
"You wake up expecting a couple of hickeys and find out later you have a couple of fang marks in your jugular," Mr. Shissias said. "These people aren't interested in politics. They are interested in establishing a theocracy."
In Greenwood County, one of the places where the old Republican order has been thrown out by Christian-right newcomers, Bonnie Grancelli, a leader in local anti-pornography campaigns, was recently elected the county's new Republican chairman. She credits her victory to a lack of conviction on the part of the old order.
"They are people who can go either way on some issues," she said. "But now we have people in place who are dogmatic on how they feel about some things. When I say dogmatic, I mean that when it is the word of God you are talking about, you don't compromise."

HEADLINE: Bolivian Businessman Is Leading in the Election for President

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 6

 BODY:
A millionaire mining entrepreneur appeared to have come out ahead in Bolivia's presidential election today, receiving almost 38 percent of the vote, according to early and unofficial results.
For the entrepreneur, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, a similar outcome took place four years ago when he came out ahead in the popular vote in the presidential election only to lose out in the negotiations that characterize Bolivia's system of electoral politics. 
 Polling organizations and television networks, compiling results from across the country this evening, gave Mr. Sanchez de Lozada a lead of about 15 percentage points over his chief rival, Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, the former dictator whose Patriotic Accord coalition won an estimated 23 percent of the vote.
Of the country's population of 6.4 million, more than 2 million people had registered to vote in elections that fielded 14 presidential candidates and and a list of hopefuls for the 27-member Senate and the 130-member Chamber of Deputies of Congress. The public appears to have handed the 63-year-old Mr. Sanchez de Lozada the largest plurality since the country returned to democracy in 1982.
 
Chicago University Graduate
 Although it was still too early tonight for indications of the total voter turnout, the projections were made on a count of 600,000 votes.
But the vote does not necessarily mean that Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, a millionaire who holds a philosophy degree from the University of Chicago, will become Bolivia's next president. If he fails to win more than 50 percent of the vote, he will have to negotiate with members of the new Congress from other political parties to form a coalition government representing more than half of Congress.
Indeed, that sense of not actually electing a president, of not controlling the final outcome of the electoral process, was echoed among voters here.
"We vote today for a president, but we don't elect one," said Paulina Laura, an Aymara indian woman who sells sugar-water drinks, popcorn, candy and banana chips in the sprawling and impoverished city of El Alto, which overlooks La Paz, the capital. "It's okay to vote, but politicians in the end decide who is president."
Lorenzo Gutierrez, a union leader and supporter of the populist candidate, Max Fernandez, said, "The deal making starts this evening and no one knows how it will come out."
When Mr. Sanchez de Lozada won the election for president four years ago as the candidate of his National Revolutionary Movement, he failed to win a majority and eventually lost in the negotiations that followed.
"You need to lose the elections in Bolivia to become president of Bolivia," he has often said.
 
Backroom Deals Begin
 Indeed, beneath the veneer of peaceful and open elections is the backroom bargaining, payoffs, bribes, defections and negotiations that will begin in earnest on Monday and end when the new Congress selects a President.
For example, even if Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's party wins seats in the Congress, it does not mean that the elected deputies and senators will remain loyal to their party leader.
Over the last four years, 25 percent of senators and deputies have changed parties, with many of those switches due to political favors and payoffs, political analysts say.
But the race seems to have come down to the two major candidates: Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, a Bolivian raised in the United States who speaks Spanish with a thick American accent, and General Banzer, whose Patriotic Accord, a coalition of right- and left-wing parties, appears to have placed second.
Political analysts said much of Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's support came from his record as Planning Minister in 1985, when he was credited with stopping a hyperinflation rate of 25,000 percent. While he is seen as a candidate not tainted by corruption, the public has perceived arrogance at his sometimes quick and biting wit and a style that is more American than Bolivian.
General Banzer, a 67-year-old former leader of the country, won the most votes in 1985, but he was outmaneuvered in the negotiations by Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's party. The general ruled as a dictator from 1971 to 1978, and many Bolivians remember those years as a time of prosperity. General Banzer says this is the last time he will run for office.
Most of the country was calm today. All car and truck traffic was forbidden and political gatherings were banned as Bolivians went to the polls for the fourth-consecutive time since the last military government fell in 1982.
Voting, however, was marred by accusations of fraud and ineptitude. In La Paz, there were 7 percent more registered voters than supposedly exist there, according to the National Electoral Court, and that disrepancy could skew the results for some candidates.
 
Annulment Is Threatened
 In the southeastern city of Santa Cruz, General Banzer's Patriotic Accord complained that only 40 percent of the polling booths had opened by noon and that there were not enough ballots distributed in the area. The party threatened to call for an annulment of the elections in that region.
"You have to have some suspicions about the voting with that kind of problem," said Alfredo La Placa, a leading artist, after he voted.
Whether General Banzer or Mr. Sanchez de Lozada becomes President, both embrace policies to control Bolivian inflation, now among the lowest in Latin America, to encourage foreign investment and to foster close ties with the United States. Such free-market policies have created the most vibrant economy Bolivia has seen in years.
"Whatever the outcome, the winner will be our economic model," President Jaime Paz Zamora said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Feels Pressure On Rates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The sharp jump in new jobs in May has brought closer the day when the Federal Reserve will have to raise short-term interest rates, traders and analysts say.
"It changes people's expectations," John E. Silvia, the chief economist for the Kemper Mutual Funds in Chicago, said. "I think the likelihood of a Fed tightening is up by 10 or 20 percent." 
 The prospects of the Federal Reserve's lifting interest rates to fight rising prices has been the talk of the bond market since mid-May. The speculation began after the Consumer Price Index for April showed inflation rising at a 4.3 percent annual rate this year. It intensified after news reports that said the central bank had decided to shift to a bias in favor of higher short-term interest rates at its monetary policy meeting on May 18.
But the increase of 209,000 nonfarm payroll jobs reported on Friday for May, combined with the revised April increase of 216,000, up from 119,000, indicated that the economy might be stronger than expected -- and that inflation was less likely to subside substantially in the second half of the year.
 
Key Reports Due
 More important, the data may indicate that the economy is strong enough for the Fed to contemplate raising interest rates without worrying about harming what has been a subpar economic recovery. Hence, the days of reckoning may arrive sooner.
They may come as soon as Friday and June 15, the days, respectively, for the release of the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index for May. If these inflation indicators rise at the rate seen in the first four months of the year, some analysts said the Fed would raise rates immediately.
"The Fed will need a trigger, and it is likely that could be the upcoming inflation numbers," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "But, given these employment numbers, the elements to justify a move are already in place."
For short-term interest rates, the heightened Fed threat means yields will be moving higher, as was already evident Friday. The yield on the two-year note jumped to 4.31 percent, from 4.13 percent Thursday. A little more than three weeks ago, when talk of a Fed tightening was first heard, the rate was 3.76 percent.
The surge in short-term rates could not have come at a much worse time for the Treasury, which said on May 5 that it was making a major change in its borrowing practices. The Treasury cut the sales of 30-year bonds and shifted the borrowing to shorter-term, lower-interest-rate securities from three-year notes down to three-month bills.
Since the announcement, the discount rate on the three-month bill has jumped from 2.86 percent to 3.08 percent; the rate on the one-year bill has gone from 3.09 percent to 3.50 percent, and the rate on the three-year note has moved from 4.11 percent to 4.64 percent. This could put a crimp in the Treasury's hope to cut borrowing costs, but at least it assures that it was not trying to be a market timer.
For long-term interest rates, the outlook is a little less clear. If the employment data are signaling that the economy is on a growth path of 3 percent to 3.5 percent, rather than the anemic pace of nine-tenths of a percent shown in the first quarter, then traders and investors could be worried. Not only would they fear that 1993 inflation would be higher than the 2.9 percent of 1992, but also that it is on a trajectory to rise further in 1994. This would put upward pressure on long-term interest rates.
But an increase by the Fed in short-term rates could also reduce the upward pressure on long-term rates by helping convince investors that the central bank will do what is necessary -- even if it means a clash with the Clinton Administration -- to keep prices from rising too quickly.
The potential for this kind of impact was seen in the last two weeks. While short-term rates have jumped much higher since the inflation reports for April were released in mid-May, long-term rates have held steady, remaining essentially in a trading range below 7 percent. Even with a sharp selloff Friday, the yield on the 30-year bond rose only to 6.91 percent.
Another sign of this impact is that the spread between the yields on short-term and long-term securities -- which is called the yield curve -- has narrowed, or, using the market term, flattened drastically. On Friday, the spread narrowed to 2.60 percentage points, the flattest the curve has been since May 1992.
"The surprise of the past few weeks is that the Fed has appeared more ready to act than many investors thought," Mr. Lipsky of Salomon Brothers said.
Just the reports that the Fed had shifted to a bias toward higher short-term interest rates, he said, were enough to "hold long-term rates down relative to short-term rates and contain the backup of long-term yields."
 
Assuming an Increase
 Analysts said Friday that investors and traders have already appeared to factor in an increase of one-quarter of a percentage point in the central bank's target for the Federal funds rate, which is the interest on overnight loans between banks and is the rate that the Fed uses to enact monetary policy. The Fed target for that rate has been 3 percent since September.
Neal M. Soss, the chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, had a dissenting view. He did not think the Fed would raise interest rates soon or that the jobs data made a Fed move more likely.
He argued that even with the jump in new jobs in May, the increases were way behind those of a normal recovery and "the Fed will not want to restrain the economy until labor markets have caught up." He also said that fear of derailing President Clinton's economic program by generating opposition in Congress with higher short-term rates should also restrain the Fed.
And just because short-term rates have risen in expectation of a Fed move does not mean a move is going to happen. The market has been wrong before. Though the yield on the two-year note was up to 4.82 percent last Dec. 1 and was more than 4.40 percent in November, December and early January, the Federal Reserve left its target for the Fed funds rate at 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Pact Seeks Uniformity in Stock Rules

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 5

 BODY:
Regulators from 11 Latin American countries, the United States and Canada have signed an agreement to toughen and unify regulation of stock exchanges in the Americas.
The accord, reached in meetings here on Thursday and Friday, reflects the new-found popularity of Latin American stocks and a realization that these emerging markets are plagued by manipulation, insider trading and other abuses. The regulators agreed to increase the reporting requirements for brokers, to speed up dissemination of trading information to the public and to monitor more closely investment advisers working with foreign clients. 
 "We are now convinced that the countries that have the best regulated, the most transparent, fairest markets, where there is the least possibility for manipulation and fraud, will attract the most investment from abroad," said Luis Miguel Moreno, the president of Mexico's National Securities Commission. "What we have done does not have the force of law, but commits the regulators to a path of better regulation."
The agreement was signed under the auspices of the Council of Securities Regulators of the Americas, which was formed last year in response to rising investor interest in stock markets in Latin America.
The Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington said holdings of Latin American stocks by United States investors have risen to $4.4 billion this year, from $2.6 billion in 1992.
 
A Need to Attract Capital
 "I think these countries know that in order to continue their current rates of growth, they need to attract more and more capital from abroad, and one way to do that is to have efficient, transparent markets," said Mary L. Schapiro, the acting chairwoman of the S.E.C.
Ms. Schapiro said many of the goals adopted by the securities group would provide the public with more trading information than is available on many European exchanges.
Latin American markets have boomed in the last two and a half years in part because of the privatization of state-held companies and by economic policies that have reduced inflation, re-ignited growth and brought stability to countries like Mexico, Argentina and Chile.
Among the privatization efforts is the planned sale next month of stock in Argentina's state oil company, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales. An underwriting syndicate, led by First Boston and Merrill Lynch, hopes to raise up to $2.5 billion for a 35 percent interest in the company, making it perhaps the largest initial public offering in the world this year.
Wall Street's interest in Latin America is such that almost every brokerage firm now has a group doing business here. "I don't know of any Latin American economists on Wall Street who are out of work," said Suhas Ketkar, a Latin American economist for First Boston.
But S.E.C. officials worry about the 50 investment advisers in Latin America who recommend stocks for American investors. There is also concern over reports that brokers often buy stocks for their own accounts before buying for their customers, pushing the prices up.
American regulators also worry that American investors may not get fair prices and that some Latin American investment advisers may fill orders for local customers first.
"What we need is for the regulators here to make sure the services these investment advisers are giving are consistent with the law," said Michael Mann, the head of the international division of the S.E.C.
Under the accord, the regulators have agreed to develop reporting systems on exchanges that would disseminate trading data on all transactions within 90 seconds of the trade, what they refer to as "real-time reporting."
In the United States, most trades are reported within nine seconds, although in Europe delays in reporting often extend for hours, making investors less confident that they are getting the most up-to-date price on a stock they are trading. The time lag also increases the possibility that market makers would take advantage of short-term discrepancies in the prices of stocks
The agreement called for the implementation of tough audit trail requirements for brokers so regulators could trace possible insider trading and manipulation activities. It also would require closer monitoring of clearing and settlement houses.
Still, the agreement does not mean overnight changes and freedom for investors from the risk of market manipulation. Many countries have admitted that such systems would require higher staffing levels, extensive training in investigative and auditing techniques, and millions of dollars of computer systems.
Many of the changes would also require legislation. In Mexico, for example, the Congress is considering three significant changes in its securities laws. One change would permit regulators to exchange confidential trading information with regulators from other countries.

HEADLINE: Experts Wavering on Steep Rise in Cigarette Tax

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
President Clinton is eagerly eyeing a fat new tax on cigarettes, and for reasons easy to fathom. Tobacco addicts are a proven menace to themselves and others, so why not turn that to advantage, deterring their destructive behavior with high costs and using the revenue to offset the burden smokers add to the nation's health bill?
While the size of the tax is still being debated in the Administration, reports last week suggested that it could be as high as $2 a pack to help cover the cost of the health-care plan the President is preparing to submit to Congress later this year. 
 "They know cigarette taxes are both good health policy and good politics," says Michael Pertschuk, who was chairman of the Federal Trade Commission in the Carter Administration.
But what seems like slam-dunk common sense to many people arouses unease, if not outright opposition, from economists who study issues at the intersection of health and tax policy.
 
Smokers Seen as Paying Costs
 While smokers do generate a burden on the medical system, the widely held view that smokers do not pay for the damage they cause is probably wrong, most agree. And while many experts justify Government-imposed restraints on the ground that adolescents and nicotine-addicted adults cannot accurately judge what is in their long-term best interests, this view is being increasingly challenged.
An obvious reason for taxing tobacco is that is where the money is. According to the Advocacy Institute, a Washington group that works closely with anti-smoking advocates, an extra $2 a pack would generate close to $40 billion next year. And though revenues would quickly fall as cigarette sales diminished, the cash infusion would help offset the cost of expanded health insurance coverage until savings could be realized from efficiencies in health-care delivery.
If the only thing needed was a broad-based new source of revenue, the Government could as fruitfully, and more reliably, tax shoes or soap. But cigarette taxes are more easily rationalized as forcing smokers to cover their own costs, much the way so-called green taxes force polluters to pay the cost of tidying their messes.
Smokers do, indeed, put special burdens on health insurance. The latest estimates, from Thomas Hodgson, the chief economist at the National Center for Health Statistics, show that the lifetime medical costs of the average male smoker exceed those of men who never smoked by 32 percent.
 
Pensions Not Collected
 That is not the complete story, however. John Shoven, an economist at Stanford University, said the higher medical costs are substantially offset by the fact that smokers conveniently die before their time and thus contribute a disproportionate share into the nation's pension funds. The difference for Social Security alone, he estimates, comes to more than $20,000 paid in and never collected by each smoker.
Will Manning, now at the University of Minnesota's School of Public Health, led of team of economists who in 1989 calculated the "external" costs of tobacco use (the costs not borne by smokers) and subtracted smokers' implicit pension transfers to nonsmokers. Their estimate of that external burden, 24 cents a package, is substantial, but far below the tax rate under consideration by the Clinton Administration. In fact, it is far less than the tax already collected on most packs of cigarettes sold in the United States.
Ken Warner, an economist at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health, pointed out that the Manning calculation was made before the effects of "passive smoking" were well understood. A proper estimate, he argued, should include the health effects on the families of smokers and the fetuses of pregnant women who smoked.
But Mr. Manning said he doubted that a full accounting of these added costs would increase the cost for a pack much more than 50 cents. And in any event, some analysts say they are not convinced that focusing on smokers' faults is warranted in a world that is full of antisocial habits, many of them affecting society's total health bill.
"People take all sorts of risks with medical consequences," notes Robert Tollison, the director of George Mason University's Center for the Study of Public Choice who is sometimes consultant to the tobacco industry. "Why tax smoking, but not the consumption of saturated fat?"
The case for heftier taxes on smokers is further complicated by the lack of competition in the tobacco industry. Through the 1980's, argues Philip Cook, an economist at Duke University's School of Public Policy, the price of cigarettes rose far faster than production costs and tax increases could have conceivably warranted.
Joe Camel and the Marlboro Man now seem to be suffering from a resurgence of price competition from generic cigarettes. But cigarette profits, and prices, remain high by any market test, suggesting that smokers are already paying a monopoly "tax" to cigarette makers on top of Federal and state taxes. Thus any calculation of the optimal tax that would penalize smokers for the harm they do to others ought to be reduced by the amount of this tribute siphoned off by the tobacco industry.
The weakness of the conventional wisdom that smokers fail to pay their own way is quietly acknowledged by some anti-smoking strategists. But they say they do not believe that that argument is really necessary to justify a big tax on tobacco.
 
Canada's Tax Cuts Smoking
 Higher prices would be an effective deterrent to beginning a tobacco habit and a powerful motivator to quit, they say. In Canada, where a $3 tax has more than doubled the average price to close to $6 a pack since 1982, average consumption of cigarettes has fallen by 40 percent.
But does Washington have the right to play national nanny, inhibiting self-destructive behavior with a tax that would cut deeply into the living standards of heavily addicted people with modest incomes who choose to smoke in spite of the tax penalty? The answer, for many analysts, is an emphatic yes.
Smoking is a habit typically acquired early in life, they point out. And teen-agers hardly fit the model of the rational people whose "consumer sovereignty" economic theorists so vigorously defend. "I would not trust the 17-year-old Philip Cook to be a careful steward of the 40-year-old Philip Cook's body," said Mr. Cook, a former smoker.
Thomas C. Schelling, an economist at the University of Maryland's School of Public Affairs, said he also saw a case for intervening in the behavior of adult nicotine addicts. He says decisions about tobacco are a struggle between short- and long-term desires, in which the powerful urge to alleviate an immediate, concrete hunger conflicts with the more abstract desire to avoid future health problems.
 
All Overestimate Risks
 Quitting is obviously tough -- tougher, Mr. Schelling suggests, than neophyte smokers understand. And regret sets in early. In a 1980 survey, he noted, more than half the smokers 20 to 25 years old who smoked said they had made three or more unsuccessful attempts to break the habit.
But economists with a strong libertarian bent are not satisfied with this justification for paternalism.
W. Kip Viscusi, an economist at Duke University and the author of "Smoking: Making the Risky Decision" (Oxford University Press, 1992), used a 1985 survey of some 3,000 smokers and nonsmokers to see if they correctly perceived the risks of smoking. The results matched many earlier findings that, on average, both smokers and nonsmokers actually overestimated the probability of death and illness from tobacco. Perhaps most surprising, teen-agers attached a higher risk to smoking than did the rest of the population.
That does not necessarily mean teen-agers make good use of the perception. But research by Baruch Bischoff, an experimental psychologist at Carnegie-Mellon University, suggests that the view of adolescents as myopic thrill-seekers is overdrawn.
"We haven't found that teen-agers think they are invulnerable," said Mr. Bischoff. "We haven't been finding much difference between adults and teen-agers in how they process information about risk."
 
Raising Many Questions
 But he did offer some important qualifications. For one thing, he noted, adolescents may fear social ostracism more than adults, making them more susceptible to peer pressure to take risks. More generally, he said he thought that numerical estimates of risk were crude indicators of how people perceive risk -- that people did not really have a way of grasping how percentage chances of dying actually compared with each other and what they meant.
But Mr. Viscusi does not find these to be convincing counter-arguments for a tax-based deterrent, even if one accepts them. If the object is to stop teen-age smoking, he says, why tax adult smoking? If the object is to save the innocent from passive smoking, why tax smoking in private? Enforcement of regulations against the sale of cigarettes to minors and the use of tobacco in public places, he believes, would be a "more efficient" means to these social ends.
This debate has not filtered into public consciousness so far. Even if it did, the arguments against the tax would probably not persuade many people.
What probably matters most is that a cigarette tax could be a major cash cow, a means of collecting a lot of revenue with minimal offense to the three Americans in four who do not smoke, and at the same time of saving thousands of lives. But is a big cigarette tax, on balance, justified by the conventional wisdom? Like many of his fellow professionals, Mr. Schelling is troubled. "I just don't know," he concedes.

HEADLINE: Jitters in a Showplace of Gadgets

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 6

 BODY:
Dell Jones played a round of golf today -- without ever leaving a television set here at the Consumer Electronics Show.
His hand on a remote-control device, his eyes on the animated golfer he was guiding, Mr. Jones, who is middle-aged, happily hacked his way through the Palm Springs Open. Throughout, he laughed at the kibitzing golf announcer who commented on every shot.
"This is great!" he exclaimed to spectators nodding their agreement.
Mr. Jones' enthusiasm was typical today in the vast McCormick Place exhibition halls, as more than 25,000 electronic-gadget lovers played video games, watched demonstrations of wristwatch telephones and huge home television sets, put on sunglasses equipped with miniature television screens, and otherwise sampled the newest wares of more than 100 electronics companies.
 
Joy, but Not Resolution
 But if their smiles were music to the vendors' ears, they did little to answer tough questions facing the consumer electronics industry when it came to town four days ago for its 48th semi-annual show. 
 The optimists and the worriers both have plenty to ponder as glimmers of renewed industry growth have been clouded by concern about what the recently rising Japanese yen may do to a market in which Japanese goods play a pivotal role.
Consumer electronics sales, though still sluggish by long-term standards, have been stronger than expected in the first few months of this year. Indeed, forecasters have revised their projections for all of 1993 to growth of 5.6 percent -- more than two percentage points higher than the forecast at the winter Consumer Electronics Show in January.
Such growth would lead to total hardware sales of about $40 billion. Despite a sluggish economy, consumers appear to willing to buy a wide range of items, not to mention spending $4 billion more on games and software for equipment they already own.
Rapid growth areas include large-screen television sets, which are expected to increase unit sales by 30 percent; camcorders, up 15 percent; portable compact-disk players, up 28 percent, and cellular telephones, up 20 percent, according to a survey by the Electronics Industries Association, the show's sponsor. Revenue will be up somewhat less as prices continue to drop in many categories.
But many manufacturers and retailers worry that even growth areas could be hurt by the continuing decline of the dollar against the yen. At the current exchange value of just under 108 yen, the dollar has dropped nearly 20 percent since the beginning of the year, and this is sharply cutting into the profits of the Japanese manufacturers, who are being paid in these weakened dollars from sales in the United States.
This currency movement suggests that prices might fall less quickly on some products than consumers have come to expect -- fax machines, for instance -- and could rise for others -- like television sets, which have been sold for much longer periods.
Pressure on Japanese manufacturers to raise prices has been cushioned this year, compared with previous periods when the yen was strong, because a higher proportion of their manufacturing is now being done in the United States or in lower-cost Asian countries.
Another damper on growth is the confusion about which technologies will emerge as the industry standards in interactive multimedia products, widely seen as the industry's most appealing growth segment.
Will consumers prefer games and entertainment to television, as Philips Consumer Electronics and the 3DO Company are betting with their competing compact-disk systems that attach to a standard television set? Or do people prefer to play on the screens of the increasingly powerful computers showing up in more homes?
 
Scenes From 'Voyeur'
 For at least the next few years, traditional video-game companies like Sega and Nintendo do not expect either approach to replace their far-cheaper cassette-based products that are now widely used. But Sega has already introduced its own television compact-disk system, and Nintendo, which had promised to introduce one last year, continues to invest in developing its own.
As demonstrated at the current show, compact-disk technology is nudging open the door to the manipulation by users of full-motion video, high-quality graphics and high-fidelity sound on their television sets.
Philips showed scenes from "Voyeur," an interactive mystery movie being made for its system starring Robert Culp, that enables a user to peer into various rooms of a house at any time, collect evidence, call in the police and even get shot at by characters on the screen if he or she makes a wrong move.
Among the more noteworthy announcements at the show was A.T.& T.'s agreement with Sega of America to develop a device code-named the Edge 16 to let players of Sega's video games compete with other players over regular phone lines.
A.T.& T. also announced that it would take majority control of EO Inc., a two-year-old start-up company in Mountain View, Calif., which has been a pioneer in what are known as personal communicators.
These hand-held devices -- on display at the show in an array of shapes and sizes -- combine telephone and computing functions and are controlled by a pen. EO's product, which costs as much as $4,000 for the most advanced model, can record handwritten notes, send and receive faxes, and connect to on-line computer services like Compuserve via modem or cellular-phone circuits.
The industry in general was somewhat less enthusiastic about the show than the consumers who flocked to it today. There were fewer exhibitors this year, in part because of sluggish sales in some products and also because of a trend by major manufacturers to show their new products during private sales meetings in April and May.
The major television makers who chose not to exhibit included Sony and Toshiba. Those who displayed their wares emphasized feature-laden large-screen models that have larger profit margins.
"A little more than a Timex," commented Shelly Lawler, tapping her watch as she demonstrated a line of Panasonic television sets ranging up to a 58-inch model that will cost $6,000. "But a little less than a Lexus."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago on Saturday, Doug Sobery donned Virtual Vision glasses equipped with television screens. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trenton Acts to Loosen Industrial Cleanup Law

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 3

 BODY:
Confronting a precipitous loss of industrial jobs, New Jersey is preparing to weaken environmental cleanup rules for land intended for industrial or commercial use.
Although environmentalists are worried that the proposal will set a bad precedent, urban planners are applauding it, saying it would address a problem that exists to varying degrees across the country: urban land lying fallow, in part because of the costs of cleaning up pollution. 
 For a decade the New Jersey law, the Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act, has required sellers of industrial property to undertake a stringent cleanup of the land, thus raising the price of the land and creating uncertainty about when the deal could go through.
This is one reason that companies wanting to build industrial plants have ventured out into rural areas. As a result, old industrial areas have often not been redeveloped.
In Union County, N.J., for example, a recent survey by the Regional Plan Association found that abandoned industrial properties made up 2,500 acres or 4 percent of the county.
"I'm sure it's in the tens of thousands of acres for the region as a whole," said Robert D. Yarrow, executive director of the association, which covers parts of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.
If urban land is not recycled and plants move into rural areas, Mr. Yarrow said, urban sprawl increases, creating a need for new roads and other infrastructure improvements, and moving jobs out of the reach of people who must use public transportation. Local authorities in London and Paris, said Mr. Yarrow, make old industrial sites "the focal points for metropolitan plans."
 
Action in the Legislature
 Urban sites may be abandoned for other reasons, of course, including crime and taxes. But the political consensus in New Jersey, which has seen a sharp decline in economic activity, is that inflexible environmental laws play a big part.
Today an Assembly committee gave unanimous approval to a major revision of the environmental cleanup act, which has required that when industrial property changes hands, the seller must reduce contamination so that no single pollutant will cause more than one fatal case of cancer for each million people exposed.
In March the Senate gave unanimous approval to a similar bill, and the Florio administration supports the measure. Final passage is expected soon.
The main way people are exposed to contaminants in soil is by swallowing dirt or dust, so the practical effect of the existing cleanup standard is to require that dirt be clean enough for use in a playground, even if the parcel is to be a factory or a parking lot.
Business owners, municipal officials and real-estate brokers say that rather than assuring that each property is cleaned as it changes hands, the effect of the law has been to make old industrial properties almost impossible to sell.
 
A Variable Standard
 "We thought 10 years ago, in trying to preserve the environment, that you'd return these lands to pristine picnic areas, but it can't happen, it's impossible," said William J. Pascrell Jr., the Mayor of Paterson and a state assemblyman. Instead, he said, investors are scared off by the barriers to buying old industrial properties.
"We've slowed the process, and we haven't cleaned the environment," he said.
The new bill retains the one-in-a-million standard, but calculates exposure differently, taking into account the proposed use of the land. If the use is going to be residential, individuals would still be presumed to be exposed 24 hours a day. But if the land is going to be, say, a parking lot, then people would be assumed to have a far lower exposure from a given amount of a contaminant. Thus the site would meet the standard after a less extensive cleanup.
Some people worry about what would happen if housing were built on the land decades from now. But supporters say that cleanup may get easier over time and that, in any case, factories are seldom torn down to make room for housing.
 
A Mall as an Example
 To some extent regulators in other states have taken future use into account, even if there is no statutory provision. In Syracuse, for example, the Carousel Mall was built on the site of an old industrial landfill, over which there had been a cement plant, a fuel company and a junkyard.
The state allowed some contaminated material to be left under the mall buildings and parking lot, said J. Langdon Marsh, the executive deputy commissioner of the state's Environmental Conservation Department.
"It was a good re-use of basically a very tough to re-use property," said Mr. Marsh. "If it had been a residential subdivision I very much doubt there would have been any construction allowed without excavating the whole soil down to bedrock."
To some, the concept shows welcome flexibility. John T. O'Connor, executive director of the Jobs and the Environment Campaign, a Boston-based organization made up of representatives of citizens' groups from communities near toxic sites, said: "The environmental community as a whole ignores the economics of its actions. The community has not put the environmental agenda in the economic context."
 
'A Very Troubling Precedent'
 But Daniel J. Weiss, the director of the Sierra Club's Environmental Quality Program, said, "This a very troubling precedent."
He argued that, while the one-in-a-million standard for cancer fatalities might sound high, it actually understated the risk. Each site may have several pollutants that each pose that risk, he said, and individuals may have several sources of exposure.
In addition, he said, the standard used was based on healthy white adult males, while children, the elderly and members of minority groups may all be more vulnerable. And the calculation only counts cancer, he said, not birth defects or genetic changes.
He said New Jersey's approach could set a precedent for the 1,100 polluted sites at old military bases, which Washington wants to convert to civilian industrial use.
Many New Jersey environmentalists have doubts about the changes, but they are in full retreat here as their opponents argue that environmental rules are responsible for the state's industrial job loss, which comes to 200,000 since 1986.
 
Criticism of Uncertainty
 Business is not completely happy with the new bill either, because it retains a cleanup procedure that some experts say is overly cumbersome and, as with the current law, leaves uncertainty about what must be done and when it can be completed, and therefore when the property can change hands.
The Regional Plan Association, a voluntary group that studies issues of interest to the region's economy and environment, plans to hold a workshop on urban land recycling at its annual meeting on Tuesday at the New York Hilton. It supports standards based on intended property use, but also supports more emphasis on cleaning up urban land.
The New Jersey bill would, in fact, provide $50 million in state money for grants and loans for cleanups. But it still leaves a welter of problems.
Take, for example, the situation faced by Lewis S. Ripps, the president of Palmer Asphalt Company, a roofing materials company on West Fifth Street in Bayonne, N.J., that employs 11 people. The company has been in Mr. Ripps's family since it was founded in 1932.
Mr. Ripps does not know if the site of his company has environmental problems and does not want to. "If you don't have knowledge of it, you don't have to do anything about it," he said.
 
An Asset or Liability?
 But ignorance is not really bliss. He would like to expand but cannot borrow money against the property, he said, because it is subject to the environmental cleanup law. Banks in New Jersey, as well as around the country, are wary of approving mortgages on land that may be polluted, for fear of ending up with a liability instead of an asset. Mr. Ripps, in fact, fears that his property may have "a negative net worth."
And if passing the business on to his son-in-law some day requires a sale -- as it may because Mr. Ripps has a partner who does not have a child interested in the company -- Mr. Ripps is not sure how it could be sold. In some cases, simply determining whether the property has a problem can cost tens of thousands of dollars. "Am I giving him a gift," he said, "or am I giving him a prison sentence?"
Many rules governing soil pollution are Federal and thus are unaffected by New Jersey's law, but the law here, known by its initials, ECRA, has become a lightning rod for complaints about the state's business climate.
"I've never seen any data that ECRA has saved one life or prevented one illness," said Mr. Ripps.

HEADLINE: Not on My Median;
Park Ave. Sculpture Show Opposed

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
When the monumental bronze sculptures of Fernando Botero arrived on the Champs-Elysees a few months ago, Paris embraced them. Thousands flocked to see them. Children climbed over them. Tourists posed beside them. And traffic snarled as drivers craned for a glimpse. The artist himself marveled at the "orgy of love and sensuality."
Now the sculptures are due to come to Park Avenue -- to New York City's own Champs-Elysees. And people are outraged. 
 In fact, an offer by the Public Art Fund to put 14 of Mr. Botero's cheerfully corpulent humans and animals in the medians of Park Avenue on the Upper East Side has met the sort of neighborhood opposition more often engendered when someone proposes to build, say, a shelter for the homeless.
"What comes next?" said Margaret Ternes, the executive director of the Park Avenue Malls Planting Project, a private organization that has tended the avenue's verdant gardens for 12 years and vowed to fight the installation of the sculptures, arguing, among other things, that they could lead to traffic accidents.
 
'It's Just the Precedent'
 "I have nothing against Botero," she said. "It's just the precedent of it all."
The reaction has stunned and befuddled those who hoped to re-create in New York some of the extraordinary public fervor that greeted the sculptures in Paris. And it has raised questions about who should decide what belongs in the city's public spaces.
"We thought we were doing something good," said James Clark, the executive director of the Public Art Fund, a nonprofit group that installs artworks around the city. "Now it seems we're putting an incinerator in the neighborhood."
With the neighborhood's two community boards expected to vote this week to recommend endorsing or opposing the sculptures, the city's Department of Parks and Recreation has suddenly found itself staring at the unenviable prospect of having to choose between two philanthropies that have done much to beautify the city's sidewalks and parks.
"We'd like to have everybody's blessings," said Jonathan Peyser, the department's curator of public art.
 
Works Forged in Tuscany
 The large bronze sculptures -- part of a new series forged by Mr. Botero, a Colombian, in his studio in Tuscany -- depict men, women, children, birds and cats in the voluptuous style that has made him one of the world's most popular artists.
Mr. Clark said he decided to arrange an exhibition in New York after visiting Paris last winter and witnessing the excitement the sculptures generated among an anxious public in the doldrums over France's economy and other woes. With Mr. Botero and the Marlborough Gallery in Manhattan, Mr. Clark asked the Parks Department to grant a permit to place them at the tips of avenue's grassy, flowery medians between 54th and 61st Streets for eight weeks beginning in September.
The department enthusiastically accepted, but then the trouble began.
Ms. Ternes said the proposal has infuriated many of the residents along Park Avenue who have donated more than $3 million since 1980 to plant and tend the gardens on the avenue's medians between 54th and 96th Streets.
The residents, she said, have nothing against Mr. Botero's work, but rather oppose "any kind of anything" on the mall except for tulips, begonias, grass, trees and shrubs (specifically a variety called taxus, which, she noted, is "almost indestructible except by car and taxi").
In a strongly worded letter to parks officials and members of Community Boards 5 and 8, Ms. Ternes said the sculptures would attract thousands of art lovers, young and old, increasing the risk of traffic accidents and quite possibly disturbing the flora.
Most of all, though, she said, residents feared that the sculptures would set a precedent of crass commercialism.
As it did in Paris, the exhibition will focus attention on Mr. Botero's work and almost certainly increase the prestige and value of his art, but Jack Mognaz, the vice president of the Marlborough Gallery, said none of the sculptures would be for sale during the exhibition, part of which is scheduled to move to Mexico City next and later possibly to Spain.
 
'A Great Idea'
 The motivation, he said, was purely philanthropic. "Everybody thought -- and Mr. Botero agreed -- it was such a great idea to give something to New York," he said.
The proposal has the enthusiastic support of many residents and other groups on the Upper East Side, including the Park Avenue Association, who have vowed to rally around the sculptures.
Either way, the controversy has again underscored the deep passions New Yorkers feel toward the city's precious open spaces, its parks and gardens that, more and more in recent years, have been kept alive with private donations and manpower.
And it has raised an intriguing question about what some see as another troubling precedent: can a private group buy the right to decide what is appropriate for a public space simply because it contributes money or manpower to it?
 
A Right to Space
 "There are people who feel proprietary about their spaces," Mr. Peyser of the Parks Department said, recalling a recent exhibition in a tiny park in lower Manhattan that at first bothered the homeless people living there. ("They're my toughest critics," he said.) "But I don't know when you begin to say someone has more right to space than someone else."
Warrie L. Price, the chairwoman of Community Board 8 and a resident of the avenue who has also expressed concern about the sculptures, disagreed. She said the planting association deserved a greater say because of all it has contributed to the city.
Still, Ms. Price and parks officials said they hoped that the neighbors' concerns could be addressed amicably and that in the end the sculptures would find a welcome patch in the city.
"Art is inevitably controversial," said Michael Presser, the chairman of Community Board 5 on the East Side, who supports the exhibit. "It seems to become a lightning rod whenever you talk about what public space should be used for. And Park Avenue is particularly delicate space."
Mr. Botero, reached by telephone at his studio in Pietrasanta, Italy, spoke philosophically about the dispute, saying that even in Paris the sculptures had to overcome bureaucracy and egos in the beginning. "It's almost impossible to please everybody," he said.
Mr. Botero, who is 61, added that he understood that much about New Yorkers, since he keeps an apartment in the city. "Actually, I live on Park Avenue -- at 79th Street," he said, pausing for a moment. "But I'm not against my own show."

HEADLINE: Hillsborough Journal;
The Talk of the Isle (Pop. 6,000): Liberty or Death

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HILLSBOROUGH, Carriacou

 BODY:
In these times of blossoming multiculturalism, the tiny island of Carriacou has decided that self-respect demands that it too should join the struggle to say its piece.
For too long, residents say, they have been the silent victims of their administrative overlords in Grenada, or the "mainland," 20 miles to the south, and recently they have begun to insist that they be allowed to assert their own traditions. 
 The unlikely inspiration for this dissonance under the sedating Windward climes is an activity that the 6,000 Carriacouans assert is ingrained in their very fiber: contraband, or bobol, as it is known in the local, French-inspired patois.
In a debate that they say strongly echoes the American independence movement against Britain, they have begun to argue that with little in the way of return on their taxes paid to Grenada, there is no reason they should submit to customs duties on imported goods imposed by their sister island.
 
Invoking Their Birthright
 Unlike Grenada with its banana and nutmeg farming, they say, the people here make their living through a combination of fishing and sailing from island to island throughout the region, trading goods freely and informally and returning with whatever is lacking at home. To interfere with this livelihood, Carriacouans can be heard to say nowadays, would be to rob them of their birthright.
Fittingly, the Patrick Henry of this drama is an American-trained lawyer, Anselm B. Clouden, who by evoking the seafaring ways of his ancestors, and their descendants' supposed mistreatment at the hands of Grenadians, has begun to arouse strong nationalist passions in his neighbors.
To the outsider, Carriacouans and Grenadians can seem very much alike, both in appearance and accent. As might be suspected, the two islands share much history, from the destruction of local Indian populations, to the importation of slave labor from West Africa and colonial rule under France, then Britain.
But comparisons bring from Mr. Clouden a detailed and impassioned accounting of the cultural differences that separate the people here from their neighbors in Grenada.
 
A Different Mentality
 "Grenada has evolved from a plantocracy, so their mentality is different from ours," said Mr. Clouden, peppering his speech with phrases like "liberty or death," and "taxation without representation," evocative of the American Revolution. "We being a small island look to the sea for our living. Our forefathers always made their living the same way, risking their lives as brave men to bring the goods home to their valiant wives.
"Trade has never been subjected to customs here, and what the Grenadians are trying to do to us is nothing short of the kind of ethnic discrimination that many have suffered from in your country."
On the streets of Hillsborough, the waterfront town of 600 that would serve as capital if this 16-square-mile speck of land were to achieve its dream of independence, others put this sentiment more simply, but with similar conclusions.
"The Grenadians are a bit different from us, but I can't say exactly why," said Lennox Corion, a taxi driver. "We have an old saying here that if a Carriacouan and a Grenadian get married, their life together won't last."
If Carriacou can be said to have had its own Tea Party, most residents would say the event was the arrival some months back of a British customs expert contracted by the Government of Grenada to see to it that import duties were being paid here.
When the agent arrived on a Saturday, residents recount, none of the island's few taxis would carry him with his bags to his temporary residence. On the next Monday, when offices opened, local government workers too refused to help him, and police officers had to be sent from Grenada to assist.
Many here described this passive resistance as a deeply satisfying, if appropriately low-key, act of defiance for a slumbering fishing settlement where chickens feel secure enough to rest in potholes because of the lack of traffic.
"I wouldn't speak of an insurrection, but whenever government is destructive to the rights of its citizens, the people must contemplate their own liberation," Mr. Clouden intoned gravely, talking up the idea of forcing a vote on secession in the next elections. "When we meet eyeball to eyeball, every true Carriacouan simply wishes to be left alone."
 
Patience Is Urged
 But while Mr. Clouden dreams of a new republic nourished by what he says could be a boom in things like tourism and international ship registry, many of his fellow Carriacouans seem to have less exalted aspirations.
"I am one of those people who believe that we have to have a little patience," said Cuthbert Snagg, a shirtless 32-year-old who was repairing the small boats he rents to the occasional tourist. "It is true that Grenada has neglected us, but we should focus on getting a few basics, like running water and some paved roads. Otherwise, I am afraid people will be expecting much too much too soon."

Clouden, the Patrick Henry of a growing dispute between Carriacou and Grenada. (Howard W. French/The New York Times)
