HEADLINE: Moynihan Is Moving to Halve 1993 Tax Increase

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, whose committee will begin work this week on President Clinton's economic plan, said today that under the measure he was contemplating wealthy taxpayers would face only half the tax increase proposed by the President this year, with the full increase not effective until 1994.
"It doesn't feel right to anybody" to make the tax increases retroactive to Jan. 1, Mr. Moynihan said, so he would make the new rates effective on July 1. 
 That would not mean that income earned or deductions claimed in the first half of the year would be treated differently for tax purposes from those in the second half. Rather, the total increase in taxes due next April would be only half as large.
"That's our stimulus package," he added, referring to the fact that many economists have said that a steep tax increase this year would inhibit the economic recovery.
Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat, is chairman of the Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over all tax legislation and about half the spending measures in the President's package. He was interviewed on the ABC News program "This Week."
At the White House this morning, President Clinton met with his top economic advisers and said later, "We're going to stick with the basic principles of the plan."
His budget director, Leon E. Panetta, told reporters at the White House that those principles involved $500 billion in deficit reduction over five years, with three-quarters of the new taxes borne by taxpayers "at the upper-income bracket." More revenue would be raised from a tax on fuels based on the amount of heat they produce as measured in British thermal units, or B.T.U.'s. There is "flexibility to negotiate within those principles," Mr. Panetta said.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said that the fuel tax would be modified and that the changes would be "matched with further spending cuts." Mr. Bentsen appeared on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
As proposed by President Clinton and approved by the House of Representatives last month, the top tax rate, now 31 percent, would rise to 36 percent for couples with incomes between $140,000 and $250,000 and for individuals with incomes between $115,000 and $125,000. For couples with incomes above $250,000 and single taxpayers with incomes above $125,000, the top rate would be 39.6 percent.
Under Mr. Moynihan's plan, apparently the top rates in 1993 would be 33.5 percent and 35.3 percent, and the full increase would be effective in 1994.
A Congressional budget official said the change would lower revenues by less than $10 billion in the 1994 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1 and is the first year of Mr. Clinton's five-year economic plan.
 
Spending Cuts Expected
 That would presumably be offset by spending cuts, especially in Medicare.
Mr. Moynihan said that he and the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, planned to meet with Mr. Clinton and other officials on Monday to work on the details.
Mr. Moynihan said he was prepared to use unorthodox parliamentary maneuvers to get his bill to the floor of the Senate if he could not win a majority in the Finance Committee, but he said he did not expect that such a step would be necessary.
The Democrats' majority on the committee is only 11 to 9, and one Democrat, David L. Boren of Oklahoma, said this weekend that he could not support legislation that contained a fuel tax based on B.T.U.'s.
Mr. Boren's public statements are often contradictory, and it is impossible to pin down exactly where he stands. After expressing opposition to the Clinton budget for weeks, he declared last weekend that he and the Administration were close to agreement on a measure he could support.
Mr. Bentsen said this about Mr. Boren today: "He has said many things about this that can have different interpretations, but I would hope that when we finally get this package together, he will be supportive of it."

HEADLINE: SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: The Homeland;
High Hopes, and Stakes, For China's Boat People

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 6

 BODY:
The desperate risks that Chinese boat people take to get to the United States, even jumping into the ocean to swim to shore, reflect the burden of the trust that has been placed in them by friends and family.
Very few Chinese can afford the thousands of dollars demanded by the "snakeheads," or smugglers. So those who yearn for a better life in the United States borrow from relatives, friends and even neighbors. 
 They may carry with them an entire village's hopes for a better future, for if the migrant prospers in the United States he will send back money and help others migrate as well. On the other hand, if he is caught and sent back, he has not only humiliated himself but wasted the savings of those who bet their money on him.
Why do they go?
Some want more political or religious freedom, or to escape from the tyranny of the village Communist Party secretary, but the most powerful force usually appears to be the yearning for a better life.
Many of the boat people are peasants, especially young men. The per capita income for peasants in China is only about $125 a year, and land is so scarce that most can look forward to farming only a fraction of an acre.
Most of the migrants come from Fujian province, a hilly coastal region opposite Taiwan. The boldest people of Fujian have been emigrating since the 17th century, when the first waves began sailing for Taiwan and Southeast Asia.
Even today, Fujianese dialects are common in Singapore and Hong Kong, and the southern Fujianese dialect is dominant in Taiwan. President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan and Corazon Aquino, the former president of the Philippines, are among the many overseas Chinese who traces their roots to Fujian.
Today Fujian is richer than many other parts of China, but it is still clear to any Fujianese peasant that those who migrate do better than those who stay behind.
 
Unrealistic Expectations
 The yearning to flee is compounded by unrealistic expectations about what life abroad can offer. The snakeheads tell prospective migrants that ship conditions will be comfortable and the journey easy, that it is simple to make a fortune in Meiguo, "the beautiful country," as the United States is called in Chinese.
The phenomenon of the boat people is a consequence of the economic liberalization in China, and of the Communist Party's diminishing control over the population.
Private boats used to be rare, wealth was difficult to hide, and peasants were stuck in their own villages. But these days, the economic boom and loosening of Government policies have resulted in a profusion of private boats and far greater mobility for peasants.
No one notices or complains if a peasant disappears from his village, or if a worker resigns from his factory job. And the Fujian coastline is dotted with boats that since the early 1980's have done a thriving business in smuggling goods from Taiwan and Hong Kong.
 
Boom in Smuggling
 Smuggling takes place on a huge scale -- more than 90 percent of the videocassette recorders sold in China are smuggled in -- and has resulted in growing corruption among the police. It has also led to the emergence of Mafia-style criminal gangs that have contacts in Taiwan and in Chinatowns in the United States and Hong Kong.
Starting in the late 1980's, the snakeheads began to smuggle Fujianese peasants into Taiwan, and that business is still going strong. But in the last few years, the boom has been in the smuggling of Fujian peasants to the United States. Taiwanese ships are usually used, partly because individual mainlanders still have mostly fishing boats rather than ocean-going cargo ships.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
Between the Idea of a CNNNewspaper Alliance and the Reality Falls the Shadow of Ted Turner

BYLINE: By William Glaberson

 BODY:
SOMETIMES in business you come this close to the dream deal.
That is what happened last week to Leland Schwartz, 44, the founder, editor and publisher of States News Service in Washington. Mr. Schwartz's small news organization supplies news reports from the capital to some 300 newspapers around the country. 
 Three years ago, States added to its offerings an unusual newspaper, The Latest News, which promotes itself as the nation's first hourly newspaper. Assembled in Washington and sent by computer to local print sites, it comes out every hour, from 4 P.M. to 9 P.M., at airports in New York, Washington and Boston.
Distributed to airline shuttle passengers, The Latest News has established a modest niche by printing wire-service updates on national and international developments for people who, Mr. Schwartz said, are lost in the "news blackout" of business travel. Mr. Schwartz says the newspaper has made a modest amount of money with advertisers like BMW and others that aim at the affluent audience of 5,000 shuttle customers daily.
Mr. Schwartz said that he recently had a "once in a lifetime" idea: turn Cable News Networks' constant flow of television reports into print. He said that he convinced midlevel CNN executives that the potential was unlimited. CNN, owned by the Turner Broadcasting System, and States were soon dreaming about a possible $50 million business, with vending machines nationwide dispensing The CNN/Latest News.
Last week, reality hit. "CNN told us Ted Turner said he did not want to be in the newspaper business," a shaken Mr. Schwartz said on Friday.
A spokesman for Mr. Turner said that there had been some miscommunication about the possibilities. "This is one of those many discussions," the spokesman said, "that take place in a company like Turner."
End of dream deal.
The Latest News will continue, Mr. Schwartz said, but the newspaper will never be what it almost was.
"Losing what we thought was a magic CNN deal," Mr. Schwartz said, "is crushing news to us."
 
Publishers Critical of Clinton
Newspaper publishers sometimes have special antennas about the business climate. If that holds true, President Clinton has much to worry about.
A survey of newspaper publishers and their business employees at newspapers across the country found that they were very cranky about the new Administration. The survey of more than 150 newspaper business executives is to be released this morning by Kenneth T. Berents, a newspaper securities analyst at Wheat, First Securities Inc. in Richmond. He conducted the survey, he said, because "the newspaper industry is a barometer of our economy."
More than 70 percent of those surveyed said consumer confidence had diminished as a result of the President's economic policies. More than 70 percent said Mr. Clinton's proposals would not give the economy a lift, while 69 percent said the Administration was anti-business. And 44.8 percent of the publishers said they had lowered their profit outlook for next year.
 
Association Head Draws Fire
Cathleen P. Black, 49, the marketing-oriented former publisher of USA Today, is the first president of the Newspaper Association of America, the year-old trade organization of the country's newspaper publishers. And she does draw ink.
This spring, her old mentor, Allen H. Neuharth, the USA Today founder, made waves among newspaper people when he went after Ms. Black in print, criticizing her stewardship of the organization. The N.A.A. was formed last June in a merger of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and six other trade groups.
The new organization's leaders, Mr. Neuharth wrote in his USA Today column, are "promotion-oriented hucksters and lobbyists." Ms. Black responded that Mr. Neuharth was taking some of her comments on marketing out of context. "Shame on you," she wrote in response in the pages of the newspaper where they once worked together.
Ms. Black is now the subject of a new war of words. The topic: how much Ms. Black earns at the association and whether she is worth it. A trade magazine, Newspapers & Technology, recently ran an excerpt of a book about USA Today, "The USA Today Way," by John K. Hartman, a journalism professor at Central Michigan University.
Mr. Hartman wrote that Ms. Black is earning $1 million a year as the chief of the N.A.A., "more than what all but a handful of newspaper company C.E.O.'s make." He suggested that under Ms. Black's leadership, the organization, with an annual budget of $32 million, had not demonstrated an ability to help newspapers with their business problems.
One of Ms. Black's top deputies, James E. Donahue, lambasted the trade publication in a letter, saying "you should have checked the facts." Ms. Black's salary is $600,000, not $1 million, Mr. Donahue wrote.
Mr. Hartman responded by challenging the trade organization to disclose Ms. Black's total compensation, including benefits and perks.
Last week, the organization's spokeswoman, Nancy Jones, said Ms. Black's total compensation from the organization for fiscal year 1991-1992, when she was president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the N.A.A.'s predecessor, was $893,485, including salary and compensation for items like stock options, which Ms. Black lost when she left USA Today. Ms. Black was also paid $83,333 by USA Today that year, raising her total annual compensation to at least $976,818.
In the fiscal year that ended May 30, Ms. Black's total compensation from the N.A.A. was about $780,000, Ms. Jones said.
The organization's "board clearly believes Cathie Black was worth this," Ms. Jones said. "They're the ones who hired her and set the terms of the agreement."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Magazines Pressed to Change Looks

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
For a man who makes his living creating the looks of new magazines and redesigning the appearance of old ones, Roger Black sounds suspiciously like a print person.
"The one thing that is going to save magazines is writing; it isn't visuals," said Mr. Black, a leading art director who has recently been involved in redesigns of Newsweek, Premiere, Esquire, Town & Country and Harper's Bazaar and in the start-ups of Esquire Gentleman, Smart Money and Out. 
 "The writer sitting down and writing has direct contact with the reader," said Mr. Black, a cheery man with a puckish smile. "The reader sits down. It's a great piece. It's the reader and the writer. And if you, the art director, forget that, you're cooked."
Art directors have become a major force in the magazine world. When advertising began to decline in 1990 and friendly competition turned into the survival of the fittest, publishers tried to make their magazines more attractive by redesigning covers, modernizing logos and jazzing up the overall appearance.
 
Redesign Doesn't Rescue Some
 Some, like HG, despite attractive redesigns, just didn't make it and ceased publication. Others, like Time, are still reinventing themselves.
By the time the recession hit, Mr. Black, 44, had already established himself in Europe as well as in the United States. He began his career at Rolling Stone, where he was the art director from 1976 to 1978, and moved on to The New York Times and Newsweek. In 1987, he formed Roger Black Inc., an editorial design firm that has studios in New York and Milan and is about to open one in Dusseldorf.
"While New York may be the center of the publishing universe, there are a lot of people in Milan and Hamburg and Sao Paulo who really don't care," Mr. Black said.
Mr. Black has also been under contract to Hearst Magazines for two and a half years as a general design consultant for all its magazines.
His love of print serves him. Editors love Mr. Black because he thinks the way they do.
 
'He's a Collaborator'
 "What appealed to me about Roger was that he really interviewed me," said Susan Lyne, editor and publications director of Premiere, which will introduce its redesign in the fall. "He wanted to know why I was interested in doing a redesign, what I wanted to accomplish, who our audience was and what they looked to the magazine for. He's not coming at it with, 'I have this brilliant idea; I see what this magazine should be.' He's a collaborator, not an artiste."
Richard M. Smith, president and editor in chief of Newsweek, first worked with Mr. Black in 1985, when the magazine went through its first major redesign.
"The greatest thing about Roger as a designer is that he is a smart, editorially minded person," Mr. Smith said. "He quickly grasps what a magazine is all about and what it is trying to convey to its readers. Roger doesn't only have one arrow in his quiver. He really thinks like an editor in using design elements that really support the relationship with the reader."
It is one thing to redesign eye-catching magazines like Esquire and hip ones like Out, but how about old, gray Foreign Affairs, the bimonthly publication of the Council on Foreign Relations?
 
 
The Post-Cold War Look
 James F. Hoge Jr., the new editor, said he felt that with the passing of the cold war, the magazine had to reflect the sea change in international relations, not only in its text but in its design. He called in Mr. Black.
"The first intent is just to make a better magazine that is more in tune with the times, and get deeper readership from its current subscribers," Mr. Hoge said.
The redesigned magazine, which makes its debut this summer, has a glossier cover and a redesigned logo. It will introduce photographs and -- at Mr. Black's insistence -- an old typeface called Caslon, which is intended to make the magazine more readable.
"The fun thing with Foreign Affairs was to go all the way back and look at its history, realize that this is a reading magazine -- not an infopopping magazine -- for people who want a real background in text issues," he said. "So the most important thing was to make the type legible."
 
 
Quiet and Subtle
 Mr. Black said that design should be done quietly, subtly and without too much fanfare.
"I don't like face-lifting," he said. "I would rather be a nutritionist."
Mr. Black deplores what he calls the celebrity trap. Celebrities on covers sell magazines at the newsstand, and many advertising agencies, he said, use newsstand sales as a gauge of "hotness." Most magazines, however, mainly make their sales through subscriptions, and covers are just not that important.
"Increasingly P.R. people and agents are calling the shots on celebrity covers," he said. "They will only allow their movie-star clients to show the good side of their faces, so all the photos look alike. They will say, 'My client has been too much of a bimbo lately; we now want her in glasses reading a book.' Many P.R. people insist on review of the pictures before they are published."
Mr. Black is also an apostle of restlessness.
"I tell all art directors to start looking for a job after two years," he said. "Never stay more than five years. You stop seeing what's wrong."

HEADLINE: Don't Sacrifice the Needy Workers

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has agreed to shrink the proposed energy tax in order to push its economic plan through the Senate. That's an acceptable, though regrettable, compromise. But it's unacceptable that the Administration seems willing to make up for much of the lost revenue by cutting back its proposed tax credit for low-paid workers.
Such reneging would trash President Clinton's lofty pledge, repeated as recently as last week, that his budget would guarantee full-time workers enough money to bring their families out of poverty. Political compromises are fine, but not when they victimize America's poor. 
 Mr. Clinton has vowed to "make work pay" at least to the extent of lifting workers out of poverty. Now work doesn't pay for minimum-wage workers. A parent with two children working full time at $4.25 an hour earns less than $9,000 a year, more than $5,000 below the poverty line. The gap would widen under the President's original plan because he would impose an energy tax whose costs would, in effect, push the poverty line up about $200 a year.
President Clinton proposed three ways to close the gap: a higher earned-income tax credit -- which provides cash to low-paid workers -- more food stamps and increased subsidies for home heating. The combination would, roughly, bring most families with a full-time worker close to the poverty line.
There are two reasons why Congress ought not scale back the proposed tax credit substantially when it cuts the energy tax.
Large families -- those with two or more children -- need almost every penny of the Clinton tax credit to escape poverty even if energy taxes aren't raised. There's little leeway to save money by reducing their credit.
Nor is the Senate about to raise food stamps and energy assistance -- the other two prongs of Mr. Clinton's anti-poverty strategy. So if it rips away a sizable part of the tax credit, the package would deliver an unconscionable blow to needy families.
Beyond that, cutting back the tax credit is shortsighted. Over time, the value of the minimum wage -- the amount of food and clothing that $4.25 will buy -- is diminished by inflation. The wisest way to combat that erosion is to combine tax credits with a slightly higher minimum wage that would be indexed to offset inflation. But if Congress ratchets down the tax credit this year, it will be forced to raise the minimum wage even more next year.
The Clinton Administration has wisely put off deciding about raising the minimum wage until next year. It feared discouraging hiring while the economy was still sluggish; and it didn't want to alienate small employers, whose support it desperately needs to push the Administration's economic plan and health care reform through Congress.
Eventually, however, the Administration will propose higher minimum wages, so it makes sense to keep the hike small by boosting the credit as high as financially prudent.
The best budget would include the original $70 billion hike in energy taxes proposed by Mr. Clinton. But that won't happen given strong political opposition. It's the responsibility of Mr. Clinton -- and Congress -- to make sure they don't make America's lowest-paid workers pay for this political expediency.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
